number of helpful: 29 of 31 people (94%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												"Their fate rests on your effort. On the strength of your hands, and of your heart..."Arkane Studios and Bethesda really outdid themselves with "Dishonored". It's an amazing stealth FPS that'll leave you wanting more.You play as Corvo Attano, the Empress's Bodyguard and you've just brought news from foreign land in seek of help from the rat plague that has infested the city of Dunwall. Due to unforseen consequences, you are framed and became enemy of the state, hence the title.The story of the game is not bad, but not great either, although I love the ending that I got. Some parts are predictable while others are unexpected. I do love the fact that your actions affect the outcome of the story. I feel as if I have control over the game and not just following a scripted flow of events. Plus, making wrong/different decisions add drama and tension to the plot which makes you careful in deciding what to do next.  Visuals are smooth and well-made. It's using the Unreal Engine 3 so you'll find it somehow similar to the cartoony nature of Bioshock Infinite, but darker. I honestly prefer the atmosphere of Dunwall to Columbia, for reasons I am not entirely sure of :/ Ambience wouldn't be complete without music, and it fits very well with the visuals. It's by no means the best, but it's just perfect for the game.Now, I wasn't really a fan of the stealth genre but "Dishonored" made me think otherwise. It's fun, smooth and rewarding. You wield a sword in one hand and a Charm/Pistol/Crossbow/Trap/Grenades in another. It's kind of confusing to sort them all out, but once you do, it's fast and easy ^_^ Speed and silence is key, this game rewards you for not attacking enemies head-on because once you do, they will outnumber you in a matter of seconds. I love how you can play the game at your own pace, you have to go from point A to point B, but it gives you freedom how to get there e.g. Use the rooftops and go unnoticed by ground forces, or use the shadows to slide past your enemies, or explore the area to find hidden passages. You're given the tools, and it's up to you, how you want to use them.Overall Experience: This was honestly one of the best games I've played so far. I just love the freedom it gives you in gameplay and the astounding atmosphere it sets you in. You don't need a high-end PC to play this game, it's very well-optimized and that's always a plus for me ^_^ I highly recommend "Dishonored" even if you're not a big fan of stealth.Tip: Explore the surroundings..... you'll find untold stories that add to the ambience of the game.

number of helpful: 27 of 28 people (96%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
Teal DeerDevelopers: Arkane Studios Publishers: Bethesda Softworks Initial release: Oct 2012Genre: FPS, Stealth, Open World, Action#Worth/NotWorth: #DefinitelyWorthExposition, Concurrence and SummationDishonored might be one of the best stealth based games EVER made. Hyperbole aside, I'm not even kidding. Dishonored places you in the very capable hands of the Empress of Dunwalls head bodyguard Corvo Attano. The game begins with everything very calm and rather jovial. The empress's daughter Emily even invites you to play hide and seek as a form of a tutorial. Soon after the Empress is attacked by assassins and Corvo easily fends the first few off, however one succeeds after restraining Corvo and quickly vanishes leaving Corvo lying next to the slain Empress. Thus, 'Dishonored' begins. Near the beginning of the game you're greeted by someone known as the Outsider. He grants you the ability of magic to include teleportation, seeing through walls, among other things. For obvious reasons, he remains elusive throughout the game. The freedom of movement is rather unique and something I've not really seen other places. The movement, the narrative and the setting (London-esk during the late 1800's ) Where technology and magic exist together though the latter remains known only to a select few; Comes together in a package that feels unique like no other games quite hit every spot right like this. Additionally, the narrative goes along perfectly with the actual gameplay. Each target as well as each objective that your rag tag team of seemingly misfit people assign to you in an attempt to prove your innocence and regain order, can be dealt with lethally or non lethally (which leaves some room for ambiguity) This may seem like a trivial distinction in most games, you might assume that doing either will get the job done and your next task will be marked. However, this game keeps track of each kill, each time you where seen and a number of other things that all go into your overall chaos rating; which markedly changes the world. The way people react to you and what defenses may or may not be set up to dissuade you from completing your task. I've played through twice now, DLC included (which is remarkable. Some of the best DLC I've played since Bioshock Burial at Sea and the Witcher 3 DLC. I am not even close to joking. And I wholeheartedly think you should play that as well should either having more missions interest you or seeing the story from another perspective interest you) I've taken the High Chaos and the Low chaos route; the game takes the best from Thief and adds more content and playability to make it a near perfect product. You can be the stealthy rogue on a mission with a heart of gold or play the ruthless killer bent on revenge and the world will reflect that sentiment. I am in love. Follow my curation for more

content:
Posted: April 18, 2016
												Do YOU like loading screens? Well then you're out of luck, 'cos in this game, they're more of a subliminal message flash than a loading screen. I probably didn't even get to read the majority of the loading screen tips.A very Assassin's Creed-like game, if Assassin's Creed were capable of producing a story you actually cared about. As predictable as the story can be (Really, we're achieving all our goals this early? That seemed a bit easy, I wonder!), I found myself connecting with it, with Corvo, with Emily, with poor, ol' Sam. The game isn't just about calculated choices to achieve ends that I want. I found myself passionately hating certain characters. I felt disappointment when I realised I won't get to put a knife through their eyes. I felt mercy after hearing the tale of another character. And so it goes. And if you want a bit more challenge, play through the game without killing anyone, or being detected - and not just because of the associated achievements. There's genuine focus and thought necessary to clear out clusters of enemies. Figuring out the enemy patrol patterns, best angles of approach and the timing. Heck, I probably spent a good hour clearing out one part of Flooded District, home to the Assassins. I felt genius anxiety about there being an assassin around the next corner or on the next rooftop, and very overlapping patrols/sightlines. Overall, it's a great game with a less-than-original story that is presented incredibly well. The combat mechanics aren't the greatest if you just run around with knife and pistol, but once you start being a bit more creative, you can have loads of fun decimating piles of Watch Guards. Just do yourself a favour and reconfigure the combat controls, blocking with Mouse2, Sword attack with Mouse1 and Power/Gadget on a thumb button of preference worked really well for me.

number of helpful: 23 of 23 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
												What a masterpiece. There's a lot of differing opinions about this game, but I'm not sure why. You know all those games that boast "multiple choices" and "multiple endings"? You know how whenever they say that 99% of the time the choices are meaningless and the endings are decided by a quick "yes or no" question at the end? Dishonored is nothing like that. Every choice you make, every person you help, every thing you kill has an impact on the the story and gameplay. For example, the more people you kill will make more rats and "zombies" (called Weepers in game) appear in later levels. Not to mention that depending on who you kill could hugely affect other characters, and they remember. They will mention it multiple levels later. If you help them, they remember and pay you back later on. This all may seems simplistic in nature, but how the game plays and handles it is all the best I've ever seen. The multiple choices doesn't feel like a gimmick, it feels like the game was made around it. So lets talk how the game actually plays. It's a really good stealth game. Each level is very open allows TONS of options with how you want to go with things. Every level I felt like I was the first to ever go the way I did, that I discovered a new weird route, though in reality, the developers made that one of the paths available. It's not that long, about 14 hours, (and that's with doing almost all of the side-quests) but I know that you'll end up playing it much more than that. There is SO much replay value. It was the first game that I was really excited to replay it, before I had even finished it the first time.

content:
Posted: January 22
												Dishonored... This is the video game that got me so hooked as if it was a TV series.  I even dreamt about it once.  I wanted so much to make good decisions in every turn of the game.  And most of all, I wanted Samuel to be proud of me coz he deserves it.  He saved my life.  He was though until one time I decided to be a jerk out of curiosity.  To end the siege of Hounds Pit Pub, I decided to burn everyone using Piero's and Sokolov's machine.  But, I unknowingly killed Callista (who's like a mother to Emily too).  I had no inkling she will be included in the machine's targets.  Piero said enemies only.  Anyway, after the end of siege, I met up with Samuel.  I felt his razor sharp words cut through saying what I had become in between while giving me information about Kingsparrow Island.  When we reached the destination, he didn't wish me luck (like he used to) and was practically throwing me out of his boat.  He yelled get out of his boat like a couple of times, even fired a gunshot to alarm Kingsparrow Island guards -- which it did.  I had to run for my life.  It was my last boat ride with him too.  I was surprised and still am.  It was like real life and didn't feel good at all.  Well, it's a good thing it is not real life.  Dishonored is spellbinding!  It was like a drug for 2 weeks straight for me.  Still high on it to this day.  PS. Sorry for any spoilers.  :)

												You can't describe to someone who wasn't a gamer in 2004 what the first playthough of Half-Life 2 was like, but you can have them play Dishonored, and that's just as good. That feeling as you rush through the Flooded District, of being dangerous and powerful but isolated and hunted, in a world that is both horrific and starkly beautiful in its devastation, playing a strange cosmic game for the favor of an inscrutable and cruel patron - the only thing missing is headcrabs and a horrible airboat section.If you never played HL2, play this so you can feel those feels without the vehicle section fail. If you did play HL2 when it came out, play this game so you can relive that old glory and ruminate on how far gaming has come. If you are any kind of single-player video gamer, I cannot recommend this modern classic enough.

number of helpful: 23 of 25 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2013
												You should play this game. Briefly, here's why:1) It is fun. Not content to simply shoehorn mediocre gameplay into the gaps between story, the developers have managed to make a game where simply BEING Corvo is fun. Running around, double-jumping, and using Blink to explore rooftops... these are actions that would be enjoyable even in the absence of story entirely, and other powers continue to add interesting ingredients as you unlock them. That they THEN wrapped this gameplay in an interesting story is the proverbial icing on the cake.2) The art. LOVE the art. The character designs are in my personal Top 3 (with Brink and DE: Human Revolution) and the environments are beautiful too. I could (and probably have) spent hours just appreciating the visual style.3) Open to different play-styles. You can treat it like a shooter and kill everyone, or you can finish the entire game without killing a single person. (Or somewhere in between.) Furthermore, the environments themselves offer great flexibility in terms of your desired approach, instead of just being narrow corridors funneling you along the intended path, like many other games I won't name here.4) It is a polished, AAA, single-player-only, original IP. If that sentence doesn't make you nod with respect, you haven't been paying attention to the past few years of AAA games and the epidemic of "Sequelitis." It takes real stones to make a game like Dishonored happen in an age where publishers are VERY reluctant to take risks. The fact that Arkane and Bethesda stepped up to the plate is admirable, and the fact that the resulting game is actually GOOD is something worth supporting.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												You play as Corvo Attano, the bodyguard to the Empress. You go on a personal mission to rescue her kidnapped daughter Emily. In the dark and depressed city of Dunwall. It's always nice to see a new quality franchise. Dishonored is a first person stealth assassin game, where you get the freedom to choose who to eliminate and how. Your playstyle even has some effect on the surrounding world, for example if you go on killing everybody, there will be more rats in the city. Your choices also shape the ending. It's possible to do completely non-lethal run of the game, which is one of it's great features.  The art style is magnificent, it's a bit caricaturized victorian steampunk. There's also huge amount of high profile voice talent in the game. Including Susan Sarandon and Chloë Grace Moretz. The games weakness to me comes from the upgrades, while most of them are inventive, fun and open up different possibilities how to approach the game. Some are just bit too overpowered and make the game too easy and other skills useless. Highly recommended to anyone looking for a great stealth game with rich characters and story. If you want, you can also play it as straight up action game. While it truly shines with more stealthy approach. The choice is yours. [Score: 92]

Posted: June 22, 2016
My Experience:Civilians screaming for help? Sure thing man! Dishonored: "You must kill them or leave them, no rescuing!Me: "But..."Dishonored: "No buts!"Me: *leaves the building, watching two innocent civilians scream for help. *sobI shall feel guilty until the day I die.My Review:This is a great introduction to horror games in my opinion. This isn't even a horror game, but since I'm the jumpiest person to ever walk the Earth, this was enough for me. The atmosphere is so tense. Just walking around my room, and I was expecting a jumpscare..in game of course. I was going to try the Metro Redux series, but that seemed too scary for me, so I came to this. The difficulty settings are great! For once it isn't just that enemies are stronger and you are weaker. Yes it is that, but it's more. The main thing being the perception of the AI. It's really good. REEEEALLY GOOD!The fighting is good too. I hate those games where you face 10 enemies, and when you attack one, the others stand around just watching...wtf man do something! This is not the case here, as when I walked around the corner (like there's only one in the entire game) I was swamped by guards all slashing at me with their knives, some standing back, only to be throwing %&$#@!# grenades.To assist you with the stealth gameplay, you are able to peak through keyholes and, forgetting logic, you are able to "peak" around corners to see where everyone is...It's not just peaking though, it's leaning your entire body apart from your feet out of cover. And yet you remain unseen? This is not a bad thing though. Just questionable.As many people say, right click=left hand and left click=right hand, this can be confusing, but it makes sense to have your main weapon as left click.I can't wait to see what they have in store for Dishonored 2!GET IT OR REGRET IT

content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
Product received for free
												I played and beat this game on free weekend, and yeah, it's about as good as everyone says it is.Because my reviews are always obnoxiously inconsistent, this time I'll write a list of pros and cons:Pros:-Excellent stealth level design as well as nonlinear design (For example, every level obviously directs you go to the same location- But how you get there is up to you. For example, when crossing a bridge, do you take the direct route? Do you climb up into the higher levels of the structure? Do you hide in the maintanence shafts and crawl under the guards' feet?)-A pretty cool universe. While the story's just "Good", the actual universe the story takes place in is almost stunningly original. I'm not gonna act like I haven't seen steampunk before, but Dishonored is far more than just that.-A large range of different playstyles-Suitable recognition of all those different playstyles-QUICKSAVING-Excellently fun abilitiesCons:-Too much stuff is clearly designed for non-stealth gameplay. Don't get me wrong, options are always better, but there's not enough stuff stealth players can upgrade compared to crazy, non-stealth players. This isn't that bad with Runes but with buying upgrades it's extremely glaring. The only thing that directly advantages pacifist stealth players are sleep dart upgrades (Which you won't need if you're doing a Ghost run and not being seen), and boot upgrades which you only get in the extreme lategame.-It's also noteworthy that in my first playthrough I managed to buy every single money upgrade in the game- I did loot as much of the level as I can but it's a little ridiculous I was able to buy literally everything.-Bodies despawn- Or rather merge into each other. This is a little hard to explain, but I noticed in my playthrough that leaving multiple bodies together would result in me coming back and finding only one body. Whatever the case I don't think this is acceptable for a stealth game, bodies despawning is a big deal.-The Good ending is a bit anticlimatic. Obviously it's good, but let's just say you won't get the big battle you were hoping for. In the other endings you're put under significantly more pressure.-There are boss fights, and I'm amazed that they're all optional- But I personally didn't like the way they played, unfortunately.However, all these things are relatively minor marks on an otherwise unbelievably enjoyable game for the reasons I listed above. It's important to distinguish when a game's flaws does and doesn't overshadow the entire experience, and Dishonored's flaws certainly don't.

number of helpful: 22 of 28 people (79%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												INTRODUCTION:Dishonored is a First Person Stealth Action-Adventure game released in 2012. It seeks to be the spiritual successor of the popular Thief series who, back in 1998, had set a very high bar for the stealth game genre.The player steps into the boots of Corvo Attano, an elite bodyguard to the Empress of the Isles who was murdered by a shadowy organization of assassins. Accused by the people and condemned to death by the State, the player will follow Corvo's struggle to redeem his name, avenge the death of the Empress and stop any usurper from claiming the empty Throne.PROS:+ Action and Stealth Balance: -The game offers different ways to finish a mission and multiple methods of completing an objective. The game can accommodate player preference, whether they like action, non-lethal stealth or assassination oriented approaches. Use the various tools, skills and powers available to your advantage. Just beware of the consequences of your Actions.+ Great Visual Design: -The city of Dunwall is dark, wet, dilapidated, poor, disease stricken and all of this are completely beautiful. The game boast a unique texture design making the whole world look like it was oil painted, this gives it a unique personality and a gorgeous aesthetic. The city itself has great atmosphere due to the people and the overall level designs along side the Steam Punk theme. There is a large world to explore in-between and during missions.+ Rich World: -If the player takes time to explore and discover some of the lore that is spread around the game, (like books, letters, conversations, the different character's thoughts by using 'The Heart' item), the City of Dunwall, 'The Isles' and the world in which it is set, suddenly becomes alive.+ Complex Political Intrigue: -The main plot itself is straight forward and a bit cliche, HOWEVER, if you take the extra time to listen to conversations, reading thoughts (See above), and go out of your way to discover non-lethal solutions to your main objectives, you will uncover a conspiracy that goes far deeper than what you expected.CONS:- Voice Acting: -The voice acting is not 'bad' per se, but at times, specially with certain characters, it feels kind of stiff or lifeless. Some people might find this annoying since it can really pull you out of the otherwise great immersive experience.- Limited Non-Lethal Takedown Tools: -Aside from your choke hold (which have only ONE animation by the way) and sleep darts, there is simply a noticeable lack of tools for the non-lethal track. Watching the choke hold animation gets boring after a while. Would have loved it if they incorporated other animation types or different moves for non-lethal takedowns like an inverted grab and choke from a ledge or a ceiling beam perhaps?-Occasional AI Glitches: -I normally don't put glitches or bugs as cons, unless, they occur more than I would like. I have played this game 3 times already and on each one, I encountered some bizarre (but hilarious) bugs that causes some of the AI to do some weird stuff. Not game breaking though, it's more like a minor annoyance than anything else.CONCLUSION:GREAT GAME! A true spiritual successor to the Thief series, Dishonored creates an amazing stealth system while adding new characteristics and twist that makes it a truly exceptional game.If you're the type of gamer who is into gun play than anything else, then I would NOT RECOMMEND this game for you. Dishonored encourages combat variation by mixing ranged, magical and melee attacks. The different weapons and tools, including the gun and crossbow, only compliment each other and it is ill advised to only focus mastery on one.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------Like my Reviews? Follow my Curator's Page:http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6861651-Miyumi%27s-Review-Corner/

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												My absolute favorite game EVER!Let me explain you why:Dishonored can be played in a countless of ways, not just stealth, or non stealth; every level has many different ways to be cleared and explored. I started playing this game the non stealth way, destroying anything that so much as looked at me sideways. What I love about this, is that it affects the ending a great deal, your actions have consequenses!So, after my first playthrough, where I brutally obliviated everyone in my path, I decided for a more stealthy approach, and it was the most fun I've ever had playing a game!There's so much to do in Dishonored, I'm still not done discovering, and I've cleared this game quite a couple times.That gets me to the bit of the game that I didn't like so much.Dishonored has a VERY short storyline, and I feel like they rushed it, an extra mission or two would've helped. Then again, the story is VERY well written, and it all checks out so well, on both endings.Also, there's a lot of side missions, and non-lethal approaches for dispatching key targets, and a lot of hidden objects to be found, wich makes the exploring of a level a lot more interesting.I also love the special ability's Corvo has, the 'Blink' is a teleportation wich comes in handy whenever you find yourself in a nasty situation, and you need to escape. It also proves its worth in combat, when you blink up to an enemy and slash his throat, he'll never know what the f*ck hit him!There's a HUGE number of upgrades and tools that can be bought, powers will have to be accuired and upgraded by finding 'Runes'.One thing is for sure, you will never find yourself bored playing Dishonored.Graphically, this game lacks very little, the only thing I'm a bit bothered with, is that it doesn't run very smooth on my PC, but that's more due to my PC, I can't blame the game for that :P.So... to summarize:Pro's+Beautiful graphics.+Great gameplay, many different options and approaches.+Very good storyline.+A lot of secret areas and side missions to discover.+Combat is fun, but stealth is AWESOME+A HUGE number of different tools and weapons, which makes the killing all the more fun!Con's-Short storyline, could've been longer-You need a decent PC to run this on.10/10 -It's a piece of ♥♥♥♥ing art in my opinion!

Posted: October 29, 2016
												A action-stealth game of epic proportions, Dishonored is a game about choice, stealth, and that little panic that happens whenever someone looks your way at the wrong time.In Dishonored you can make your way through the streets and sewers of the city of Dunwall as you sneak or slaughter your way through patroling foes and plagued citizens to accomplish your missions and explore a city on the verge of ruin. To help you on your way you have a number of otherworldly powers allowing you to teleport, manipulate time, summon rats, and other useful abilities.You also have an arsenal of equipment to assist in your endevors, state of the art weapons, high tech gadgets, and a telescopic mask that will allow you to choose weather to fight your way through your enemies, or take a more subtle appoach and mearly knock them out.Choice takes a major part of this game as you must not only choose your appoach through the missions and their multiple paths, but you must also choose how to deal with those who wronged you and caused your dishonor.All in all Dishonored is a great game that will captivate stealth fans as well as offer something even for those who prefer a more direct route, as you explore a wonderful world on the brink of collapse.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
												Unlimited assasination combos, this is the life.You are Corvo, the Queen's formal bodyguard. Within this game, the emphasis is on choice. Throughout the whole game you can choose, to assasinate or detain, to kill all opponents or dispose of them non-lethally. You gain rewards, medals if you do the mission non-lethally. Another large part is gaining Whale Bone Charms or Runes to upgrade spells. The game can be played over and over and over again each time trying a different difficulty, or collecting all the Runes and WBC, or doing the mission non-lethally.Although I found this game fairly short, I was amazed at the possibilties and graphics the game had to offer. Every detail was considered and looked into to improve the gameplay and quality. There are many ways to eliminate enemies, such as backstabbing them, or jump stabbing, or pulling off epic blade combos, or assasinating the enemy with a bow, or shooting them with your gun. There are also non-lethal ways, such as Sleeping arrow, smothering the enemy unconcious, shocking the enemy with an electric bullet. The possibilities are endless.. All the characters were thought out carefully, every aspect of their emotions and wording showed there personality. The plot is fairly good, between missions you can relax and talk to your so-called "allies", each ending with you sleeping. All-inall this game is amazing and I enjoyed every second of it. I failed in the end, and made a mistake. having known the characters so well, I felt sad for a while. This game is something on its own.First Posted: 26/11/2014Last Edited: 26/11/2014

content:
Posted: March 6
												Rating: 9/10Overview: First Person Stealth/ActionThe Good:+Steampunk with a Victoria era aesthetic provides an unique look not seen in any game + The level design is phenomenal, rivaling the level design in the Deus Ex series. Every level provides multiple ways of completing objectives. Every level is fun to explore and encourages multiple playthroughs to see how events unfold. + By playing more action oriented, killing lots of enemies, later levels will be different than those who took a stealthier approach. Later levels will have more enemies, characters will speak to you differently and major objectives will also be different. This is something that really sets itself apart from other games in the genre.  + The main story and characters are interesting and every level has books, notes, and letters scattered around that flesh out the world, locations and lore. + By finding runes you can upgrade certain powers. The main power is ‘blink’; the ability to move very fast covering a short distance. By using this power, you can move to hard to reach areas and discover new pathways to complete objectives. + Lots of graphical/gameplay options+ voice acting+ The 3 pieces of DLC are also excellent. The fist is the Dunwall Trials. 10 levels that feature combat, stealth, and speed challenges with a lot of interesting ideas thrown in the mix. These trials are difficult and getting the achievements even harder. The other 2 pieces of DLC tell the story of another character where you play through 6 more levels which are just as equally good if not better than the main game. The Average:+/- Despite the great art style, textures seem blurry and low resolution.   The Bad:-  If you decide to play stealthy and want a no alert, no kill playthrough, you may accidently alert or kill someone without knowing it and the only way of discovering this is at the end of mission, in which case you would have to replay the entire mission over again.  Conclusion:I love this game and the genre itself. The art style, level design and gameplay all come together in one complete package. Like all stealth games, it can be very slow paced which is why you also have the option of killing your way through with sword and pistol.

content:
Posted: March 13
												I really enjoyed stepping into the skin of Dishonored protagonist, Corvo Attano. He is quiet, agile, smells really nice, has fun abilities and a thirst for revenge, oh yeah!You can rush through this game in six hours if you like or you can easily get 30+ hours out of it if you leave no stone unturned. Personally I take my time and have fun with it but I have little patience for boring books or the shenanigans of the good people of Dunwall. Fortunately I am free to ignore them, like I ignore most side missions, missing out on some rewards of course. MY POSITIVES- First person- 110 FOV- Various ways to reach your goal- Be non-lethal or join the dark side- Useful and fun abilities with room for creativity- Fetch runes and bonecharms to further enhance Corvo- Stealth was satisfying- Revenge is sweet- Nice story- Nice setting- No timed missions afaik, I did not do all side missions thoughMY NEGATIVES- Corvo wears half a bottle of Davidoff Silver Shadow yet the dogs never pick up his sent- Normal difficulty leans a bit more towards easy- Could do with a bit more tensionHAPPY BOXES TICKED- Customizable controls and FOV- Inverted Mouse and Mouse rebinding- Save game and Quick save options- Reduce head bob is possibleI paid €3,29 for this which is shameless and influenced my review a bit. Had I paid full price I would still be enjoying it but I'd be disappointed in some main missions  (I believe there are 9) for being too short if you're not careful.

												Went through this game once as a nonlethal ghost.Went through a second time as a revenge driven badass killing anyone who stood in his way.Went through a third time to  see Emily fall to her death Dishonored is honestly my second favourite stealth game. (sorry nothing can beat MGSV) It has numerous endings that change depending on how you play, a dynamic world that changes depending on how you play, characters who change depending on how you play. Everything you do in this game affects something. Whether it be more rats and guards on the streets of Dunwall, or a character hating you for something you did. getting her uncle killed, sorry not sorry It really is just a game you have to experience.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												I have a hundred steam games, played some more non steam games, and have went through stacks of console games that are longer than a Tyrannasaurous Rex's♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and out of all these games, Dishonored still stands to be my favorite. Although the game may be short, I feel like this is a good thing as the game is so good it makes you want to replay, and as you replay thhe game you get to experience new things you never experienced on your first playthrough, whether it be your first time shoving a knife in a guards neck, or your first time sparing your main targets, the gameplay stays fresh whenever you replay the game. One thing that disappointed me with this game is the lack of stealth equipment, as your arsenal is quite low for stealth, and it makes the stealth route less appealing, however the stealthing itself, and the mechanics of it are really nice and make it enjoyable for me. If you enjoy murdering everyone in sight then this game will make you very happy as there are so many creative ways to kill people using the supernatural arsenal of corvo, when someone shoots you, you can freeze time, put them in front of their own bullet, then after their dead summon a swarm of rats to clean up for you. The story, although being short is really good, especially since the choices you make directly change the story, and you progreesively see the choices you make changing the environment around you, making you feel more connected to the choices you decided to make in game. I bought this game around when it came out and it went on sale for 30$, the prices has obviously dropped since then, but I feel I have gotten way more then my money's worth, and I guarantee your money would not be misplaced upon buying this game

content:
Posted: October 10, 2016
												Dishonored is a unique stealth game that allows you to progress through the main story in two fashions: killing a lot or killing nobody at all. The outcome of the game is the same in both paths, but the events that lead up to it vary depending on the choice.The powers you obtain are interesting and beneficial to a typical stealth game ranging from teleportation to mind-possession. I found myself using them more often than the actual weapons you are given including a crossbow and foldable blade. The art style is also sweet and unique. The texts and imagery presented to you in the UI and objectives tabs look like straight-up paintings popping out. The graphics aren't overly intensive, but still pleasing to the eye. The story felt a little predicatable, but maybe that is just my own opinion. Overall, Dishonored is well worth the money.

												Dishonored is becoming one of my favorite stealth games, nay, one of my favorite games of all time.It has it all. Amazing gameplay, dialogue, story, art direction, world, level design, freedom, and replayability. The biggest strength of this game is that you can be extremely creative with how you kill your enemies or sneak around, lending itself to many playthroughs and playstyles. The amount of detail and lore put into the world is just staggering, each note and book you find only adding to the fascinating world of Dunwall and the cities beyond. As icing on the cake, the voice acting is top notch and you can always catch interesting conversation between guards and noblemen alike.I can ramble on and on about how wonderful this game is, but you should play it for yourself. It's rare to see a game that's so well crafted in every aspect. 10/10

content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												With its fantastic mechanics and grim but dull setting, Dishonored remains a favorite of mine, and a great accomplishment for the genre.Dishonored is a first-person stealth action game set in a heavily Victorian inspired world where you play as Corvo Attanowho after being betrayed and blamed for the murder of his beloved Empress to whom he served as an agent and personal bodyguard, meets a being shrouded with incredible mystery.. A higher entity referred to as the Outsider.With the assistance of the Outsider, who chooses neither evil nor bad, only whatever is of interest to him, Corvo gains 'magical' powers.Dishonored does a great job in balancing your set of physical tools and magical abilities. Neither are enforced. These only give to the already vast variety of playstyles and add through the magical aspect of this game a great deal of depth to the gameplay and mechanics.As a silent protagonist, Corvo is an empty shell the player is supposed to fill.Little to big differences in the world are made as a result of your actions in it. Your actions have impact. The way you affect the world is not common.It's not just what you say to this person or that character, it's your playstyle.You dared not to hurt a soul? From that you gain as part of your reward cleaner sewers. Meaning less weepers (a certain type of enemy) to avoid or kill or render them unconscious.You've been a good boy? Good job, little sweet Emily's drawings is that of a happy, sunlit place. You've been bad? Well, you can see that reflected upon the new dark, sinister characters in the paintings.This succeeds in making you feel regret for acting as you did, playing as you did as Dishonored manages to get you emotionally invested in Emily's character, and when you see her drawing of you, smiling bright, you smile in real life. But when you don't get to see that happy creation, cheerfully titled 'Daddy' you see the masked murderer you are.Whether you choose to see her turn you into her savior or her fear, a tower with flowers and a rainbow or murderer with a bloody knife and a pile of bodies is for you to decide through your playstyle alone. It's important to mention that these specific details are not forced, as you might not even notice them while playing through the game. They are worth glimpsing at though.This all sounds awesome, right? What a wonderful mechanic.Well, not necessarily. The only reason to purchase any game at all and play through it, is for the sake of your personal entertainment. It's your game, you should choose to play it however you wish to. Now, although I am all for the specific player-action-affected events I stated above, Dishonored has one heavy punishment for the player should he choose to be a bad boy.Paintings are one small thing. Game ending is another. And that is broken. Unknowingly, you will be punished by the game's ending if you carelessly killed all who stood in your way.This is wrong. This is not a 'your choices matter' game. This is a game you play for the fun in its gameplay and mechanics, for its openness in level design, letting you move on from this place to the next however you'd like to.Giving you a bad ending is a needlessly unforgiving and punishing mechanic.Your way of enjoying this game shouldn't be a negetive deciding factor for the ending which you receive.For stealth-action fans, I'd consider this game a must have in your game library.Of course, not that you can't have incredible fun with it if what you're into is decapitating enemies or watch them being eaten and devoured alive by swarms of rats controller by you. Honestly, it can be just as satisfying as bypassing every guard without being noticed.Dishonored is a fantastic game. Its setting is an incredible fit. Its mechanics in gameplay are a joy to use and the animations do a magnificent job in delivering the satisfaction of a kill. And while the story may not be the most interesting, I did find myself invested in some of the characters and I did find myself immersed to extreme measures with the world of Dishonored to the point where I found myself reading the different notes and excerpts scattered throughout the game to enrich my knowledge of the interesting lore behind it all.I'd also like to mention the DLC expansions in which you get to play as one of the antagonist and see through his eyes and reason. The extra story enables you to experience and understand the mindset of the very person who set you upon this path for the sake of money and greed. A path which brought nothing but horrors bestowed not only upon you, but the entire city as well. If you liked Dishonored, these are a must-buy.Overall, it was one hell of a ride and I enjoyed it immensely.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2013
												What made Dishonored great in 2012 is what keeps making it great as I replay it all over again in 2017. It is not just the finely tuned stealth gameplay; or the coherent, immersive worldbuilding; or the iconic, dismally dystopian art; or the myriad possibilities of reactivity to the player’s choices and gameplay approaches... It’s all of these things and more.Originality is not creating something from nothing; instead, it’s creating something great inspired by many other great things. Dishonored is unashamed of its inspirations and influences. Not only is Deus Ex the main, pervading inspiration and influence, the game was developed by three Deus Ex veteran developers: Harvey Smith, Ricardo Bare and Austin Grossman. And that’s very evident in the intricate, multilayered, multisolution level design, and the pervasive verisimilitude in lore writing. Add that to the fact that the art was designed by Half-Life 2 City 17 creator, Viktor Antonov, one of the greatest artists in the games industry. It is a recipe for a masterpiece, which is what Dishonored is indeed.Developed with the Unreal Engine 3, it runs butter-smooth, especially on 2017 hardware. Unlike its successor, framerate is not an issue. This is not a photorealistic game, however: the character design is supposed to look slightly cartoonish, as in BioShock or Fallout. The textures could use some improvement, but it’s still visually stunning even five years later. The gameplay, when skilfully played, becomes surgically delicious. There is such a wide array, such a range of possibilities to kill and maim and behead and dismember... but also to not kill, to incapacitate and render unconscious and move like a ghost, which is arguably the best way to experience it, because it is more challenging. It gives the player freedom, granted: you can go in guns blazing and knives slashing; but this is not a shooter or a hack-and-slash, it’s a stealth game that rewards patience and planning, a tactical approach to missions. And as such, even after five or six playthroughs, you will still manage to find details and approaches that you didn’t originally, which makes it truly rewarding.The story has better reactivity than many RPGs out there. Depending on how you approach the missions, who you kill or not, the characters, and the notes and books you find along the way, change and react in a way that is almost lifelike. The case can be made for the fact that the reactivity rewards nonlethal gameplay, but even in a severely lethal playthrough there are so many interesting moments and reactions from the characters.Above all, Dishonored is deeply immersive. It was custom-made following the immersive sim school of game design, which has its roots in Ultima Underworld and Deus Ex. While it is a linear game in its formula, the gameplay and the interactions with the world are far from linear. Instead of a game like a maze where the player follows the intended path and finds the only way out, the immersive sim design allows the player to make his own way and find his own way out, to come up with his own solutions to puzzles and situations, sometimes even in ways the designers themselves could not have anticipated. This is what games are supposed to do; this is how the medium sets itself apart from any other medium because it does something no other medium can do. And that’s what Dishonored did and still does.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												Favorite game of 2012, I pre-ordered it and loved it.Gameplay is smooth whether on a mouse and keyboard or controller. Combat has several ways to integrate all types of play styles, from murderous desperado to a ghost, Dishonored gives you the option to take out enemies (or don't) however you want. The powers Corvo has (which are optional as well) are interesting and help create some of the most interesting game moments, and the upgrades actually do something. AI could be better, but it's passable on higher level difficulty.Great design and art direction make Dunwall (despite being plague ridden and filled with a corrupt stand in government) an interesting place filled with colorful characters. The lore in this game is a bit buried, but listening to conversations or reading some of the many books you find around Dunwall will clear a lot of it up.Story is pretty good, there are two endings based on your chaos level (how many people you kill, alarms you sound, how many bodies are found yada yada yada) but it's probably not what you'll be focusing on, with the exception of Daud (which is why the Brigmore Witches and The Knife of Dunwall DLCs are highly recommended) nonetheless it's a nice part of the game.Dishonored is a beautiful game that still plays and looks better than some stuff getting shoveled out, if you didn't like the Thief reboot, or want a stealth game you can play over and over, I really really recommend Dishonored.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2015
												If you are a fan of stealth games, then you are in for a treat in Dishonored - a first-person stealth game heavily inspired by the Thief franchise (and a few others).Going straight to its selling point, mechanically, Dishonored is near flawless as far as stealth games are concerned, no doubt about that. It has been more than long due to finally see a stealth game which provides such vast possibilities for approaching your objectives. Want to use the rooftop to get in? Go ahead. Prefer getting in through the sewers? No problem. Want to become a fish? Sure, why not. The things I wished Mark Of The Ninja (a brilliant 2D stealth game) could have done better were granted in Dishonored. Aside from common mechanics seen in almost any other stealth game such as hiding in shadows and sneaking past guards, the addition of magic abilities such as Blink, Possession and Time Bending provide a new layer of depth in the gameplay. Although these abilities do make the game fundamentally easier than the old-fashioned stealth games like Thief, with some a bit too overpowered, it is remarkable how creative you can be with them. This makes a playthrough totally different than the next one and increases replayability. Even without its new mechanics added in, the fundamental ones which define a stealth game are up to par in Dishonored. The only time when immersion seems to break is when you hide underneath something, like a table or inside a fireplace, after you have been spotted and the alerted guards stand idiotically in front of you doing almost nothing to you. Sometimes they throw objects at you, but otherwise you can stay there and cheaply kill everyone else near you, one by one. This is something which I experienced not once, but a couple of times in the game. So yes, there are a few AI issues, but these are mostly encountered rarely.Funnily enough, Dishonered unashamedly took evident inspiration from games such as Bioshock, Half-Life and, unsurprisingly, Thief in its visual presentation, narration and level design. As a result, while its setting may look all cool with its blend of steampunk and Victorian London, it is hard not to feel like it borrowed too heavily from the aforementioned titles. “A City Unlike Any Other” is written in its description on the its Steam page which is a bit “dishonest” – it is nothing more than a modernised City 17 from Half-Life 2. Obviously, this aspect is just me nitpicking it and does not retract how beautiful and well-designed the world in Dishonored is, although you would have expected the person who once worked at Valve and envisioned City 17 in the first place would at least attempt to create something actually new rather than a rehash of his previous work when he moved to Arkane Studios. The point which is being made here is that there is nothing to praise about in terms of originality, but again, that does not make its setting any less enthralling. Graphically, it looks pretty good despite some textures feeling noticeably washed out. Whether this was an artistic decision, I cannot say. Its soundtrack is also good, but nothing too memorable though.With an interesting premise, the story in Dishonored is perhaps its weakest aspect. You take the role of Corvo, a bodyguard of the Empress who eventually gets framed for her murder and gets thrown in jail. With the aid of underground allies from the outside fighting for the same cause (finding the real murderer), Corvo manages to escape his prison cell and begins his long quest in avenging his Empress’s death and protecting her heir to the throne. All-around, the story feels only slightly above average – it honestly is neither great nor bad. In fact, what puts it above average is how your actions in missions do actually affect the narrative of the game in some form or another; even when you start questioning how the moral system implemented actually works when the game punishes you for things you might not have done (or was forced to) if you are aiming for the good ending. Annoyingly, the game offers plenty of cool gadgets to use in your missions and you just cannot resist using some when the occasion arises, but indirectly lets you know that you are a bad person if you kill someone. At the end of the day though, if you are someone who does not care about which ending they get or can pretend that is the ending they got, then you are free to approach things whichever way you want, blazing through or sneaky peeky. Anyway, the story is by and large pretty forgettable with its only major plot twist also getting somewhat predictable halfway through the game. Sadly, most of the characters in Dishonored tend to end up feeling not fleshed out enough. “Why should I care?” was a frequent question running through my mind all the time. “Because you’re the great Corvo and we believe in your skills!” said someone amongst those lines in the game, more than once. Well, okey, thanks bud. Heck, even Corvo becomes a pretty uninteresting protagonist due to a lack of personality and the charms of someone like Garrett from the Thief games. Corvo’s only motive is to simply avenge his Emperor’s death and protect her heir to the throne, Emily, a young girl who I personally had no attachment whatsoever throughout the entire time, even when the game forces her on me. Muted protagonists have been done better before, and Corvo is not a great example. Take away all of its story, then you come to realise that what you are playing are nine missions with relatively large environments to play around, which alone I am personally more than satisfied with. Then, does its weak story affect the enjoyment of the game? Absolutely not. In actual fact, the entire game can practically be played without paying too much attention to the story as long as you complete your objectives successfully, thanks to Dishonored's gameplay.Conclusively, Dishonered is a mechanically brilliant stealth game, if not the best in recent years, and a true modern homage to the classic Thief games. It hits that sweet spot in its gameplay. With new interesting mechanics added on top of staple elements from the stealth genre to keep things fresh and a myriad of possibilities to approach the mission objectives, Dishonered is a blast. Where it lacks in story and characters to care about, it compensates in one of the most satisfyingly fluent gameplays and level designs in a stealth game. It really is the type of game where its gameplay outshines everything else, even with its small issues. So if you like stealth games, then Dishonored is for you.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Dishonored is a 2012 stealth action-adventure video game developed by Arkane Studios and published by Bethesda Softworks. It was released worldwide in October 2012 for Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 3, and Xbox 360. Set in the fictional, plague-ridden industrial city of Dunwall, Dishonored follows the story of Corvo Attano, bodyguard to the Empress of the Isles. He is framed for her murder and forced to become an assassin, seeking revenge on those who conspired against him. Corvo is aided in his quest by the Loyalists—a resistance group fighting to reclaim Dunwall, and the Outsider—a powerful being who imbues Corvo with magical abilities. Several noted actors including Susan Sarandon, Brad Dourif, Carrie Fisher, Michael Madsen, Lena Headey, and Chloë Grace Moretz provided voice work for the game.The game is played from a first-person perspective and allows the player to undertake a series of assassination missions in a variety of ways, with an emphasis on player choice. Missions can be completed through stealth, combat, or a combination of both. Exploring each level opens new paths and alternatives for accomplishing mission goals, and it is possible to complete all missions, eliminating all of Corvo's targets, in a non-lethal manner. The story and missions are changed in response to the player's violent actions or lack thereof. Magical abilities and equipment are designed to be combined to create new and varied effects.Storyline is amazing.1 of the best games I have played. :DRate: 11/10

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												One of the best games I've ever played.I came to it late, having only seen screenshots with a lot of sword-fighting and shooting, but as usual the major reviews did the game a disservice, because Dishonored is so much more than that.Firstly, you don't have to harm anyone.  You don't even have to be SEEN by anyone.  Play as the good guy who is out to right the wrongs done against him and the people of Dunwall, and the game will pan out differently to playing as the angry guy out for vengeance - with a totally different ending to go with it (incidentally, I recommend playing BOTH styles to experience two different games).  As a result, there can be a lot of stealth-play (if you choose that play-style) and it's all very well done (though the stealth mechanics are not quite up to the stealth mechanics of Thief).  Secondly, the art style is incredible - one of those games where you just want to take stock and look around.  It's a very atmospheric game, though as usual the story revolves around "white male trying to rescue young female" (like we haven't seen that done to death already) and all the female NPCs are in some kind of servitude role or p♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s (Arkane loses some Brownie points for that).  But the story is incredibly well executed, the world extremely well designed (I must have played this game through some 20+ times now, and still find secret passageways, vents and such I can use) and it's just about the usual 15-20 hours in length.Finally, the controls for keyboard and mouse are incredibly easy - a delight to use.  No clunky awkwardness with button combos or anything like that, and no having to commit different keys to memory.  The early levels are actually a combined story opener and tutorial.  Again, very well done.All in all, an excellent game and one I thoroughly recommend (along with its story-based DLC packs).

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
-Quick Review-Dishonored is a first person stealth-based game developed by Arkane Studios and released in 2012. Dishonored capitalizes on allowing the player to complete various challenges with a great deal of creativity and independence. Meaning you can get through the game using combat, stealth, or your own unique blend of the two.


"Stay behind me and close your eyes. I'll need a minute." 
Community Created Artwork for Dishonored
By: Burn




-Detailed breakdown review-Story/NarrativeChoice has an impactDishonored's story is advertised as having a great deal of choice, and the levels will change or there will be some effect or impact based on your decisions throughout the game. The steam store itself reads "The outcome of each mission plays out based on the choices you make."There is some truth to the statement, the story did change a little bit on my second time through, but it didn't change as drastically as I was expecting. I come with a presupposition that when I hear that "my choices and actions will effect the game", I'm expecting something significant to happen.For example: if I spit in little Timmy's Cereal, I would expect little Timmy to dislike me, maybe his father would come after me. If I met Timmy again and I picked up his cereal and threw it across the room, I would hope that Timmy would sick his dog on me, and Timmy would try to attack me with a butter knife.To illustrate the impact of my decisions in Dishonored; if I killed Timmy, there are just going to be a few more rats, security will be tighter, more enemies, and the epilogue MIGHT change slightly change to show I did a bad thing. But unless I kill a lot of Timmy's the game won't notice until much later in the game when things get bad regardless of Timmy killings. All in all, not a great impact.The games that I think of when I think about "decisions" and "choice" in video games (where your choice leaves an impact) is KOTOR, KOTOR2, and Mass Effect. In those video games Timmy would hire some thugs by spending the small mounts of money he looted off level 3 sewer rats, and your character would have an obvious physical/emotion/spiritual shift because of being a Timmy-hating-monster.The redeeming factor of Dishonored method, is that it doesn't really have as much of an "ethics" explanation. The Protagonist is justified in his decisions - or at least VISIBLY justified in his actions. But the epilogue has a clearly "good" and "bad" ending, even though they're masked through the term "high chaos" and "low chaos".Story: You play as the Protagonist "Corvo Attano", body guard to the Queen. Corvo gets framed for a crime he did not commit, he's given magical powers, and he becomes an assassin. ...Sounds like a normal Friday night to me! As I've already elaborated above, you get to choose how Corvo behaves, whom he kills or helps, and your choices will be reflected in the idle-chatter from the guards, and the number of guards, rats, and "weepers". Dishonored takes place in Dunwall, which has been plagued (literally) by disease and rats. The Plague produces zombie-like-creatures known as "weepers" whom will wonder around aimlessly and attack on site.


That moment when a game forces you into "revenge mode" when they kill your Queen (lover) and kidnap your princess (daughter). 
A Screenshot of Dishonored
By: Burn




GameplayControls: Mechanically speaking, the game plays and feels exactly how it should, with a keyboard and mouse. I did rebind the attack keys though, because your left click is melee (right hand) and your right click is offhand (which can be magic, fire arm, cross bow, mine, etc, held in the left hand). I would have eventually gotten used to it, but I wanted right click to be right hand, left click to be left hand. And that's what made sense to me. (God bless key rebinding)You can use your number keys, or scroll wheel to switch between the different off-hand weapons you can chose from. You can also click in the scroll wheel which will either pause or slow down time; I couldn't figure out which it did, because I just tried to make my choice asap. Your melee attack never changes, so whenever someone's close you never need to question which button to press or click, or scroll through weapons.There's a lot that can be said about all the different kinds of weapons and magic abilities you can use, a big part of the game is coming up with ways to chain together the different abilities! To give you an idea of my favorite flavor of combat-gameplay: If a game lets me play stealthy, I try to stealth... be it pacifist or killing. the abilities I will chose compliment that play style, so I want mobility, stealth/quiet feet, and being able to detect my foes. (so I used the eye site and teleportation magic skills)I would ninja through the level, (and yes, that's a verb I don't care what you say Merriam-Webster!) but whenever I was caught I would warp around from enemy to enemy, like a mage from World of Warcraft with no cool downs.However, on that note it's important to point out that magic uses a magic resource. I don't think the game ever explained what the resource is called this time... which is just as well; it's blueberry juice, and anyone who tells you differently is a filthy liar. (*mumbles* I guess to restore it you used a "spiritual remedy" but that's less funny to mention.) You have ammo, a health bar, mana/blueberryjuice bar, and oxygen bar when underwater.http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=713056385Progression: One of my favorite values is "how do you progress through a game. in Dishonored you progress via upgrades to powers, purchased upgrades/ammo/blueprints with gold, as well as the general progression through the story. There's progression all 'round.Style/Graphics/Appearance: The first word that comes to mind for me is "steampunk", but that's not reaaaalllyyyyy the best description of the style. There was some steampunk inspiration, but the architecture and setting was largely influenced by England, and the word is a combination of technology, and magic. (Always a popular choice)Price/value/game time played: Dishonored is priced at $9.99. So far I've played 25 hours of the game. I've had two play-throughs, once getting the "good" ending and the other getting the "bad" ending. Immediately after my first game I knew I had to play it again and see what other types of outcomes I could experience.Like I've hinted at, I was a bit disappointed because of my overly inflated expectations for what kind of impact I would have with my choices, but the second play through was still extremely valuable and interesting, it turns out I had somehow completely avoided a boss battle on my first play through! That's really impressive in my opinion, and does redeem the aspect of choice somewhat.HOWEVER, that's really one of the few negative things I have to say about the game, as a whole I was extremely satisfied and got a great deal of entertainment out of the game, and will undoubtedly play through it again in the future.Conclusion: to wrap this review up... Great game, all around loved it. I've been on a stealth-game-spree lately, and this game is one of the good ones. There's a great deal of depth in the game, various difficulties, plenty of achievements, a fair bit of replay ability to keep people interested in playing through the game.I feel like this game will appeal the most to stealth game enthusiasts, (not sure about the hard-core-stealth-game-crowd, It's recently come to my attention I'm no where near as good as those people.) But the game can appeal to people who mainly play FPS or slashy mc stab stab styled games. There's a nice mix of genre's in this game to appeal to a very large demographic of gamers.Now is especially a good time to get and play through Dishonored, because Dishonored 2 cometh! -- As always, thanks for reading my review!

God daaamn this game is beautiful..Dishonored is, without a doubt the greatest game i've ever played in my life and i've played plenty let me tell you.Everything about this game is beautiful, it just makes me feel some kind of way.Let's start with my Overall score. Dishonored 2 will come out this year so i thought that now is a good time to replay the first game just to get a feel for it. and boy got i hooked.. huh i've played the game on the hardest difficulty and tried my best to get the highest achievements but in the end it didn't work out for me. Thats alot for a game that costs like 5 euros on sale right? anyway i'm not gonna bore you- the world, the lore, the art direction, the gameplay...is just so well done that it makes you wish you lived in that world.You play as Corvo, an ex-bodyguard that is accused and imprisoned falsly by a corrupt government. When you get to play as him he will be a super-assassin. choking biches left and right :D you can choose how you want to play the game, you can either play it as a silent shadow without being seen, or you could go full rampage and loud. content:
Posted: January 22
												I love this game so much that even after taking close to 50 hours to finish the main campaign, I wished the game was a bit longer, just so I could spend some more time immersed in the world of Dunwall. It's a beautiful game that I simply couldn't get enough of. GraphicsWhen someone mentions artistic games, they most likely are talking about indie games such as Firewatch. In fact, some might even frown upon anyone mentioning a AAA title. So it might surprise some people when I say that Dishonored is one of the most artistic games I have ever laid my eyes on. You can take screenshot of almost any place in the game and it would look like a beautiful oil painting, even when Dunwall is a dark and dreary place to be in, infested with rats and plague. Its atmospheric look evokes a sense of mystery and suspense. The world is so well done that I wanted to learn the history of the city. When, say, I passed by an abandoned building, I wondered about the people who used to live there. That is how well done Dunwall is, pardon the pun. I was so immersed in it that it felt real. It made me curious. I wanted to know more. I wish they written novels about Dunwall. I would definitely read it. There is plenty of lore, if you're interested in it, to learn the backstories of some of the characters, and places. But I wished there were more. GameplayLot of people love to look down on AAA games for being violent and crass and shower praise on indie titles such as Undertale for going the opposite route. "You can finish the game without killing anyone", they would say. Well, guess what? In Dishonored, you can finish the entire game without killing anyone too! In fact that's encouraged. And there is an achievement if you happen to not kill a single person in the game. And it's not easy not to kill. The game makes you work for it. Sometimes killing is so tempting. Especially because, in this game, apart from your regular weapons such as the sword and gun and crossbow, you also get special abilities such as super vision, ability to stop time, ability to possess other people etc.  If you don't mind a darker ending, you can unleash all your powers on your enemies. But the game rewards you with a better, brighter, more positive ending if you exercise restraint.  StoryDishonored has a decent main story plus lots of interesting side stories. There are a lot of literature lying around in the world for you to read to discover the back stories of the places and the people. That makes the game even more immersive. You can even ignore all of it if you want, even though I wouldn't recommend it. All in all this is a great game and it's a must play for anyone who loves playing immersive games.

												Dishonored in quite possibly the most innovative and enjoyable single player game I've played since I was a kid. Why?Corvo, the empresses bodyguard turned "Assassin" by a group of loyalists that wish to put Emily, the late empresses daughter, in charge of the kingdom. How you do that however is compleatly up to you.You will get missions to go Eliminate targets and you can do this by Killing them or "Removing" them if you are the "I can't be bothered to use stealth!" type of person you can run in there willy nilly and stab your target or you can be more creative. Poison, choking them out and throwing them into a pack of hungry rats, or using your magic to send them to the moon Or on the flipside, you're the type of person that likes stealth and to be as non-leathel as possible you can find alternitive means to eliminating your targets.The way you play greatly affects the outcome of the storyThis game is increadibly innovative. Good line of sight on guards, fun and interesting ways to kill and neutrilize people, amazing story with charaters you get attached to, combat that makes you think of how you're going to tackle groups of enemies, whilst still being a challenge to the player.So far I've played this game through to the end 3 times and every playthrough has been different.If you're browsing through steam for a good game to play at a reasonable price, £7.99 at the time of writing this, I highly recomend this game.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
												Dishonored is a great game both story and gameplay wise. It allows you to approach every mission very creatively and this allows you to challenge yourself with multiple difficulty options such as having the option to just use the starting equipment and never getting powers apart from Blink. Because of these options Dishonored has masses of replay value and has a wide selection of choices with different tactics that are rewarded with spacious environments riddled with pathways and secrets.Unfortunately Dishonored isn't perfect with the stilted voice work and animation and the lack of stealth options that gets beaten out by action gameplay even though it encourages stealth to get the good ending. Dishonored may have flaws, but they are outweighed by the beautiful atmosphere and openness of the level structure and won't cause massive damage to what is a fantastic game.

Pour berry mixture into the crust, and dot with butter. Cut remaining pastry into 1/2 - 3/4 inch wide strips, and make lattice top. number of helpful: 12 of 16 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												Goddammit, I promised this one a LONG time ago and now with my vacations, I can actually put some love into this one. [Thanks to HateBreeder for the reminder ;)].Anyways... Dishonored went under my radar because 1) It looked like it was sh*t; and 2) The moral choice didn't encourage me to buy it at all (which I will explain why later).It's hard at all to give a good premise to a game and Dishonored gets it half well and half badly: The lore is great, you have an Empress who rules Dunwall with it's lords and assistants, a very... steampunk-ish city where the plague infects everything and everyone. Everything feels depressing and everyone just ♥♥♥♥♥es about how they are sad and hate life and lifes hates them.The game succeeds in putting you in Corvo Attano's shoes (the protagonist), a guard for the empress who, right off the bat is accused to murdering the Empress, that moment.. sucked! It was so stupid as to how Corvo (he can't ♥♥♥♥ing talk!!) didn't say a word, he just stood there while everyone said "TRAITOR!" or "MURDERER!". It totally breaks from his character and the immersion of the world. Sadly... Dunwall falls flat as well with all this:Dunwall doesn't have character! (I know, it sounds weird...) It all sums up to you finding a dead body somewhere with a suicide letter because their wife or girlfriend or sister or mother and/or whatever died because of the plague!It shoves depression down your throat every. Single. ♥♥♥♥ing. Time! It's not appealing! It needed (not much, but at least a little bit of) life or joy somewhere, hell! Even the mission at the party is ♥♥♥♥ing depressing in groundbreaking levels of depression!The Steampunk city could also be better described, like how some stuff works for the curious, I mean, how the robot patriots work, among other technologically interesting stuff! Cities like Bioshock Infinite's Columbia is miles away better than Dunwall, it made a great contrast between the superficial perfection of Columbia and the deeper depressing and violent Columbia, while explaining cool stuff you might be wondering (Like how a beach and it's ocean work in a city in the SKY! (yes, that is explained!) Dunwall is just... a background! It could've been a daylight version of Point Lookout, Maryland from Fallout 3 without the skreekers and the Ferals and it would have had the same ♥♥♥♥ing impact!)Whale Oil isn't giving the city "a deeper layer of character" like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t reviewers like IGN claim.Anyway, after you are arrested 40 minutes into the game, you get introduced into the the very first of 2 major plot twists in the game's story, which I won't say what it is about, and after that, the story starts as it should, a nice vendetta-style story that isn't as good as The Darkness 2 but gets the job done to motivate you into every mission. It really does motivate you, but more because of:-The level design: it's very varied throughout the 9 missions you get (I sadly do not own any DLC, though I plan of getting them in the (unclear) future). Every character you will kill has it's own... massive property and surroundings. This helps give you a feel of size that Dunwall has instead of just... background! The levels were clearly well thought out and, honestly, seem to be the best part of the game and the main reason I played this game twice and still intend in doing a 3rd playthrough.The charm also comes from the gameplay: it's probably one of the best gameplay systems ever made, ever! It feels unbelievably fluid, how you can run and dodge everything while blinking ANYWHERE (real ♥♥♥♥ing level design, THIEF 2014!, you know why? Because when I actually say "anywhere" I mean A-N-Y-W-H-E-R-E!). It's amazing, it truly is! If you think, "Oh, a roof... I wish I could go there are escape that "wall of light" (a shield barrier than instantly kills you in the game), well, welcome to dishonored, where you can actually go through that roof or sewer or door or anything! Kudos to Arkane!The peek system is a bit OP though... by pressing Q (lean/peek right) or E (lean/peek left), you can see what's on the right of the box you're hiding behind, HOWEVER, no one can see you while you are in lean mechanic! (Except guards on the side or behind you, of course. But the ones in front of you, just can't see you, even like 50 centimetres in front of you). It makes the game a tad easy, especially for me, who breezed through the game in both Hard and Very Hard (2 hardest difficulties), completing every side and main quest, which is, I admit, a bit... weird, I wanted a bigger challenge, like DX: Human Revolution provided effectively!The story is good overall except for the stupid moral decision where: - Kill much? = Bad ending- Oh, you play like the Pope would play? = Good EndingIt's not well thought out, because killing is the funnest way of playing! Because guess how many of your skills (magic powers) are lethal focused? Yep, 70% of them! SO, for stealth purists who prefer knocking out the guards, you will end the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ game with like 15 runes to spend BECAUSE THERE ARE NO MORE NON-LETHAL BASED SKILLS!They focus the skills in killing when the story prefers a non-lethal playthrough! It makes little sense though stealth is still really fun nevertheless!Both styles of play are fun, but the skills focus on combat when they should be more split between lethal and non-lethal. Also, there are many gadgets (grenades, spikes, crossbows, pistols, etc.), right now I am thinking 1 only thing that is useful for NON-LETHAL! Which is the sleep dart for the crossbow. ARE YOU ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ME? It's not very balanced between the 2 styles and it looks like it has a massive identity crisis between which style of play it wants to focus on...Lastly: The graphics! Textures on High are muddy, though they feel intentional, and with a reason: a painting in motion! It looks like it to be honest, like one of those water paiting from Van Gogh. The style is colourful which sadly, contradicts AGAIN with it's feel. If it feels depressing and the game wants to give us a deep sense of sadness and pity, then why so many vibrant colours?!Graphics get a "good" from me though because forgetting these weird... stuff the devs put in the game, this is still one of my personal Games of the Year 2012 and from now on, my favorite stealth game of ALL TIME, thanks to it's incredible level design and remarkably fluid and perfect gameplay! It's from now on my main basis of comparison. Every stealth game coming soon will be compared to dishonored before my purchase. That being said, why do you think I haven't bought Thief 2014 yet? Exactly...Nevertheless, these "small (on the story/writing/non-gameplay issues part) but big (as a whole)" problems will affect the score, which made me think of what to to give this really good game (a 7.5/10). But from a gameplay standpoint it's really sweet, the level design is superb and the story pretty cool overall (despite the (clearly) rushed ending, that still worked I suppose), making it from now on a stealth game model to follow! 9/10 is the other number is my mind.Whichever score you focus your eyes, on, Dishonored deserves nothing more than your hard-earned cash. It easily one on the best games on this last decade because of how well it nailed level design and gameplay fluidity and efectiveness, making a "boring genre" to some people (the stealth genre) into a (somewhat) fun and fast paced game, and that's remarkable is so many standpoints, that I still have a feeling of going back and get into a 3rd playthrough and even buy the praised DLC's.Such a gem to be honest. Sad I didn't buy it earlier. Still, best 7,49€ I spent in months.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												This game's artistic style is a mix of Thief 1+2 and BioShock. Of course I liked it, is that even a question? I also commend the game designers for successfully creating a game that was equally fun playing either fully stealth or mass murdering everyone. Unlike Garrett, Corvo is fully capable of fighting guardsmen head-on and there are all sorts of weapons that make it fun, interesting, and satisfying the entire time. On the other hand, if you choose to go stealthy there are lots of little conversations to overhear that further add to the fantastic amount of world-building. You really can't go wrong here playing either way, though I'd recommend picking one style and sticking with it.This game has a lot more Thief-y feel than the actual sequel Thief (2014) did. It's a real shame that game turned out to be what it was. Unsurprisingly, I discovered that there's some overlap between the production staffs for the original Thief games and this one. The blood will tell, as they say.

												A wondefully crafted story. You are a bodyguard hired to protect Queen Victoria of England from the Black Plague, but when Budd from Kill Bill murders her, you are framed for it. After escaping prison, you systematically assassinate everyone in the entire city to prove that you're not a deranged killer. Then you wake up in the boat from Willy Wonka on the choclate river, but you ate way too much choclate, so the Oompa Loompas bring to Budd and he takes all your stuff. You get really mad at him for that, so you kill him too, and then you're done. Oh, and there's some subplot about rescuing a girl or somethnig, but that's not important.
