content:
Posted: January 15
												Fantastic!  This game had it all.1. Rich lore and world building from the start.  I loved the care taken to explain the whale oil economy, scrimshaw,  and debaucherous holidays.  Take a moment to read the tomes and notes scattered around, they go a long way toward building a fleshed out breathing world.  Pointing the "heart' at someone can sometimes gives you insight on someone's true nature or simply tell you that their family has been taken by the plague.  Good stuff.2. A myriad of creative ways to execute and incapacitate your foes.Dishonored offers you a dozen tools that can be combined for a rewarding combat experience.  Lay razorwire traps on alarms, fire your gun in the air to alert the guards and watch as they get shredded when they reach for that alarm button.  Possess guards to remove explosive whale oil barrels, drop the barrel in a group of enemies and then fire an explosive crossbow bolt from your hidden position.  If anyone survives, summon a swarm of carnivorous rats to finish them off or let them dispose of the bodies and erase any trace of your dirty work.3.  Great level design and layout.Run across rooftops, jump through windows or duck into sewers, under tables, hide atop rafters.  Most areas are accessible and allow you to go through or around your enemy.   The setting is a city in economic and social decay but is still quite beautiful.I loved this game from start to finish and wish I hadn't passed it over for so many years.  10/10 would search through Lady Boyle's panty drawers again.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												Overall, it's like the stealth version of BioShock. Dishonored is heavily based on stealthy approach to complete the missions and you'll be given a lot of choices to determine the outcome of your current mission's story, the other character's dialogue and behavior, plus the ending.  Like BioShock, you'll have a weapon (unlike BioShock, sword only) on your right hand and multiple tools on your left hand, both controllable individually. The difference is, Dishonored has way less choices of supernatural powers and weapons. The combat only focuses on melee combat even you're given a flintlock-like pistol and a crossbow as a ranged weapon.Here's the goods and the bads of the game:Pros:+ Another beautifully written story for a video game+ Challenging combat. you are not extremely OP like in most other games, but also not awkwardly animated like Chivalry: Medieval Warfare's sword fight+ Your actions and decisions will decide the outcome of the story+ Supernatural powers, even though it's very limited (new powers for the DLC campaign) but it's still very fun to use. Just like BioShock, you hold the magic power on your left hand while your right hand will hold a weapon (in this case, sword only)+ A lot of choices to complete your missions. Different approaches are available each with their own consequences and benefits.+ DLC is also pretty good, telling a story that's happening on the other side with a character that will eventually meet your main character on the main story. If you like challenges, one of the DLC offers a complete set of challenges that will test your in-game combat, stealth, and agility skill.+ Enemy types varies just like Assassin's Creed even though the enemies in Dishonored don't have any weaknesses that can be exploited.+ Collectibles, hidden objects to power up, hidden rooms, etc. If you love those kind of things, this game's totally for you. Mostly, you'll have to sniff around and explore almost every corner of the map in order to level up your powers properly.+ Pretty good graphics, but not great.Cons:- Horrible character graphics, they only have very limited models plus lack of details sometimes make it very obvious that a lot of duplicates are walking around.- Story outcome solely based on your capability to stealth. A stealthy and merciful playstyle will save the entire kingdom while aggressive and murderous playstyle will throw the kingdom into a deeper pit of chaos since all your actions will be taken example of by the upcoming Empress.- Kills are limited on every level (around 15 each mission if you want a good outcome) which makes this game pretty weird. An assassin who is not allowed to kill anyone, seriously? You must use non-lethal weapons if your stealth fails and stuck in inescapable conflict.- I'm no fan of finding hidden objects which are usually very far and way too tedious to find it and I'm sure I'm not the only one. Lack of power upgrades will make stealth much harder.- Some maps are confusing, especially the Brigmore house in the DLC- Sword range is weird, the animation won't show the sword reaches you but you will still get hit. Sword blocks sometime fail to work during this time.TL;DR If you like BioShock, you'll like this game. It's almost the same thing, just much more limited weaponry and choices. But if you hate stealth games, don't buy this game. It is solely based on stealth, nothing more.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
												It's disheartening to see how Arkane Studios appears to be the only developer still around which has the necessary skills to take usually overlooked vertical exploration and rich level design to such a, pardon the pun, high degree. So much so they can rightfully be placed at the very essence of Dishonored which revels and is at its best when it lets you explore the extremely well designed world of Dunwall which absolutely oozes atmosphere and character at every corner, but is sadly diminished by its poorly constructed and even worse, poorly executed narrative of the main story which leads to unsatisfying revelations and tacked on abrupt ending not redeemed in the least by an epilogue. This carries over to characters and their own stories which end up being very forgettable and merely serving a purpose.Things are just as conflicted in the gameplay department where game offers multiple ways to go about your bloody business, but then proceeds to hamstring your stealth approach with very limited arsenal of tools at your disposal, at least compared to a more violent route which gives you much more freedom and utility. There are also customary problems associated with stealth AI detection and rats getting in the way of devouring your unconscious enemies which leads to some no kill failure states. Some of the non-violent target solutions could've also used a bit more challenge and less contrivance in some cases, but it's nothing worth writing a paragraph about and can be waved away.In the end Dishonored is a widely uneven game, but one who's faults fail to overshadow the positives in the grand scheme of things. Shame I didn't get to tackle the DLC, but it's something for the future because Dishonored is most certainly worthy of replaying.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2016
												I highly recommend this game.Firstly to lovers of the gendre, but really, if you want to try a good stealth game that will challenge your skill and intelligence, you must try Dishonored.At the eve of Dishonored 2 I believed it was high time to give this acclaimed gem a try. And I must say I was not disapointed.Don't get me wrong, all games have their flaws, but Dishonored has the rare quality of having very few of those.To me the negative points never surpassed the positive ones, or I wouldn't have played the game in full :)Before I go into specifics please keep in mind this is my own personal opinion.What did I like?+ The story + The characters + The graphics + The artwork + The challenging missions+ The world + The non kill option+ The longevity + The powersWhat did I dislike?- The ambiance- The rats- The unbalanced game style- The extreme demands of stealth mode- The clichés - The absence of a radar - The dark vision powerMore details on those positive points:While Dishonored doesn't have the most original storyline it still has enough plot and twists to it to keep you firmly seated at you PC screen. But the main atraction is it's gameplay.The main character may be silent, but all those around him help to build a world full in variety, color and depth. The other characters all have their stories and secrets, you don't spend much of the game speaking to anyone, but the use of a particular item will tell you much more. Abuse it, it's worth it! But don't worry, the game won't provide any spoilers. :)The graphics have some good textures and shapes, very correct and respectful of the standards of 2012 frankly still looks great today. A pity the world of Dishonored looks so static at times. The character motions also leave a bit to be desired but nothing major.The actual artwork (on paper) is very good in my opinion but it doesn't fully translate into the game. However, the somber clothing and hairstyles totally respect the game world. As well as the angular faces, a look I wasn't familiar with but which I enjoyed in the end, plus beautifull scenarios to enjoy at times from the rooftops during sunset.The game is non-linear in it's gameplay, all paths lead to rome true but there are many of them. One mission goal equals at least 5 ways to go about it. Depending on whether you prefer to go unseen, or wish to cause as much 'chaos' as possible. The game will measure how much of a mess you made and Will punish you for it.It's dificult to create an original world in which to place your characters, this game studio found a clever mix between steampunk and broken utopia, very original. Hint, read all books.As mentioned briefly before, there are two ways to play this game, kill or not kill, each with it's dificulties and rewards. Naturally it's never so simple. You will obtain achievements for killing all, for killing some, for killing Only some and killing none. Even the bosses! Which is a much apreciated novelty! One important distinction to learn early on? Ghost and Shadow. You can not get seen and can not kill, or you can not get seen while still going for the kill.Naturally, one playthrough won't be enough, which, is another positive point!Me, I took over 41 hours thus far. Reduce that by half if you're an expert in stealth games. :)The abilities or powers awarded the players are frankly a breath of fresh air. Blink gives you so many original and cool ways to get about, and Dark Vision is pratically indispensible!The rest? Well, that depends on how you wish to play the game, and I won't ruin it for you. But note that collecting certain items will be essential for acquiring those powers. Rather than a nuisance it will help you know your misions levels all the better.More details on the negative points:Dishonored is dark, in more ways than one. There are no rosy cheeked kids no puppies and no flowers. Of course it was integral to the game, but you can only stomach so much disease and death, regarless of the cold truth it depicts.Rats? Why rats? Distasteful to say the least. You best not suffer from this particular phobia or you Won't be able to play the game. On a slightly happier note those are one of two things you Can kill without saction.Killing is the fastest way, stealth becomes madatory later on however, so you can either be very patient or triger happy, the game takes into account both choices and delivers it's consequences. But I can't help but feel that those who choose 'kill' are hindered more than the non-kill, more rats for one, more agressif 'people' on the streets, more security and guards.Stealth much? Knock out a guard, hide him in a dark corner for fear of discovery, need to do the same with the guard dogs for another dog will go on alert at the sight of it's sleeping canine friend, and careful where you place your sleeping beauties for someone on the below floor may hear you! But by all means slash your weapon at the back of your unsuspecting victim at two feet he won't hear a thing... logic is not Dishonored's strong point.Did you say 'cliché'? As I said before, the story is not the most original but some events might have you griding your teeth. I can't say much more without spoiling the game.You must unlock a power to see through walls (Dark vision), but the game offers you an achievement reward if you don't get it, hmmm... but if you have no radar to begin with this game becomes a tremendous headache without it.Can it be done? Yes. Is it worth the headache for one achievement? No thanks.And speaking of Dark vision, yellow... why yellow and why do their eyes need to glow like flashlights?I could go on about it at lenght, but I think each futur player of Dishonored should focus on what good they can take from the game and from there pick out what they like the most and the least.Especially since this Is a good game and a game worth playing at least once in your gamer life. Like many rare pearls out there Dishonored has earned it's place in legend.Enjoy your game!Kind regards,Keiyan

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												This is a review for Dishonored: Game of the Year Edition, that means the review takes in account of the dlc's as well.This game was definitely one of most entertaining games I've played. Being one of the few first person stealth games, the control are very smooth and Skyrim-like. I would say the game is worth every penny, but due to some pros and cons, players generally like or dislike this game, I'll suggest you either rent or buy this game while it's on sale if you're "unsure".First, I'm going to cover the background info. The game takes place in a steam punk era, where magic and technology exists together. The main campaign goes something like this, you're the royal bodyguard who came back a bit earlier than expected. Being wrong place at wrong time, you were framed after witnessing your queen getting assassinated and the princess getting kidnapped. The main plot is essentially very straight-forward, linear and a bit predictable. So readers be warned, don't expect Mass Effect level of plot. However, while the main plot is not extremely good, it's not bad either. What makes the plot however, really highlighted and up high on the scale is when you play the DLC's, where you get to play as the master assassin Daud, who's story takes place after his murder of the queen. The DLC's are fairly lengthy and I have to say, for me it was very interesting the way the plot weaves along with the main campaign, so if you consider getting this game, definitely pick up the DLC's or the GOTY edition.The game mechanics is what really kicks this game up high for me. You get variety of abilities such as teleporting, freezing time and even possess your enemies to sneak past security. With the amount of weapons and abilities, you have a bucket load of ways to enjoy the game, rather it is to sneak past enemies or to fight them straight up. Here's however, in my opinion where the main flaw for me came in. The game uses a system called chaos system. Based on the amount of enemies you've killed, you either end up with a high chaos or low chaos endings along with some effects on certain missions. I played through my main campaign on low chaos, and I've seen the high chaos ending as well. Honestly, I would highly suggest you to play the way you would play on any assassin games, don't worry about how you eliminate your targets, you will end up getting the most fun out of the game by trying out all the gadgets. Also, the ending is not different by much.Graphic: 7/10Explanation: The graphics uses the unreal engine, it was intended to have a comic and more Borderlands feel to it rather than realistic. I enjoyed the graphics as it combined with the game atmosphere very well, but it's certainly not the "high-end-best" graphics.Plot: 8/10Explanation: You may be a little bit confused about my plot scoring, originally I was going to give the plot a 6/10 after playing through the main story, but since the DLC's really pack a punch and connects with the main plot, I felt the need to give it a higher score of 8 out of 10. Keep in mind for Open World RPG players, this game does not have as much side missions as you would expect, most side missions revolve around the main mission. Providing you with alternative ways to approach targets or reward you with new abilities.Gameplay: 8.5/10Explanation: The gameplay is absolutely amazing in ways, your abilities are very awesome, and overpowered at the same time, I however, was not looking for difficulty but rather enjoying the game the way it is. But for you hardcore gamers out there, there's options for higher difficulties. Players that choose to be pacifist or run the game on low chaos will end up limiting themselves over the usage of tools, making it less enjoying than when playing the game on high chaos. But rewarding in ways as well.Replayability: 6/10Explanation: There are some challenges in the DLC's such as the Time Bend Massacre, where you go through many rounds to try and murder people as many as possible with the time frozen for a limited amount of time. This I can see as being fairly enjoyable, but aside from this, maybe another run-through just to see the alternative chaos ending, I would not hold this game high on replability.Overall: 8/10Conclusion: Great game, definitely a steal when you buy it on sale, fairly reasonable price at it's full as well. If you enjoy casual, stealth, first person killing games, you would get a lot of out of this game. The game is pretty linear and fast pace, so no grinding or the need to feel dragged. A good game worth picking up when you want a new game.

Dishonored.All i have to say is,this is my favorite stealth-action game.A game themed with steampunk ''culture''You are Corvo Attano,a protector of the Empress.After a trip,you go back to the tower of Dunwall,a place located in Dunwall,a city corrupted by a rat plague.So,you go to the Tower,to see the empress,and her daughter,Emily.Suddenly,you get attacked by assassins,and as a result,the Empress dies and they kidnap the young lady.The guards believe that you are the killer,and they lead you inside the prison.Your only option is to escape.Escape to save Emily,and take revenge.This game gives you the freedom of choice.There are multiple endings depending on your actions.You want to go loud?Go,but there will be disadvantages.More enemies in the future.You go silently?less enemies for you.You prefer making the enemies go back to bed or kill them?You want to assassinate your targets,or let them live a different life?How do you want to go that place?From the sewres,from the main door,from the window?FREEDOM. You have different abilities,from teleporting to summon rats as your minions.You've got 3 different weapons,a sword,a gun,and a crossbow.You can upgrade your weapons,give them different bullets to use.You can also use grenades.I loved every single moment of this game.the way it gives you the option to deal with your quests exactly as you want.I would love to see a prequel,yes,a prequel.a background story of Corvo.Story : 8/10Gameplay : 10/10Graphics : 8/10Sound :9/10Conclusion : 8,75/10

You can also get achievements for finishing the game in some of these ways which I know some people enjoy getting including me. I think anyone could enjoy this game beacasue you can play it anyway you want!

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												Excellent game all around - no need for me to use ink here on talking about what makes the game good. Well it just works and looks good and so on... Instead i want to point out how to get the most out of this game. To do that i  STRONGLY advise to not go after the 'Clean Hands' achievement unless you really like to do things the hard way. (Clean Hands = Dont kill anyone in the game) To contradict what i just said i must also say a 'no-kill' game by avoid killing as much is  also a strong recommendation for first playtrough... just dont try do the Clean Hands which is 100% clean game as that is a serious source of frusttration. Now if you do a 'no-kill' game you will be getting used to the load/save screen a lot anyways but completing the game without accidentally killing anyone is just a mess. Better keep a very large library of saves as you will need to backtrack sooner or later. I was very careful but hilarious (well not at the time) game bugs was a big problem. Here is some methods i used to 'kill' someone that i can remember: - Dropping a unconsious guard near a brick wall so that the foot of the guard got stuck on the wall. Nothing big there, happens all the time. But as i was about to leave the place the body jumped up and - fell down a level as i was on the roof. Guard died. - There was once 2 guard pile near a railing. Some pipes below. Apparently putting a 3 guard in the pile made the guy at the bottom to 'zip out' like a toothpaste tube being pressed and then....he fell down. a couple of meters. and died. Didnt even notice it at first so a reload time it was later  (That 'unconsious' text is your friend when checking if people are still alive - at least before you get the turn to ash -ability. Which in turn is only usefull if you actually see the guard dying)- I took out a guard on a long set of stairs. Guard slowly started to drift down the stairs slooooowly accelerating it's speed and... you guessed it. At one point the speed got too fast and guard died. Needless to say i was only able to see this after i left the place and i just happened to turn around and use the vision at the time. - Leave a body on the ground and a pack of roaming rats find it. And you killed the guard of course when things do go bad.  Logical yes, but it is troublesome again as the rat packs form up and roam independently so unless you are nearby to see it then they can 'stealth' kill a body.  Things like this is what makes this achievement annoying as hell. Not impossible no, but for me the annoyance factor got so bad it easily made a 9/10 game to just 7/10. But it was my own fault for trying to get achievements that dont matter. So a word of advice: play the game as nonlethally as possible - it is definitely worth it as there are some VERY devious ways to achieve main objectives with added satisfaction but skip the clean hands BS.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
Get the feeling of agility, power, stealth and more in: ASSASSIN SIMULATOR 2012 A.K.A DISHONOREDOk, at first I bought this game because, you know, assassins. BUT the more I played like an assassin killing everyone the more I saw negative repercussions on Dunwall, I turned half town into zombies and the cops all hated me and that really didn't help my case of being "innocent". In other words: an assassin game that made me not want to kill my marks! I love this game, it's made for multiple playthroughs with multiple styles: from a completley ghost-no-casualties style to an all out no-one leaves-here-alive style. Awesome. That's what you typically expect from assassin games, yes, but you can also just stealth along every mission without as much as interacting with any of the guards (be it choking or killing them), so: Stealth!ALSO, remember how playing the no-killing game is always tedious for everyone and you just do it for the bonuses in stealth games? NOT HERE! At least not for me anyways, you get awesome options that every stealth game should have (looking at you DE:HR) where you can choke someone to faint in the middle of a square, carry the body, blink the hell out of there onto a roof, leave him there and keep on doing that until you've passivley cleared the area!You can either go like a normal assassin or use these incredible powers granted to you, there's even an achievment for not upgrading any power but blink, which is really the only thing I almost always use, though really why you wouldn't want to use these powers (if you want to play like a normal assassin) is beyond me since "falling out of the sky and slitting a guys throat to watch him turn into ashes while his partner is just about to turn around only to see nothing since you blinked away" is incredibly satisfying to do.Now, granted, this game isn't for everyone, people who like action games probably won't like it a lot, it has a block and counter combat system that I've never really tried out since the intro because I never even get caught, but still, no idea how that would work. Also, I think it has a [necessary] flaw with the NPC detection (at least in normal) where you can have a dude watching a hall and a patrol whom you kill at the end of it and even though any normal human being would see that he for some reason does not, but that is all forgiven thanks to the ability to climb on top of freaking lamps and s**t!. Just, awesome.But enough of me fanboying-out, yes, this has become on of my favourite games, and yes I love it and it's characters, with a good enough consecuence system (better than Skyrims that's for sure) and an awesome concept and lore (if you read the books and pay attention to the places you visit, there is a lot of it) you'll surely like this game.9.9/10 If only because it can get tedious to get some achievments since the missions can be rather lengthy, especially for a ghost-&-no-deaths playthrough and such, but I'd still say you should buy the GOTY edition with the extra missions and such, a no brainer in my opinion.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												I deleted my old review for the sake of writing a new one. This is the first game I reviewed and I don't think my old one did this title any justice.First of all, let me preface this by saying that this is, hands down, no holds barred, my favorite game. Ever. Of all time. Everything from the atmosphere to the gameplay to the replayability is just... It's flawless.Well, in my opinion at least. I won't lie, there are some pretty big flaws with the game that are hopefully addressed in a future sequel. Seriously, I hope.In general, this game is sort of the child of Bioshock and Thief (The original Thief series, not the half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥reboot). It's a stealth-action game that goes through a linear story of ten missions. In addition to this, there are three DLC packs. The first is the "Dunwall City Trials" pack which adds another ten missions, though those are more side/minigames. They're very challenging and I recommend them for pro players who want to test themselves. There are two story-based DLCs following another character on top of that. "The Knife of Dunwall" adds three missions and "The Brigmore Witches" adds another four (though one is just an intro mission, really.)The gameplay is where this game shines the most. While each mission, and map in general, is highly linear, there are a countless number of ways to approach each mission objective and it's limited only by your creativity and whatever weapons/powers you have. In the spirit of Bioshock, the protagonist (Corvo in the main story, Daud in the DLC) wields a sword in his right hand, and an arsenal of weapons and supernatural powers in the left. Swordplay is very tight, surpassing that of games like Chivalry and Skyrim, in my opinion. (Of course, that's in MY opinion.) It's very streamlined with a dedicated attack button and a block button, and it's all about timing parries and knowing when and where to strike. As for the other hand, you gain, early on in the story, the Blink power, which allows instantaneous teleportation across short distances. On top of that, you can unlock further powers, like Posession (which allows you to possess rats and animals, and can be upgraded to possess people), Bend Time (slows down time Matrix-style, and full-on stops it when upgraded), and a ton more. On top of that, you have a few subweapons like an upgradable pistol and a crossbow that fires different kinds of darts like steel darts, tranquilizers, and explosive/incendiary darts. You also get a few other cool stuff like razor traps and grenades.Now, with all these options you can clearly see why there's a number of ways to approach your target. There's a ton of combinations you can use against enemies. Freeze time, shoot a few rounds at multiple guards, and watch as they all go flying at once. How about possessing a guard and making him walk in front of his buddy's bullet? While this is technically a stealth game... I mean, c'mon, you have all these toys? Why not wreak a little havoc? Slice and dice and shoot down everything in sight. Or maybe you're like me, where you prefer not to be seen? Good news for you, you can literally go through the entire game (both the main mission and the DLC), and I stress this, THE ENTIRE GAME, without either killing a single person or being seen or detected once. Good. God.Now, while it seems like I have nothing but endless praise for this game, for the sake of not sounding like a total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ shill, I do have to say this game had a few flaws.For one thing, it CAN get a little dull once you've played it enough. The replayability is endless but sometimes you'll find yourself using the same strategies each time. Blink is outright broken and there's even an achievement for not buying/upgrading ANY powers and just using Lv. 1 Blink. And the sad thing is, if you know what you're doing... It's not hard.Secondly, the music is really highly forgettable, and the only good song in the game is the closing track, "Honor For All". The sound direction is okay at best, and really you only use it to avoid being detected by listening for sounds.And the story is really kind of dull. The characterization is abysmal and the writing is predictable and cliche. Now I say this, but the Daud DLC really improves on both writing and characterization, so it's not as big a problem with that... Just don't expect anything much playing the main story.Another thing I saw this game catch flak for (I didn't mind it so much myself, but it is a legitimate grievance) is that the game punishes you for going high chaos. IE being detected often, killing too many people (threshold is about 30% of npcs per mission). You will get the bad endings. On the upside though, if you prefer this playstyle and don't mind the endings, it does sort of reward you by making areas more highly populated by guards and other enemies. If you like to kill a lot, you get more to kill. You'll just get the bad ending in the process. You'll definitely want to try both playstyles.Now, those complaints aside, I still HIGHLY recommend this game for literally everyone. Even if you're a casual gamer, or an RPG fan, or an FPS fan, or hell, even an RTS fan, just give it a go once. There's a very good chance you won't regret it. It's really a fantastic title.

Posted: November 7, 2015
Dishonored - an epic fantasy title by Arkane Studios... can it counter a game like Skyrim? Let's find out!Imagine a pretty solid guard who gets magical powers by a supernatural guy known as The Outsider, being falsely accused of murdering the queen... doesn't that sound pretty cool? Well, it actually is!Dishonored takes place in the industrial city of Dunwall, where technology and otherwordly forces coexist. The city design is modeled on London and Edinburgh in the 18th century. With a very dark and foggy atmosphere and an interesting art style, aesthetically it serves very well as eye-candy. But not only the graphical aspects make this game a masterpiece - the concept designs, story lore and mechanics are solid and complex. Since it's sadly not a sandbox game, you are relatively limited to exploring, freedom of roaming etc - but the points above completely compensate to that. The storyline is a masterpiece, aesthetics are eye candy and an engine that is actually working. Sounds satisfying, right? Besides the awesome visuals provided by the dark themed style - you also get supercool abilities which give you tons of possibilites how to defeat your enemies - or sneak past them without anyone noticing. Different playstyles are definetely possible in this game, and give even the sneakiest rogue-players a good challenge and satisfaction. I would buy, and recommend the game again!10/10Originally posted by ysarts (Specs):GTX 980i7 4790k @3.9ghz32GB Vengeance RAMCooler Master V8120GB SSD + 3TB ext.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												Although it's advertised under the stealth genre, Dishonored is, more or less, what you make of it. Dunwall, the game's focal city and capital of the empire, is in the midst of crisis. Its beloved empress has been assassinated, and you - her bodyguard Corvo - have the blame thrust upon you simply for being in the wrong place at the wrong time. Her daughter, and proper heir to the throne, is kidnapped by those truly responsible for her mother's death. Meanwhile, the destabilized empire struggles to contain an outbreak of plague, which has been spreading throughout the city at unprecedented speeds.Armed with an arsenal of gadgets and powers, Corvo must traverse his way through the rapidly dilapidating urban center of Dunwall. Your mission is to rescue heir Emily and clear your name: the mastermind of the assassination has seized power and appointed his fellow conspirators to key positions in the government. It is here where the game begins, freed from prison by unexpected benefactors. How you choose to accomplish your goals will greatly affect the city, others' opinions of you, and the game's outcome; should Corvo indiscriminately slaughter the innocent and guilty along the way, Dunwall will visibly deteriorate throughout the course of the game. Conversely, it's possible to complete the game through entirely nonlethal means - and young Emily will be watching, influenced by her role model's moral compass. Dishonored is unique in that two different people can approach the game with two separate playstyles and come away with two different impressions. There is a lot more depth to the game's story than meets the eye and while the nonlethal ending is far more fulfilling, the lethal and nonlethal routes will yield two very different games. If you are a fan of stealth-based gameplay, adapting your movements carefully to avoid detection, you should be delighted with Dishonored. If you prefer to steamroll your way through haphazardly, you may be less impressed.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												Dishonored is a gritty action stealth game in which you play a revenge-driven assassin with a full complement of deadly gadgets and supernatural magics. There is an emphasis on avoiding bloodshed, in combining logic and patience (mostly patience), to outwit the enemies and follow the storyline, undetected.Never fear, if you are completely incapable of sneaking past a guard, even if he was deaf, blind, and asleep - like me, Dishonored still offers you the awesome fun of hacking, slashing and zapping everything to death in a bloody rage. This is called a high chaos playthrough - and it'll change the storyline, and affect the way you play the levels, what side quests you can complete and ultimately, the ending. If you are some sort of crazy completionist, you'll have two whole playthroughs to enjoy, and some of the achievements are only to be attempted by those with the patience of a saint, and prepare to lose some sanity in the process.Downsides are the game is a wee bit on the short side; although if you're buying the GOTY addition this is somewhat made up for in the story DLC which adds a fair chunk of side story as well as some new gadgets and abilities.A unique setting, compelling storyline, fluid gameplay, replayability and challenge, in case you can't tell, I recommend!

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												I'm aware that this is an unpopular opinion, but it's just that- an opinion.I've played the vanilla game twice, once as an insane murderer, stabbing and shooting my way through a city, and once as a pacifist twiddling his thumbs as the guard crawls past at a snail's pace. I didn't have the DLC for this game.Very unenjoyable to me. The game's mechanics and story had an excellent setup, but failed to deliver at all. By mechanics, I mean specifically stealth. It's boring to stealth because everyone has a 2 inch sightline and the memory of a goldfish to match. The most fun I remember having is tied between the "time manipulation", and my murder playthrough. There's clearly a mismatch in story and gameplay: the most fun most people have is, most likely, the murder playthrough. Stab and shoot and stab and laugh, because if you're looking for a game where it's fun to just mess around as basically a god, then this game is great, two thumbs up. But as a stealth game? The whole thing is booooring. You crawl around, blink to skip encounters, you have just one stealth item in comparison to the 30-odd items that you have to murder people, so don't forget to spend your cash on that when you can. On the other hand, nothing was quite as fun as getting detected, stopping time, running into the vents... and then the fun stops as everyone scours everywhere but above them. This game world wants you to play like a pacifist, but the game makes you want to play as a psycho. I didn't even want to play through twice, but Sam somehow guilted me into it.In terms of story, I don't think I cared at all until I found Sam the boat guy (I think that's his name... I can't even remember my favorite character's name.) alive at a certain point when most characters were dead. The setup is incredible here, there's details everywhere about the world and how it's dying, and how the whales are critical to the survival of the people- but then you talk to them, and you wish you could just stop playing because everyone talks like they've just woken up and they just don't understand why this peasant wants to talk to them about saving the world. And if you try and pay attention, that attention to detail appears again as the devs have created this arcs for these characters, some of which overlap, but then the failure to deliver ruins any enjoyment.OVERALLFun fighting, "loud" mechanicsDetailed world and charactersStealth is suprisingly boring in a stealth gameCharacters might put you to sleepWorld is boring to actually look at.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
												Bayağı oldu inceleme yazmayalı. Bunun en büyük nedeni 1 saat 2 saat oynayıpta inceleme yazmayı sevmiyorum. Kısa bir oyunsa bitirdikten sonra yazmayı tercih ediyorum. Yok değilse en azından inceleme yazacak kadar oynama taraftarıyım. Bazen görüyorum; adam yardırmış, giydiriyor oyuna. Oynama süresine bakıyorum; 15-20 dk, oyunun vaadettiği süreye bakıyorum 50 saat 60 saat hatta bazen 100 saat. Ben bu incelemenin nesini dikkate alayım. Destan yazın demiyorum ama 50 saatlik senaryousu olan oyuna da 15 dk oynayıp inceleme yazmayın. Gerçekten komik oluyor. İçimi döktükten sonra gelelim incelemeye. Eski pc min über berbatlığı yüzünden bir türlü oynayamadığım oyunlardan biriydi Dishonored. Düşünün şu anki pc imle 100 küsür fpslerde oynadığım Dishonored eski pc imde medium da 30 fps yi zor görüyordu. Optimizasyonun ne kadar mükemmel olduğunu burdan da anlayabilirsiniz ve tabi eski pc min über berbatlığını :) Kısmet bugünlereymiş. Neyse güç olsun da güç olmasın diyerekten devam edeyim. En sonda söyleyeyim; oyun çok çok güzel. Özellikle oynanış kısmı mükemmel. Hele bir de gamepadiniz varsa alacağınız keyif 3-5 e katlanıyor.  Dishonored size inanılmaz bir serbestlik sunuyor. Gizlilik/aksiyon türünde bir oyun olmasına rağmen sizi hiçbir şeye zorlamıyor. "İlla bu yoldan gideceksiniz" diye bişey yok oyunda. Tamamen size kalmış. İster milleti doğraya doğraya gidin. İster hiçkimseyi öldürmeyin, isterseniz hiç farkedilmeden ilerleyin. Tamamen size kalmış. Grafiklere gelecek olursak çok iyi diyemem ama çokta kötü değil oyunun temasına uygun olmuş. Açıkçası gerçekçi grafikler yakışmazmış bu oyuna. Oynadıkça onu farkettim. Zaten bi yerden sonra grafik umrunuzda olmuyor ki bu çoğu oyun için geçerli. Oyun kaliteliyse bir şekilde oynatıyor kendini. Dishonored bir intikam hikayesi. Bi görev dönüşünde kraliçe öldürülür ve kızı kaçırılır. Suç bizim üzerimize kalır ve hapse gireriz. İdamımızı beklerken bir şekilde hapisten kaçmayı başarır ve kraliçenin kızını aramaya koyuluruz. Bir yandan da adımızı temize çıkarmak için uğraşırız. Biraz klişe bir hikaye ama ucu açık bitiyor Dishonored 2 nin duyurulduğundan hiç haberiniz bile olmasa oyunu bitirdikten sonra "bunun mutlaka devamı gelir" diyorsunuz. Uzun lafın kısası; hala bugüne kadar oynamadıysanız ilk fırsatta mutlaka satın alın ve oynayın. Parasını sonuna kadar hak eden bir yapım olmuş. Ben oyunu yüksek kaos ta bitirdim. Gerçi son 5 bölümün 4 ünde öldürdüğüm insan sayısı 10 bile değildi ama başlarda katliam yaptım resmen ondan sanırım. Ama siz mümkün olduğunca gizli ilerlemeye çalışın böylece hem itemlerinizi fazla harcamak zorunda kalmazsınız hem de mermi/ok sıkıntısı çekmezsiniz. Ayrıca araştırmacı olun. Direkt göreve gitmeyin.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												An excellent, albeit not great, FPS game!If I had to summarize Dishonored in one sentence, that would be: A stealth-based Bioshock.Truly the game's mechanics (weapons in one hand, magic in the other, plus a big variety of ways to -or not to- kill the enemies), dark story with enough twists and choise-based multiple endings reminded me a lot of Bioshock, though Dishonored comes as a lot more stealth based than the former (and personally less innovative than Bioshock, in my opinion).Nonetheless, Dishonored is an excellent stealth game, thanks to its magical powers hiding becomes a lot simplified, compared to traditional stealth games like Metal Gear Solid or Splinter Cell and I can say even fun enough. Some magic powers like Blink, Possession and Time Bend, to name a few, were really innovative and cool to use.The rest of the weapons (a pistol and a crossbow with various types of ammunition, a variety of grenades or mines, plus your standard sword) provide very brutal kills, for the FPS players wanting action and not stealth.Basically the game is set so that the choices you make affect the ending and your deeds catch up to you: needlessly killing many characters in the game will result in the so called High Chaos and as so a bad ending, while sparing the lives of most enemies will result in the Low Chaos ending, the good one.I'll have to admit though that I was expecting more from the main story, based on all the good reviews I had seen of the game, while I found it just ok: it had a few twists, but nothing as shocking as, say again, Bioshock. I'll admit that the story is quite dark though and full of betrayals and brutal killings, should the player decide to go that way.While I usually find myself liking these multiple endings in games, Dishonored and it's achievements are set to make you play the game at the very least twice, so as to see both endings and collect each one's achievements, which, if you add the fact that the game's last two DLCs demand the same treatment, makes the game very time-devouring (took me about two months to get all the endings and achievements, without playing every day of course though).Speaking of the games DLCs, there are three in total: the first one, Dunwall City Trials, is, as its name suggests, a set of various challenges and not related to the game's story, while the two latter ones, The Knife of Dunwall and The Brigmore Witches, show the story from the perspective of another character, the assassin Daud.As it happens with many TV series spin-offs, I found myself enjoying the Daud DLCs a lot more than the main story, their duration was shorter and just enough to make you enjoy the game (even with both endings) and the connection they made to the main game made the story a lot more enjoyable. What helped it a lot, in my opinion, was the fact that I found it a lot easier to empathize with Daud, who has the opportunity to make amends for his past deeds and get his redemption, compared to the overall "good-guy" assassin of the main game, Corvo, who is there just to save the day.The fact that Daud had a voice actor (Michael Madsen of Kill Bill fame) helped the above fact, while Corvo was, sadly, your usual mute protagonist (meaning that we just don't get to hear him speak, not that he is an actual mute in the game, think of Gordon Freeman for example). Hopefully, in the now announced Dishonored sequel, they will fix this issue and give Corvo a voice actor.On the other hand, the Dunwall City Trials is a sadistic DLC, with the challenges's difficulty reminiscent of very hard 8-bit platformer games. I'll even admit that in order to get the final five, or so, achievements and not leave the game incomplete, I had to resort to using a trainer program, with which (before you can even think of accusing me of cheating) let me tell you that I still had trouble in getting said achievements, you can imagine the difficulty (though I'll admit some challenges were a bit fun, when you got the hand of them).Leaving the story aside, the graphics were also just good, I was expecting a bit more of them from all the positive reception of the game, but at the same time they were not bad. What I personally found bad, was the game's PC optimization, it resulted in a lot of lag and low performance in my side, while the graphics didn't justify such issue. I found out that many AMD graphic card users like myself had similar issues, truly a shame (one of the reasons I had to resort to using a trainer program for the Dunwall City Trials DLC was also related to lag, impossible to play some challenges with it).The Soundtrack, again, was just ok, fitting, but nothing too immersive. Maybe it had to do with the game's stealth atmosphere, this is not Doom or Wolfenstein after all, but still...Gameplay-wise though, the game was quite great, the quick-access wheel was very comfortable to quickly find your next weapon and the creativity you had with the "stealth or kill" environment was nice.Overall, the game was excellent and I'm not trying to say otherwise, but personally the big hype and the frame rate issues were what ruined it a bit for me.I'll still recommend it for the moral choices it provided, the few plot twists and the variety of ways to engage or avoid enemies. Most of all, I'll repeat it, I recommend it for the two Daud DLCs, which will make you appreciate the main story a lot more.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												Dishonored is a fantastic, original game with a great art style and soundtrack. I enjoyed all the missions, although The Golden Cat was my favorite. Even though the graphics are not superb, the game looks so unique that you will not care. It is fun to use the powers, sneak around, and even have shootouts with the guards, and since the main part of the game is supposed to be stealth, it has some of the best stealth gameplay on the market. The Dunwall City Trials DLC that comes with the Game of the Year edition is worth it if you can get it for $2.50, but it is nothing like The Knife of Dunwall or the Witches of Brigmore, two DLC single-player campaigns that are shorter but are just as high quality as the main game. If you enjoy Skyrim's Dark Brotherhood, Thief, or games like those, then this is the game for you. If you are going to buy Dishonored, make sure to get the Game of the Year edition.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
												   I want to start out by saying this game IMO deserves a 9/10. I highly encourage you to pick this game up, upon reading this review! It's a great game, and I loved every second of it! There really aren't many negative things to say, but I do have a one or two. Let's start with the PROS.              PROS                  *Stealth- You can play this game with out much confrontation. Sneak around, sparing the lives of your enemies. (The more blood you  shed, the darker the game's outcomes will be in multiple ways.) Their are many ways to silently, and humanely dispose of your foes, with out shedding too much bodily fluid, but at the same time, you can slit their throats, and leave them choking on their own blood, or send crossbolts into their flesh, unknowingly. Maybe if you're feeling the urge to see your enemies scatter in fear, you can rewire, and turn their own defenses against them, witnessing the cool breeze taking their warm, dry ashes with it. Don't feel like a coward if you need to run away. It is a very huge part of the stealth gameplay. The best part, is that you can not only run, but jump, climb, slide your way into the shadows or roof tops, leaving your pursuers to fumble around in the gnarly, Brined Hagfish scented crop dust you left for them to choke on. Their are many ways to "neutralize your enemies, but I'll let you discover that with your prefered play style.                                  *Close Combat (When you don't care who hears and sees)- You can always go head on and Destroy your enemies, leaving them in their own puddles of blood and ash. Upgrade your sword, and pistol, to mold them into the killing machines they are meant to be. Nothing like striking down your foe, and thrusting cold, sharp steel in between his shoulder blades. Explosive bolts? Yeah, I'm sure you can imagine how many head will be rolling when you get your hands on those babies.                  *Engaging Story- I really enjoyed the story, even though it didn't take me long to complete it. There are many ways to play through it, with loads of choices, allowing you to play the story your way. The game has unique characters, and rewarding side mission's that will have you treking in the direction you so chose to go.                  *Runes, and Bone Charms- These are basically items that power up your character, and abilities. They give you the ability to make the Corvo that you want.                  *Bethesda- (Nuff said)            CONS (or things I would've liked better)                  *Non-Lethal Melee Attacks- The game definitely has it's ways of dealing with enemies once they spot you. (IE.. Sleep darts, Running away, Killing.. ect.) However, I would've liked to be able to bash an enemy with my sword, rendering him unconsious, rather then gutting him like an animal. I just wish that there were some alterative ways to silencing an agro enemy, without killing them, or wasting precious sleep darts. (and they are precious!) There are just those times, when running away may not be an option, and if you don't want to compromise your belief that all life is precious, then that means re-loading a last save. The only alternative, is to be more sneaky, and plan out your takedowns. I'd say it's a way of making the game more challenging, but I think combat was that already, especially when surrounded by multiple enemies, shooting, and stabbing you.Like I said, not many cons. That's the only one that I had, and it wasn't really a con. More of a reference, really. Anyways, pick up the game and try it out, before #2 comes out! It's going to be awesome, and I hope it lives up to all the hype! Well, Happy slashing!                                                                                                                                 Sincerely, Deathtoll. (:

content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
												I played through this game only once and I felt like I missed a good amount of the content.  I was a little disappointed that I was only told that the number of people I killed influenced the state of the story and city after a couple of levels where I had already killed a number of people.  After that I Primarily used nonlethal takedowns.  Even for characters who were targets of a mission, I chose the stealthy and sneaky way to kill as few people as possible,  but everybody still reveared me as a mass murderer, so for the last few levels I just said screw it and killed everybody.  Stealthing is pretty fun, but the combat mechanics feel kind of clunky.  Perhaps they meant for it to be this way to encourage you to be sneaky.  Although, the problem I found with going full sneaky-beaky is that there would be a lot of weapons and powers that you would never be able to use since they are loud and explody and cause your enemies to be eaten by a swarm of rats as they scream in agony.  So either way It feels like you can't get the whole experience of the game in just one playthrough.  That was my main issue.  Other than that, it was entertaining.

												A well-made game where the player's choices greatly impact the outcome of not just the ending but later in the game as well, Dishonored puts you in the position of Corvo Attano, in an alternate world 1837 filled with magic, corruption, advanced technology, and a revenge-seeking dishonored assassin. I have played Dishonored's main storyline so many times I lost count long ago (but enough times to say almost all of the dialogue along with the characters), then purchased and used every single DLC for it and played them through several times as well, and now I can say that this is actually one of my favorite games. Compared to the Fallout and Elder Scrolls series, Dishonored is one of Bethesda's lesser known games, denying it of much of the fame and love it deserves.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												It feels like a Mixtape between Bioshock Infinite and Thief.  It's about revenge; armed with deadly weapons and supernatural powers, you seek vengeance upon all of those who orchestrated your downfall. It's about a city; the plague-ridden industrial port of Dunwall is lovely to behold, exciting to explore, and seething with secrets. It´s about rescueing a little girl the daughter of the murdered Queen.  The Story is very exciting and its told in a good way..not too much and not too less. So you are never bored and have to skip videos and you also know always why you do what you do. The incredible variety of ways you can engage or evade your enemies is impressively flexible and utterly captivating. The Graphics are fine. Im using an old 2 Core Computer atm..it runs perfectly smooth on it, so it got very well programmed. I didnt see any Bugs. It has easy controls and also Full Controller Support, both work perfectly fine. I cant say anything negative about this game. If you love Games like Bioshock Infinite or Thief then defenetily buy it. Its in the sales for 3,24 € and its worth minimum 20 € compared to the quality of this game, so im very pleased with it.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												It feels like a Mixtape between Bioshock Infinite and Thief.  It's about revenge; armed with deadly weapons and supernatural powers, you seek vengeance upon all of those who orchestrated your downfall. It's about a city; the plague-ridden industrial port of Dunwall is lovely to behold, exciting to explore, and seething with secrets. It´s about rescueing a little girl the daughter of the murdered Queen.  The Story is very exciting and its told in a good way..not too much and not too less. So you are never bored and have to skip videos and you also know always why you do what you do. The incredible variety of ways you can engage or evade your enemies is impressively flexible and utterly captivating. The Graphics are fine. Im using an old 2 Core Computer atm..it runs perfectly smooth on it, so it got very well programmed. I didnt see any Bugs. It has easy controls and also Full Controller Support, both work perfectly fine. I cant say anything negative about this game. If you love Games like Bioshock Infinite or Thief then defenetily buy it. Its in the sales for 3,24 € and its worth minimum 20 € compared to the quality of this game, so im very pleased with it.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
IntroductionWant a game that makes you feel immersed by its colorful and peaceful atmosphere? A game where you could explore the world to its unimaginable limits? Last but not least, a game that is immensely moddable? Well, this game is not for you! Dishonored is an underdog game developed by Arkane Studios that brings you to a new universe filled with government corruption, discrimination towards the lower-middle class, and rat plague.You'll be able to play as the disgraced lord protector, Corvo Attano, who seeks revenge towards those who... 'dishonored' him... -along with the Outsider's powers that apparently requires you a lot of mana potions for you to do some rad killstreaks. That unless you want a stealthy approach, then prepare to load your game every single moment the enemy spots you for ridiculous reasons.If you have the DLCs, The Knife of Dunwall and The Brigmore Witches, you'd also be playing as the master assassin, Daud, who journeys through Dunwall discovering the mystery of a powerful Witch who deems to rule the city (and soon the world). His goal is to stop her evil plan to justify the guilt trip that he had after what he did.ReviewThe game is close enough to being a masterpiece if not because of the difficulty it lacks (there's a mod for that apparently), the strange bugs that haven't been fixed after 2-3 years, and the nerve wracking plot. However, it was still able to live up as one of the greatest games that came out as a first title to a new franchise. It gave us a fresh feeling to a new game by giving us a powerful yet stealthy assassin that has a mix of first-person combat and cheap parkour. It has some sort of semi-rpg aspects put into it since there are sub-quests scattered all around the area during your mission and there are choices you make that slightly affects the environment of the next mission and the game's ending.THE PROSAs you dwell into the plot, you'd think that the whole story would be cliched. You are right. However, it won't be a linear one. The game gives you a choice or rather an opportunity that would affect the last chapter of the game. In fact, the main story is more dynamic than an Elder Scrolls game but less dynamic than a Fallout game. The books that you probably wouldn't read includes the game's lore of the city and outside of it and some journals that once you look at the corpse who wrote it, you'd feel bad for him/her. Seriously, those rotting couples who died while hugging each other and being surrounded by plague rats, and an enemy guard that has an infected friend who wanted to euthanize him; these started to hit me right in the feels after reading their last words written on a letter... It shows how cruel the plague has lead to the people of Dunwall.In terms of gameplay, the developers were somehow able to make the game pass through that awful area that we call: repetitiveness. As mentioned a while ago, the game gives us varied ways to go through the objective. On each mission, there are sewers, open hallways, alleys, or hidden passage ways for you to decide whether you go rampage mode or go Thief style sneaking through every living obstacle. Even though the upgrades were only few, upgrading one skill already delivers an impact to the gameplay.Other than that, the graphics are the ones that surprised me out of all the stuffs I've experienced in this game. The developers have learned that even mere textures and right lighting could make a visually compelling atmosphere without having high-poly models and applying the frame killing Ambient Occlusions. An eye trick as what it seems. What more if you add a graphic enhancer mod to it.The audio gave a decent feel into the game's surroundings. The soundtracks were so emotional that it immersed me throughout my playthrough. They made a way to make the ambience feel lively even if the area wasn't crowded. Overall, it's decent.THE CONSHere's the part where it gets slightly bad. On the plot of the main story, the part where your 'allies' tell the things you do for the mission doesn't make sense for me since they themselves never tend to help you at all! Captain: "Corvo, kill this man in order to cripple the main boss! Now if you'll excuse me, the other loyalists and I will just stay here in the pub and intensify our tea-sipping as you kill 50 men on your way." The DLC story although fixed that by giving you the power to summon your allies and fight with you, but the main story of the game apparently never had such.Going back to gameplay, there are cases in the game where it starts to glitch out such as when you have to bring an unconscious body to someone for a non-lethal approach of the mission. Once you go near to the person who told you the objective while bringing the body, it will go to a scene where the conversation starts and your character will drop the unconscious body which somehow lead to his/her death. Thus, your non-lethal objective failed. There are also some cases where you just wanted to hide the body, but as you gently drop them near a movable object, it's possible that when they hit the object, they'll die. It's one of those annoying things if you wanted to achieve something in the game.Even though the UI settings was well implemented (though, you can't turn off the item selection UI whenever you bind them to your hotkeys), it's hard to say the same thing with the graphics options. Obviously, it lacks options. - AA only has 3 options: Off, MLAA, and FXAA- There are no Shadow options at all- The Rat Shadows doesn't even work even if you toggle it On!- Level of Detail options don't existYou may ask why are all of these mentioned when they're practically unnecessary; it's because there's actually an option for that if you look into a/an .ini file! You can even change the density of the particles, turn up the textures that is beyond the in-game texture settings, and increase the intensity of Anti-Aliasing and Anisotropic Filtering! Other than that, there are those very VERY low-res textures even if the textures were set on high. Even a 2000s game could beat this (that would be those Source engine games).Lastly on the audio, the guard dialogues were repetitive that it ended up being funny whenever you hear them; the rest of the characters however were good as it's not overly exaggerated nor dead boring.Verdict  Concept Rating   Main Plot 7/10 (+DLCs 9/10)+ Dynamic story depending on your actions+ (DLC) Plot Twists- Main story is predictable and linear- A couple of questionable plot holes- cliche cliche cliche   Gameplay 8/10 (+DLCs 7.8/10)+ Gametime of 1 to 30 hours depending on your style of gameplay+ Lots of choices with a different experience on each+ Each power upgrade matters- A few bugs/glitches- (DLC) Daud's Powers are OP!   Graphics 8/10 + Visually stunning environments+ Surprisingly smooth FPS while maintaining the current gen graphics- Lacks graphic options- Some really low-res textures on certain areas    Audio 8/10+ Decent yet immersive soundtracks+ Ambience? Good.+ Upright voice acting- "Think you'll get your own squad after what happened last night?" (10x)  OVERALL: 8/10 - Great game for a new franchiseOVERALL (+DLCs): 8.9/10 - DLCs are the ones that spiced it up

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2012
												From the creators of Deus Ex and Thief, with the talents of the art director from Half-Life 2 comes Dishonored, and man, does it ever show. The streets of Dunwall are like how City 17 might have been if it was in a world where magic and steampunk technology existed, and the threat wasn't from aliens but corrupt officials who stole power after a beloved leader died.As Corvo Attano, you get to choose just how you'll seek your revenge; with bloody brutality, subtle killings, or neither. Much like Batman (and in Fallout), you can go through the entire game not killing anyone, and also like Batman, you can still manage to unnerve your opponents by doing so. There's no leveling system, but you do gain a limited amount of runes and money, which lets you customize your character to fit your playstyle. The world is enormous and there's lots of scripted events and passageways which exclude the other, so you will not be able to see everything in one playthrough.One of those rare recent games worth buying right now, at full price. If it ever goes on sale and you still don't have it, then you certainly MUST jump on the opportunity and do so. Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												This is one of the greatest masterpieces of recent computer games. A cautivating story, a well designed playability and the sandboxed environments with multiple paths reminds me a victorian-style Deus Ex: Human Revolution.It may be difficult to become an expert efficient assassin in the first gameplay so that plus the capability to replay it in numerous different ways is the perfect incentive to travel through Dunwall two, three or even more times exploring, practicing and enjoying all the secrets and learning about the background and the history of the nation and its people.Long story short, this is one of my most precious games in my library so I have nothing to say about it but good things.

Posted: April 6, 2015
												There's something more about this game , it's not just "find your target and kill whoever stand in your way" stealth game. (I'm looking at you assassin's creed)Your actions define the ending , kill or spare ? chaos or not ? lethal or non-lethal ? EVERYTHING affects the ending even the world reacts to your actions ; weepers , rat plague , guard chatters . pretty nice detail (good job arkane studios)Even there's so many ways to your target .It's true that assassinating people with witchcraft is fun , but are you ready to face the consuqences ? spreading chaos wherever you walk while the Outsider watches you ?There's something i learned from this game , revenge NEVER solves everything (180 degrees different from the game's trailer XD)11/10 Would non-lethal takedown again.

content:
Posted: January 29
												Cant count how many times I've played this on my PS3 , this is the best game of all time and was a refreshing trip from the endless killing presented in other games at the time of it's release. Actions actually have consequences and even a minor choice here and there can affect how the game ends for you. There are three major endings but each of these can vary slightly based on small things. Pros:1. Amazing gameplay and stealth mechanics , but the guards might seem ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ at times (like everyone who doesn't know Clark Kent is Superman like how TF do you not recognize him ?!! He just slicked his hair with gel and took off his glasses ) I love the combat as well. 2. Choices have consequences , more killing plus bad choices lead to a bad ending and vice versa. But it's well  balanced how many bad choices you can make before you cross the threshold into a dark and twisted world. You should play it for yourself to experience this but it's a highly detailed system. If you play as a maniac who goes kicking down the front door and taking lots of hits , a character in the game will eventually let you know about a health elixir shortage and you will experience a shortage of said elixir.3. Amazing Storyline that can go  many ways the possibilities are endless , and there are small side stories hidden throughout the world . I couldn't find them all in one playthrough but they are each interesting enough to be worth your time.  I also love the Knife of Dunwall DLC , where you can see everything from Daud's point of view. The DLC also implements the same choices and consequnces technique from the main game.4. You feel like you personally know some of the NPCs , and their character has aa lot of depth ( I'm looking at you Cecelia !) Cons: 1. If you own the definitive edition , the Void Walker's Arsenal gives you bit of a boost at the beginning of the game which i didn't like . It sort of ruins some of the gameplay involving loot and scavenging. 2. Dunwall City Trials is nothing impressive so pass on this one unless you purely like the gameplay without any story.Overall it's a great game but I only bought it on PC so I could see how it looks with all the graphics settings turned up. Recommend it to anyone who likes a good story in a stealth games and enjoys a refreshing break from the endless killing presented in games like GTA V , Far Cry , etc..

content:
Posted: December 13, 2016
												So i have been dying to play a good bethesda game and do hope this game is another bethesda game i enjoy.....first being wolfenstien the new order. With that said i will be reviewing the game in a pro/ con style and ending with my final conclusion.Pro:      Wide open levels so you can tackle each assassination mission in a new and unique way. That is so cool it does remind me of other stealth games like the new hitman or metal gear solid 5. With that said the game doesnt limit you on play style so if you want to go around killing all that moves, you can. Want to be that guy who walks among the shadows to complete the mission, well you can do that too.      A variety of weapons. The weapons that corvo uses ranges from handgun, bow gun, sword, bombs, and magic. You can use any of that in a combo to pull off some really sick kills. Doing so feels so rewarding.     Multiple endings. The game gives you an ending based off of how much chaos the player gains, chaos is gained from high kill counts so you get one ending for being pretty much a pacifist and another for being a psychopath. That increases replayability.     Likeable characters. Everytime i hear samual talk it always brings a smile to my face because i really like his character and it doesnt end there, i like all characters to a degree but samual has to be my favorite.    Unlikable villains. Yea that sounds odd but it is a good thing because they were created so the player hates them, they need to be assassinated, ect. because they were pawns to a man you once worked with and got framed for murdering the queen you sworn to protect.Con:      The game starts out super strong with its amazing level design but ends with a limp wristed meh level design that focuses on for the most part linear style rather than its normal verticality wide open design. Sure i have 2 options of which ways to go but what is the point they are pretty similar that choosing one is no better or interesting that the other.     Wonky blink controls. I think it is a really cool and useful tool in the game but it does have some issues that really need to be fixed (which i know will never be fixed). When inside a tight room like in a building the ability to speed to cover in a stealth game is a must have. What if your cover is ceiling light? Oh boy, those things are a nightmare. Under pressure to flee and hide from incomming guards is so difficult when trying get on one. You can not be too close or you wont be able to blink up there but if your too far you also can not get up there so you need to find the right angle and distance which keep in mind you are in a rush to hide and this is the only hiding space in the location.     Glitched achievements. Some achievements are still glitched to which i say if i went through the entire game without killing a single enemy and i know for a fact i didnt kill a single enemy but didnt get my achievement. I am an achievement hunter and this annoys me to see this happening. I put in the work but just didnt get what i deserve.     Trial challenges. Nothing annoys me more than having to do these stupid challenges. Can you say buggy mess? I sure can. One challenge requires you to kill a specific target from hints gain from the map but sometimes when you kill the correct one the game throws you in a mission failed screen. Awsome. How about the stealth mission where on expert you can not use magic power....a main commonent of the game but guards have wonky pathing. Sometimes they walk through a door just to re-enter the same door 2 seconds later or completely change their AI route to be in reverse. What is this? Payday 2? Nah because payday 2 has better stealth where you can 1 have a partner spot you when your doing some objective and 2 not limit the main game play.Conclusion:            I really did like the game but i stand by that the trials dlc sucks. I hate being rushed to stealthly assassinate someone in a style similar to guess who. I dont like having the core gameplay ripped away from me. Sure it is suppose to be expert but why take so much to sneak in and steal stuff. Would it be easy? Yes but i can counter balance the wonky AI pathing and maintian flow. Stealthing was really fun in the main game due to having so many ways to funnel into my objective. You could go through the sewers to reach the location i need to be, go roof top jumping or running on the street to make my way to my location. Another reason why i hated moments i was inside small buildings like the doctor's house in the first mission or the entire last level. I highly reccommend the game but i still preffer the new order as my favorite bethesda game. So to new comers into this series, do pick up dishonored its a super fun game at its core but when you play the trials dlc.... prepare to see how just that dlc ruin's the games flow making things either unfun or obnoxiously difficult for no apparent reason just to slap on the title of expert. I dont mind a challenge but taking away the core of the game to make me expert...yea no, your just making me miss what the game is all about. Running around an open world doing an assassination how i want to and stealing some cash. These trials do not protray the game's core features in any good light so do skip that dlc. As for the other 2 dlc's i dont know how well they are im still stuck on the first dlc working on these challenges for those achievements.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2015
												I just LOVE this game. It's like a stealth Bioshock Infinite, could match, or even be better than Deus Ex - Human Revolution. Great story, great lore (and I usually just skip through all the books), interesting powers and decisions that actually make difference in darkness of the world you're in.That said, I also must mention some cons. First of all, game is too easy, even on highest difficulty. It felt like there was same number of guards on normal and on very hard, just the amount of damage and their ability to spot you differ. Secondly, during the game you're giving decent amount of weapons and upgrades for them. But the game encourages you to try not to just go running and killing, which prevents you from using those weapons. Furthermore, sleeping darts and mana potions are far less found throughout the world, especially in last 2 missions, so if you didn't buy them before endgame and you run out...tough luck. On contrary, regular bullets, darts and other "high chaos" ammo can be found on any guard that you knock down, randomly on shelves and lockers, which becomes annoying at one point if you're trying to stealth the entire game.Also, if you're trying to go through the complete game without killing anyone, being detected or raising any alarms, be warned. Game has some unusual ways of crediting you with random deaths that happen around you that you did not cause or had anything to do with. But, nevertheless, this was the most challenging thing trying to do, I had so much fun doing it, and there is some strange satisfactory feeling waiting for your results after each chapter and finding out you did it perfectly.Game per se is short enough (around 10-15h) so it gives you opportunity to play it again, with other decisions so you can see how exactly dark/light can the world stay. Just...save a lot, have patience and have fun, this game definitely deserves high praises.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												Completed a play through on my PS3 maybe 12 months before writing this review. Solid game. Imagine first person Assassins Creed with Skyrim-ish Magic and that's what Dishonored is. I would recommend anyone who likes Stealth games give this a shot, as the AI can be difficult at times to avoid or lure away. The DLC for the game is quite expansive, and even adds new features such as buying equipment pre-mission (but only in the DLC missions, sadly). The story is quite decent and the characters you meet are quite well designed and thought out and have some depth. It's a story of backstabbing and betrayal with a few plot twists that I didn't see coming. I consider this game one of my must plays.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2013
												Dishonored is one of those games that doesn't have to innovate its gameplay or tell a particularly great story, rather it is a game that brings every element of its genre together in a perfect balance of addicting gameplay and enjoyable plot. It's hard to compare it to other games, the closest thing I've played is probably Thief: Deadly Shadows, another game that strikes a decent balance without really innovating its gameplay. For the right price, just about anyone can enjoy Dishonored, but if you are like me and bought the game on launch you probably felt a bit underwhelmed. It didn't really deliver on my expectations at the time, but over the years I have grown to appreciate it more. I don't particularly like the art direction or aesthetic of the game, but if you like contemporary steampunk you might enjoy it. No matter where your tastes lie, I doubt you will regret your purchase.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												Put simply, this is one of the very best games I have ever played. It bests Ocarina of Time, BioShock Infinte, Deus Ex: Human Revolution, etc. This is insanely replayable (on my third run as I write this). This is a game where you have many choices. Lethal or nonlethal, stealthy or guns blazing, different points of entry to buildings, etc. It fits anyone's ideal playstyle, whether that's combat or stealth. Arkane thought of everything with the level layouts. The atmosphere, level design, and setting are excellent. Dunwall may be my favorite video game setting ever. From what I've heard the DLC is even better than the main game. This game also presents a nice challenge, but even on Very Hard (my current run), the game is relatively easy once you get used to it. Dishonored, in my opinion, is one of the best video games ever made, and is in my personal top 5. I would give this game a 10. If I was stuck on a deserted island and I could only have three games with me, this would be my first choice. It's that damn good. I bought it for $4.99 and I feel like I've cheated Arkane here. I would have happily spent 60 at release for this game, and I will whenever a sequel releases. Just scroll up and go buy this game, even at full price. You WILL not regret it. tl;dr I love this game and probably sound like a paid shill but whatever 10/10

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												I honestly didn't expect to love this game so much. But it has quickly become my favorite.The design of the city is amazing. The story is great. There are many different approaches to completing the tasks, which makes the game entertaining even if you play it over and over. You can kjill everyone in your way, or choose to kill noone. You can create chaos, or stay completely in the shadows. However the more poeple you kill, and the more chaos you make, the more rats and weepers you encounter. One more thing: the DLCs are absolutely fantastic. I especially loved Knife of Dunwall and Brigmore Witches DLCs, which together tell Dauds story from the point in time, when he assassinated the Empress. You pretty much get a second game.
