number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 17, 2016
												Yes this review is long, but I really enjoyed lol, there's a TL;DR at the end!Ooooh where to start? Well let's get the basics down first, Dishonored was definitely a well structured game. It's definitely unique from different stealth games I've played. I know it's been out for a while, but I just snagged it off of humble bundle for a nice price along with the dlc. It's honestly a shame I've waited this long to get my hands on this game. So to start off, Dishonored breaks the paradigm of stealth games to be honest. By that I don't mean it does some whacky off worldly♥♥♥♥♥♥where it changes and contorts "stealth" gameplay. The part that I really enjoyed about dishonored was actually the super natural aspect. The different abilities are new to me for stealth games, although in terms of stealth games I've only played the far cry series, splinter cell series, and theif. Regardless it was a nice refrehser since I am really starting to get into stealth games as of late. What was cool about that aspect was how the powers could be used differently and upgraded to fit your style of play. Depending on if you like to take it quiet, or for some reaason like to go loud and guns blazing in a stealh game (No judgement :D, you do your thing man) it really does cater to a variety of playstyles. This also goes a long way with weapon and gear upgrades as well. Another aspect I really enjoyed (Or enjoy in all games for that matter) was the decision making. Depending on how you play the game, it would actually alter how the game ends with the final cutscene. (If you're anything like me you won't actually replay the game just to see them -.-, instead you'll just look it up on youtube like me ^^) The next on the list would be the storyline. The plot was not the best, but I've definitely played games that have plots with less effort put into them. It was very simple and easy to follow, but there was a certain foreshadow that really gave it away (for me anyways). It was easy to see the "twist" coming, that is also due to the short gameplay. The story advances rather rapidly sort of giving away a decent amount. To add on to that, yes the gameplay was rather short actually! I was hoping for some more without the use of DLC. (This review is being written before playing the DLC, just so I can review the base product.) The game took me roughly 12 hours to complete and that wasn't on a run of just barging through the game and trying to finish. I took my time to try and soak in as much of the story as possible. While there some options to get more gameplay during missions (Won't go into specificis due to spoliers) the game didn't seem very content heavy. But despite there being some cons with the pros, I'd still give Dishonored an overall positive rating! It's worth it for the price it is, and while in my opinion it does not possess the best plot or content quantity, it makes up for it in its quality as well as uniqueness. If you want to have a fun time with a nice stealth expereince Dishonored is definitely a must have.TL;DR: You lazy ♥♥♥♥ers ~.~.Pro's: Unique gameplay. Caters to stealth lovers(IMO). Great quality. Versatile playstyle.Con's: Not too much gameplay content. Not a great game for those who like a good plot. Overall rating:9/10. This is because I never really care about the amount of content, so as long as the gameplay is dynamic. I also could care less for the plot, I read Dean Koontz if I want a plot.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												It is kind of late for a review for this game, but after my second playthrough I think I should tell you guys how great this game is.You play in first person in a medieval world with magic and science. You will start a level with at least one goal, sometimes the goals change or you get more goals or you can decide which of the ways to reach the goals you want to use. Mostly it is the decicion: Lethal or not lethal.Inside the level you are free to go where you want. You can play the whole game like DARK, you try to not to be seen, your only target is the mission goal. Even if you do so, you can still decide if you kill at all. You WILL be responsible for dead/capture, but you can make it kind of... third parties fault.The complete different approach is the killing spree.If you use knife, crossbow, pistol, grenades, mines and magic to the fullest extend you can do incredible cool things.You can freeze time and put a grenade in the hand of someone, take a bullet from the air, teleport behind an enemy to strangle him, send rats to eat your enemies alive or blast them against walls.You can take over a fish or another animal and use different routes, take over a human and walk him out of the sight of others, reprogram towers to kill your enemies and so much more.So you can either play the I-do-not-kill-guy with a good ending or the kill-all-enemies-guys with a bad or at least dark ending.Either way, the game is fantastic.I really love the graphics, I love the music and the gameplay is very smooth and fun.The only thing which is not so good: the character faces are... don't know.. kind of ugly. All of them.This game is a must play. At least once! I did 2012 the killer-guy playthrough, 2014 the ghost - not in all levels :( - playthrough and now I will have some fun with mindless killing again :)

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												Just finished my first completion of Dishonored.  I was trying for as bloodless as possible and I had many flashbacks remembering the Thief series while playing.  It's not the same game or story but being able to sneak around through a game again is so much fun.  No moss or water arrows but that's good because they got to be a bit silly with that.As it stands, you have a massive number of options for completing your objectives in Dishonored.  You like rooftops?  You can be Spidey.  The sewers and maintenance areas feel more comfortable?  Crawl away!  The myriad paths and the optional side missions make some of the missions exceedingly long when you don't know the maps but they are still all enjoyable.  I can see real opportunities for speed runs when you know exactly where to go but you'd miss so much of the content.  The story is well done and detailed with believable characters though the end is a bit overdone.  Even many of the NPCs are almost fully fleshed out with backstories - families, friends etc.  You will eventually hear guard conversations repeat simply because you encounter so many of them but it often pays to hang out for a minute and listen to the guards because they are chatting about optional paths or things you are interested in...if you hover around.All in all, I enjoyed the hell out of Dishonored and strongly recommend to anyone who remembers Thief or the old Metal Gear Solid when it was stealth focused.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Dishonored is one of my all time favorite singleplayer experiences to date up there with BioShock and Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory. It gets high marks for replayability as there are countless ways to move towards an objective and means with which to dispatch enemies. You can complete the game killing everyone or no one - the choice is yours. Dishonored doesn't feel like it has something to prove with it's story or gameplay. (I'm looking at you BioShock: Infinite!) You are given choices and they have consequences. The stealth/combat gameplay is nothing too revolutionary but it's executed flawlessly and for me, that makes it all the more fun. (and you simply MUST get the 2 story dlc packs "knife" and "witches" as it tells a whole nother story that's just as good (even better perhaps) than thtat of the main game. I sincerely hope there's another game coming down the road set in the "Dishonored" universe.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												WOW what a game. I brought this game on sale and feel like I ripped off the developer. I have not played a great single player game in a while that I have not wanted to stop playing after a few hours. Such a great story line will keep you wanting more and it will immerse you into the world with a sympathetic connection to the characters. If this game had really high end graphics I don't think it would be as enjoyable as the simple yet beautiful art style that this has. Once you max out your Blink and Agility runes with the addition of Swift Shadow and Fleet Fighter bone charms moving around the roof tops at speed and blinking between ledges is such a great feeling. I highly recommend this game to anybody, easily worth the money. Developers really need to make more games like this 10/10.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 14, 2012
												You begin the game as Corvo, Lord Protector of the Empress of Dunwall, but soon find yourself stripped of that title and imprisoned for her alleged murder. You must escape, clear your name and ultimately restore her daughter, Emily, to the throne.You'll take on a string of missions through a city riddled with plague and corruption, taking out those in power by assassination or indirect means. Each mission involves several openly designed zones, where you may freely explore to find upgrades, ammo, coin and optional objectives along the way.Both stealth and brute-force playstyles are viable, with a wide array of weaponry and powers at your disposal.  Blink instantly from point to point; possess rats and fish to tunnel your way in, or guards to walk them to a secluded area for disposal; stop time to sneak past a group of enemies or slaughter them all undetected; or just go in guns blazing.  A lot of fun, looks amazing, well-optimized, and has great level design.  Highly recommended; my single-player GOTY.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												Dishonored is a rarity in today's AAA video game industry. It does not treat the player as if he/she is stupid and it gives you the freedom to make the experience your own. Launching Dishonored for the first time and going through the options menu already tells the player what they can expect out of the game; the ability to shape it into what you want it to be.Are you tired of the constant nagging to get to your objective in games? *Click* Gone. Are you sick of obnoxious objective markers ruining any sense of exploration and the joy that comes with figuring things out on your own? *Click* Gone. Sick of glowing objects telling you "THIS IS IMPORTANT AND USEFUL!" *Click* Gone.The game itself is very good and encourages multiple playstyles. You can fight your way through the open levels or play it sneaky. You can kill everyone you see or go through the entire game without killing a single person. The game gives you a variety of tools to accomplish your goals. You can teleport short distances, possess other NPC's or small animals, summon a group of man eating rats, slow or stop time, etc. In terms of weapons you have a crossbow with various ammo types such as sleeping and incendianary darts, grenades, traps, a pistol, and more. The levels are expertly crafted and offer multiple paths and enough mass to make use of your weapons and powers. Your choices do have consequences so you need to be aware of that. My original intention was to play through the entire game without killing a soul but that changed later on in the game.  I went after a character that had nothing to do with the mission itself. I wanted that character dead because I overheard what they do for a living and it made me angry so I went out of my way to hunt them down. That piece of gameplay was one of the standout moments for me because of how unexpected it was and the attachment it made me feel towards the game world.There are 4 difficulty modes; Easy, Normal, Hard, and Very Hard. If you want a challenge I recommend playing on one of the latter two difficulties. The AI can be very stupid under Normal  and it took away from the immersion and challenge. You are allowed to change the difficulty mid game so if you feel it's too easy or too hard you don't have to start over.I enjoyed my time with Dishonored and will be giving it another playthrough switching up my tactics and making different moral choices. I was engaged from start to finish and not once did I feel the need to just rush through it and get it over with. Its length was perfect and the entire game feels consistent and very well made.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												MAY CONTAIN MILD SPOILERS If I had a list of the best stealth games I have ever played, Dishonored will be high on the list. Dishonored executes the stealth aspect just like I expected and even exceeded it. Why? You have ♥♥♥♥ing powers. Want to possess a person? Do it. Want to summon a horde of flesh eating rats? Do it. Dishonored gives you a lot of choices too. Go stealth or go kill everyone in sight. Kill the target or spare his/her life? All your choices will affect the story and thus the ending too.There is great satisfication when killing your target. Drop killing especially, feels awesome. But why not kill everyone in sight? You can do so without anyone even touching you (but that doesnt mean the game is easy, it isn't). Sound badass right? Yes it is. There are dissapointments though. The obvious one, as you may have known already (reading the reviews), the main story is too damn short and predictable. I finished mine in about 9 or so hours, in hard difficulty. The storyline too, for me, is too weak. I don't care about the soon-to-be empress that you are saving. She may die? I don't really care. All I want to do is to kill people. The DLCs, though, has a way way better story. Also, you get more badass powers as Daud. Who cares about summoning rats when you can summon a master assassin anytime you like? Also stopping time every few seconds is so damn awesome. Seriously, buy all the dlcs, that is how awesome it is.If you, for some reason, decide not to buy the dlcs (buy them!), the base game itself is a memorable experience. A masterpiece. So what are you waiting for? Buy Dishonored. You will be in for a real treat.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												I recommend Dishonored with caution. From the outside it looks like a complex stealth game and for the most part it plays well approaching it in this manner. However I think it'd be better described as a puzzler, as that's how it ends up feeling. Don't get me wrong, I have played through Dishonored twice and loved every moment of it, but I feel people looking for a game with lots of stealthy/action filled combat would be dissapointed.Each part of the story in Dishonered has various choices and decisions to make, both in what you do when you beat the section and in terms of how you get there. A couple of playthroughs are enough to explore them both. You may or may not like that the replayability of this game comes not from hours of storyline but redoing said story in various ways. Sadly you cannot replay areas with all your abilities unlocked, which is a shame as I think this would have added a lot of hours to the content.The gameplay boasts various ways to overcome situations, some of which call for a more out of the box approach. However, some of these options don't open up until nearer the end of the game so having the opportunity to do so is limited, especially when you can't replay sections with your endgame content. There are also a few challenging achievements and things to collect in the game, if you like that sort of thing.The world and lore of Dishonored is fantastic, slightly surreal and fairly unique from what we usually see in this genre of game. The characters are believable and a little quirky which is nice but also a shame as you don't get to know the majority of them well enough, I feel. Considering that a lot of decisions on how to play are based on your attachments to characters and reaction to story this is a bit of a shame, there's so much offered but you still feel left wanting a little more. Overall, if this game is on a good offer, snap it up, it's certainly worth a play through or two.

												+:* Clearly inspired by BioShock and Thief, both of which are very good games.* Exceptionally well realized art style.* Supernatural abilities are a whole lot of fun to use* Side missions are neat and rewards you for thinking ahead* Stealth is generally encouraged.* Level design allows for many different approaches to a target.* Very few buIIshit moments (a staple of many stealth games).-:* Corvo is OP. A few more missions before you get to free Emily would be in order.Verdict: Recommended

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												Dishonored is set in a dark Victorian Steam Punk world. You play as Corvo an assassin in service of the local empress. After her assassination a dark and gripping story begins. The world is a sort of decaying city where the economy thrives on whale oil and the strange technology is fuelled by the same oil.The game is a FPS-style stealth game but you can choose to play more action oriented. However, this is not an action shooter! So no machine guns, rocket launchers, …Your primary weapon is a sword and secondary a pistol and crossbow (for silent kills). Next to that you have grenades, mines and that’s it. Ammo is limited. You also dispose of several magic (super natural) abilities. By playing the game you will find objects (runes, coins…) to buy new abilities.When you play you can choose different ways to complete the levels. Go stealth mode and try to kill no one or as little as possible or choose to play more action style.I find the level design impressive, with a nice and original graphic style. The acting is also quite good. It took me 19 hours to complete the game.I can also confirm that the game runs perfectly on ultra-wide displays in 21/9 aspect ratio. I tested it on a 2560*1080 resolution.I highly recommend this game!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												Dishonored is a great stealth game that also allows a non-stealth approach to completing missions. The addition of supernatural powers enables different playstyles and the outstanding level design enables a lot of exploration and provides different paths to reaching objectives. The chaos mechanic is an interesting one: it makes the game respond to how you act. If you choose a more violent approach (killing lots of enemies) the chaos level in the city will be high and the environment will change accordingly (there will be more enemies and rats), as will the outcome of the story. A less lethal playstyle will have a more positive outcome. This contributes to the game's replay value. Some have criticized this aspect of the game, claiming that going for a non-lethal approach makes the game boring, because there are only two ways of dealing with enemies: knocking them out or using sleep darts. I turned the non-lethal approach into a challenge to completely avoid enemies as much as possible, without knocking them out or alerting them, and see how far I can progress in that manner, which made it an interesting challenge. However, it is true that there are far more ways to deal with enemies in a violent manner.The two story DLCs (Knife of Dunwall and Witches of Brigmore) are not continuations of the main story but provide an interesting addition. They have three missions each and introduce a couple of new abilities.Dunwall City Trials DLC is not story-based, instead it comes with 10 different challenges that test the player's skill in stealth, agility, ability to quickly perform assassinations etc. The achievements are pretty difficult to get.Overall I would strongly recommend the game: it has a great level design and a great story with multiple endings, and it allows the player to approach it as a stealth game or as a more action-oriented game.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												Linear, open-level design done right. It reminds me a lot of Deus Ex where you're given a choice of a stealth or a lethal approach, and you're also given so much freedom in how you tranverse through each level. The world is dark, engaging, and full of intrigue. The watercolor-like art style is unique, and gives a lot of character to the world. The supernatural powers are mechanics seen nowhere else, as you're able to scale buildings with ease and navigate through levels unconventionally (taking control of animals and going through sewer pipes). The developers managed to create a tightly-designed game that avoids needless pandering or padding while giving the player so much freedom to tackle objectives.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 13, 2012
												Lovely game. It was one of the more interesting stealth games when it game out.There are some interesting aspects to this game that makes it good. The fact that the same guy who designed City 17 in HL2 made Dunwall (the city in Dishonored). The fact that the whole city runs on whale oil opposed to electricity, therefore all the textures are very water colored and desaturated, this results in an amazing overall aesthetic. The fact that every single character in this game is hideous on purpose.The gameplay is good but not amazing. It does a great job in making you feel like you are cheating by using your blink ability and high agility. The levels are quite big and there is a fair amount of exploration (also the loading screens are incredibly fast, so transitioning from an area to another is blinking fast :D).I wasn't a big fan of the binary good\evil ending, however the journey impressed me. Every single area you find yourself in has it's own personality and is highly memorable.And on top of all that, it allows you to play non lethal, finishing the game without killing a single living thing (except rats, ♥♥♥♥ rats).It's a nice stylized experience and I recommend it!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
The Game: Dishonored is a very fun stealth-based first-person objective-based game; with the option to explore other areas on most maps. You play as Corvo, a man framed for the murder of the Empress. You escape prison with an unknown person’s help and meet them at their bar. After this you begin to do missions for these people; to help destabilize the current and corrupt government. There are two ways of doing any of the missions, either in High Chaos mode, in this mode you are not concerned about Stealth at all and engage in combat with anyone (who is marked as an enemy). Keep in mind if you get enough of the enemy onto you, you’ll either need to “Blink” (a magical ability Corvo has) away at a higher level (like on top of a ledge or building) and keep hidden; or you can die (quite quickly) trying to kill them all, since the men without blades will use flintlock pistols to shoot you and the men with blades want to remove your head.You can also do missions in Low Chaos mode, which may be a little “harder” and it does take a bit longer and require more patience, however in this mode you do not get detected (you must try not to anyways, otherwise it can go to High Chaos if you’re detected and decide to engage in combat). I honestly recommend playing the game while trying to achieve “Low Chaos” since this mode is the most fun (in my honest opinion). Other than those few things there is Corvo’s signature blade, which is equipped in your right hand – in Corvo’s left hand you can equip various things from magical abilities (like the previously mentioned “Blink” ability), various types of grenades, and finally, Corvo's crossbow (with various types of darts including ones that only put the enemy to sleep, helping your “Low Chaos” Score as that doesn’t count as a death (they’re only asleep)). Overall: All-in-all I believe Dishonored is a great game with an amazing story and characters. It surprised me that Arkane Studios (the developers behind Dishonored) were able to pull off such an amazing game, especially since before this game I’d never heard of Arkane Studios in my life. Either way, the game runs very well as it utilizes the Unreal Engine 3, so most PC’s that were made in the past five years (as of 2015) should be able to run this game with no real issues. To be safe, make sure your PC is a 2012-2015 model; this way you can play anything that is out, including the newer more graphical games (W3, GTAV, UE4 Games, etc.) I believe that anyone with either patience or the skill to kill several enemies before disappearing and reappearing to finish them off, then Dishonored is for you!Score: 4/5 – An amazing game with a very fun and interesting Story and Stealth Mode.

												Lovely game. It was one of the more interesting stealth games when it game out.There are some interesting aspects to this game that makes it good. The fact that the same guy who designed City 17 in HL2 made Dunwall (the city in Dishonored). The fact that the whole city runs on whale oil opposed to electricity, therefore all the textures are very water colored and desaturated, this results in an amazing overall aesthetic. The fact that every single character in this game is hideous on purpose.The gameplay is good but not amazing. It does a great job in making you feel like you are cheating by using your blink ability and high agility. The levels are quite big and there is a fair amount of exploration (also the loading screens are incredibly fast, so transitioning from an area to another is blinking fast :D).I wasn't a big fan of the binary good\evil ending, however the journey impressed me. Every single area you find yourself in has it's own personality and is highly memorable.And on top of all that, it allows you to play non lethal, finishing the game without killing a single living thing (except rats, ♥♥♥♥ rats).It's a nice stylized experience and I recommend it!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												Dishonored is a great stealth game that also allows a non-stealth approach to completing missions. The addition of supernatural powers enables different playstyles and the outstanding level design enables a lot of exploration and provides different paths to reaching objectives. The chaos mechanic is an interesting one: it makes the game respond to how you act. If you choose a more violent approach (killing lots of enemies) the chaos level in the city will be high and the environment will change accordingly (there will be more enemies and rats), as will the outcome of the story. A less lethal playstyle will have a more positive outcome. This contributes to the game's replay value. Some have criticized this aspect of the game, claiming that going for a non-lethal approach makes the game boring, because there are only two ways of dealing with enemies: knocking them out or using sleep darts. I turned the non-lethal approach into a challenge to completely avoid enemies as much as possible, without knocking them out or alerting them, and see how far I can progress in that manner, which made it an interesting challenge. However, it is true that there are far more ways to deal with enemies in a violent manner.The two story DLCs (Knife of Dunwall and Witches of Brigmore) are not continuations of the main story but provide an interesting addition. They have three missions each and introduce a couple of new abilities.Dunwall City Trials DLC is not story-based, instead it comes with 10 different challenges that test the player's skill in stealth, agility, ability to quickly perform assassinations etc. The achievements are pretty difficult to get.Overall I would strongly recommend the game: it has a great level design and a great story with multiple endings, and it allows the player to approach it as a stealth game or as a more action-oriented game.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2013
												Alright, Dishonored.Dishonored is a masterpiece. It is not only well-rounded, but also replayable, making it an extremely fun assasin-style game. However, its combat system is also up to par, so it doesn't even need to be an assasin game if you don't want it to be.Graphics:The graphics in Dishonored blew me away. They are not boring and ultra-realistic, but instead a styled, almost caricature-like moving painting. They still, however, manage to have the perfect balance of realistic...ness. If you're worried about this being immersion-breaking, don't be. Nothing in this game is immersion-breaking.Story and characters:While the story is somewhat linear, there are always options, no matter how small, that give you rewards or punishments in varying degrees. There are a few characters with interesting personalities, but there are also some relatively dull ones. Nothing horrible, just something once in a while that annoys you slightly. Gameplay:The gameplay is exceptional. With good AI, fluid motions and movement, and a seamlessly integrated combat menu system, I don't even know what else to ask for. The supernatural abilities add another layer of good, chewy gameplay. There are an extremely large number of ways to complete each mission, and you can even go through the entire game without killing anyone.Well. That sounded professional.

Posted: November 17, 2014
												It is an amazing game which lets you choose several ways to solve a problem. It is great that you can do it in so many ways and that it also  affects the story , For example: I took away a bottle whilst someone was painting another person, when I later found the painting I noticed that the bottle was not in the painting anymore. Eventhough in my first playthrough I killed almost everybody in the city (because it is the most obvious way to dispose of an enemy) I had more fun playing it through for the second time and trying not to get detected. Another great feature is that you can get information on how to complete a challenge and a sidequest by just listening to plain conversations between citizens and guards. Last but not least I adored how there are 3 different endings, for some reason I really felt that I played the game better when I actually had the best outcome.Conclusion: It is an amazing game and I would definetly recommend buying it if you like using amazing powers to sneak past or assassinate people. You can choose very distinct playstyles and therefore it feels like you are more involved in the story.9/10

content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
												Dishonored is a title that left me with mixed feelings. While I appreciated the game's aesthetics, setting and gameplay, there are other aspects that didn't quite live to my expectations. I'll sum up briefly what I think are the most positive features as well as the negative ones. Let's start with the pros:+ Environment exploration is rewarding and satisfying. Not only there's lots of loot hidden around and some side quests, exploring is also a key element of the gameplay since there are many alternative routes available to reach the missions' goals. By looking around and being curious you'll be able to choose the way you see fit to proceed in your task from a good array of options.+ There's good freedom of action. The game gives its best if you choose a stealthy approach but if you feel like going for a fight without relaying too much on an elaborate strategy you're free to do so. Of course you'll have to face the logical consequences if you do, and you'll need all your arsenal of upgrades and powers to face an army of guards shooting and assaulting you with swords. There's always more than one way to eliminate your main targets too, so you can either be merciful with them and make them pay for their crimes by having them arrested or exiled or simply kill them, directly or indirectly.+ The powerups you unlock will reflect your playstyle. Since there are not enough runes in the whole game to unlock all the possible magic powers you'll have to choose them wisely basing on what kind of run you intend to do: if you're going with stealth and non-lethal approach you'll find the offensive abilities pretty useless, on the contrary if you are more prone to fights it will be better for you to skip some of the supporting skills.Now with the cons:- The chaos/morality system. The game evaluates the amount of chaos you leave in the world at the end of each mission, ranking it as "low" (few killings/no killings at all) or "high" (lots of blood spilled). This should theoretically afflict the game's ending but there are practically only two different endings available, which one you get is simply determined by what rank you get the most. Since you can still maintain a low chaos level by killing all your main targets and even some guard there's no real reason for trying not to kill anyone in the whole game, making the relative achievement end in itself. It's a sterile challenge that has no effect in the game story and universe.- The plot. It's very basic to say the least, I won't spoil anything but there's not much to expect. You can tell since the very beginning what's going to happen. It's still enough to give the player a reason to go out and fight, but the ending is abrupt and worst of all it gives absolutely no explanation about why the Outsider chose you, what is his real purpose and who is he really.- As a minor point, sometimes the stealth mechanics are buggy. It's a common issue with this genre of games to see guards acting dumb, not seeing you when you're right next to them or inexplicably launching an alarm where they're absolutely not supposed to see where you are. This title makes no exception, but fortunately those are pretty rare events that don't really ruin the experience.- Lastly, not really an issue but still bothering for me: lots of stupid achievements. This is a game that privileges a stealthy, no-killing approach and it's filled with combat-based achievements. Kill x enemies with this, kill y with that. It's stupid even in FPS, here is exponentially more stupid.Considering all, I would recommend Dishonored to everybody who likes stealth and exploration-focused games, with the advice to not being charmed by all the hyper-enthusiastic reviews. This game is overall good but it still has very noticeable issues, if you don't expect a masterpiece and just want to play with good stealth mechanics then go ahead and grab it (preferably on the Definitive Edition that has all DLCs included). If it's a good, captivating story and memorable characters you're looking for then leave it alone.

Posted: December 30, 2014
												While I don't find as good as other people say, I still find it as a great game and I do have my reasonsFirst of all the good:+ I love the Steampunk setting+ All of the weapons are useful and are fun to use, my fav being the Crossbow+ Lots of powers+ Fantastic weather effects+ Chaos system is a good idea+ Some fun levels+ Runes and Bones are fun to find+ Dat mask+ REALLY FAST LOAD TIMES AND I MEAN FAST!Downsides:- Stealth has been glitchty for me, before you say your doing it wrong, I compeleted MGS 1,2 3, 3DS, 4, twin snakes and Peacewalker all on Euro extreme/hardest setting stealth, no alerts and no kills, so I know stealth. But here, guards keep popping out of no where, and dark vision does f*ck all to see them, I know it has a range, BUT WHEN THE RANGE IS 2CM, THEN WE HAVE AN ISSUE, other then that, Stealth CAN work sometimes, most of the time guards just insta spot me while I'm hiding in the shadows, so I'm forced to go in guns blazing 75% of the time.Also smashing glasses does f*ck all, not joking, I smashed a glass in a guards face and he did nothing, didn't move, didn't attack until I walked infront of him....- The Story is unintresting, while in the beginning it plays the obvious parent is gonna die and the child is gonna be kidnapped card, thats the only intresting thing, rest of it is boring and I keep finding myself skipping them.- Some powers are no where as good as the others, like I mentioned Dark vision works whenever it feels like it, Blink is broken and is the only power you should use, freezing time while fun, is only good for escapes or quick kills, Devoring Storm is nearly useless, and the Wind Power is decent.- Some cutscenes can't be skipped, while others can..... why?- All company logos can't be skipped.... why?Other then that, this game is a lot fun.

												I absolutely loved it. This is a great stealth combat game. It has a detailed and well constructed world, a great story (or stories, as the expansions give you another great storyline running concurrent with the original), memorable characters, and interesting challenges and achievements. Also, if you aren't turned off by binary moral choice systems you can play through each story multiple times. Posted: November 30, 2013
												The steampunk action game I've always wanted.Dark, stylish, clever, exciting and diverse, Dishonored offers a unique and beautifully realized world packed with character and visual flair, while arming you with an exceptional variety of enjoyable gameplay mechanics with which to explore it and a freedom with which to use them very reminiscient of Deus Ex.On top of the excellent quality of the game itself, its unique art style has resulted in fairly low system overhead, and while the graphics options ingame are limited, I found there wasn't really any tweaking needed as the game ran like a charm out of the box.A must-have for steampunk fans and Deus Ex fans alike, and if you're a fan of both, I hope this is already in your library.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												This is a great game. It combines the multiple paths of classic games like Hitman, Deus Ex, and Thief with fantastic stealth and combat systems. You can be a total pacifist if you want, but if you do choose to kill, there are plenty of great ways to do it: stealthy assassinations, epic swordfights, carefully placed traps, crossbows and guns, or even just summon a huge swarm of rats to eat your enemies alive. Levels are huge. There's plenty of gold to find and safes to open. You are rewarded for exploring your environment instead of just focusing on the end goal. The game is quick to learn but hard to master. Easy enough that you won't have any trouble beating the game, but deep and difficult enough that there's always a new challenge offered. The plot isn't terribly great, but it's still pretty good. Enemy design is fantastic. Graphics won't have you gasping in awe, but they get the job done.The game's only flaw is that it doesn't really do anything new. There are plenty of games similar to Dishonored. But what it does do, it does really well. It may not be groundbreaking, but it's still a solid game with tons of replayability. Perfect for the gamer who likes to set challenges for themselves, as well as players who found the original Hitman/Thief/Deus Ex games inaccessible. Definitely buy it.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
Agent 47 meets Ezio Auditore and Booker de Witt in City 18Again, one of my reviews:in shortThis game blends quite succesfully a First Person Hitman experience with the verticality of Assassin's Creed's Ezio Auditore. There is an evolved version of Bioshock's Plasmids which don't just copy the BS ones. The art director is the same as in Half-Life 2 and sadly sometimes you feel really like in a City 17 clone a century before. Through a Low/High Chaos system, the game ensures that there is a stealth approach, as well as a "standard" FPS one and provides the enemy spawns needed. It caters to the Fantasy community, but after the first 2 chapters, it is even for someone like me playable. Recommend it, if you like stealth games, though w/o frustration due to supernatural powers and blood & gore approach possibility.Recommend yes, but a 87-90 meta score would have been more than enough: Entertaining and a nice blend but nothing too special; still one of the better games, I guess.in detailstoryHm, personally I am not a Fantasy person and not really into empresses, mana and haunted castles, so forgive me being biased towards this game, but as mentioned, I nearly skipped the whole game after meeting the empress and all of that Outsider's gibberish. I collected all audio tapes (or Voxophones) in Bioshock, which added greatly to the atmosphere and gave insides. Here, this abundance of audio diaries, notes and books either merely state the obvious or are simply boring ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t which is only loosely connected to the main story. Sometimes hints are buried under these tons of "paper". - The overall story is ok though and the characters themselves got personality, just the collectibles are hastily done.Voice-acting itself is brilliant, but the dialogues are flat but getting better towards the end. Background score is another plus.gameplaypositive:leaves many options and approacheseven in hardest achievement combo, w/o killing nor alerting anyone, nor using superpowers not frustrating (on normal)side quests are well integrated into the main story - this is a huge plus and only the Half-Life franchise manages that from what I played so farfew but distinguishable weapons and gadgets which I prefer over tons of the samenegative: very short in a blood & gore approachunlike Assassin's Creed not open world at all - cannot understand some comments which state otherwise. nothing really exciting level design-wise. Get from low ground to high ground and back down again unlike Notes, Books don't disappear after being picked up and are often double, which is a pain when leaving all cover just to find out, you already got that one. Obviously should help to collect them, but no good approach.graphicsReally, have to be mentioned because this might be the most controversial part of my review and again, before you downvote my review for not being helpful, please accept my personal view on this:I found the graphics unlike HL2 very kitchy and the coffin like structures everywhere were a too unsubtle reminder of the overall plague situation in Dunwall. Besides, the citadel structures next to the Boyle estate made me looking for Alyx & Dog; sorry this was too much of copying City 17. Besides, and this is non controversial, the graphics also feel as dated as in HL2 and this was 10ys ago. Ok, one or two sunsets doesn't make much of a difference. The characters lack polygones, but this is nicely compensated for by using caricature like expressions.Again, the ♥♥♥♥♥ are a disgrace like in any American video game's brothel: No♥♥♥♥♥♥or♥♥♥♥♥♥to see as usual but at least some shiny tattoos.Why is it an adult game then - nipples are worse than chopped off heads or what?bugs/etc.The game itself seems ok, but I had massive bugs in the Steam overlay due to failing synchronisation which caused game critical bugs (as in killing the game). Exiting and re-entring Steam helped as a workaround. Luckily, this only happened once in-game.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												Dishonored is a first-person game that takes place in a steampunk setting, in the city of Dunwall, after being framed for the murder of an Empress, you must clear your name and make things right, and at the same time dealing with those that conspired against you... The game is gorgeous visually, so many details you may not even notice, between level design and architecture and items, superb... I love the gameplay, the weapons, the abilities (personally, I use Dark Vision and Blink the most), the choice between stealth or straight-up murder, justice or revenge, the mechanics of this game are incredible... I have played through the game both stealthily, not killing anyone, not being detected in a low-chaos  way, as well as a kill everyone and everything and be a major jerk in a high-chaos way, and both can be equally as fun... The story, while somewhat predictable, is still quite compelling and enjoyable... and everything you do affects which way the story goes, if you choose to behave in a good-natured way, you will have a good ending... if you are of ill-intent, your story will become dark... The characters are great, you play Corvo, Lord Protector of the Empress, along the way you come across some other very fascinating people, Emily, Samuel, Havelock, Pendleton, Martin, Piero, The Outsider, Granny Rags, and many others... Overall, I absolutely adore this game, everything about it, I love to explore every area, every item I can find, and various paths to my goal, brilliant game! 10/10, highly recommended!EDIT: as of Feb 23, 2016, I have played through this game multiple times, and its DLCs, and have collected every achievement to 100%, so you can take my word for it, I have played everything thoroughly ;)

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												I originally thought that Dishonored was an open world RPG similar to Skyrim or Fallout, but it turns out that it’s actually closer to Deus Ex Human Revolution (action/stealth). Since I only had the free weekend to finish the game I didn’t try to go for all the achievements that I normally would. However, the game lets you know right from the start that the fewer people you kill, the better the outcome will be. That means no hacking and slashing like I was planning to. In the game you play Corvo, the chief bodyguard of the empress. When the empress is killed and her daughter kidnapped, you get framed for the crime and sentenced to death. Your main goal in the game is to rescue the daughter and bring the actual murderers to justice.  Since the bad guys are high up in the government, this means you’ll mostly be fighting government soldiers and religious zealots. You’re not alone in your quest since a magical being called the Outsider gives you powers that you can use to complete your objectives. The game does a lot of its background storytelling through notes and books that you run across all over the place. The Dishonored world seems to be roughly 1800’s technology with magic thrown in, resulting in a steampunk environment. The graphics are very similar to the Bioshock games (including that annoying blur effect when you walk through falling water).As I alluded to earlier, Dishonored is not really an RPG. You don’t gain experience or level up. There’s no big reason to kill or knock out enemies if you can just sneak around them (unless you want them out of the way for exploration). Your magic powers are upgraded by finding “runes” throughout the game world. Each rune acts like a skill point that you can use to gain or improve your magic powers. The main power you’ll be using is Blink, which is a short range teleport, which is great for getting around and avoiding enemies. The magic powers are generally not “offensive” meaning you’re not throwing fireballs or shooting lighting. Generally they’re for supporting your stealth (see through walls, killed enemies disintegrate, turn into a rat). Almost all your objectives have multiple solutions. You can run through fighting (not recommended) or find various hidden paths like climbing roofs or going through small tunnels. Similar to Deus Ex, when you sneak up on an enemy you can choose a non-lethal takedown or assassinate. Then you need to hide the body since enemies will raise alarm if they find dead or unconscious buddies lying out in the open. There is also a combat system which includes guns and the sword (you can block enemy sword swings). Since I played stealth, I didn’t engage in very much combat. And since I didn’t do a lot of fighting, my ammunition filled up really fast. You can hold a small number of healing/mana potions and arrows/bullets for your weapons. Overall Dishonored is great and well worth your time. However I wouldn’t say it’s “must play” like some others (Bioshock Infinite, Tomb Raider 2013, etc.). If you’re not into stealth games you will probably get annoyed at times when the enemy random patrols just don’t give you a chance to sneak past. I’ve read online that some people thought the game’s story was weak. It’s not amazing but not bad either. The story mostly just drives the gameplay and tells you where to go. I managed to finish the game during the free weekend a few days ago and it took roughly 16 hours, probably because I was going for no-kills and no-detection. Failed both by the way :(

content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
Stands tall on its gameplay, visuals and setting. Disappoints with a predictable main storyline.*Spoiler free. Combined review discussing Dishonored, Dunwall City Trials, The Knife of Dunwall and The Brigmore Witches.*I've never been a fan of the silent protagonist. Dishonored and its two DLCs, "The Knife of Dunwall" and "The Brigmore Witches" present an interesting opportunity to play as both a silent and a voiced protagonist within essentially the same game. The main game has you playing as Corvo Attano who has a backstory but is otherwise a blank slate for you to control. Both DLCs put you behind the eyes of Daud, an assassin that you first run in to as Corvo. It would have been jarring to suddenly strip Daud of the voice he had in the original game, so he retains it into the DLCs and, in my opinion, they are better for it.As Corvo, you sit and listen as characters monologue at you or talk to each other. As Daud, you have conversations, relationships and motives of your own. Giving your protagonist a voice makes him or her interesting, allows for natural conversations and doesn't force the game's writers to avoid lines that would normally elicit a response. And it doesn't come at the cost of robbing players of making choices at key moments, as the DLCs demonstrate.There are positives to get to, but let me get through one more negative first. Dishonored's primary story and characters are mostly predictable, standard fare. NPCs are limited to the aforementioned monologues that are generally kept short in favor of gameplay. Both DLCs are significantly better in this regard but don't expect RPG levels of depth. The voice acting, however, is all around excellent.The main attraction of Dishonored is its gameplay. It's a fusion of stealth, parkour, magic, and both melee and ranged combat. All slickly delivered from a first-person perspective. Besides the blink spell (short range teleport), you are given the choice of what spells and upgrades you want to unlock first to best match your play style. There are two general play styles that result in different endings to the game: the nonlethal (often stealthy) "low chaos" path and the "high chaos" path that revels in death and battle. This is true in the DLCs as well. Whichever style you choose, the level design will allow you numerous ways to get around and sometimes multiple ways to accomplish an objective. Game length can vary wildly with high chaos being the quicker route.While Dishonored's story may be lackluster, the atmosphere of the world it takes place in is wonderful. The art and sound design both excel at bringing this place to life. The soundtrack takes a more subtle, atmospheric approach that gets the job done but is otherwise unremarkable. You'll find notes and books scattered throughout the game that fill in the details of what goes on in this world. I hesitate to list this as a complaint, but there is a spell that significantly alters how the world looks for the worse but is so useful that I rarely turned it off. It allows you to see enemies through walls while tinting everything orange (similar to the Batman Arkham games' detective mode).Dunwall City Trials is exactly what it sounds like it is: purely gameplay. No story, no impactful player choices, just arcade style pursuit of high scores. I would suggest replaying the rest of the game at a different chaos level than your first playthrough and then if you're still hungry for more, play these.Dishonored: 7/10 --- 16 hours*Dunwall City Trials: 5/10 --- 3 hours*The Knife of Dunwall: 8/10 --- 6 hours, no alerts or kills*The Brigmore Witches: 8/10 --- 7 hours, no alerts or kills* (* estimated playtime for my single low chaos playthrough)

content:
Posted: October 23, 2012
												Here are the essentials that you should know about the game: It is a first-person stealth action game set in a steampunk industrial city infested with a plague (except that everything runs on whale oil instead of steam. The city inherits the city-on-a-coast that is slowly falling apart while a ruling class harasses the citizens vibe from City 17 (Half-Life 2) mixed with the steady unveiling of stories and details through books and audio recordings from Rapture (Bioshock). So the setting is already off to a good start, as I enjoyed both of those games immensely.As was revealed to us before the game came out, you play as Corvo Attano, the Empress' body guard. In the first scene the empress is assassinated, her daughter is kidnapped, and you are framed for it. Not the most original plot, I know, but you really do get caught up in it. Before they can execute you of course you escape with the help of a group loyal to the true heir and the rest of the game is the story of your revenge.Of course, the way that you go about exacting your revenge is entirely up to you. It is entirely possible for you to go in guns blazing and murder everyone in your path; it is also possible for you to kill almost no one throughout the whole game. You can even deal with most of the main targets in a nonlethal manner. The way you play affects several things in the game: the more people you kill, the more rats and plague victims there will be, and the ending of the game will be darker. This concept of giving you a moral choice within a linear framework reminds me once again of Bioshock.I opted to try to kill as few people as I could, partly because it is a refreshing change of pace from most video games, and partly because I knew that the guards that I was encountering didn't know the truth and were just following orders.Corvo has some pretty nifty gadgets at his disposal, including a folding blade, a crossbow, a pistol, rewiring tools, razor mines, and grenades. Oh, and of course his mask.The guards in this game aren't completely clueless, so sneaking around them undetected is actually pretty challenging until you start getting awesome supernatural powers from The Outsider. This guy lives in The Void, which is the otherworldly realm where everything magical comes from. He apparently seeks out interesting people to give powers to in order to see what they will do with their powers.  He kind of reminds me of the G-Man (Half-Life) but he manages to be creepy in a whole different way.The powers he gives you include things like short-range teleportation, seeing things through walls, stopping time, possessing animals, and creating a giant swarm of rats that will devour people.Both your gear and powers are upgradeable; for gear you collect money and supplies during your missions and bring them back to Piero to have him give you new goodies; for powers you collect whale bone runes and you can select a power to acquire as soon as you have enough runes.Being that you are the Empress' body guard and her daughter was abducted, one of your main goals is to ensure Emily's safety. I am noticing that this is a rapidly emerging theme in video games: The Walking Dead, Dishonored, Bioshock Infinite, and The Last of Us all have grown men as the player character with a young girl they must protect.There are a few things that I have to complain about, but they are relatively minor notes:The game isn't quite as long as I was expecting. I was almost expecting another plot twist that would keep the game going, but it really was the end.It isn't the most graphically impressive game I've seen. It makes up for it with a unique art style."Player choice" and "many routes to your goal" doesn't mean open world.$60 seems like too much. $40 would be a much more reasonable price.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2013
												I tried Dishonored back when it first came back on the 360 and while I thought it looked cool and sounded cooler; it just didn't grab me.  It kept nagging at me though because I thought it was definitely a game I should like.  I gave in during the summer sale and and I’ll be honest; I hit a point at the very beginning where it still didn't grab me.  This time, I pushed through my frustration and it turns out, I love this game! I was totally caught up in the story and I really dug Korvo.  I was even caught a bit by surprise by the twists and turns that happen.  Hell, I even fell in love with the world of Dunwall and the side stories you find in all the books that you collect along the way.  The Outsiders powers are fun though I really only used Blink and The Ash powers, but they fit well with the combat they've built into the game.  Early on, it was the fact that they give you wide open maps and leave it up to you to figure out how to get get through them that overwhelmed me.  Once I figured out that the key to playing Dishonored is to explore and make your own way, the game really opened up for me and turned into something special.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												I was waiting for Dishonored to come out. Waiting and hoping. It had so much potential. A pseudo-victorian steampunk dystopia, a supernatural menace, a tale of revenge. The animated Tales of Dunwall shorts caught my breath. They were making a game for me. And then it came out. And I wasn't disappointed. I'm terrible at stealth games, but they knew that so they gave me magic powers to solve that conundrum. My computer was broken, so they used a cartoony but subdued visual style which didn't cause my hardware to explode. They knew I loved complex supernatural mysteries, so they gave me just enough Lore to digest that I could piece together a searing cosmic revelation. And they gave me a little girl to save, whose unshaped persona showed me how my actions were effecting the world. As I moved from inspired setpiece to inspired setpiece and nonlethally punished insidious villain after insidious villain, I knew I'd be coming back with a sack full of grenades to try it again, once more with feeling.Play this game, and don't forget the DLC which serves as an excellent accompaniment to the original story.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2014
												A game of love, hate and betrayal, Dishonored's storyline and dialogue are a cut above and the art style - while naturally a matter of taste - is strong, consistent and I think beautiful in its exagerrated, oil-paint fashion. The time you spent in Dunwall fighting for the future of the empire and her empress will stick with you, long after the game is complete. This city has personality and flavour - it feels like a place, not a set of repeating assets.You can take three paths in dishonoured. After your downfall you can remain a righteous fellow, trying to stick to your principles, or you can turn into a crazed maniac, wrecking vengeance on all who stand between you and your goal or you can tread the muddly ground inbetween. Whichever route your nature takes you, the city reflects your heart and so do some of the people closest to you - heartbreakingly, in some circumstances.The stealth, magic and combat mechanisms in Dishonoured are a joy to play with once you get comfortable with the controls. I've dabbled heavily in all three (particularly in the Dunwall City Trials DLC) and found them all to a pleasure to work with. This is quite rare - usually in stealth games the combat is a nightmare, or in combat games the stealth is a series of awkward wall-hugging moves - none of that here. The magic is straightforward, but if you don't like magic, that's okay - there's an achievement for you too, going through the game with no magical upgrades at all.Dishonoured is a love letter to the original Thief as well as being a great game in its own right. If you enjoyed Thief: The Dark Project, you'll probably enjoy this. It's easy to imagine Dunwall lying across the sea from Garrett's city - minus the burricks.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2014
												Hither came Corvo… A reaver, a slayer and a thief.Lord protector was his title, stripped of all dignity and denied all fair justice, it is now up to you to clear his name or go down with those who were the cause to all of this.The world before you is a harsh one, a plague-ridden, rat infested dump of a city. Filled with lush-consuming nobles, bribed officials, honourless assassins and a lush for greed.With the training of a bodyguard and an assassin you must fight your way up to the top of the food-chain to be free your accusations and to save the people you care about.Without spoiling, one mission that often comes to mind when I think of this game is “the ball”.Sneak around disguised among other masked high-class and try to talk and lure your way into the secluded areas, make new friends and find out the latest gossips amongst nobles.Dishonored is truly a game worth mentioning, it takes the stealth-genre into a new era with more fast pace combat and a replayability never seen before. Emerge into a world that is very much convincing and chose a path that you decide.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2012
												Here are the essentials that you should know about the game: It is a first-person stealth action game set in a steampunk industrial city infested with a plague (except that everything runs on whale oil instead of steam. The city inherits the city-on-a-coast that is slowly falling apart while a ruling class harasses the citizens vibe from City 17 (Half-Life 2) mixed with the steady unveiling of stories and details through books and audio recordings from Rapture (Bioshock). So the setting is already off to a good start, as I enjoyed both of those games immensely.As was revealed to us before the game came out, you play as Corvo Attano, the Empress' body guard. In the first scene the empress is assassinated, her daughter is kidnapped, and you are framed for it. Not the most original plot, I know, but you really do get caught up in it. Before they can execute you of course you escape with the help of a group loyal to the true heir and the rest of the game is the story of your revenge.Of course, the way that you go about exacting your revenge is entirely up to you. It is entirely possible for you to go in guns blazing and murder everyone in your path; it is also possible for you to kill almost no one throughout the whole game. You can even deal with most of the main targets in a nonlethal manner. The way you play affects several things in the game: the more people you kill, the more rats and plague victims there will be, and the ending of the game will be darker. This concept of giving you a moral choice within a linear framework reminds me once again of Bioshock.I opted to try to kill as few people as I could, partly because it is a refreshing change of pace from most video games, and partly because I knew that the guards that I was encountering didn't know the truth and were just following orders.Corvo has some pretty nifty gadgets at his disposal, including a folding blade, a crossbow, a pistol, rewiring tools, razor mines, and grenades. Oh, and of course his mask.The guards in this game aren't completely clueless, so sneaking around them undetected is actually pretty challenging until you start getting awesome supernatural powers from The Outsider. This guy lives in The Void, which is the otherworldly realm where everything magical comes from. He apparently seeks out interesting people to give powers to in order to see what they will do with their powers.  He kind of reminds me of the G-Man (Half-Life) but he manages to be creepy in a whole different way.The powers he gives you include things like short-range teleportation, seeing things through walls, stopping time, possessing animals, and creating a giant swarm of rats that will devour people.Both your gear and powers are upgradeable; for gear you collect money and supplies during your missions and bring them back to Piero to have him give you new goodies; for powers you collect whale bone runes and you can select a power to acquire as soon as you have enough runes.Being that you are the Empress' body guard and her daughter was abducted, one of your main goals is to ensure Emily's safety. I am noticing that this is a rapidly emerging theme in video games: The Walking Dead, Dishonored, Bioshock Infinite, and The Last of Us all have grown men as the player character with a young girl they must protect.There are a few things that I have to complain about, but they are relatively minor notes:The game isn't quite as long as I was expecting. I was almost expecting another plot twist that would keep the game going, but it really was the end.It isn't the most graphically impressive game I've seen. It makes up for it with a unique art style."Player choice" and "many routes to your goal" doesn't mean open world.$60 seems like too much. $40 would be a much more reasonable price.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Dishonored is stealth action game with great gameplay and a really nice world for you to explore.STORY: You play as corvo who is the main character of the game. Corvo is a bodyguard and is protecting the empress of the city dunwall. but when Corvo comes to see the empress at the very beginning of the game, the empress gets killed by assassin's and corvo is the one they blame for the murder. Then some bad people take control over dunwall and you need to make things right.The characters are also good but nothing that special.GAMEPLAY: Dishonred focuses mostly on stealth gameplay. with every mission you need to kill or neutralize a target so the good people regain something. The good thing about the gameplay of dishonored is that you can complete the missions in so many different ways. You can fire a sleepdart to make your target go to sleep for an example. or you can slice him into bits with your sword, or you can avoid all enemies and only neutralize the target. These are one of the many ways you can complete your mission. if your looking for a game with good stealth gameplay then dishonored will not disappoint.THE ENVIRONMENT: When you look at the graphics of dishonored you might think that the graphics are bad,but thats not the case. When i walk around in the world of dishonored i feel like im playing in a painting. This gives the game a really good and unique feel. The world also feels like there is really something going on.dishonored's world feels alive and is really nice to look at. CONCLUSION:  Dishonored gives you fun missions that you can complete in all kinds of ways. combine this with a good story and great gameplay and you get a really good stealth game. The missions also have a ton of replay value, so you might want to play this game for a long time if you want to get the most out of it. If your looking for a game with good stealth gameplay and a nice world for you to discover then dishonored might be the game your looking for.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												An excellent game with a mix of stealth and action gameplay, Dishonored is set in a steampunk world with some magic thrown it it. The story is set in the Empire of the Isles, and follows Corvo, Royal Protector of the Empress, who's wrongly accused of murdering the empress and kidnapping her daugther. However, the day before his execution, he's freed from prison by a group of loyalists who seek to stop the real conspirators.The game is filled with many interesting characters, including the aforementioned loyalists, and the members of the conspiracy. There's also some mysterious characters, most notably the Outsider, who gives his mark to Corvo, granting him supernatural powers, all of which are really fun to use, and offer a nice variety, whether you go for a stealth-based approach, or want to kill everything in your path; which, by the way, are both perfectly valid ways to play this game.A great thing of the game is, like I mentioned above, the different paths it offers. And it's not as simple as two paths, you can actually approach your targets in several ways; you can even get through the whole game using only your weapons, without ever touching the powers; you can kill everybody in front of you, or you can finish the game without killing anybody, including your targets, as the game offers different ways of dealing with them. Something to keep in mind, though, is that your actions affect the world; the city in which the game takes place, Dunwall (capital of the Empire of the Isles), is afflicted by a strange plague, carried by rats, and the more chaos you cause, the more rats there are, and the more dangerous the city gets, leading to different endings depending on the overall chaos.As far as environments go, they're really good. The city is somewhat reminiscent of Half-Life's City 17, which should come as no surprise, considering that Viktor Antonov, who designed the environments for Half-Life 2, worked in this game as well. Even some of the enemies might remind you of ones encountered through Half-Life 2. However, don't think this is a bad thing; even though there are similarities, the overall tone of the game, of a steampunk nature, makes the city feel pretty unique. There's also many pathways to get through the different levels, depending, once again, on the approach you wish to take; and also many areas that you can explore, even when they're not directly related to your mission.As for gameplay, I've already talked about it in the above paragraphs. Something I haven't mentioned is that you always dual-wield your sword (on the right hand) along another weapon (or power). This leads to a very dynamic combat system, where you can attack enemies at a distance, while defending yourself in close combat. There's also several powers that allow for easier movement across the levels (from teleportation, to possessing animals, or even human NPCs), and others that give new combat options (like summoning rats to attack your enemies). Then there's the bone charms, which grant you passive effects as long as you have them equipped, enhancing your abilities.The story is excellent; as I mentioned, it starts with the death of the Empress. After Corvo escapes from prison, he joins the loyalists, and starts going against the conspirators, weakening the power of the Lord Regent, who was behind it all. Depending on what you do, you can even learn more about the plague that's destroying the city, or you can simply get your revenge on those that wronged you.So, to conclude this review, Dishonored is an excellent game. Great story, great visuals, great characters. It's become one of my favourite games, and I'm eagerly waiting for the sequel. It should be more than obvious that I recommend this game.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
												Screw Assassin's Creed, this is what a stealth game should be like. Dishonored is a first-person stealth adventure game that casts you into the role of Corvo Attano, a former bodyguard, now turned supernatural assassin all because the Empress of the city of Dunwall has been murdered and he has been framed for her death. Everything about Dishonored is fantastic. Pros:+Enemy AI reacts to everything the player does, whether they have been seen or not.+A wide variety of skills and weaponry makes every playthrough unique - take the silent route focused on stealth, or be ruthless and slaughter everything in sight.+The art style and direction is awesome.+Actions have consequences, and some of them can be quite significant...+Excellent level design. If you can see a door in front of you, you most likely can open it. If you see a rooftop, you can climb to it. The possibilities when it comes to navigating levels are nearly endless!+Likeable cast and characters.Cons:+Some of the textures look a little outdated when viewed close up, considering how this was released in 2012.+A couple of characters exist merely as plot devices. Overall, Dishonored is a fantastic game if you can overlook what it doesn't do quite right, and maximises what it does do right. The Knife of Dunwall and The Brigmore Witches DLC only adds to the sheer awesome that is this game, so I highly reccomend those too.

												After doing one run of the game so far, I am shocked I didn't do it sooner. Dishonored is not your average stealth game. There is a lot of freedom to it, something more games need.Stealth ain't your thing? You can straight up murder everyone in close combat and still beat the game no problem.Wanna keep your hands clean? You can go through the game without killing a single person. One can literally play the game however they want, and there is so much fun that can come out of it. The replayability value of this game is so high, and more games should be like this one. Honestly, Dishonored is one of my favorite games, and I really should have looked into it sooner.
