content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
												It has been two days since you were withoutSummer-Rain, after that excursion with her,the one with the milkshakes. You think abouther as you run along rain-slicked marble wallsand drab stone architecture, with the magicaltattoo on your hand's exterior glowing yellow and blue.DISHONORED.Framed for the murder of the beloved Rulerof the City of Dunwall, Empress JessamineKaldwin, you take the role of Corvo Attano,disgraced Royal Bodyguard-turned-deadly,supernaturally-powered-assassin.Granted a vast array of paranormally-chargedpowers by the strange, ever-watchful Outsider,the world is yours to either silently navigate tosave the city from an all-consuming plague andgovernment corruption, or for you to unleashmayhem and wreak bloody havoc upon thosewho have wronged you.Dishonored's world draws you in with its rich, meticulously-crafted nuances and mythology scattered from minute notes to unspoken baroque and gothic-styled overtones from atmosphere to architecture.Dishonored's mission and level design rankhighly in terms of effort put in and time spentmaking these levels become a reality. Eachchoice made, whether you choose to spare orkill whoever stands in your wayhas lasting consequences upon the outcome of the story, in what the game explains as 'Chaos.'Complete the game in High Chaos, and you seethe city of Dunwall plunged into a new Dark Age,based on your choices and a playthrough of aviolent killer. Complete the game in Low Chaos,and Dunwall is spared a grim fate, and the newEmpress, Emily Kaldwin- daughter of JessamineKaldwin- will reign in a new Golden Age, in partdue to your efforts in a non-lethal, stealth-basedplaythrough.You realize then, after playing the mission toretrieve Emily from a posh brothel called theGolden Cat, that the game's model of Emily inher white dress looks eerily similar, as if youhave seen it on someone before, in the past.It hits you then. This is not the first time thatyou have seen the girl in white. There was theschool dance and there was this bombshell inthe form-fitting white dress, golden bangs andher black bob-cut. She was alone and at thetime, Ms. Novocaine was running an hour late,but there were rumours that your girlfriend wasdoing improper things with the sports jocks.You invited her to dance, the girl in white.You danced with Summer-Rain, once upon a time.A thread of drool drips unconsciously from yourhalf-open mouth as your mind wandered. Youreyes snap back to reality, wiping your mouthwith whatever time you can muster before theguards are upon you in one of the greatestDishonored missions, Lady Boyle's Last Party.You infiltrated the mansion, mingled with theguests. You had to identify which of the threeBoyle triplets she was, and choose a methodto eliminate the target. You went for yourfolding sword and stabbed the Boyle sister inwhite while you had your flashback epiphany.You save and exit Dishonored before sitting atthe foot of your bed, dialling her number andwaiting with baited breath. "Hello?" The linepicks up, and Summer-Rain's sweet voicewashes over your shaken form. "Hey. Youalright there?" She chimes."I remember. That night, when Ms. Novocainedidn't turn up. We danced the night away, butin the morning, you were gone. I woke up onthat hill overlooking town alone." Silence fromacross the line, then you can almost feel hersmile from the receiver."You knew, didn't you? About Ms. Novocaine."Summer-Rain's tears fall freely now. Her sobsecho in your ear and through your heart, andonce again, the Outsider whispers daggers toboth you and Summer-Rain."Even when we were children, I loved you.Loved you from a distance." Summer-Rainwhispers, her voice making you wince ininvoluntary pain. "But who could ever love Summer-Rain, whoherself was once just like Ms. Novocaine?"Summer-Rain playfully says, mocking herself."Pretty." "Spoiled.""Dishonored."The line goes dead."By the Outsider." You start, lookingat your empty hands, breathing slowly."Hear me. Grant me the strength to win over Summer-Rain, and heal her heart."You clench your hands, and have neverfelt more sure in your life. "Grant me an endless love for Summer-Rain that will be the stuff of legends, O' Outsider."

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												Compareable to - Thief (stealthing based on gadgets and special powers)- Half-Life 2 (Dystopian elements: fighting a regime, propaganda streetspeakers, meeting suffering civilians along the way, an omnipresent and pressing threat - in this case a rat plague)- Hitman (you go on kill missions and have sort of a safehouse)It's story-driven, but the story for most parts revolves around neutralizing key enemies scattered around the fictional (but highly "British"-looking) city of Dunwall. There is a kind of safehouse where you talk to allies and relax for a moment before entering hostile territories again. Your basic three approaches at all time are to stealth your way around, to knock out everyone or to kill all you see. You can finish the game without killing a single person or animal. There is one situation where I couldn't find a satisfying non-lethal way though and where I felt pressed to kill somebody. I will look at that again, maybe I missed how to do it the way I was hoping to.Rather easy. I played on "hard" difficulty (there was "very hard" too I believe). Standard stealthing mechanics. You can take out guards one by one (kill or put to sleep), drag them into dark corners and by thus slowly empty the levels of all danger. You are invisible while leaning around corners. Your special powers make you see enemies through walls, stop time for a brief moment and teleport for some distances and on rooftops and things which makes things easy. A.I. isn't the smartest and only having basic abilities (patrolling areas, cone of vision, some awareness to noise). Guards you take out are eventually replaced by others, you will see more guards either patrolling the area you've been in previously after switching back and forth to other places (with a loading screen inbetween) or see "live" replacements coming from where you are meant to progress to. I noticed guards being replaced one time at best - after taking the replacement down the area would stay empty.Combat is somewhat underwhelming. Enemies step up to you and will either swing their swords or stand still, aim their flintlock pistols and shoot at you. You basically do three things then: Block with your own sword (one button, blocks all sword attacks, if timed well enough your enemies are stunned and vulnerable to instant-kill animations, sometimes you'll be kicked at which breaks your block), step sidewards when pistols are aimed at you (which makes enemies holster them again rather than adjust their aim) and spam your own attack button. Enemies evade or block a hit or two, or cross swords with you, but they don't keep this up for long, you kill them rather swiftly and even easier when using your special powers. Occassionally (in particular when attacking enemies previously stunned by timed blocks) you will see a specific animation in which your character grabs their arms or something before cutting their throat. It's not looking badly or anything, it just isn't very hard or challenging or anything, no one in this game stands a chance against your character.Looks nice and fitting overall. Some textures are blurry. But it ran like a charm, I had no performance issues, and it just generally felt like a very polished game. All special powers make sense and support either stealthy or loud approaches. There is quicksaving/-loading and loading times are practically nonexistent, this way you can do everything perfectly the way you want it to be or test out some of the freedom the game gives you.I just had that one issue when getting hurt or taking control of other creatures with my special powers the various effects that go along (blurry or colored screens) wouldn't disappear too easily. That wasn't too bad since I was stealthing mainly anyway. I noticed that enabling VSynch will make these effects fade out properly. One thing that irritated me is that bodies of people you took down will just disappear. You knock out two or three guards, toss them in a trash bin or in some dark corner, come back a minute later and some of them will have simply vanished. Not sure was that was about. I was first trying to explain it with them being found by other patrols, but even when roaming nearby they would disappear, and when the game shows you your mission statistics these bodies never counted towards "bodies discovered". One feature I liked a lot: There is a heart (half organical, half mechanical) you can hold in your hand and which will whisper secrets to you about the location you are in or about the persons you are aiming at with it. It's voice actress sounded nice, and the way her voice was "manipulated" (with some kind of echo resonating around multiple times) felt intriguing. Especially the various allied NPCs you meet over and over again in your safehouse are given some good depth that way, along with talking to them or listening to "audiographs" (short voice recordings) made by them. I was generally caring for the characters or curious about their intentions and doings, I thought they were all neatly crafted. Aiming with the heart isn't always easy, often I heard location secrets even though I tried aiming at persons. Sadly, from the middle towards the end of the game you will keep meeting the familiar types of enemies or civilians and there is only one pool of lines for each type (and for each key character), so if you've exhausted all of them early on you won't be using the heart later on too much anymore except for key kill targets you meet for the first and only time.The game seems to have multiple endings. A set of snipplets looking towards the future of things, and how these snipplets look like seems to depend on how much you stealth around or not causing chaos to the city (mission debriefs have a "chaos" indicator - if you kill many people it will tell you the chaos is "high", and in the next missions there are presumably supposed to be more "Weepers" (plague victims) or rats or stuff. I was having "low" chaos throughout most parts of the game so I wouldn't notice. Guards, streetspeakers and other NPCs will make remarks in some instances on how brutally or peacefully you'll have advanced through the game.The game ends fairly solid though some questions are left unanswered. There is some DLC available. Not sure if those answer some of my questions. Bethesda is apparently planning of turning this game into a franchise. There is some lore background allowing to do more. There are various fictional continents, they designed a world map you can glance at several times ingame, there are texts and voice recordings giving insight into the characters, industry, politics and myths of the world circling noteably around whaling business and a world being seemingly in some kind of industrial revolution.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												Disonored is a first person stealth game. Highly atmosperic and immersive, it tells an amazing story and puts you in control throughout it's duration. The game starts out easy enough but soon after throws you into the lions den. As the title suggests, you are dishonored and stripped of your status and thrown into prison after a certain event transpires. It is here the game makes brilliant use of a stalking/cover mechanic as you are forced to escape your binds. You are able to peek around corners to remain unseen and you always have the option of a non violent approach. Sneak up behind and knock them out or bury your sword into their neck, the choice is yours. When combat is initiated, you have a plethora of options open to you. You hold your sword in your right hand and have the option of equiping crossbows, pistols and powers in your left. Careful timing of your block opens enemies up to counter attack and choose to put an arrow in their skull, blast a musket ball into their chest or finish them with your sword. There are options open to you even if you are in combat, to resolve the situation non violently if you choose. Options include sleep syringes shot from your crossbow or using your powers to disappear into the darkness. But be carefull, killing all in your path has a negative effect and can drastically change each mission and the world as a whole. Some of the powers at your disposal include a blink ability to quickly teleport and (but not limited to) conjuring a swarm of rats to attack and eat your enemies. There are several other powers but I dont want to spoil the surprise. I will say there are powers to purchase and upgrade that will suit any playstyle. You purchase powers and upgrades by finding runes hidden throughout each level. Some can be bought and others found. There is an item that puts markers on runes and charms when used so you never have to leave any behind. Charms you can collect and find, offer passive bonuses like being able to choke out an enemy faster or that make a power more potent. There are tons of charms to find so the combinations are endless. Up to 6 can be equipped at a time unless you have the DLC which allows you to equip up to 10. Between missions, you have a home base to buy equipment and upgrades. Here is where you recieve your next mission and often are given clues about side missions to complete while tackling the main. This is a large area packed with lots of goodies to find and people to talk to. The story in Dishonored is stellar. Events always unfold in first person and there are no camera shifts the break immersion. The voice acting cast has stars like Susan Sarandon and Brad Dourif just to name a couple and they do an awesome job of fleshing out their characters. There really is no complaint I can level against Dishonored. It is a masterpiece and multiple playthroughs using different tactics never dull the fun. From its beautiful graphics, story, characters, weapons, powers and atmosphere to its high replayability, there really is nothing wrong about the game. Anyone that enjoys first person games with emphasis on stealth and combat, with RPG elements sprinkled in, will enjoy Dishonored.

												Dishonored is one of the better assassin games I have played recently. The art design and is unique and the gameplay is outstanding. Dishonored takes place in an industrial era where someone has framed you for killing the queen and taking away her daughter. You then have to escape a jail and find your way to some allies. Then from that point on you try to redeem yourself and find the queens daughter. Throughout the game you find new unique abilites that you can choose to unlock. If you want a challenge then up the difficulty because it gets very hard. Overall the story is outstanding and again the gameplay is very good. So I would give Dishonored a 9/10. So if you are looking for a great game to buy, well it looks like you just found yourself one.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												Being an assassin never felt so sad. Corvo's silence is the home of coiled emotions that are merely tamed or kindled by the player's. And Dunwall: Dunwall is a place that feels so alive it could devour you; but so alive in its desolation and poision, how odd; and Dunwall's soul is ever by, but ever so elusive. Truly, in Dishonored, choosing mercy or revenge is of great consequence. Chaos is ours. Empress Emily's cruel melancholy or tender hope, echoing from our actions, will touch us; whatever joy or regret come, they be ours too. Aesthetically, the game is wonderful. Its world-design is vivid and immersive, eerie and beautiful at once; throughout, the textures are blurred so that the world appears to be painted in pastels: if we didn't know that this is in great measure due to low-res textures, we could say that the pastel-style is deliberate. The sounds, too: they wrap us with their nightmarish draperies.Now, the characters have very distinct looks: they are stylised to the point of being emblems of their heart's secrets; can we not tell, or at least surmise, from their countenances or their shapes what their marrows hide? And they are richly human, harlequin, these characters: if not our heart, then another heart may tell us of their wins and woes. And if no one else so truly, Emily, Empress Emily, does care about Corvo's compassion, or his dread touch. When we are let loose here in Dunwall, to play with its loving and its wicked inhabitants as we please, do we not ask ourselves if the chaos, grand or vanished, in our wake is our very soul's, and not Corvo's?

content:
Posted: November 9, 2013
												Vooshka! After raving about Bioshock Infinite (BS:I), I wasn't expecting to experience another game of that quality for quite some time.  But Dishonored is AMAZING and easily BS:Infinite's equal - and that's no small compliment!!!  Comparing the two is inevitable.  If I'd happened to have played Dishonered first, I'd still be comparing them but just doing it in my  BS:I review instead.Like BS:I, Dishonered has a very richly detailed world with tons of character and characters.  As great as the storytelling and ambiance is, what sets Dishonored apart for me is the variety and excellence of gameplay:You can see the influence of games like Bioshock (guard the little girl); Half Life (same lead artist - just look at the barricades and tall boys); Thief (the stealth elements) and Deux Ex (multiple ways/paths to achieve goals).  However, it's important to note that the game doesn't feel derivative at all.  It manages to riff off all the best elements but is still very much it's own game and not a knock-off.While stealth is encouraged, you have many ways to complete an objective including going in guns blazing. The synergy of your various powers work well together and really succeeds in making you feel very ninja-esque!Pacing is also excellent.  The story and and new abilities progress fast enough that things are constantly interesting but not so fast that you're overwhelmed or lost.This is another one of those 5 star games that I just didn't want to end and is easily on my MUST BUY list!  If you haven't played it yet go buy it... NOW!I'm off to jump into the DLC...

Posted: February 13, 2014
												Highly enjoyable and highly recommended.  Dishonored hits stealth right on the head.  Not since the Thief series has stealth felt so good in an FPS.  More importantly, the game gives you options to play the way you want to.  You could murder every living creature in your path, or never harm a soul.  You could go in guns blazing or never be seen once.  There is no strict morality system, but is one where your actions contribute to the level of chaos in the world which ultimately affects the ending and the environment around you.The powers and weapons are satisfying, the world is refreshingly different, and the story is compelling.  Wipe the rust from your whale oil powered rig and install this game.

Posted: July 8, 2014
												Dishonored is a game that I almost completely missed out on. The first time I ever heard dishonored was when I was looking up a list of B games. I was buying some games for my Xbox, and saw that this game was getting great reviews from people. At the time it was only 25$ so I got it along with some others and waited a little while to play it. I can easily say this is one of my favorite games of all time. I am normally against stealth games, but this game is so different.This game is my "Half-life". I eagerly await a sequel in any form. I could describe why this game is good, but I doubt I could do it justice. I will say that it has thrilling story, fun and non-limited game play as well as a new type of art design. Without taking the extreme graphic engine approach, Arcane made a game that looks vivid and nice all around. This game is a solid 10/10. Generally with a good game, at some point I would say something like "I don't agree with this decision but its not a big deal". However, with Dishonored I never found myself saying that. Even the DLC game of the year content that I only recently tried has been great! I completely recommend this game.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												Don't get me wrong, Dishonored IS a good game. The gameplay in it is fantastic, the setting is really cool and interesting, and the pure number of ways you can deal with just about any scenario is nothing short of awe-inspiring. However, it does have its claws, most of which settle around the story and how it frames its characters, but it's best to try to be ignorant of them if you want to get the most out of this game. Just play it and try not to get too invested in the story because the game won't really reward that investment. I'll list my issues below in a spoiler, but if you are even thinking about buying this game, grab it.  Characters as a whole never really feel like people, they come off as robotic cardboard cutouts most of the time, primarily because they don't seem to ever react to anything. This is something that if you notice it, it's hard to ignore if you are trying to get into the story. The city itself is interesting, it's just that the flatness of the characters never really makes it feel alive.  The other problem that I have with the game is how it calculates how your actions "impact" the rest of the story. Whether or not you get a good ending is mostly determined by how many people you have killed and how much general "chaos" you have created. However... I went through my playthrough taking mostly knock outs and only killing someone if I needed to silence them before they rang the other guards. Despite these tactics I was still getting high chaos ratings at the end of every mission because of the bodycount tha I was hitting. None of these bodies would ever be found, and most of the people who ever saw me are now dead, and yet still, everyone knows who I am, and the city is going to hell. I'm not dropping corpses to the rats, I'm not charging guards head on, and yet the game still treats me the same way simply because of this bodycount. It's actually frustrating, because the moments where you'll find yourself seen and then have to fight your way are the BEST part of the game. Summoning a rat swarm at the top of a tower, and accidently luring all the guards in the area up the steps, then throwing a grenade too kill every one of them because I'm cornered shouldn't make me a saint. At the same time however, that's just one section out of four in the level and even if I don't kill a single soul after this I'll still get high chaos because I happened to kill eight people out of necessity. It just feels like the emergent gameplay side of Dishonored conflicts with the morality system in a way that punishes the player on the story end of the game because they wanted to play Dishonored the "fun" way. Again, fantastic game and this is a gripe I have with it, but the more you refuse to care about the morality/chaos system, the more fun you'll have.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2013
												Vooshka! After raving about Bioshock Infinite (BS:I), I wasn't expecting to experience another game of that quality for quite some time.  But Dishonored is AMAZING and easily BS:Infinite's equal - and that's no small compliment!!!  Comparing the two is inevitable.  If I'd happened to have played Dishonered first, I'd still be comparing them but just doing it in my  BS:I review instead.Like BS:I, Dishonered has a very richly detailed world with tons of character and characters.  As great as the storytelling and ambiance is, what sets Dishonored apart for me is the variety and excellence of gameplay:You can see the influence of games like Bioshock (guard the little girl); Half Life (same lead artist - just look at the barricades and tall boys); Thief (the stealth elements) and Deux Ex (multiple ways/paths to achieve goals).  However, it's important to note that the game doesn't feel derivative at all.  It manages to riff off all the best elements but is still very much it's own game and not a knock-off.While stealth is encouraged, you have many ways to complete an objective including going in guns blazing. The synergy of your various powers work well together and really succeeds in making you feel very ninja-esque!Pacing is also excellent.  The story and and new abilities progress fast enough that things are constantly interesting but not so fast that you're overwhelmed or lost.This is another one of those 5 star games that I just didn't want to end and is easily on my MUST BUY list!  If you haven't played it yet go buy it... NOW!I'm off to jump into the DLC...

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												I just finished my first playthrough, and I am about to do my second, but I thought I would take the time to review the game first. The game has wonderful story, level design, and ar and theme.I enjoy stealth games, but I usually lose interest in them eventually before I beat them, but in Dishonored the story kept me engaged and playing the game to the end, and now I'm about to do it a second time to see what effect my choices have on the story. I would go out of my looking for books and notes with as much determination as looking for runes and bone charms. Sometimes the choices you make come back in really interesting ways, but I won't give spoilers (sorry!). The resolution was fantastic, I've worked hard for my low chaos run and it payed off.The early tutorial levels keep saying Play Your Way and give a bunch of examples of how to beat the level, after the tutorial there are still many ways for you to win with high and low chaos and different impacts on the story. The levels are perfect to let you sneak through vents, climb over rooftops, hide under tables or peak around corners (probably unrealistic but super helpful for not getting detected), or just run through everyone with your sword and gun. There is also a lot of variety in the levels.I am in love with steampunk. I wore goggles to school a couple of times. My friend told me it was cringe-worthy, but a bunch of people I don't even know gave me compliments, which was nice, so, maybe go out and by goggles for yourself? get steampunk a bit more mainstream? I'm getting off topic. The point is: I love steampunk and this game has fabulous whalepunk, which is basically the same thing, but more creative and original. I love all the art. The whalepunk street lights and Victorian sort of clothing, how dark it is (I mean gloomy, not hard to see), everything is great, especially the faces. Everyone is all caricatured and looks really unique. The textures are super neat also. They seem pretty realistic, but also sort of painterly. Like a really realistic oil painting.To summarize: the developers of this game deserve much more money than what they are charging, but the game is pretty old by now so it's cheaper. Lucky you.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2013
												You can play this game two very different ways, or something inbetween, and each feels different. You can go a stealth approach and look for alternative pathways, and you can even go for a non-lethal solution in every mission. Or you can use all your powers and weaponry and have a good old slaughter. What is really interesting is how the game is affected by your actions. Murder without restraint and you end up with a darker version of reality. Or keep it under wraps and keep things a little less chaotic.The graphics of this game are something unique, in an art style that suits the somewhat Steampunk dystopian world. The level design is done well, plenty of nooks to explore but without getting lost. Alternative solutions to each mission make it replayable, and in two runs you can get all achievements if you so chose to. 'Hardcore' gamers will find joy in doing a non-lethal playthrough with no powers used, but there are also challenges for pushing certain skill combinations to the limit. And with the game being chopped into mission parts, which none the less flow into each other, you can easily sit down and play just a little bit. The downside? It's a short game. DLC is cheap enough however, and you do get a quality experience for it which isn't dragged out because a game should be X hours long.

												Do you like stealing everything not nailed down in Skyrim? Do you enjoy the sneaking around like a ninja like in Metal Gear Solid or Thief? Are you a fan of the unique atmosphere of Bioshock - with it's art deco and it's magic?You will LOVE Dishonored! The game is similar to Bioshock and Deus Ex where you're given a task, and you have multiple ways of accomplishing it. Do you sneak through the shadows? Do you take over a rat and run through the vents? Maybe you rather leave bodies placed in sexual positions for guards to find.Either way, Dishonored is fantastic! I'm excited to get the DLC to continue more Dishonored.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												An excellent stealth game. Plenty of strategy and patience involved when choosing how to progress though levels, and moving past small armies of enemies undetected feels very rewarding. Abilities are useful and varied, though it is possible to go through entire playthroughs only using a handful. The environment is extremely well done and levels are large enough to spend significant time exploring.My only complaint is that the campaign is fairly short, and additional playthroughs can be completed in a few hours. They are a great few hours though, and thoroughly recommended for lethal/non-lethal/undetected playthroughs. The most fun I've ever had pretending to fang around in a mask. Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Grades: Longevity: 8/10 Story: 9/10 Gameplay: 8.5 / 10 Graphics: 9/10 Sound: 9/10 The main story of Dishonored portrays the journey of Corvo Attano, protector of the Empress. This is murdered by other assassins in front of Corvo and his daughter Emily, at the behest of Lord Regent, which is a corrupt and unscrupulous governor. Emily in the aftermath of these events is kidnapped by the assassins, and Raven then has to go save her and kill the Lord Regent, and other strategic targets, so Dunwall can return to normalcy. DLC in The Knife of Dunwall, we follow the demand of Daud, the assassin who killed the Empress, in search of Delilah, the name that was pointed out by The Outsider. The DLC in Brigmore Witches, continue to demand Daud, in search of Delilah. Starting with longevity, this editon took me 23 hours to complete, main story + DLC's, so longevity is not a strong point, but for the type of game it is, and how it's done, is an acceptable longevity . The story is the strongest point of the game, I enjoyed the story has moments that make us think hard in our decisions that affect its development, and has plenty of moral issues with parallels to real life. The gameplay is also one of the strengths of the game, has many similarities to Bioshock, where we have a weapon or power in his left hand and a sword in his right hand. We have two approaches to the game, the stealth approach or more "careless" approach and kill everything in front. The game also offers several ways to reach the destination, either through hidden tunnels, passes through the tops of buildings or even at street level, yet even possessar rats and get in on the ground pipelines. The combat is also well done and sometimes presents some challenge. The game's graphics are very good also, much of the gender of Bioshock, the characters very well made ​​and animated, and has very beautiful and sometimes breathtaking landscapes. The sound is also very good, although the very guards repeat their lines, gender, we always hear the same song whistled, or the guards with the same voice muttering. In short: Positives: - Gameplay - History - Characters - Landscapes - Combat - Powers Minuses: - Repetition of lines of guards FINAL GRADE: 8.7 / 10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												This game. Man. This game. Right, so Arkane Studios had me at hello. Every game they had something to do with development in; I loved. Dark Messiah: Might & Magic was the first game I ever played by them, and man. I PLAYED THE MOTHER ♥♥♥♥ING♥♥♥♥♥♥OUT OF THAT GAME. Then Bioshock 2, CoD: WaW (level design).  This review might be slightly biased due to my love for both Bethesda and Arkane Studios; so heed my warning. I am also not judging the DLC that had been released for Dishonored, for I haven't even touched it. Right, so after 85 hours, I can rightfully say that I practically know most of the game, inside and out. Played it on the hardest difficulty without killing anyone and without being spotted once through the entire playthrough. So a brief rundown on what Dishonored is. It's a stealth based action game, based in a steampunk Victorian Britain. It's very much a "choose your own path" game. You can run through it without killing a single being, or without being noticed by anyone; or you can get spotted by every one and decapitate them to your heart's content. Most of the level design also allows you to play through a map multiple  times, finding lots of ways to clear them. The game is very story intensive. But the beauty of it is; if you don't wish to explore the lore and story of every inch of the game's setting... Then don't. There are hundreds of books in the game. I literally mean hundreds. Which tell you the story of Dunwall and the isles that surround it. And you can choose to read none of them. It's hard to say what's wrong with the game, for I can't think of much... The AI is pretty good, along with the stealth. It's one of the games which make me happy because the fact you're in the shadow, doesn't make you completely invisible; it just makes you less visible. The sword-play is simple and fun to use. The powers are great too. However, I note that it's quite irritating when you want to play a complete passive game; and it forces you to equip your sword at all times. I would prefer to wield two powers in each hand, rather than have my sword constantly there; even if I weren't to use it.  Overall; I believe the game has a beautiful art-style and setting; great game-play, and it often makes you feel ♥♥♥♥ing awesome after you've successfully done something. Like if you choke-out a guard, get spotted; toss the knocked-out guard into the one that spotted you; making him stumble to the floor before you jump ontop of him and slice his neck open. There are probably loads of negatives I've missed out, but like I said. Biased. If anything, it would be replayablity. There are things there to make second play-throughs fresh; but really, after you've both killed everyone, then let everyone live; there's not much to explore unless you go hardcore. I would probably r8 it 8/8 m8.

content:

												Single-player assassination game with a unique twist. A story that is well executed and that changes depending of the style of play you'll have throughout the game, lethal or non-lethal. You're choosing your skills freely and you can tailor them to fit your own playstyle. Slide through shadows, sneak past guard and get your way in, or go head-on with your blade and slash your way, or combine the two. All at your hands.Improvisation and adaptation is the key. Dishonored is a vicious, raw, and incredibly good stealth-action game."Feed him to the hungry rats for dinner. Early in the morning."

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												Honestly, one of the best stealth games I've played.Unlike some stealth games (Like Hitman Absolution) which requires you to do very specific things to get through things, Dishonored lets you go about things your own way. You can take out your enemies one by one, you can simply time your movements correctly to sneak around the guards, you can use one of the many different routes to get through or simply jump in the middle and fight all of the enemies using your weapons or the abilities you get.The way you go through things effect the world and the ending of the game. Killing a lot of people will cause high chaos, causing people heavily infected with the rat plague, known as weepers, to spawn more and the more people you kill, the more weepers there will be. Doing the oppisite will cause less weepers to spawn. Doing these things doesn't only effect how many weepers will spawn though, it also effects what your allies think of you. Killing less people will make people like you. Killing a lot of people will make them hate you, people in the city will become more violent and the city watch will start to crumble.I don't want to spoil anything because it is something you should experience on your own.GetThisGameRightNow/10

content:

												After all the media hype for this game I wasn't expecting much after the Diablo 3 stinker.   But boy, does this game deliver!The art style is one of the best I have seen in a game, even surpassing the beautiful Guild wars 2 art direction. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												The world of Dishonored is fantastic; it is so rich and well-established by way of in-game books, notes, overheard dialogue and even just little scenes upon which you can stumble. Some people call Corvo, the protagonist, boring and characterless, but what's facinating is the effect that your actions  - and by extension, Corvo - has on those around him.People treat you differently by way of subtle changes in speech or tone and the lasting effect on one particular character is nothing short of brilliant.As far as gameplay goes, Dishonored isn't perfect. The stealth mechanics are pretty close to perfect, with leaning around corners, clearly visible alert warnings and a multitude of clever ways to get around without being seen, but it falls apart a bit in the combat. Corvo is heralded as a master of arms, able to 'beat three men at once', as a guard can be heard saying. Ironically, fighting more than one person at a time can be infuriatingly difficult. And that's on moderate settings.Because almost all NPCs use a combination of sword and pistol, you can cross swords only to be shot at point blank range by someone you can't stop, they can kick you; an unblockable attack that deals as much damage as a bullet, or they can just swing their sword as you jump backwards out of range and hit you anyway. Their sword range is about three times the length of their sword and you must block every single hit.The killy death tools are nicely varied, allowing for very stylish kills with grenades, crossbow bolts and shrapnel mines, and that's not even touching on the supernatural powers. Adding them, the game becomes a flowing action of combat adding a clever third dimension to swordplay (at least the way I fight). Aside from just jumping and teleporting high, time manipulation, rat control and blasts of wind are just some of the tricks you can use.Admittedly, you'll probably find one or two powers that you use more than the others, but the options are there to experiment.While the story can be a bit predictable, it serves as a good framing device to take you across the breadth of Dunwall, killing and stalking people of all kinds. Also all of the cutscenes are skippable for those who want to try speedruns.The DLC is an interesting topic, allowing a new perspective on the story as well as some different powers and amazing sprawling levels.The downside of these slow, stealth-based games is they can be lacking in F**k Yeah moments, but Dishonored makes up for that in lasting enjoyment, replayability and a world that you can be lost in for days.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												This game...i have mixed feeling towards it. On one side I loved the graphics, the style and voice actors and the music. I also loved the level design and overall the great freedom it was given to the player.....BUT this freedom was taken back due to the STUPID Chaos system present in the game. Which chaos you get influence the endings, problem is that chaos level is not affected by how stealthy you play but how many people you kill. I did a lethal stealth gameplay (never discovered/killed all the guards) and got the bad ending. Basically the story forced my gameplay, if you want a good ending you should not kill anyone which is bad. Non-lethal gamplay is boring and made a lot of powers and gadgets useless and restrict your options. This thing really ruined the game for me.However if we put this thing apart you get a solid game, with good levels and lots of fun. DLCs are a must have in this game. If what I mentioned earlier is not a problem then go for it, it's really a satisfying game to play. Personally I enjoyed Daud story more over Corvo's so I highly recommend all DLCs (except the trials of Dunwall that are useless).

												***WIP review***If you are a fan of the original Thief trilogy, you MUST play Dishonored.  This is about as good as a modern day Thief experience as it gets.  6.1 hours in and I'm loving every second of it!  I'm still very early in the game, and I already know I'll be replaying this title for a dozen times, if anything, to simply experient different ways to blast / sneak / ghost my way through.(so far I've been proceeding with the non-lethal way, ie choking + hiding bodies, but my next playthrough will be done with knives, and the next next run will consist of tossing whale oil tanks at the foot of some City Watch boys HAHAHA)Pros:- Immersive atomsphere!- Great story, weaven by characters that you actually care about, enriched with fascinating lores.- Open level design, with myriad of solutions to dispatch / get around enemies.- Most fluid movement / parkour system I've seen in a FPS (Mirror's Edge is garbage in comparison).- Skill and items that actually enhance gameplay and enpower the player.- Glitch-free audio and video, like the way a true PC game should be.Cons:- Occasional crashes, though thankfull they do not corrupt saving files.- Could use higher resolution textures (though I get the water painting-esque style is probably intentional)

content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												This game completely exceeded my expectations. When I first saw the trailer gameplay, I quickly dismissed it as a Bioshock rip-off (actually in some ways it is, like being able to use superhuman powers like summon rats to kill enemies or even manipulate time and the overall creepy tone of the game with the Weeper xombie-like enemies that reminded me of the deranged Splicers from the Bioshock games) but the overall gameplay is a lot more fun than Bioshock 1 or 2 (I haven't played Infinite yet). The reason is because it allows for so many different options to either bypass or eliminate enemies. For example the Blink teleportation power allows for quick teleporting over short distances that can be used to access difficult areas or instantly appear behind enemies and dispatch them. There are many hiding places as well for stealth playthroughs, such as hiding underneath tables and fireplaces to avoid contact with enemies. Speaking of stealth, the game actually encourages you to not kill people other than your targets by the increase of rats and Weepers in each level depending on how many people you have killed. The story is serviceable but a bit generic, as it basically involves a government bodyguard who is framed for the murder of his Empress by his own comrades and must exact revenge on his adversaries with the obligatory plot twists added for good measure. The graphics are pretty good (I only ran it on medium-high and I only encountered minor buffering problems), but I didn't really like the cartoon-like visual style of the game because it looked kind of weird.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
 Take a journey to Dunwall, Bethesda's version of liberal south California. You play as Corvo, a completely reasonable man who believes in equality among genders. You return home to your girlfriend, the empress of Dunwall, and everything seems perfect. Nope. A large mass of hippies have just discovered that you not only identifiy with the gender you were born with, but you have been r@ping every woman in a 100 mile radius over 300,000 times a day. In order to extract their revenge, they murder the empress you allegedly r@ped and kidnap her daughter to frame you. You are thrown in prison as people on the street express how glad they are you will be r@ped in prison.But Corvo's tale has just begun! Say hello to the resistance, a small band of like-minded individuals who believe r@pe is a-okay. While you don't agree with their views, you'd rather provide aid to the ones who will help you save the small child who's life you've probably ruined and/or ended.Gameplay is pretty fun.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												Fantastic game. It is so hard to be "good" though, it's almost not fair. You are given so many wonderfull and satisfying ways to dispatch your enemies, only to be reminded that they are not always your enemies. If you didn't want me to kill the misled officers of the city watch, perhaps you should not have given me the ability to posses them into suicide. Or summon plagues of rats to devour them. Hrm? I'm looking at you Arkane Studios. The art style and setting highten the story, which may not be entirely original, but I couldn't find anything to complain about. You may be able to see the end coming from miles away, but it is still an enjoyable trip getting there. I was a bit concerned at the abrupt start to the game with no true backstory besides a paragraph of text. Then I discovered the story and history of the game world through exploration and knick knacks found throughout the game. If you are a speedy gamer who like to blast to the end, this may not be as enjoyable for you. On the otherhand if you enjoy skulking around, finding every piece of loot, note, and clue...  this is your game. Truly.

												One of my all time favourites... (dont be fooled by my playtime^^)the gameplay feels increadibly smooth especially with your teleport power and stealth assassination.There are in general 3 different ways to approach each mission.The most casual one would be to run in and openly murder every single guard you see in a big gun/crossbow/sword fight. That is also fun dont get me wrong but i prefer the predator style.Sneak in and get rid of the guards that are in your way. either by killing them quietly or buy putting the to sleep. Nothing to big or something but the gameplay just puts this game at the top of things.Get it. You will enjoy it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												A very fun game with some moral choices. You can go one of four ways: 1) Complete stealth; nobody ever detects you at all and you only knock people out.2) No kills; you may be seen but you never kill3) Some kills; you may be seen and you try not to kill, but when it needs to happen it does4) Rambo; you run into any fight and kill everyone.Depending on what you choose, the game has three different outcomes based off your "chaos" level. Higher and lower chaos will affect different things as well as change the last level.The swordfighting mechanics are great and you will never survive a fight using just the sword in a group of 3+. Using your magic powers via the Outsider's mark you can stop time, teleport around and generally have fun. Plot is simple but passable. Definitely a game worth multiple playthroughs, and each one may vary in time. A kill-everyone run takes only about 8 hours while a full stealth could take up to 30-40 hours. The DLC is very fun, in the Knife of Dunwall and the Brigmore Witches you get to play as an antagonist from the main game, the assassin Daud. The only other DLC currently is the Dunwall City Trials, which are very fun for everyone.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2012
												Dishonored is the best game made by Arkane. It is able to balance well the action and stealth gameplay with a great level design. It is a game that allows you to play as you like without feeling to be railroaded or punished by adopting a certain play style or paths. Thus its replayability is high, even if the story feels like a fatality which you can't change much the outcome. However you can influence its morality, not by making the classical RPG two sided choices but by actually playing the game, each of your actions weights in the final result, which is quite an innovative game design standpoint that makes this game so special. On the pure artistic standpoint, it has a distinct personality that cast it apart from most productions. While a lot of the actual material and fluff of this game is purely optional, if you actually make a halt in your journey, read, watch and listen to all Dishonored has to offer you may discover it has a lot to say behind the actual game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												Fans of DX:HR will find a lot to like in Dishonored. Though the setting and story are very different, it has many of the same awesome elements, like powers (some passive, some active), fantastic stealth and non-lethal gameplay options, and multiple ways to access areas / complete objectives. You can kill people, but if your death toll gets too high, things can get uncomfortable for you by way of more rats, more weepers and everyone thinking you are a complete jerk. The game monitors this with Chaos - minimal or no kills keeps you at low chaos. "Chaos" is an apt word, I think, because at higher chaos levels, having to deal with more hordes of vicious rats and rabid plague victims trying to kill you does make things a bit chaotic.The stealth is a bit different than DX:HR as there's no cover action. Cover is just whatever you are hiding behind. There is, however, a lean function. At first I wasn't keen on it and wanted to be able to "lock on" to cover items, but once I got used to it, I liked the fluidity of it.I recommend that you not try for achievements on the first playthrough. You'll unlock some of them along the way regardless, but going after Clean Hands or some of the others before you're familiar with the game (and all the ways you can accidentally kill people) is just going to be frustrating.Since I can't review DLC separately, I'll do that here, too. I haven't played The Dunwall Trials, but I just finished up the two story DLCs, The Knife of Dunwall and The Brigmore Witches. Together they make one story, and you play as a different (and very interesting) character from the main game. I thought that they were very well done, and felt like a rich addition to the game. Unlike many DLC, they didn't feel like "more of the same" - though the basics are the same, your DLC character has access to some different powers, items and upgrades. The story runs concurrent to the events of Dishonored, and I suggest playing the main game through completely before the DLC for the added richness provided by the combined perspectives.My only complaint is that the game menu design makes it take entirely too long to start up the game and navigate to where you load a DLC save.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												I didn't get around to playing this until a free weekend gave me the chance to test whether or not my PC could handle this game at all. When it turned out my PC could, and quite well at that, I found myself running around a quirky Steampunk Victorian England... place filled with gross rats and strange looking people. Most of whom wanted to attack me. And I got to respond to them sneaky-like or with a wide assortment of deadly weapons and abilities. It reminds me quite alot of Deus Ex: Human Revolution in its gameplay, except of course this game focuses more on the main storyline rather than having a bunch of side-quests to distract you. I mean, there are side-quests, but the ones I did actually led to giving me more options to complete the main story thing I was really there to do, which I found really cool. I've always had a thing about side-quests in games, especially when the plot is seemingly something of great time-sensitive urgency like finding your father before the post-apocalypse eats him alive (Fallout 3), hunting a renegade wizard with a seriously murderous revenge plan (Baldur's Gate II: Shadowns of Amn), or an extremely destructive dragon who likes to set stuff on fire (Skyrim), that all the side-questing I'd do when this major issue was going on just seemed... unnatural. My character has more important things to do than to hunt some fire-breathing ants, retake some girl's keep, or mess around with some thieves (Though at least Fallout 3 and Skyrim let you keep playing after the end, which would be the logical time to do all this other stuff). So to have Dishonored's side-quests be "do this and i'll give you a tip about how to deal with your main objective" just seemed kinda neat to me in that regard. Didn't feel like I was getting side-tracked, but was rather finding better ways to take care of my original business.Anyway, the gameplay is good and the story, while beatable in ~10-12 hours and having some plot points that were a bit too predictable, works fine as well. I was also surprised by the number of voice actors I recognized, and didn't know whether that was something I should be proud of for having such a good memory or embarassed of because it means I pay attention too much. The only real issue I have with the game is that the game is one gigantic moral choice from start to finish. Everything you do will end up affecting the ending... but only in the sense of "good" or bad" (though there is a middle ending apparently, but no achievement for it). The end result being that you basically have to do two playthroughs where once you are a huggly saint who kills nobody, not even people who deserve it, and the other time where you leave so many corpses in your wake that you probably could use the bodies to walk across all the water you cross in a boat during this game.Bringing up DX:HR again, it had the same thing except it didn't affect the ending and only related to achievements, and therefore was not a moral choice system but rather just different options to solve the same problem, with minor rewards or penalties depending on your choices. And this is where Dishonored has a problem, because unlike DX:HR where both the Stealth and Combat style of play were fun and interesting, Dishonored is clearly geared towards more violent solutions. You only get two abilities that let you take people out non-lethally (an attack from behind and a ranged tranquilizer crossbow thing with pretty limited ammo). I mean you can use the other abilities to help too, like blink and the time stop to help bypass enemies, but that's really it.Or... you can shoot people with guns, slash them with swords, dive on people from the top of buildings, get a pack of ravenous plague rats to overwhelm your foes, mind-control someone to set themselves up for an unintended suicide, stop time and shoot a bunch of people in the head at once, Set traps for enemies to walk into and die horribly, take over turrets and other hostile devices to work against their former allies, and... yeah I think you understand where I'm going with this. There's alot more fun and interesting ways to make people die horribly in this game than there are to simply have them take a long nap. So play through the game once as the huggly saint for the achievements, then spend the rest of your time being a murderous psychopath bent on ending all life you come across.Anyway. I write too much as usual, so I think I shall wrap this up by answering the only question that matters: Is it fun? And yes, it is quite alot of fun. And with the ability to go back and replay specific missions to do things differently or just find more ways to mess about (a major source of appeal to me in Hitman: Blood Money), I can see myself playing this game quite alot more despite having beaten it now twice in only two days. And I still have the DLC's to do.So yes. Play it. Especially if you like Action-RPG things like Deus Ex or Bioshock. I'm glad I picked this up. :D

												About time I recommend this excellent game! Dishonored is a stealth based First person action game. The best part of the game is the choices, although the dialogues don't contain a lot of choices the gameplay does. You can play as I played my first play-through, spare everyone or just be a crazy killer using a lot of cool spells. Many see Dishonored as Assassin Creed in first person. Although bear in mind this game does contain a few flaws mostly being bugs, the pros are still way more than the cons.Dishonored have a quite unique graphic style as well, set in a "Steam punk, Victorian age"Final Verdict: A must buy, especially if you enjoyed the Thief franchise.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2013
												I just realized that I never got around to recommending this, so I'll do it now. I'm not going to try to write a review, but I want to explain why I love this game so much.I love Dishonored because it puts me in a world filled with intricately linked systems and sets me free to experiment with them. Every item effects every other item in logical ways, producing a depth of interactivity that is incredibly deep, with combinations of systems coming naturally as you think about your environment as an actual world.I love that Dishonored doesn't try in vain to deliver photorealistic graphics, and instead utilizes a gorgeous visual style of watercolors and caricatures combined with surrealist lighting. Where so many other games struggle for life-like detail and end up slipping into the uncanny valley, Dishonored uses a non-realistic approach that is evocative and suggestive, making every character and locale a joy to look at.I love how Dishonored feels when I'm moving around. Every motion in the game is so beautifully smooth, from running to climbing, jumping to sliding. After playing Dishonored it's hard to go back to games where sprinting is limited and I can't jump up and grab a ledge to get over a wall. Mirror's Edge did running so well, and Dishonored surpasses it in every way.I love playing Dishonored because of all the options I've given when approaching a situation. There are countless ways through each area and multiple solutions to each objective, making stealth and combat equally viable playstyles.I could go on and on, but I'm going to cut this short. Simply put, it's a game that does nearly everything right. Every single aspect of the gameplay is masterfully crafted and polished to perfection. Buy this game. Buy it right now.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												Don't get me wrong, Dishonored IS a good game. The gameplay in it is fantastic, the setting is really cool and interesting, and the pure number of ways you can deal with just about any scenario is nothing short of awe-inspiring. However, it does have its claws, most of which settle around the story and how it frames its characters, but it's best to try to be ignorant of them if you want to get the most out of this game. Just play it and try not to get too invested in the story because the game won't really reward that investment. I'll list my issues below in a spoiler, but if you are even thinking about buying this game, grab it.  Characters as a whole never really feel like people, they come off as robotic cardboard cutouts most of the time, primarily because they don't seem to ever react to anything. This is something that if you notice it, it's hard to ignore if you are trying to get into the story. The city itself is interesting, it's just that the flatness of the characters never really makes it feel alive.  The other problem that I have with the game is how it calculates how your actions "impact" the rest of the story. Whether or not you get a good ending is mostly determined by how many people you have killed and how much general "chaos" you have created. However... I went through my playthrough taking mostly knock outs and only killing someone if I needed to silence them before they rang the other guards. Despite these tactics I was still getting high chaos ratings at the end of every mission because of the bodycount tha I was hitting. None of these bodies would ever be found, and most of the people who ever saw me are now dead, and yet still, everyone knows who I am, and the city is going to hell. I'm not dropping corpses to the rats, I'm not charging guards head on, and yet the game still treats me the same way simply because of this bodycount. It's actually frustrating, because the moments where you'll find yourself seen and then have to fight your way are the BEST part of the game. Summoning a rat swarm at the top of a tower, and accidently luring all the guards in the area up the steps, then throwing a grenade too kill every one of them because I'm cornered shouldn't make me a saint. At the same time however, that's just one section out of four in the level and even if I don't kill a single soul after this I'll still get high chaos because I happened to kill eight people out of necessity. It just feels like the emergent gameplay side of Dishonored conflicts with the morality system in a way that punishes the player on the story end of the game because they wanted to play Dishonored the "fun" way. Again, fantastic game and this is a gripe I have with it, but the more you refuse to care about the morality/chaos system, the more fun you'll have.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												This game is by far my favourite on Steam, and I would totally reccomend it to anybody who likes stealth games. This game is set apart from the rest by its astounding, immersive atmosphere. The soundtrack is beautiful, originally composed, and totally fits the theme. The level design is rather clever because it's very, very easy to get the objective and get out, but the replayability and challenge comes from collecting every last item and bit of money in the game. The controls feel extremely fluid and responsive, unlike other stealth games I've played which is a great bonus, and grounds for some of the parkour DLC gamemodes. Graphics are good considering the game's release, however the art style definitely redeems it a bit. Unlike the Hitman series, this game is very much playable going loud as well, because it is almost done in a Payday 2 sort of way. This doesn't compromise stealth at all though, as it was truly built for that I feel.This doesn't even mention the DLC, which, is definitely worth it as it ties up some loose ends and provides a lot more gameplay. The Dunwall trials are some fun challenge maps.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												This game completely exceeded my expectations. When I first saw the trailer gameplay, I quickly dismissed it as a Bioshock rip-off (actually in some ways it is, like being able to use superhuman powers like summon rats to kill enemies or even manipulate time and the overall creepy tone of the game with the Weeper xombie-like enemies that reminded me of the deranged Splicers from the Bioshock games) but the overall gameplay is a lot more fun than Bioshock 1 or 2 (I haven't played Infinite yet). The reason is because it allows for so many different options to either bypass or eliminate enemies. For example the Blink teleportation power allows for quick teleporting over short distances that can be used to access difficult areas or instantly appear behind enemies and dispatch them. There are many hiding places as well for stealth playthroughs, such as hiding underneath tables and fireplaces to avoid contact with enemies. Speaking of stealth, the game actually encourages you to not kill people other than your targets by the increase of rats and Weepers in each level depending on how many people you have killed. The story is serviceable but a bit generic, as it basically involves a government bodyguard who is framed for the murder of his Empress by his own comrades and must exact revenge on his adversaries with the obligatory plot twists added for good measure. The graphics are pretty good (I only ran it on medium-high and I only encountered minor buffering problems), but I didn't really like the cartoon-like visual style of the game because it looked kind of weird.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												Imprisoned, in a dark; dank cell, stripped of your pride and honour, the Empress who you guarded with your life killed under your very nose, and her daughter snatched away. These thoughts press on your mind as you sit in your cell, awaiting your unfair execution. Your attention is snapped back to reality when a tray of soggy looking food is slid under the cell door, only holding your attention momentarily, except for the small piece of paper with a scrawled note on it. You pull apart the bread to find the key to your cell door hidden in it. With freedom within your grasp, and redemption close behind it, what path will you take? Will you slaughter everyone in your path, and climb your way to your goal upon a pile of corpses? Or will you slip through the shadows undetected, leaving a trace no more than the entrance guard sleeping under a bush? The choice is yours.All in all, I really enjoyed this game, from start to finish. The story, though predictable, was both emotionally engrossing and enjoyable.The art style is gorgeous, the graphics breathtaking, and the effects mesmerising.The gameplay is smooth, tactile, and well thought out.The range of paths to a goal are almost overwhelming, whether you want to wipe a building clean, slip through undetected, or take every enemy out, one by one, like a ninja, noone aware of your presence.And finishing an objective can be acheived through various means too. Will you slaughter your target mercilessly, staring into his eyes as his consciousness slips away, will you sabotage something so his death appears accidental, or will you bribe the local gang leader to make them "disappear"And your decisions have an effect on the outcome too. You can feel the distaste in the boatman's speech as he tells you of the screams he hears coming from the building you infiltrated, or his praise as he commends you on your wise course of action. Aditionally there are multiple end cutscenes, each a glimpse at the effect your endeavours have on society.I know this is a long review, but I really enjoyed this game, and I believe it's a must have, both for the stealth gamer, and the action epic alike.I can't recommend this game more.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												This game. Man. This game. Right, so Arkane Studios had me at hello. Every game they had something to do with development in; I loved. Dark Messiah: Might & Magic was the first game I ever played by them, and man. I PLAYED THE MOTHER ♥♥♥♥ING♥♥♥♥♥♥OUT OF THAT GAME. Then Bioshock 2, CoD: WaW (level design).  This review might be slightly biased due to my love for both Bethesda and Arkane Studios; so heed my warning. I am also not judging the DLC that had been released for Dishonored, for I haven't even touched it. Right, so after 85 hours, I can rightfully say that I practically know most of the game, inside and out. Played it on the hardest difficulty without killing anyone and without being spotted once through the entire playthrough. So a brief rundown on what Dishonored is. It's a stealth based action game, based in a steampunk Victorian Britain. It's very much a "choose your own path" game. You can run through it without killing a single being, or without being noticed by anyone; or you can get spotted by every one and decapitate them to your heart's content. Most of the level design also allows you to play through a map multiple  times, finding lots of ways to clear them. The game is very story intensive. But the beauty of it is; if you don't wish to explore the lore and story of every inch of the game's setting... Then don't. There are hundreds of books in the game. I literally mean hundreds. Which tell you the story of Dunwall and the isles that surround it. And you can choose to read none of them. It's hard to say what's wrong with the game, for I can't think of much... The AI is pretty good, along with the stealth. It's one of the games which make me happy because the fact you're in the shadow, doesn't make you completely invisible; it just makes you less visible. The sword-play is simple and fun to use. The powers are great too. However, I note that it's quite irritating when you want to play a complete passive game; and it forces you to equip your sword at all times. I would prefer to wield two powers in each hand, rather than have my sword constantly there; even if I weren't to use it.  Overall; I believe the game has a beautiful art-style and setting; great game-play, and it often makes you feel ♥♥♥♥ing awesome after you've successfully done something. Like if you choke-out a guard, get spotted; toss the knocked-out guard into the one that spotted you; making him stumble to the floor before you jump ontop of him and slice his neck open. There are probably loads of negatives I've missed out, but like I said. Biased. If anything, it would be replayablity. There are things there to make second play-throughs fresh; but really, after you've both killed everyone, then let everyone live; there's not much to explore unless you go hardcore. I would probably r8 it 8/8 m8.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												Fans of DX:HR will find a lot to like in Dishonored. Though the setting and story are very different, it has many of the same awesome elements, like powers (some passive, some active), fantastic stealth and non-lethal gameplay options, and multiple ways to access areas / complete objectives. You can kill people, but if your death toll gets too high, things can get uncomfortable for you by way of more rats, more weepers and everyone thinking you are a complete jerk. The game monitors this with Chaos - minimal or no kills keeps you at low chaos. "Chaos" is an apt word, I think, because at higher chaos levels, having to deal with more hordes of vicious rats and rabid plague victims trying to kill you does make things a bit chaotic.The stealth is a bit different than DX:HR as there's no cover action. Cover is just whatever you are hiding behind. There is, however, a lean function. At first I wasn't keen on it and wanted to be able to "lock on" to cover items, but once I got used to it, I liked the fluidity of it.I recommend that you not try for achievements on the first playthrough. You'll unlock some of them along the way regardless, but going after Clean Hands or some of the others before you're familiar with the game (and all the ways you can accidentally kill people) is just going to be frustrating.Since I can't review DLC separately, I'll do that here, too. I haven't played The Dunwall Trials, but I just finished up the two story DLCs, The Knife of Dunwall and The Brigmore Witches. Together they make one story, and you play as a different (and very interesting) character from the main game. I thought that they were very well done, and felt like a rich addition to the game. Unlike many DLC, they didn't feel like "more of the same" - though the basics are the same, your DLC character has access to some different powers, items and upgrades. The story runs concurrent to the events of Dishonored, and I suggest playing the main game through completely before the DLC for the added richness provided by the combined perspectives.My only complaint is that the game menu design makes it take entirely too long to start up the game and navigate to where you load a DLC save.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2012
												Dishonored is the best game made by Arkane. It is able to balance well the action and stealth gameplay with a great level design. It is a game that allows you to play as you like without feeling to be railroaded or punished by adopting a certain play style or paths. Thus its replayability is high, even if the story feels like a fatality which you can't change much the outcome. However you can influence its morality, not by making the classical RPG two sided choices but by actually playing the game, each of your actions weights in the final result, which is quite an innovative game design standpoint that makes this game so special. On the pure artistic standpoint, it has a distinct personality that cast it apart from most productions. While a lot of the actual material and fluff of this game is purely optional, if you actually make a halt in your journey, read, watch and listen to all Dishonored has to offer you may discover it has a lot to say behind the actual game.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												Being an assassin never felt so sad. Corvo's silence is the home of coiled emotions that are merely tamed or kindled by the player's. And Dunwall: Dunwall is a place that feels so alive it could devour you; but so alive in its desolation and poision, how odd; and Dunwall's soul is ever by, but ever so elusive. Truly, in Dishonored, choosing mercy or revenge is of great consequence. Chaos is ours. Empress Emily's cruel melancholy or tender hope, echoing from our actions, will touch us; whatever joy or regret come, they be ours too. Aesthetically, the game is wonderful. Its world-design is vivid and immersive, eerie and beautiful at once; throughout, the textures are blurred so that the world appears to be painted in pastels: if we didn't know that this is in great measure due to low-res textures, we could say that the pastel-style is deliberate. The sounds, too: they wrap us with their nightmarish draperies.Now, the characters have very distinct looks: they are stylised to the point of being emblems of their heart's secrets; can we not tell, or at least surmise, from their countenances or their shapes what their marrows hide? And they are richly human, harlequin, these characters: if not our heart, then another heart may tell us of their wins and woes. And if no one else so truly, Emily, Empress Emily, does care about Corvo's compassion, or his dread touch. When we are let loose here in Dunwall, to play with its loving and its wicked inhabitants as we please, do we not ask ourselves if the chaos, grand or vanished, in our wake is our very soul's, and not Corvo's?

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2013
												Vooshka! After raving about Bioshock Infinite (BS:I), I wasn't expecting to experience another game of that quality for quite some time.  But Dishonored is AMAZING and easily BS:Infinite's equal - and that's no small compliment!!!  Comparing the two is inevitable.  If I'd happened to have played Dishonered first, I'd still be comparing them but just doing it in my  BS:I review instead.Like BS:I, Dishonered has a very richly detailed world with tons of character and characters.  As great as the storytelling and ambiance is, what sets Dishonored apart for me is the variety and excellence of gameplay:You can see the influence of games like Bioshock (guard the little girl); Half Life (same lead artist - just look at the barricades and tall boys); Thief (the stealth elements) and Deux Ex (multiple ways/paths to achieve goals).  However, it's important to note that the game doesn't feel derivative at all.  It manages to riff off all the best elements but is still very much it's own game and not a knock-off.While stealth is encouraged, you have many ways to complete an objective including going in guns blazing. The synergy of your various powers work well together and really succeeds in making you feel very ninja-esque!Pacing is also excellent.  The story and and new abilities progress fast enough that things are constantly interesting but not so fast that you're overwhelmed or lost.This is another one of those 5 star games that I just didn't want to end and is easily on my MUST BUY list!  If you haven't played it yet go buy it... NOW!I'm off to jump into the DLC...

content:
Posted: April 19, 2013
												About time I recommend this excellent game! Dishonored is a stealth based First person action game. The best part of the game is the choices, although the dialogues don't contain a lot of choices the gameplay does. You can play as I played my first play-through, spare everyone or just be a crazy killer using a lot of cool spells. Many see Dishonored as Assassin Creed in first person. Personally I say this game really reminds me of Thief, although Dishonored contains a lot more murdering. I also finished the "Knife of Dunwall" which let's you play as the Assassin Daud adding some more powers, gadgets and about three more missions. The story in Dishonored is pretty damn good as well. Although bear in mind this game does contain a few flaws mostly being bugs, the pros are still way more than the cons.Dishonored have a quite unique graphic style as well, set in a "Steam punk, Victorian age"Final Verdict: A must buy, especially if you enjoyed the Thief franchise.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Dishonored is a game that I almost completely missed out on. The first time I ever heard dishonored was when I was looking up a list of B games. I was buying some games for my Xbox, and saw that this game was getting great reviews from people. At the time it was only 25$ so I got it along with some others and waited a little while to play it. I can easily say this is one of my favorite games of all time. I am normally against stealth games, but this game is so different.This game is my "Half-life". I eagerly await a sequel in any form. I could describe why this game is good, but I doubt I could do it justice. I will say that it has thrilling story, fun and non-limited game play as well as a new type of art design. Without taking the extreme graphic engine approach, Arcane made a game that looks vivid and nice all around. This game is a solid 10/10. Generally with a good game, at some point I would say something like "I don't agree with this decision but its not a big deal". However, with Dishonored I never found myself saying that. Even the DLC game of the year content that I only recently tried has been great! I completely recommend this game.
