number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												I didn't get around to playing this until a free weekend gave me the chance to test whether or not my PC could handle this game at all. When it turned out my PC could, and quite well at that, I found myself running around a quirky Steampunk Victorian England... place filled with gross rats and strange looking people. Most of whom wanted to attack me. And I got to respond to them sneaky-like or with a wide assortment of deadly weapons and abilities. It reminds me quite alot of Deus Ex: Human Revolution in its gameplay, except of course this game focuses more on the main storyline rather than having a bunch of side-quests to distract you. I mean, there are side-quests, but the ones I did actually led to giving me more options to complete the main story thing I was really there to do, which I found really cool. I've always had a thing about side-quests in games, especially when the plot is seemingly something of great time-sensitive urgency like finding your father before the post-apocalypse eats him alive (Fallout 3), hunting a renegade wizard with a seriously murderous revenge plan (Baldur's Gate II: Shadowns of Amn), or an extremely destructive dragon who likes to set stuff on fire (Skyrim), that all the side-questing I'd do when this major issue was going on just seemed... unnatural. My character has more important things to do than to hunt some fire-breathing ants, retake some girl's keep, or mess around with some thieves (Though at least Fallout 3 and Skyrim let you keep playing after the end, which would be the logical time to do all this other stuff). So to have Dishonored's side-quests be "do this and i'll give you a tip about how to deal with your main objective" just seemed kinda neat to me in that regard. Didn't feel like I was getting side-tracked, but was rather finding better ways to take care of my original business.Anyway, the gameplay is good and the story, while beatable in ~10-12 hours and having some plot points that were a bit too predictable, works fine as well. I was also surprised by the number of voice actors I recognized, and didn't know whether that was something I should be proud of for having such a good memory or embarassed of because it means I pay attention too much. The only real issue I have with the game is that the game is one gigantic moral choice from start to finish. Everything you do will end up affecting the ending... but only in the sense of "good" or bad" (though there is a middle ending apparently, but no achievement for it). The end result being that you basically have to do two playthroughs where once you are a huggly saint who kills nobody, not even people who deserve it, and the other time where you leave so many corpses in your wake that you probably could use the bodies to walk across all the water you cross in a boat during this game.Bringing up DX:HR again, it had the same thing except it didn't affect the ending and only related to achievements, and therefore was not a moral choice system but rather just different options to solve the same problem, with minor rewards or penalties depending on your choices. And this is where Dishonored has a problem, because unlike DX:HR where both the Stealth and Combat style of play were fun and interesting, Dishonored is clearly geared towards more violent solutions. You only get two abilities that let you take people out non-lethally (an attack from behind and a ranged tranquilizer crossbow thing with pretty limited ammo). I mean you can use the other abilities to help too, like blink and the time stop to help bypass enemies, but that's really it.Or... you can shoot people with guns, slash them with swords, dive on people from the top of buildings, get a pack of ravenous plague rats to overwhelm your foes, mind-control someone to set themselves up for an unintended suicide, stop time and shoot a bunch of people in the head at once, Set traps for enemies to walk into and die horribly, take over turrets and other hostile devices to work against their former allies, and... yeah I think you understand where I'm going with this. There's alot more fun and interesting ways to make people die horribly in this game than there are to simply have them take a long nap. So play through the game once as the huggly saint for the achievements, then spend the rest of your time being a murderous psychopath bent on ending all life you come across.Anyway. I write too much as usual, so I think I shall wrap this up by answering the only question that matters: Is it fun? And yes, it is quite alot of fun. And with the ability to go back and replay specific missions to do things differently or just find more ways to mess about (a major source of appeal to me in Hitman: Blood Money), I can see myself playing this game quite alot more despite having beaten it now twice in only two days. And I still have the DLC's to do.So yes. Play it. Especially if you like Action-RPG things like Deus Ex or Bioshock. I'm glad I picked this up. :D

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Grades: Longevity: 8/10 Story: 9/10 Gameplay: 8.5 / 10 Graphics: 9/10 Sound: 9/10 The main story of Dishonored portrays the journey of Corvo Attano, protector of the Empress. This is murdered by other assassins in front of Corvo and his daughter Emily, at the behest of Lord Regent, which is a corrupt and unscrupulous governor. Emily in the aftermath of these events is kidnapped by the assassins, and Raven then has to go save her and kill the Lord Regent, and other strategic targets, so Dunwall can return to normalcy. DLC in The Knife of Dunwall, we follow the demand of Daud, the assassin who killed the Empress, in search of Delilah, the name that was pointed out by The Outsider. The DLC in Brigmore Witches, continue to demand Daud, in search of Delilah. Starting with longevity, this editon took me 23 hours to complete, main story + DLC's, so longevity is not a strong point, but for the type of game it is, and how it's done, is an acceptable longevity . The story is the strongest point of the game, I enjoyed the story has moments that make us think hard in our decisions that affect its development, and has plenty of moral issues with parallels to real life. The gameplay is also one of the strengths of the game, has many similarities to Bioshock, where we have a weapon or power in his left hand and a sword in his right hand. We have two approaches to the game, the stealth approach or more "careless" approach and kill everything in front. The game also offers several ways to reach the destination, either through hidden tunnels, passes through the tops of buildings or even at street level, yet even possessar rats and get in on the ground pipelines. The combat is also well done and sometimes presents some challenge. The game's graphics are very good also, much of the gender of Bioshock, the characters very well made ​​and animated, and has very beautiful and sometimes breathtaking landscapes. The sound is also very good, although the very guards repeat their lines, gender, we always hear the same song whistled, or the guards with the same voice muttering. In short: Positives: - Gameplay - History - Characters - Landscapes - Combat - Powers Minuses: - Repetition of lines of guards FINAL GRADE: 8.7 / 10

content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												I just finished my first playthrough, and I am about to do my second, but I thought I would take the time to review the game first. The game has wonderful story, level design, and ar and theme.I enjoy stealth games, but I usually lose interest in them eventually before I beat them, but in Dishonored the story kept me engaged and playing the game to the end, and now I'm about to do it a second time to see what effect my choices have on the story. I would go out of my looking for books and notes with as much determination as looking for runes and bone charms. Sometimes the choices you make come back in really interesting ways, but I won't give spoilers (sorry!). The resolution was fantastic, I've worked hard for my low chaos run and it payed off.The early tutorial levels keep saying Play Your Way and give a bunch of examples of how to beat the level, after the tutorial there are still many ways for you to win with high and low chaos and different impacts on the story. The levels are perfect to let you sneak through vents, climb over rooftops, hide under tables or peak around corners (probably unrealistic but super helpful for not getting detected), or just run through everyone with your sword and gun. There is also a lot of variety in the levels.I am in love with steampunk. I wore goggles to school a couple of times. My friend told me it was cringe-worthy, but a bunch of people I don't even know gave me compliments, which was nice, so, maybe go out and by goggles for yourself? get steampunk a bit more mainstream? I'm getting off topic. The point is: I love steampunk and this game has fabulous whalepunk, which is basically the same thing, but more creative and original. I love all the art. The whalepunk street lights and Victorian sort of clothing, how dark it is (I mean gloomy, not hard to see), everything is great, especially the faces. Everyone is all caricatured and looks really unique. The textures are super neat also. They seem pretty realistic, but also sort of painterly. Like a really realistic oil painting.To summarize: the developers of this game deserve much more money than what they are charging, but the game is pretty old by now so it's cheaper. Lucky you.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2013
												You can play this game two very different ways, or something inbetween, and each feels different. You can go a stealth approach and look for alternative pathways, and you can even go for a non-lethal solution in every mission. Or you can use all your powers and weaponry and have a good old slaughter. What is really interesting is how the game is affected by your actions. Murder without restraint and you end up with a darker version of reality. Or keep it under wraps and keep things a little less chaotic.The graphics of this game are something unique, in an art style that suits the somewhat Steampunk dystopian world. The level design is done well, plenty of nooks to explore but without getting lost. Alternative solutions to each mission make it replayable, and in two runs you can get all achievements if you so chose to. 'Hardcore' gamers will find joy in doing a non-lethal playthrough with no powers used, but there are also challenges for pushing certain skill combinations to the limit. And with the game being chopped into mission parts, which none the less flow into each other, you can easily sit down and play just a little bit. The downside? It's a short game. DLC is cheap enough however, and you do get a quality experience for it which isn't dragged out because a game should be X hours long.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												I know many players who have finished this game say it's a little short. And after doing a complete non-lethal stealth run through myself in one afternoon I have to agree. However keep in mind that that is just one way to play Dishonored.Personally I feel that the game was designed so as to cater to all types of players, from those who prefer to sneak around and leave enemies unharmed to those who like to run around and dismember guards with your gadgets and blade. There are also optional quests that the player can partake in to receive runes to spend on abilities, with certain abilities further catering to specific playstyles.The big motivating factor for me was the fact that how you play may dictate how the climax and ending plays out. I played through twice, once as a good Corvo and the other as a bad, and both times I was satisfied by the different dialogue and overall ending. Moreover, for those achievement seekers I feel that the list of achievements for this game also promotes the player to play through more than once.One memorable chapter for me with this game was the masquerade party; I spent hours on this one level just exploring this beautifully designed area. It's like taking part in a piece of actual history, the likes of which you know does not happen anymore.Other than that, this game isn't very graphically intensive though still looks fairly good, and the combat itself is very fluid. I wish Skyrim had a similar combat system.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												This game. Man. This game. Right, so Arkane Studios had me at hello. Every game they had something to do with development in; I loved. Dark Messiah: Might & Magic was the first game I ever played by them, and man. I PLAYED THE MOTHER ♥♥♥♥ING♥♥♥♥♥♥OUT OF THAT GAME. Then Bioshock 2, CoD: WaW (level design).  This review might be slightly biased due to my love for both Bethesda and Arkane Studios; so heed my warning. I am also not judging the DLC that had been released for Dishonored, for I haven't even touched it. Right, so after 85 hours, I can rightfully say that I practically know most of the game, inside and out. Played it on the hardest difficulty without killing anyone and without being spotted once through the entire playthrough. So a brief rundown on what Dishonored is. It's a stealth based action game, based in a steampunk Victorian Britain. It's very much a "choose your own path" game. You can run through it without killing a single being, or without being noticed by anyone; or you can get spotted by every one and decapitate them to your heart's content. Most of the level design also allows you to play through a map multiple  times, finding lots of ways to clear them. The game is very story intensive. But the beauty of it is; if you don't wish to explore the lore and story of every inch of the game's setting... Then don't. There are hundreds of books in the game. I literally mean hundreds. Which tell you the story of Dunwall and the isles that surround it. And you can choose to read none of them. It's hard to say what's wrong with the game, for I can't think of much... The AI is pretty good, along with the stealth. It's one of the games which make me happy because the fact you're in the shadow, doesn't make you completely invisible; it just makes you less visible. The sword-play is simple and fun to use. The powers are great too. However, I note that it's quite irritating when you want to play a complete passive game; and it forces you to equip your sword at all times. I would prefer to wield two powers in each hand, rather than have my sword constantly there; even if I weren't to use it.  Overall; I believe the game has a beautiful art-style and setting; great game-play, and it often makes you feel ♥♥♥♥ing awesome after you've successfully done something. Like if you choke-out a guard, get spotted; toss the knocked-out guard into the one that spotted you; making him stumble to the floor before you jump ontop of him and slice his neck open. There are probably loads of negatives I've missed out, but like I said. Biased. If anything, it would be replayablity. There are things there to make second play-throughs fresh; but really, after you've both killed everyone, then let everyone live; there's not much to explore unless you go hardcore. I would probably r8 it 8/8 m8.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												If you're into the whole stealth game with a challenge then I would definitely recommend Dishonored. But first, watch this http://youtu.be/4EoLKdCmSv8?list=PLdFqYxukiFnG7EvH5yFH8Is7CEBuTA1uL . Dishonored is pretty cool in a sense that I didn't know you could do so many things until you actually look them up. There's a whole plethora of weapons and ways to kill things and complete missions. Also, if you like challenges you could also limit yourself from using the weapons etc even.Though one thing I feel is a little awkward is that the good endings are a little pradoxical to the gameplay? If you don't kill anything or anyone, you will most probably get the good ending. It's tough and it means you don't get to use all those cool weapons etc. Which means you probably need another playthrough to get the "full" experience.I really like how the gameplay feels quite smooth and to me, the fun doesn't really die out as fast because really, there are so many different scenarios it'll probably take a while for you to finish them all. Some things that I do not like about the game though would be the damn unskippable cutscene during one of the final missions (I think it's the only unskippable cutscene) I also felt it was a waste in the DLCs because you can't really play as Daud any much more than that. I would have at least wanted to play as Daud in the Dunwall city trials but meh, the DLCs were worth it anyway. I still got tons of fun out of them, though I think people should proceed with caution when purchasing the DLCs because they are pretty short. Unless of course you don't mind. The DLCs are interesting though and offer new perspective when you playthrough the game again.All in all, buy the game when it's on offer or below $20 and you'll probably spend a good 11-30 hours on the game depending on how fast you speedrun and stuff. All the stuff written here should be taken with a grain of salt. Watch some videos about the gameplay before making your decision. :D Have fun

content:
Posted: July 21, 2013
												For the most part I do not play games all the way through to completion without getting distracted by other games.  I played about half of Alan Wake, took a three month hiatus, then came back and finished it.  Not because the game was bad, but because there were other games I wanted to play more.  So the fact that I spent just under 30 hours sneaking all the way through Dishonored's story (during Steam's Summer Sale no less) is a testament to just how captivating this game is.I love the painted look of the graphics which proves, once again, that you do not need the latest technical wizardry to make a game pleasing to look at.  The story was good enough to keep my attention throughout  even if it did get a bit predictable.  I thought the writing was better than most games and the acting was quite good (with the exception of Piero, whoever voiced him was trying way too hard).What really drew me in and helped the game become one of my all-time favorites was the city of Dunwall itself.  It is the type of place that, if given enough attention and time, will become a character in and of itself.  I cannot emphasize enough that if you play the game, do not sprint through it just going from objective to objective and ignoring everything else.  Take your time, explore, feel the city out and learn its history, its customs, and its quirks.  If you do that the game will reward you for it.  Not in achievements, but in a deeper experience and more of a connection with what is happening around you.So to sum up, if Bioshock and Deus Ex had a baby and the child was raised by Half-Life 2 you would have the spitting image of Dishonored.  You need to buy this game right now.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												The Empress has been killed and you are the scapegoat, you have been betrayed by the spymaster and his constituants to take control of Dunwall. You are set to assasinate and extract high valued targets that put you into prison and fight to overthrow the new corrupt Lord Regent. Play how you want to play in this action-stealth filled game, do you want to be a ghost who sneaks in the shadows and prefers non-lethal or do you want to go in with explosive shot pistol rounds and fight your way to your targets. The game makes great use of both with the blink power which is one of the better ideas I've seen in gaming in a while allowing you to short-distance teleport to either sneak around or counter and flank. I will say the game starts off rather slow and your more inclined to choose full frontal assault until you get your powers and learn the game a bit, but once you start it becomes very fun exploring the various routes and paths around enemies and blockades on your way to your targets. One of the few downsides is the dialogue, there arn't many recorded lines for npc's as they say will you hear about cigars and whisky, the chances are very good. 8/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2013
												For me, this is tied with Far Cry 3 for GOTY 2012. It's such a unique and refreshing game. Very hard to stop playing. The world they created is amazing and has so much potential for many sequels. However, the story is very contained within this one game. Plenty of closure. It's a very intriguing story, too. I heard people calling the story weak, but it most certainly is not. You can play the game in a variety of ways. No killing, plenty of killing, balanced, whatever. There are quite a few ways to approach every part of every mission. There are some choices you can make in the game that does effect some dialogue and some more subtle things throughout the game, depending on what it is. It's got tons of replay value and plenty of secrets to find. You could play through it 3, 4, maybe even 5 times before you've seen everything that can happen in the game. Like I said, though, it's mostly subtle stuff, but I like that. It's not for everyone, but man, I applaud Arkane (a relatively untested studio until now) on their excellent work on this game. If you like BioShock, you'd probably love this game. But again, it really isn't just another rehash of other games. You might could say it takes some of the best gameplay elements from a number of games and combines them to create something special and unique. Really fun. It's also already got a little expansion to the game, and Bethesda is teasing more DLC to come. I sure hope there will be more!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												It's not often these days, unfortunately, that an entirely new, original series will start on a strong and striking note in the gaming mainstream. Many of the best games around today (in the mainstream), it is sad to admit, are reboots and reimagined sequels to established franchises. However, trust Bethesda to deliver a new and exciting addition to the scene with all the trimmings of any other big-budget competitor.This is a stunning game and it's enormous! And when I hear a game is enormous, I usually imagine an endless sand-box world to explore, which can sometimes not really be that good a thing. Dishonored resists this temptation and opts for a more linear sequence of smaller sandboxes, not disimilar to games like the later Splinter Cell entries. Dishonored of course is first person view, which works for it, but it's just as sneaky. Or you can go for straight up shoot-em-up action if you like. It's up to you.One of the best things about this game is you can be good at it. And when I say good I mean superhero good. Check YouTube user kekkoSoNicSyNdIcAtE for examples of this. I've never played a game that relies on talent and learning ones craft this much since Street Fighter II. The type of stuff you can pull off will amaze you doing it as much as a person watching it.The world you are thrown into is diseased, dank, Lovecraftian and dirty and it's so immersive that I could have sworn I came out of it with a layer of grime on me that I couldn't shake for days. The DLC campaigns are superb as well, markedly different to the main game and contribute interestingly to the story and experience as a whole. Most surprisingly as well, considering this game is made by Bethesda who are infamous for designing and writing great games that are hindered with silly little mistakes and flaws, I didn't encounter one singular bug.Worth every penny.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												This is an amazingly atmospheric game that supports a number of different play styles--you can be a sneaky pacifist, you can charge straight into combat, you can leave nothing in your wake but a trail of bodies (or dust)... you're set for choices. The storyline also changes subtly based on how you behave--not in an overt Mass Effect-y way, but more subtly. If you kill everyone you meet in your missions rather than sneaking by, people will begin to trust you less and be less friendly. It's a great game, and totally recommended.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												It's not often these days, unfortunately, that an entirely new, original series will start on a strong and striking note in the gaming mainstream. Many of the best games around today (in the mainstream), it is sad to admit, are reboots and reimagined sequels to established franchises. However, trust Bethesda to deliver a new and exciting addition to the scene with all the trimmings of any other big-budget competitor.This is a stunning game and it's enormous! And when I hear a game is enormous, I usually imagine an endless sand-box world to explore, which can sometimes not really be that good a thing. Dishonored resists this temptation and opts for a more linear sequence of smaller sandboxes, not disimilar to games like the later Splinter Cell entries. Dishonored of course is first person view, which works for it, but it's just as sneaky. Or you can go for straight up shoot-em-up action if you like. It's up to you.One of the best things about this game is you can be good at it. And when I say good I mean superhero good. Check YouTube user kekkoSoNicSyNdIcAtE for examples of this. I've never played a game that relies on talent and learning ones craft this much since Street Fighter II. The type of stuff you can pull off will amaze you doing it as much as a person watching it.The world you are thrown into is diseased, dank, Lovecraftian and dirty and it's so immersive that I could have sworn I came out of it with a layer of grime on me that I couldn't shake for days. The DLC campaigns are superb as well, markedly different to the main game and contribute interestingly to the story and experience as a whole. Most surprisingly as well, considering this game is made by Bethesda who are infamous for designing and writing great games that are hindered with silly little mistakes and flaws, I didn't encounter one singular bug.Worth every penny.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2013
												*English Version below. Keep in mind, that I'm not that good at speaking English, but I hope it's okay for you.*Klasse Spiel mit drei kleinen MängelnDishonored ist ein gelungener Mix aus Schleich-, Action- und Fantasyspiel. Die Steampunk-Atmosphäre wirkt gut und versetzt einen in die richtige Stimmung. Das Gameplay ist an-und-für-sich auch gut, doch hier gibt es die bereits angesprochenen Mängel:1. Das Spiel ist bis auf den höchsten Schwierigkeitsgrad (viel) zu leicht! Es gibt keine Herausforderung und somit geht einer großer Teil des eigentlich enorm tollen Spielspaßes verloren.2. Das Spiel ist u.a. deshalb zu leicht, weil das Zaubern zu mächtig ist. Vor allem mit dem Teleportzauber kann man sich ohne Probleme von a nach b bewegen, ohne überhaupt aufpassen zu müssen.Dies ist mittlerweile etwas abgeschwächt worden (weniger Reichweite, langsamere Bewegung, nicht mehr 100% lautlos), was es doch ertragbarer macht. Ich für meinen Teil habe das Spiel komplett ohne Blink (so heißt der Teleportzauber) durchgespielt, so war es schön fordernd.3. Das Nahkampfsystem ist je nach Spielweise und Art des Spielers entweder sehr gut oder sehr schlecht, in meinem Fall hat es mir überhaupt nicht gefallen. Das ist allerdings sehr spielerbezogen, ich kenne auch viele, die das Nahkampfsytem absolut lieben. Daher kann ich hier leider nur raten: Selbst ausprobieren!Dishonored ist ansonsten sehr gelungen, es spielt sich je nach Forgehen flott oder bedacht und langsam, actionlastig oder vorsichtig. Aber immer spielt es sich flüssig. Man kann auch je nach Entscheidungen das ganze Spiel durchspielen, ohne eine einzige Person zu töten! Diese besondere Herausforderung habe auch ich gemeistert, auch wenn sie extrem hart ist, da es so oft Stellen gibt, wo man beinahe stundenlang rätselt, wie man an den paar Wachen vorbei kommt, die man sonst beispielsweise einfach mit Slow-Motion erschiesst oder mit den Schwertern bearbeitet.Alles in allem ist Dishonored aber SEHR gelungen, und neben The Walking Dead hatte ich mit keinem 2012 erschienenen Titel so viel Spaß als wie mit Dishonored.**********Good game with 3 little shortcomingsDishonored is a good mixture blending of sneaky-, action- and fantasy-games. The steampunk-atmosphere is well done and it gets you into the right mood. The gameplay is good overall, but there are 3 shortcomings:1. The game is except for the highest diffiulty (way) to easy! There is no challenge and therefor it's not that much fun.2. There is expecially one reason that makes this game to easy: The kinda teleporting-spell "Blink" , which allows you to get from one place to another, is to mighty. You can't be seen doing this and you can blink yourself very far away from where you're currently standing, even without having to take the bad guys into account.The developers weakened this spell a bit (less range, you're a bit slower teleported and it's not a 100% silent anymore), what makes it a bit less superior. However, I'd still recommend everyone to try to play the game without using "Blink", just as I did it to keep it hard and challenging.3. The close-combat-system is - depending on your playstyle - either very good or very bad. For me, I didn't like it at all. But that really depends on the player, some of my friends like it very much. Sadly, the onliest piece of advice I can give you concerning the close-combat-system is: Try it yourself!Apart from that, Dishonored is very well done, depending on your playstyle it can be a very fast and full of action or slow and cautious. But no matter, how you play: It always feels smooth. You can even play through the entire game without killing any person at all! This was the hardest but also most fun challenge I set myself while playing through the game, and I did it. There are some really hard areas, where you have to think very long on how you do this, and that's what I liked the most.All in all, Dishonored is VERY well done and awesome, besides The Walking Dead there was no 2012-released title which was that fun to play from beginning to end.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												9/10An amazingly well-rounded game that makes you feel like an assassin while remaining a human being. Dishonored has managed to be a game with a seemingly overused theme, (being assassins and superpowers,) and still managed to craft it into a great game. Dishonored casts you as Corvo Attano, recently banished from your home by false accusations of murder. Now with you out of the picture, inner forces of Dunwall seek to break it apart from the inside. It is your job to uncover the true murderer... How far will you go to prove your innocence, and will you become a monster trying to? Dishonored has a unique and thrilling storyline, with a conjoined weapon and power system. Even just following a simple story mission can be nothing but good fun if you use the powers and tools given to you correctly. Dishonored is easily one of my favorite games, and you can count on it for hours of good fun and thrilling action.

												Dishonored is outstanding from my prespective! The only small con is that it can be short if you do not do side quests. Other than that the story is pretty good but, the real high point of the game is the gameplay. There are numerous ways to kill enemies and to sneak around. Also there are many choices like deciding to get revenge through killing or through different ways. If your looking for a game that is mainly about story that still maintains a good amount of action, this is the game for you. I finished the game in about 8 hours (doing most side quests on hard). I just started going through it again hoping to 100% it. So Dishonored is definently a buy if your into stealthy games like this. I give it a 10 out of 10.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
												Recommend? Yes. Buy it, buy it whenever you can. full price is 100% worth it for this game.The atmosphere is amazing. Dunwall is a city fallen into plague and the city and its people rot together, while the rich sit on top of it all as if nothing ever happened. And the more you kill the worse it gets. For everyone.The gameplay is very fun and creative, whether you play high chaos kill everyone, chop em all up and feed em to the rats, or low chaos, full ghost, clean hands good guy, this game is fun. You get crazy powers, great climbing ability and pretty decent sword skills.The story is something that seems pretty empty if you just do the main objectives, but paying attention to details, dialogue, notes, and even both sides of the story (high and low chaos) give more depth to the story and the world.Because it gives you a lot of diversity in how to play, and has achivements that are fun to get, it has a lot of replay value as well.Absolutely love this everytime I play it; I did my first casual runthrough of it about two years ago and I'm still going through for achievements and just for fun.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												Actions speak louder than words in the city of Dunwall, a cesspool of crime, corruption, and plague. Corvo Attano, the hired bodyguard for the Empress, must use everything at his disposal to clear his name and rid the city of corruption and deceit.Dishonored has surprised me in many ways, from its unique watercolor art style to its brilliant combat system. Ultimately, the game is not what I had expected after seeing the first theatrical trailer featuring a man in a jail cell. That being said, I wasn’t a fan after the first twenty minutes of play. Eventually, I put it down and moved on to other things – after a few months, I came back to give it another try. That was when I realized what I had been missing.I’ll summarize my thoughts about this game in a simple pros/cons list, but I will elaborate on each item.PROS:>Unique Art Style<The brushed watercolor style that decorates a unique city called Dunwall may initially come across as outdated and technologically inferior to other games created during the same time period. Some players may view the style with that pessimistic attitude, and some may view it as a unique work of art. I chose the latter.>Interesting Story and Deep Lore<The story is a special experience, and your actions will matter – remember who you are and whom your actions affect. Read the books you find and drop eaves on conversations to discover the surprisingly deep backstory.>Excellent Voice Acting<You will certainly recognize whom you're talking to, because the voice acting is consistently stellar throughout the entire game.>Worthwhile DLC<Although they rarely see big sales, all three DLC packages are worth your time and money.>Best Assassin Experience<There is no better assassin experience in any game. I’ll explain this below in the sections on combat and stealth.>Brilliant Stealth<The game can be completed without ever being seen by an enemy – ever. It’s a tricky thing to master, but it is a very fun way to play the game. The player may also rush into battles with guns a’blazing and blades a’sparking.>Combat Is Incredible<The combat system is intricate, diversified, and very expertly crafted. There are many ways to go about clearing an area (it rewards those who enter a battle with a plan of action). This game is much, much more fun if you are creative – trust me.CONS:>Game Length<I would have loved to see more, but perhaps that’s why we buy DLC. Also, keep in mind that the length of the game depends on how you play. Fast and furious will make the game shorter, while slow and stealthy will make the game longer. Both are great fun.>NPC Animations<Corvo's actions look swift and fluid, but the actions of other NPCs seem a little repetitive, stiff, and awkward during conversations. This may take away from how much you care for characters.>Story Vagueness<Some elements of the story are a little vague, but this is minor. Plus, it is usually fixed by digging into the lore provided by books and conversations.I would place Dishonored somewhere among my top twenty favorite video games. It’s a worthwhile experience that is always fun to revisit. Do the right thing and buy this game, already.

												Amazing game.It has everything i expect from a stealth-game, like big exploreable areas full of differen ways to get to your target, but never does this area feel empty its always full of detail, some collectibles (but not too much), and ennemyes that are based on how you play the game (going for the open offensive or trying to sneek through the place). All in all it's in my opinion one of the best singleplayer-stealth games there is at the moment.I rate 9.5/10The only negative point i can think of is the AI, because very rarely it just seems to ignore you. Oh and the guards do that classic "Oh must have been the wind" even when their decapitated mate lies in front of them, but i think that is often rather funny when it happens.Just to show you how much i liked the game: I wrote a review. I just finnished the game and thought to myself i gotta write a review! Thats how much i liked it :)Thank you for reading my review i hope it can help you!

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												9/10An amazingly well-rounded game that makes you feel like an assassin while remaining a human being. Dishonored has managed to be a game with a seemingly overused theme, (being assassins and superpowers,) and still managed to craft it into a great game. Dishonored casts you as Corvo Attano, recently banished from your home by false accusations of murder. Now with you out of the picture, inner forces of Dunwall seek to break it apart from the inside. It is your job to uncover the true murderer... How far will you go to prove your innocence, and will you become a monster trying to? Dishonored has a unique and thrilling storyline, with a conjoined weapon and power system. Even just following a simple story mission can be nothing but good fun if you use the powers and tools given to you correctly. Dishonored is easily one of my favorite games, and you can count on it for hours of good fun and thrilling action.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												Dishonored is an interesting take on the stealth genre, though I think it has some major flaws. The game takes place in a plague-ravaged, post-industrial world where the main source of power is derived from refined whale oil, which has somewhat mystical properties it seems. However, despite the engineering marvels of the day, there are also supernatural forces at play that bestow the player character with magic abilities.For my very first time playing through the game, I chose the hardest difficulty available, turned off the 'cheaty' UI elements such as objective markers, and avoided using magic entirely (with the exception of the two or three places you absolutely must use Blink).These are some of the things the game gets right:- The atmosphere is quite unique- There are a great number of ways to go about navigating through the missions- You can choose non-lethal alternatives to completing objectives- Graphics are very decent- Smooth controls- The game provides options for disabling UI elements, such as floating objective markers and NPC awareness markers. These are some of my criticisms and observations:- First of all, the Game of the Year edition comes with pre-order packs that give the player a bunch of free upgrades and money after the first mission. ♥♥♥♥ that! Why do game publishers do this? Thankfully, it is possible to get rid of the free♥♥♥♥♥♥by disabling the pre-order packs in Steam settings, then starting a new game.- The plot of the story is extremely clichéd and predictable.- The game introduces quite a bit of mystery surrounding the supernatural agent that your character comes in contact with, however there doesn't seem to be a story resolution that explains its motives. As a result, it feels like a shallow way to write in game-mechanics rather than being about good storytelling.- While the missions themselves provide a lot of leeway as to how you go about completing them, the actual story progression is entirely linear. The choices the player makes ultimately have no impact the way the events of the story unfold.- Enemies repeat the same lines over and over, which gets old very quickly.- The characters you encounter throughout the game are fairly interesting, but your ways of interacting with them are extremely limited. They often feel like walking tape recorders set up to play their few lines of dialogue, rather than actual people.- The game pushes you toward dealing with threats through lethal means by giving you a substantial arsenal of deadly weapons. Actually using them generally throws the concept of stealth out the window though. - Very early on in the game, you get the Blink ability (teleport) as part of a tutorial and you can also choose to get Dark Vision (see through walls) immediately after. These abilities in particular make the gameplay utterly trivial. It is possible to use these an unlimited number of times and quickly speed through the game.Overall Dishonored is a game worth playing, but I don't recommend it highly.

Posted: July 10, 2014
												Excelente jogo de Stealth. Com uma história de vingança não muito criativa mas competente e gráficos bonitos, ainda que não magníficos, mas com um gameplay diferenciado dos clássicos do gênero (e muito bom por sinal), esse jogo garante um bom tempo de diversão, especialmente pra quem curte stealth mas está um tanto cansado do combate com armas à distância e a perspectiva em terceira pessoa. A ambientação do jogo também é digna de nota, com uma boa variedade de cenários bem contruídos, ainda que não muito extensos, em sua maioria. Os locais que você visita passam competentemente a sensação de abandono e desolação que a história quer passar. Há também uma influência de RPG perceptível no gameplay do jogo, com uma boa porção de side-quests e ocasionais escolhas que não influenciam muito nem no decorrer da história, nem em seu final.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												Enjoyed every second of this game.  The plot was intriguing and the artstyle creates a moving painting for you to see.  Leaping around on buildings and sneaking past enemies (or slashing their chests head on, if that's your thing) is incredibly satisfying.  Enemy AI is both smart yet easy to mess around with.  Rewire a wall of light and hit your sword against a concrete wall to get them distracted, causing them to investigate and burned to ashes by the shield you just rewired.  This game is in NO way linear.  There are always tons of ways to complete missions, whether it is the way you take out your targets or infiltrating a mansion.  You can actually go the entire game without killing a soul or being detected.  I need to start another playthrough just to do this, it's that good.  I honestly have no complaints about this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10
												Dishonored is a great game. It has a good plot (for a revenge plot), surrounded by a very interesting game world.I love stealth games in general, because they incourage you to hide from enemies and not make too much noise, unlike games as the CoD or Borderlands games. Not only you don't have to be stealthy in Dishonored, but when you ARE being stealthy it is a lot more rewarding. Have you tried just going around at least one level carelessly about wether someone sees you or not? It just feels so boring, especially with Corvo's choice of weapons and his powers.I really like how in every mission you don't have to actually assassinate your tragets, and instead you can neutralize them, wether you shoot them with a sleep dart or follow certain objectives than allow you to neutralize your targets in unique ways. (for example- exposing the Lord Regent's plans and sending him to prison by doing so)Another good thing about the game is the level design. Levels are designed in a way that you'll have multiple routes to take, and something about how levels are designed creates an atmosphere that really immerses you in the game.Overall, I think Dishonored is a fantastic game, and if you enjoy playing stealth games, this one is a must.

												This is one of the best games I've played! Very well planned out with a decent story and great gameplay. The Supernatural powers you have together with normal weapons and all that is what makes this game so special I feel. I loved every second of it, one of those games where you look up and 6 hours has passed already and you're still here playing. So many different ways of getting done what you came to do...Your choice if you wanna go silent through the whole game and not kill a single person with your own weapons/abilities, but in unconventional ways, or you can go HAM and kill everyone lol, your choice. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2016
												Dishonored, an oldie but a goodie.First off, let's start with the pros -which there are a lot of- The Stealth: This game has stealth, and it does it GOOD. The suspense of listening and watching for guards walking past doors, tallboys roaming, making those dreadful noises. It's incredible. Sneaking up on a man standing on a balcony, teleporting up buildings. It's well done, no, fantastically done. The Design: Each level is designed with care, and passion, and TONS of effort. Arkane did a terrific job making sure each target was well placed, the levels weren't too long, too short. Everything is balanced, and it's great. There are so many side objectives, like runes, bone charms, side missions, and the like. It'll keep you coming back, doing so many different runs, just to grab every small little thing in the game. Through the game, you'll encounter excellently written characters, whether it be side characters, main protagonists, or even antagonists.  The Story:You are Corvo, Lord Protector of The Empress. After returning to the Empress with bad news, she is assassinated, and her heir to the throne, Emily, is kidnapped. You are framed, and as the title implies, are "Dishonored." After escaping prison and coming to the Loyalist Conspiracy, you are confronted by the Outsider in a dream, and are given magical powers to take revenge on those who helped wrong you. Incredible setup, and even better execution. Never once through this game did I ever stop to think about why or how this is happening, because the writers have intricately and delicately crafted an amazing story about a man seeking retribution for the loss of the Empress, and the heir to her throne, Emily. Now onto the cons. Game can bug:I haven't had this happen to me personally, but the game can bug. Like say, the screen going black, or a guard spazzing out when thrown down. Can be a bit boring: With all the unskippable cutscenes, I felt like I was watching a movie more than playing a game. But, that's mainly all I've got, hopefully this helps some people who are buying this game to prepare for Dishonored 2.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2016
												Hooooly crap. This is a pretty ♥♥♥♥ing good game. And I'll tell ya why.Story is amazing. You will actually care about stuff, whether it's th characters you meet or to the situations your faced with. The lore is super rich with interesting things never even mentioned in the game, so if you're into that, you won't feel left out. And it's easy to the story you want, I'll get back to that. The gameplay is also amazing. It's fluid, you'll always be able to do what you want with some creative thinking, and all powers have a point. (Only thing that kinda sucks are the bone charms. They are pretty lackluster compared to the rest of the game) the way the mechanics are crafted and blended lead to neither stealth or violent combat to feel incomplete, so either play style or a blend of both feels great. Oh yeah. If you love being not seen and spend more time surveying an area than a bored pedophile at a museum, you'll love this game. If you love violence and hurting people to a worrying, almost psychopathic degree, you'll love this game. And not only do you actions have full gameplay support, the story adapts well to what you do. It doesn't boast a fancy interchangeable story like its the only thing worth the game and blends nicely into the story. Only issue for you Michael Myers out there, the game will be considerably shorter if you murder kill everybody (unless you suck). But it's just as fun, and this game deserves at least another playthough anyway, so it's nothing game ruining. Because seeing someone devoured by rats while their friends and colleges watch is very satisfying if you resent the touch of another human. And for you moral objectors and social justice warriors, you can play the entire game with killing anyone, even the targets, instead using wit and some detective work to neutralize them if your conscience desires a more nonviolent way of making problems "go away"Please, this game is worth your time. It's worth two times the price it is and you will love it

content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
 This entire thing is going to be a spoiler because i'm too lazy to type this over and over again.OKAY! So dishonored is a stealth game where your choice matters. If you choose to kill everyone, you get high chaos.If you choose to spare everyone, you get low chaos. You also get the chance to get extremely high chaos in the high chaos route. And in a few of the DLCs you get the play as Daud, get improved blink (Time freezes when you blink as Daud) AND EVERYTHING IS FUN! Because you get a variety of assassinations, and you get the chance to ruin peoples lives so they suffer because of you. Oh, and when you brand Campbell, you see him near your weapons crate as an unconcious Weeper! It makes me feel bad for using the brand on him.You also get to jump off a bridge and live by using the drop assassination. Yaaaay!The game is just fun overall, i bought every single DLC and i thought it was worth it. Especially because you get to play Daud with different types of Mines, and also help the opposite side in the gang war. The Dead Eels. I hope you have a good time while playing this game. I'm still trying to beat it while looking like a pro but i can't aim, coordinate, or think.  By the way this game is fun to abuse powers in. Especially the windblast power. <3

content:
Posted: February 10
												Dishonored is a great game. It has a good plot (for a revenge plot), surrounded by a very interesting game world.I love stealth games in general, because they incourage you to hide from enemies and not make too much noise, unlike games as the CoD or Borderlands games. Not only you don't have to be stealthy in Dishonored, but when you ARE being stealthy it is a lot more rewarding. Have you tried just going around at least one level carelessly about wether someone sees you or not? It just feels so boring, especially with Corvo's choice of weapons and his powers.I really like how in every mission you don't have to actually assassinate your tragets, and instead you can neutralize them, wether you shoot them with a sleep dart or follow certain objectives than allow you to neutralize your targets in unique ways. (for example- exposing the Lord Regent's plans and sending him to prison by doing so)Another good thing about the game is the level design. Levels are designed in a way that you'll have multiple routes to take, and something about how levels are designed creates an atmosphere that really immerses you in the game.Overall, I think Dishonored is a fantastic game, and if you enjoy playing stealth games, this one is a must.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												Short Story:  BUY THIS GAME (Game of the Year Edition)In my opinion there really aren't a great deal of quality stealth/assassin type games that exist. Of course there are the Assassin's Creed games (among others); however, Dishonored should definitely be considered among the top 5 (if not the best) stealth/assassin games of all time. The artstyle is great, the voice acting is pretty great as well, and the gameplay is superb. Every game has its flaws, but the only one I can think of for Dishonored is that they should have done more with the game.As of this moment I've put about 50 hours into the game and have played through the main game about 4 times. I have also played through the DLC about the same amount and I can say that I was never disappointed at any point through my time with the game. There were a few inconveniences (minor glitches that popped up a few times through my playthroughs) but overall I highly suggest you buy it. The DLC for the game is also pretty great, as it does a good job of expanding upon the main story for the characters (Daud is the man). The city trials might be the only one I would hesitate getting, as they are pretty stinking hard. Now that the price is super low, I would say there are no excuses for not getting this AMAZING game.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2016
												Hooooly crap. This is a pretty ♥♥♥♥ing good game. And I'll tell ya why.Story is amazing. You will actually care about stuff, whether it's th characters you meet or to the situations your faced with. The lore is super rich with interesting things never even mentioned in the game, so if you're into that, you won't feel left out. And it's easy to the story you want, I'll get back to that. The gameplay is also amazing. It's fluid, you'll always be able to do what you want with some creative thinking, and all powers have a point. (Only thing that kinda sucks are the bone charms. They are pretty lackluster compared to the rest of the game) the way the mechanics are crafted and blended lead to neither stealth or violent combat to feel incomplete, so either play style or a blend of both feels great. Oh yeah. If you love being not seen and spend more time surveying an area than a bored pedophile at a museum, you'll love this game. If you love violence and hurting people to a worrying, almost psychopathic degree, you'll love this game. And not only do you actions have full gameplay support, the story adapts well to what you do. It doesn't boast a fancy interchangeable story like its the only thing worth the game and blends nicely into the story. Only issue for you Michael Myers out there, the game will be considerably shorter if you murder kill everybody (unless you suck). But it's just as fun, and this game deserves at least another playthough anyway, so it's nothing game ruining. Because seeing someone devoured by rats while their friends and colleges watch is very satisfying if you resent the touch of another human. And for you moral objectors and social justice warriors, you can play the entire game with killing anyone, even the targets, instead using wit and some detective work to neutralize them if your conscience desires a more nonviolent way of making problems "go away"Please, this game is worth your time. It's worth two times the price it is and you will love it

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2016
												Dishonored, an oldie but a goodie.First off, let's start with the pros -which there are a lot of- The Stealth: This game has stealth, and it does it GOOD. The suspense of listening and watching for guards walking past doors, tallboys roaming, making those dreadful noises. It's incredible. Sneaking up on a man standing on a balcony, teleporting up buildings. It's well done, no, fantastically done. The Design: Each level is designed with care, and passion, and TONS of effort. Arkane did a terrific job making sure each target was well placed, the levels weren't too long, too short. Everything is balanced, and it's great. There are so many side objectives, like runes, bone charms, side missions, and the like. It'll keep you coming back, doing so many different runs, just to grab every small little thing in the game. Through the game, you'll encounter excellently written characters, whether it be side characters, main protagonists, or even antagonists.  The Story:You are Corvo, Lord Protector of The Empress. After returning to the Empress with bad news, she is assassinated, and her heir to the throne, Emily, is kidnapped. You are framed, and as the title implies, are "Dishonored." After escaping prison and coming to the Loyalist Conspiracy, you are confronted by the Outsider in a dream, and are given magical powers to take revenge on those who helped wrong you. Incredible setup, and even better execution. Never once through this game did I ever stop to think about why or how this is happening, because the writers have intricately and delicately crafted an amazing story about a man seeking retribution for the loss of the Empress, and the heir to her throne, Emily. Now onto the cons. Game can bug:I haven't had this happen to me personally, but the game can bug. Like say, the screen going black, or a guard spazzing out when thrown down. Can be a bit boring: With all the unskippable cutscenes, I felt like I was watching a movie more than playing a game. But, that's mainly all I've got, hopefully this helps some people who are buying this game to prepare for Dishonored 2.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												It's very easy to take the quality of a game like Dishonored for granted.Having just completed Dishonored on my first run (Very Hard, no kills, no alerts, old-school ghost run - I didn't even kill any rats!) I found it to be an immersive and very enjoyable game with plenty to distract you from your objectives whether it's a distant part of a map you want to challenge yourself to reach or just listen nearby to the hilarious converstions between the characters as they interact.The world of Dunwall is easy to lose yourself in, it's depth is complete and it's almost believeable that you are in fact the Empress' protector that the world's characters both fear and envy. The sheer quality of the game is massive, and it's surprising (until you think about the quality of Bethesda games in general) at the work put in to making every part of Dishonored unique and attractive, each level having areas non-essential to the core of the game, lending to exploration and inviting the curious to find alternative route.Every mission can be done in a myriad of ways ranging to the completely non-lethal to the chaotic anti-hero and most people will find themselves paused to listen or watch something unexpected or unannounced, often they can be missed if you leave an area too soon after an objective is completed or if you happen to find an alternate route.Each cut scene is meticulously crafted and will change depending on your actions through the game - not just the level.ALL of the voice acting is superb quality, though deliberately cheesy in parts - it fits the world it inhabits nicely.Dunwall is meant to be a slightly ridiculous and very ominous place. The scene and tone it sets is impossible to miss.I really enjoyed the difficulty on Very Hard, the characters have great vision and you really have to be careful to avoid their field of view, they're tough if they're alerted but Corvo is an agile and deadly foe.In fact despite how amazing the game is my only disappointment is the abilities Corvo has are limited to a single key, but it's easy to pick them using the keyboard numbers or the quick ability menu but I can only wonder how tedious it might be for those who either have to or choose a controller but it's a small price to pay I'll be honest and you won't notice it for long.Either way I'm disappointed I didn't pick this up sooner and since there are many endings and some additional, hightly-acclaimed DLC, I will certainly play through it again and I recommend people grab a copy, whether it's on sale or not.Dishonored is a must-have game in my book.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2013
												Extremely good, but could have been so much more.Essentially all the core aspects of the game are excellent, much of the story is highly well written, and certain aspects reveal the potential to have been incredible.Unfortunately, it does not coalesce into a greater whole, largely because of a failure in binding the story together into a greater narrative.The Outsider is particularly egregious. Every appearance of the Outsider is, quite simply, a weakening of the entity. It undermines the horrifying and potentially corruptive nature of the being, personifying it to the point of meaninglessness.When compared to possibly the most ingenious piece of storytelling, the Heart, it is truly unfortunate. Still, an excellent game all around.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												Really good game... Played on demo.... Unsure of how to set the weapon wheel to the shortcut bar, but it was okay. Still very difficult to make me want to replay the game.PROS1. Interesting storyline with 3 different endings depending on the state of chaos. 2. The powers in the game are very interesting are you can use them in a variety of ways.3. Teleporting assasins, VERY COOLCONS1. A little drab. 2. Most powers are almost meant to point the game towards chaos e.g. rat swarm, shadow kill, blood thirsty, automatically biasing the game towards the "bad" ending.3. Story seems to be biased towards the bad ending unless you prefer having no powers. 4. I was hoping for some Wolfenstein type guards e.g. armored guards who can't be stealth killed, machine guns.Suggestions:1. More neutral powers or good powers. Alternative, segment the powers into chaotic or good.2. Co-op for a large map would be interesting.3. Most skills make for good pvp. Could consider multiplayer. Imagine a game full of super powered assasins.4. Allow for actions to affect the game early on to show their consequences e.g. do something that could save Wallace and Callista from meeting their end or not do anything/do something chaotic that will end up in their deaths. EDIT: It is possble to save them. You just need low chaos.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2016
												After two horrendous modern titles; one that was a ''cinematic experience'' and the other being a pretentious corridor shooter, this game restored my faith in modern gaming.A stealth based title with an emphasis on not getting caught by guards and sentrys; each level is a large map that presents you with a waypoint to get to and lets you have at it. You aren't given directions, rather the map has  multiple ways of reaching the waypoint and its up to you to decide how to get there. Each map also has a few optional objectives that are attained through exploration, at the beginning of the map, or through eavesdropping on discussions. The main missions themselves have options in the lethal and non-lethal varieties which affect the ending you receive. The maps are large in that there are many corridors and crevices you can reach. Many doorways to enter and go through; rather than a large field where you can see for miles, you get a tight, compact city with a lot of alleys and vertical movement. The developers succeeded in creating a city that feels as a city should; tight and winding with a lot of places to scatter about and travel through. The only downside is that stealth isn't so much an option as much as the better overall choice. Combat with the knife feels somewhat clunky and awkward, and the guns have incredibly low range. The crossbows are fine, but the guns themselves are horrible, which makes sense given the historical period, but trash is still trash. The books you find are also pretty mediocre. The manner in which they're written is meant to be from an informative perspective (not first-hand accounts as is the case with the Bioshock series), but some of the books you find are so long-winded that you start tuning it out. I'm sure that some of the books ar emeant to add to the game world, but something as mundane as whaling shouldn't have a three part short story associated with it. Then there's the literal fanfiction erotica in some of the books. Looks like the Bioware writers invaded the Dishonored offices for a short period.Lastly there's unanswered questions at the end. Mainly: The Outsider. It's like they wrote a key character with a pivotal role in your character's development then completely forgot him and forgot to mention just WHAT THE HELL IS HE. I mean, I know you have deadlines but come ON. The guy is just...completely done away with. Nothing else is said. WTF. Then there's the plague and what exactly caused it. We know it was ''brought'' over but there's a few things left unsaid.But those are just slight blemishes on an otherwise versatile and enjoyable experience. The game still holds up plot-wise as a game of political intrigue and backstabbings. Overall I'd strongly recommend it.

												one of the best stealth games i've ever played. this game has a good story and very good endings that's replayable. you can either storm in and kill everyone or try to be a pacifist. the one thing i like about this game is the chaos meter, the chaos meter is a meter that can change the game around and alter the ending because you either did mass killings(bad ending) or don't kill a lot(good ending). the more people you kill the more weepers there are(basically half zombies) going to be since the disease carried by rats will eat dead bodies thus creating more weepers in your playthrough in each level, making it a little hard if you're a stealthy silent killer. this isn't a linear game (not  comparible to hitman absolution) where you go to one path, in some levels, there are multiple paths you can take but you have to explore a little to find these paths.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												Very rarely does a stealth game come around with such exquisitely built mechanics in every facet of it's production. Dishonored is one such game. It's a first person adventure that plays out however you want it to. While there is little story difference between the perfect stealth route and the massacre route through the game, the achievement hunting and high-scoring challenges will keep you coming back for playthrough after playthrough.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
												Dishonored is a first-person stealth action-adventure game set in the fictional plague ridden city of Dunwall. You play as Corvo Attano, body guard to the Empress and friend to her young daughter Emily. Framed for murder, you are forced to become an assassin and spend the majority of the game seeking those who wronged you.Gameplay for a single campaign can last anywhere from 15 to 40 hours, depending on how you go about accomplishing your objectives.Because of the games steam punk inspired art style the graphics still look great, despite it being almost four years old. This game boasts a quality soundtrack, gameplay that can be tailored to a wide range of styles, good artistic direction and a compelling story, but my favorite aspect of Dishonored is what a big emphasis it puts on players choice. The game allows you to complete each mission in a variety of ways. The more you explore your environment the more options become available to you. Because of this, how you chose to reach and accomplish objectives impacts the environment and the way the story progresses. You can do ‘low chaos’ or ‘high chaos’ runs - deciding to use stealth, weapons, or magic to move forward. Creating panic and leaving dead bodies spreads disease, increasing the number of rats and weepers roaming Dunwall city streets. Operating under stealth and choosing to spare people usually takes takes more effort, but will make the ending to your story a happier one. Making different choices vastly alters your environment and how NPCs react to you in the game, giving it good replay value.The DLCs included in the GOTY addition are worth playing. They do a good job of continuing and complementing the story but are not necessary for it to feel complete, which is how downloadable content should be.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												*Review Written on July 18th, 2013*Dishonored recently went on sale on Steam. So, of course, I purchased it and got a bit obsessed. I dropped path of the exile, which had been consuming most of my time, and started playing. I ripped through the first level or two attempting stealth, but mostly ending up killing people. By the third level, I decided to go with a non-violent route.Now, I’m going to stop right here and talk about how the general public has been treating Dishonored. Most people compare it to Assassin’s Creed, largely for two main reasons. Firstly, it released around the same time as the third Assassin’s Creed. Secondly, some of the gameplay has hints of Assassin’s Creed. This is a rather unfair comparision, however, and I’ll tell you why.The first thing that struck me while I was playing this game in a more stealthy method, is that you’re stuck in first person the whole time. To most people, this is meaningless, it simply makes it a “bad stealth game”. To those of us, however, that grew up playing Thief: The Dark Project, I instantly switched to Thief mode. Yes, first person view does make it harder to be stealthy. However, unlike Thief, you can lean around corners in Dishonored. Yes, shadows don’t make you invisible in Dishonored, but so what? They don’t make you invisible in real life, either. Shadows were a mainstay in Thief, but in Dishonored, they weren’t as vital.In Dishonored, you exchange shadows for ledges. In fact, the game is best played for stealth, if you’re good at thinking in 3d spaces. You cannot perform the parkour of Assassin’s Creed, but you’re not as clunky as in Thief. Thief relied on shadows, because you simply didn’t have the fluidity in the game to duck behind corners, or vault onto ledges. Dishonored simply requires you to think in a completely different way, and that throws a lot of people off.Now, you -can- play Dishonored as a hack and slash action RPGlite, if you want. However, you’ll unlock the bad ending that way, and you won’t get half of the achievements. If anything, the achievements, and ability to “Ghost” an entire level, is a callout to the Thief series.So I played my first playthrough of Dishonored, as I would have played Thief, and I had a FANTASTIC time playing the game. That said, I probably wouldn’t play the game a second time through as a non-violent stealther, but I might give it a go, one day, as a rabid, swashbuckling mass-murderer. You know, for the bad end and all that.If you were on the ledge about Dishonored, I can tell you this. Take the game without comparing it to other titles, and you’ll find a fairly fun, well-polished, and smooth game. Sure, there are the rare bugs, but in a gaming world where bugs are becoming more common place among shipped titles, they’re considerably rare. The game really only has three playthroughs in it for someone like me, who devours content and then moves on, but completionists might find a good two or three months of gameplay out of it. Considering the amount of time invested, compared to the money invested, any price tag under 20 dollars is a fair trade off these days.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												*Review Written on July 18th, 2013*Dishonored recently went on sale on Steam. So, of course, I purchased it and got a bit obsessed. I dropped path of the exile, which had been consuming most of my time, and started playing. I ripped through the first level or two attempting stealth, but mostly ending up killing people. By the third level, I decided to go with a non-violent route.Now, I’m going to stop right here and talk about how the general public has been treating Dishonored. Most people compare it to Assassin’s Creed, largely for two main reasons. Firstly, it released around the same time as the third Assassin’s Creed. Secondly, some of the gameplay has hints of Assassin’s Creed. This is a rather unfair comparision, however, and I’ll tell you why.The first thing that struck me while I was playing this game in a more stealthy method, is that you’re stuck in first person the whole time. To most people, this is meaningless, it simply makes it a “bad stealth game”. To those of us, however, that grew up playing Thief: The Dark Project, I instantly switched to Thief mode. Yes, first person view does make it harder to be stealthy. However, unlike Thief, you can lean around corners in Dishonored. Yes, shadows don’t make you invisible in Dishonored, but so what? They don’t make you invisible in real life, either. Shadows were a mainstay in Thief, but in Dishonored, they weren’t as vital.In Dishonored, you exchange shadows for ledges. In fact, the game is best played for stealth, if you’re good at thinking in 3d spaces. You cannot perform the parkour of Assassin’s Creed, but you’re not as clunky as in Thief. Thief relied on shadows, because you simply didn’t have the fluidity in the game to duck behind corners, or vault onto ledges. Dishonored simply requires you to think in a completely different way, and that throws a lot of people off.Now, you -can- play Dishonored as a hack and slash action RPGlite, if you want. However, you’ll unlock the bad ending that way, and you won’t get half of the achievements. If anything, the achievements, and ability to “Ghost” an entire level, is a callout to the Thief series.So I played my first playthrough of Dishonored, as I would have played Thief, and I had a FANTASTIC time playing the game. That said, I probably wouldn’t play the game a second time through as a non-violent stealther, but I might give it a go, one day, as a rabid, swashbuckling mass-murderer. You know, for the bad end and all that.If you were on the ledge about Dishonored, I can tell you this. Take the game without comparing it to other titles, and you’ll find a fairly fun, well-polished, and smooth game. Sure, there are the rare bugs, but in a gaming world where bugs are becoming more common place among shipped titles, they’re considerably rare. The game really only has three playthroughs in it for someone like me, who devours content and then moves on, but completionists might find a good two or three months of gameplay out of it. Considering the amount of time invested, compared to the money invested, any price tag under 20 dollars is a fair trade off these days.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
												Dishonored did something invigorating to the stealth genera, instead of focusing on slowly positioning yourself as required by patrols and line of sight, it allowed you to move quickly into opportunistic moments towards your goal.  You can still be sneaky and stay out of sight, but there is a conversation of ‘patience’ within the dishonored line, so that once you understand how you want to tackle some kind of  obstacle, you can just go for it.  Dishonored also intertwined among these mechanical empowering views on player agency, making the results of your actions in the earlier missions create systemic changes in future missions.  Hide and avoid combat and the last mission takes place in a military base with soldiers marching around in an orderly manner.  If you were a whirling dervish of murder and mayhem, then the last mission mirrors that chaos with incoming artillery fire and frantic soldiers.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												Ok let's make a generic category - point system for once.Gameplay: 8/10Both stealthy and rambo gameplay are possible, while perfect stealth + non-lethal or rambo w/o magic are the hardest and silent killer is the easiest. Being stealthy is much more fun though!There is character skilling but it doesn't go too deep, that's fine by me as the focus is really on the active gameplay.Controls are fluid, gameplay is diverse, multiple ways to succeed at your task.But the possibilities you have are all predefined by the dev's, there aren't any completely new ways you can discover.Graphics & Sound: 7/10The Artstyle is nice but there are textures which aren't really beautiful. The proportions of the characters look a bit weird, they have those huge hands and the characters don't really look unique.Sound is good, music is fine, too.Story & Atmosphere: 6/10You arrive somewhere don't know anything but you being the empress' bodyguard and BOOM she's dead. You don't know why you have to do things and unfortunately you don't really care, as you stay a character without personality just like everyone else. Could be worse though, you never feel like being completely useless and the story isn't crazy.The Atmosphere in the Game is awesome though! I really think I'm in 18th -19 th century England. They should have done more about the Steampunk part making the different between reality and this bigger, but that's personal preference. There are some books you find all over the places, not too bad, but you can't compare them to TES books.After all, is it fun? (There are good games which for some reason just don't entertain you)Yes. So let's give it 1 bonus point and finish with an 8/10.
