number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												THE FOLLOWING CONTAINS MINOR SPOILERSIf it were about how much fun I had, this game would easily be the 9/10 that a lot of 'critics' seem to have awarded it. I absolutely loved the world of Dishonored, the washed-out watercoloury art style slotted in perfectly with the nice blend of Steampunk/Old England. I loved the clothing designs (including Corvo's mask of course), and the weapons were really cool in my opinion as well. Blinking from rooftop to alleyway, dashing around guards and taking out targets was an amazingly fun experience for me in Dishonored.But despite all this I've said, looking at Dishonored from a critical standpoint reveals that it is honestly a mediocre game at best. An example of 'stealth done wrong', with basic elements like hiding bodies and using the environment to avoid combat encouraged only by the prospect of a 'good ending' and a couple achievements. The skill "trees" are what really make the game fall short. If you want to end the game not being treated like a blood thirsty merciless ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ then you must choose to avoid about 70% of basically ♥♥♥♥ing everything. A whole bunch of skills are virtually useless and some even unusable if you want to keep your chaos (the Good/Neutral/Evil system that is really more like Good/Evil/Satan-Incarnate) low. Lets not forget that using any weapons other than your crossbow, with sleep darts only of course, are strictly off limits as well (minus the choking ability that didn't even have a default keybind on the PC version). Yes, that includes that cool rewiring tool that you can use to make the turrets and electric gates only affect the bad guys. Oh, and to top it all off the game has a huge difficulty flaw in terms of being able to cheese through a whole bunch of the levels if you've maxed out blink and agility.The characters are pretty boring and one dimensional also, with clique traits following a clique storyline with *surprise* clique betrayals. The plot twists aren't even that much of a shock to player anyway, as we're barely given much of a chance to do anything with any of the characters we meet before we're shipped off to do another assassination. At least the non-lethal ways of taking out said targets are creative. The bad guys are all typical power hungry schemers or simply megalomaniacs, with the only one who has any bit of depth being Daud and possibly Havelock in the final scene. Corvo is a silent protagonist, not the kind that you can project yourself onto though however. Corvo has more than just a name, he has a backstory with possible love-related connections. You can't fit yourself entirely onto a canvas that's already half full, which has resulted in Convo simply being a really boring character where the only thing you have control over is if he decides to become a horrendous murderer and essentially doom everything by passing on his bad traits to the game's damsel: Princess Emily.Despite all I've just said, it'd probably be hard for you to believe that Dishonored is one of my favourite games. I just like playing it, despite its horrific flaws and awful characters/plot/mechanics I still find it enjoyable simply because this lame kinda genre appeals to me personally as the type of game I like jump into every now and again. I encourage you to play it for yourself before deciding on whether my judgements on the game are fair or not; I definitly recommend it for a quick playthrough if you're looking for something different yet not necessarily fresh. Thanks for reading!

Posted: December 26, 2013
												Pretty fun game, similar to Thief, and actually really in-depth and very atmospheric. Decent story and characters, plus a steampunk/victorian themed world, which is fairly unique for a game.At first I didn't rate this game that much, the starting section didn't really seem to grab my enthusiasm. But as soon as the game opened up and sent you to your first mission, the game became amazing, you can tackle the levels in a multitude of ways, and it sort resembles a crossover of Thief and Deus Ex in that respect. Once you get the powers, it gets much more fun too. There's also lots of different fun to use equipment, with melee or ranged combat, and lots of hidden and extra stuff to find.One thing is that game wasn't too great to play on my old rig, which was 3/4 years old, it's much more enjoyable to play on my new pc, so that might be something you should check on the spec requirements.I'd rate it 9/10 easily.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Arkane studios did it again!Let me start off by saying that I loved The Dark Messiah which was also done by same studio. That game was greatly underrated. It had the RPG elements, stealth, great storyline, engaging narrative, great voice-acting, exploration, choice and a few of insane twists, orcs, demons, hot chicks, lust, the ability to kick, the ability to set off traps, alternate paths, dragons, mages, and a long single player campaign. I attempted to review that game on several occasions but failed every time. The game should just be played.This game follows The Dark Messiah in its footsteps. The melee fighting is nailed once again (unlike in Skyrim). Your melee blows feel real, you can almost feel the weight of your blows and the damage to the enemies is realistic. You don't have to hit someone over the head with a mace ten times for them to die (ahem...Skyrim...ahem...). Overall, we get tight controls, responsive and properly ported mouse, the ability to peek left or right, the ability to climb obstacles. The movement of the character has been nailed perfectly. You move fast when moving forward and you move slow when moving sideways. I should say that it wouldn't hurt for this game to have the kicking ability just like in the Dark Messiah. There are certain instances where you can push the unaware enemies from ledges.As far as the graphics go. Well, it's nice see a slightly cartoony-Rage-like rendition of the Unreal Engine 3.0, but seriously, why isn't this engine on life support yet? The textures are static, the trees do not move, the faces look like lifeless chunks of plastic. The water looks horrible but swimming under water looks and feels pretty realistic. The DX9 lighting is okaish. The artistic style however almost makes up for the old engine. I wish there were more graphic options to beef up the visuals. However, you can't see your legs and you cast no shadow. It's ironic that in some instances The Source Engine rendition in The Dark Messiah looks better than in this game (that's a 6 year difference).The gameplay is where the game shines (especially the melee). The melee fights are as satisfying as ever although they don't last as long as in the Dark Messiah. You get to wield a melee weapon and a range weapon. There are plenty of upgrades that you get at your home base, as long as you have the coins and the proper blueprints. The stealth has been pulled off pretty well, which is further expanded with the ability to hid bodies. Although there's no indication if you are hidden or not so you have to rely on your instincts. You have a choice of knocking out or slaying your unaware foes but if things go sour you can easily dispatch them with your weapons too. That happens to be one of the few gripes I have with the game, even though some enemies get tougher later in the game. You also get to teleport which I think makes the game easier in oh so many ways. You also get to collect magic runes and put them towards your character development, (higher jump, more health, the ability to see in the dark, etc.)I won't spoil the story much. You play as a mute imperial bodyguard/turned assassin, Corvo, bent on restoring the imperial throne and avenging the conspirators in a dystopian alternate reality world. I don't know why FPS developers are having such a difficulty with adding voice to the main character, it kills the immersion. Anyways, you get to put the pieces together, discover what the world has to offer and seek for clues for how the rat plague started. It's also interesting to meet various characters. Each one of them offers something a different view on reality and the nature of society. You get to do secondary quests and backtrack throughout the world. Overall, the pacing of the game feels real.There are moments when you don't have to fight enemies for a long time if you want the game to play life Thief. You also don't get to fight hordes of enemies although you are almost always in danger of being discovered. And even WHEN you are discovered you can quickly dispatch the enemies. I feel there should have been more danger and repercussions for being discovered. Although, if you play on hardest difficulty, it will only take a guard to slice you 3 times for you to die (maybe 5 with the health upgrade). You can also fight every enemy you see and clear the areas that way although you may run out of ammo quickly.Overall, this is a great game with many twists and epic moments although there is some slight imbalance as far as your super-powers go, otherwise, everything else has been nailed pretty well. Don't forget, this is a Single-Player only game, which is saying a lot these days.A LOT of love and effort went into this game.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												Dishonored is fantastic.  It’s stealth mechanics are handled expertly and are balanced nicely with supernatural powers and fast-paced combat.  I’ve played the game through a few times and I enjoyed both stealth heavy and combat heavy playthroughs.  Additionally, the visual presentation, sound design, and music are all really well done and each made a good impression.Complementing the fun gameplay is some wonderful world building and storytelling.  Characters are believably flawed and nuanced, and I became invested in Corvo’s quest for revenge or redemption.  But stealing the show was the city of Dunwall.  Dunwall is a marvelous setting and I really liked the blend of steampunk, gothic, and Victorian elements.  I’d love to get to see more of this fascinating world that has been created and look forward to any further entries in the series.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2016
												I can't believe I havent reviewed this masterpiece already but I cant see a more fitting time to do so than now, whilst I am installing the second game.  Dishonored is one of my favourite games of all time. I preordered it back in early 2013 and have completed it many many times since then. It combines a dark, interesting and immersive world with interesting characters and huge level of detail, to the extent that I have still been finding areas of the game and details that i have never seen before on my countless replays. One if my favourite things about Dishonored is the choices you make actually matter (unlike so many games) as they have impacts on the way certain missions are approached, the way people percieve you and of course the plot especially the end of the game.   Dishonored also has a huge amount of variability which leads to huge replayablity potential, this includes: a wide range of powers which allow you to approach a situation in different ways, challenges and achievements such as never be spotted or never kill anyone and the huge plot and level design variety such as having several routes to a key objective as well as several means to achieve the target such as aiding an ally so that they can dispose of the target for you, or a non lethal approch such as blackmail, or a stealth assassination or going loud and causing chaos with your powers and gadgets, the list goes on and on. The mechanics of the game are also really strong, stable and fun. I am a big fan of stealth games in general and i feel that Dishonored approaches stealth in the right way by offering many ways to accomplish it and rewards for doing so such as characters thanking you for sparing their relative who was a target (via a non lethal approach) and giving you runes, bonecharms or money for doing so. The combat is very fluid and stable and looks very cool with the combination of Corvo's powers and gadgets as well as finisher moves and other similar effects. The game has moments where you can pull off crazy kills and provides an opportunity for fun at any level of skill due to its numerous approaches to everything, meaning there is still fun to be had several playthroughs in by going for hard to pull off kills or attempting challenges such as not using any powers all game.*minor main game and DLC spoilers*The story of Dishonored is also very interesting and is multi-layered with lots of small details which really add to the whole game when found and explored including the motivations of characters and their backstory. With as few spoilers as possible the story of Dishonored involves Corvo Attano (you, the Empress' body guard) being framed for her murder which you witness. The game then sees you uncover the truth mission by mission as you tackle higher profile targets and various other tasks to clear your name and unveil the conspiracy behind you.  The game also establishes lots of really great memorable characters such as Emily (the soon to be Empress), Daud (the assassin), The Outsider and Samuel the boat man who takes you to and from missions. The game does a great job of showing the close relationship between Emily and Corvo which is a core part of the game and this is sure to be a core element of Dishonored 2. I also really liked 'The Knife of Dunwall' and 'The Brigmore Witches' DLC campaigns which take place parallel to the main story but see you playing as Daud, the Empress' real assassin who as well as Corvo has powers from the Outsider. The DLC saw Daud tackling a strong threat which at first may have seemed out of character for the way he was portrayed in the main game but as the DLC goes on Daud's motivations and reasons become more compelling. He and Corvo are both very deep and interesting characters, I particularly like Daud's understanding and insight of the Outsider compaired to Corvo. These DLC campaigns also offer the wide variety of many ways to complete them and a list of new powers and approaches and the campaigns are nearly as strong as the main story and are a great addition to the game overall. It is rare that game DLC is actually good and adds meaningful content but this is certainly and example of DLC done right. There is also a challenge map DLC which is personally not my cup of tea but I do understand the appeal of wanting to use abilities outside of missions and take on time trial challenge maps etc. Overall I would 100% recommend this game, especially if you are a fan of stealth games or story rich games with immersive worlds and plots. This is one of the best games i have ever played and I cannot wait to get started on #2 in a few hours. I've now finished the 2nd game and it is incredible too, a worthy sequel to a great game.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2013
												Despite this game's best attempts, I enjoyed it.The story is poorly presented. An interesting world is painted, but the details are obtained through the optional mid-mission, flow breaking reading of found diaries and letters. Pass. The gameplay and missions are quite engaging... stopping to read a wall of text about someone's cousin coming to visit is counter-productive. Feeling obligated to stop and read the final enemy's diary mid-climax is maddening.With its score keeping system, Dishonored also attempts to steer you towards a strict non-lethal approach... granting intangible bonuses for not being seen or killing anyone. Which is a shame since it's at its best when you're able to use all the wonderful tools it gives you. When 9/10 of your options for getting through any given situation are lethal, feeling compelled to avoid them is cheating yourself out of gameplay. After a few levels, I decided to open up the playbook and feel free to kill when beneficial to the objective... and the game came alive. Dropping from a rooftop sword first onto a guard, shooting his friend, then countering and stabbing a 3rd before vanishing into the shadows is fun as hell. There is no non-lethal equivalent.Lest you think I'm just bloodthirsty....There's only one level, the Lady Boyle encounter, where the purely non-lethal approach is just as viable as the lethal ones... and it was my favorite segment. Everyone lived, though not everyone left happy :)Play naturally. Embrace "high" chaos. Dishonored is fun.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2013
												Dishonored is one of those very rare few games that comes along and is very polarizing depending on how you play it. For instance, I went through on a completely non-lethal playthrough and found it to be a slow-paced, often difficult, yet immensely satisfying experience... then went on a lethal playthrough and found it to be a short, easy, wisp of a game. Suffice to say the stealth mechanics usually work well, and the game gives you many, many ways to complete various objectives, with lots of clever ways to dispatch foes... but just as it encourages using all these, it discourages combat altogether with the chaos system. Ultimately despite its faults (which are few), Dishonored is a unique, extremely enjoyable game that I whole-heartedly recommend to any fan of stealth-action games, or anyone who's looking for something outside the current norm of gaming.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												This game, created by Arkane Studios but published from Bethesda, has everything a fan of stealth, story, gameplay and RPG needs. The graphics are wonderfully stylised, with a selection of interesting characters that aren't too out of the ordinary, but not bland enough to make you forget them. The protagonist in particular, Corvo, is wonderfully created, so you can imagine what kind of man he would be and play him to that image, whether he's the forgiving kind of killer or whether he just wants to see Dunwall burn. The story-line is intriguing and there's plenty of different turns you don't expect that I've enjoyed so far. Plus I love the man eating rats. The game has levels of customisation whether you want to use a gun, crossbow or the supernatural powers you're given early in the game, with plenty of collectbles to find each mission and requires a level of intelligence to find, as getting to them are sometimes puzzling. So far I simply adore this game and if you're a fan of Assassin's Creed, Thief and Bethesda's works, I can't recommend this game enough.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												My opinion about this game is a mixed bag. There are a lot of things that this game makes incredible well, and then there are some others that suck balls beyond EA levels.First of all, the price. The hell is this. I don't know if they changed it recently, but this game has stayed with a price tag of 60€ for a year or two after it's release. Is the game long? No. The game has multiplayer? No. Coop? No. Does it deserve the 60€'s?F#CK NO. Personally, my brother picked up this game in a sale for me as a gift, for 3€, and I think that's what is worth for a semi-dull single-player experience. Yes, I said dull. Here's why.The story, while it's quite interesting at first, there are points that get a bit boring, because it's usually the same thing over and over, even with some of those small maps re-used with little changes. And the story does have something worse, but that's still to come. So, what's up with the gameplay?It's kind of flawed. You see, you're extremely over-powered. The enemies have NO DAMN CHANCE against you, because of either their massive brain damage, or bad programming. It's easy to beat them up with a handful of slashes with the sword, it's easy to execute them with a pistol, it's easy to screw them up with a crowssbow, it's HELL EASY to sneak up on them and cut their throats, and don't even get me started on the non-lethal methods. And that's the problem I was talking about before:There are multiple endings, and there are tons of fun ways to annihilate those peasants the game tells you they're your enemies. But you know what? Killing people won't allow you to see the GOOD ending. And is it fun to sneak up on people and ocasionally knock down the few guards who won't let you go unseen? Frankly, no. I love stealth based games, like Deus Ex. And in Deus Ex HR, they did a good job with all of that crap. But in here? They kinda messed it up. Stealth is boring, combat is fun, yet repetitive, BUT YOU WON'T GET ANYTHING GOOD OUT OF IT, SO STAY IN THE SHADOWS AND GET BORED.The game also has a few DLC's, but seriously, why should I give a crap about mission-packs, and why they expect me to pay for them? I do recommend this game, don't get me wrong. It's fun for a while. But you should not buy it at full price, unless you like wasting money. Calling this a stealth game is like calling modern CoD games GOOD. This is, rather, a weird hack-n-slash game, with some escort missions and stealth based gameplay. So, 3€ for this? Fine. 60€? F#ck off.And this thing better not get any sequels. I don't want to see Dishonored 2 for 70€ for the rest of my life.EDIT: F#ck my life, it's actually getting a sequel. I CALLED IT, I FORESAW THIS!

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Dishonored by Arkane Studios brought back the memories of classic PC games like Thief or Deus Ex, the constant need of exploring just one another room, reading just another little note, and then ending up playing for 10 hours straight. Games like these are a rarity in this day and age. This is not your average cookie-cutter first person shooter; I’d even dare to call it a first person stealth choose-your-own-adventure game. You can play it like an FPS. You can play it as a stealth game. You can play it as a mix of both. You can kill everyone in the room, or you can leave no trace behind. The choice is yours.You control Corvo Attano, a personal bodyguard to the Empress of Dunwall, a fictional steampunk city based on London (though all the voice actors are American, which is a weird decision). About a minute into the game the Empress gets killed, her daughter gets kidnapped, and you get framed for the murder of Her Highness.  Exploring the beautifully crafted city is a great pleasure, although the actual situation in the city is far from lovely. Not only is the crime rampant, but the rat plague is killing citizens not by dozens or hundreds, but by thousands. During your playthrough, about half of Dunwall is already dead, as commented by the city guard. The moments in games when I think “wait, this is ♥♥♥♥ed up” are extremely rare. Seeing a wagon dropping dozens of dead bodies was one of those moments. The wagon appears again and again, throwing off bodies wrapped up in filthy bandages. It empties up and returns full again. The world of Dishonored is brutal, every character you encounter has his own agendas and reasons for acting the way he acts, and nothing is ever black or white.The approach you take when blasting (stealthing?) through missions is entirely up to you, and you have a nice variety of supernatural powers at your disposal. Do you want to wreak havoc upon your enemies? You’re likely to invest in a Devouring Swarm ability, which creates a devouring swarm (sic) of rats that attack your enemy and then clean up by eating their body. Neat. Are you MGS or pre-2006 Splinter Cell fan? You’ll probably want to upgrade Dark Vision and Possession, one of the most useful tools when it comes to stealth playthrough. Each of the nine missions is designed as a sandbox. Theoretically you could go for an objective marker (which you can turn off, by the way) and finish Dishonored in about 5 hours. But if you want to do that, it’s not the game for you. There are multiple sidequests in each of the missions, and some of them will bring repercussions in the future. The game offers you a choice- do you want a free rune that lets you upgrade your character? OK, but you’re going to have to poison Dunwall’s distillery by the request of a crazy lady. Do you want to kill the real murderer of the Empress, or give him a message and only steal his pouch that he carries by his side? Regardless of your choice, it’s worth playing through the game a second time, just to see the different ways people react to you whether you slaughter everyone or leave unnoticed. By the way- even though you’re an assassin, you can finish the game without killing a single person. That’s right. In times when 3-hour-long corridor shooters earn numerous GOTY awards and critical acclaim, an offer of a choice like this is an excellent touch.Summing up, Dishonored is a game that begs to be played at least twice. No playthrough will be the same, whether because you choose to end a sidequest differently, upgrade your character in a different manner, or skipping some chunks of content by mistake, because you weren’t patient enough to listen to the guards’ conversation which unlocked a non-lethal way to accomplish your assignment. The over the top picturesque artistic design, fantastic supernatural abilities, excellent voice acting and music, and most importantly- the freedom to tackle the missions in dozens of different ways make this my game of the year.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2013
												I got this one for 10€ + 5€ with the currently available DLCs. Let's see what you get for your hard earned money:The base game contains nine missions that will take you - depending on your game style and skill - around nine hours. And now we are already at the major point of this game. Your game style. That's what makes this game unique. You are able to choose between a lot of ways to get to reach your goal. You can kill everybody with your crossbow, your gun, with granades or your sword or invoke a crowd of deadly rats,... or you can sneak and talk with allies and try to avoid killing a single person (what is definitly manageable).To bring it to the point: Dishonored is a very thrilling game if you are playing it like a spy, but it's a damn bad FPS, if you try to have fun with killing NPCs. The IA is dumb as ♥♥♥♥ and it's not fun to fight against the clone enemies. Let me count the enemy types,.... 70% are the casual guards, 10% are the one with masks, 10% are the Assassins, 5% are the dogs together with the rats that are attacking you and the other 5% are the guards with this kind of music box that is freezing your mana and lowering your health constantly.I got the DLCs for cheap and I'm really happy that I did not spent even more money on them because they are weak. Knife of Dunwall is the only story DLC and contains three missions. That would not be bad if one of the missions would not be 1:1 copy from one of the base game. So you are getting two levels, one new grenade type and... and I think two new abilities (but also "lose" two old ones from base game - because you are playing another character).Is it a bad game? No! It's a nice game with a very unique graphic style, it's running smooth, the gameplay is solid but the recycled levels, the lack of enemy variety, the very unsatisfying AI, the bad cliffhangers at the end, the muddy story(telling) and above all the amount of wasted potentional bring this game down to the other average games we all played and thought "Why,....why did'nt you made this right? All tools are already there!"Gameplay 7/10 (thrilling sneaky parts VS dumb AI and quicksafe & quickload)Story 6/10 (the story is starting very good,...but at the end you don't give a ♥♥♥♥ what happens and why you are doing all this♥♥♥♥♥♥Music 5/10 (I really have to say that I did not even noticed,...can't be special at all)Longevity 6/10 (well, I played 25 hours. 2x main story + achievement whoring, 1x DLC and a short trip to the challenges DLC)Replayability 7/10 (You can play the base game and also the DLC 1x sneaky and 1x like a psycho murderer.... so it's not that bad....but you don't have the option to keep your skills(runes) and try to max everything out or something like that. The only motivation could be to get every achievement....but look at me. I made 76% of them and I'm not that motivated to play this game once again.)If you like games where you can sneak around and that's thrilling you, get it. If you like to play a game twice to try out different decissions, get it. But if you prefer to shoot everybody down and think this game will have a story like Bioshock or Deus Ex.... no dude. I'm sorry to say, better to keep your money.73/100

Posted: March 8
												Before purchasing this game, I wasn't really thinking much of it. It was just going to be a pass time game for me... For when other games got a bit boring for me, the main one being CS:GO. After hours of gameplay, the game got me hooked. This game feels like you completely have the freedom to do as you please. In missions, you have many ways to approach them, not to mention the amazing weapons and abilities you can use.  I now find myself periodizing this game over all others. Posted: February 15, 2015
													I'm stalking my prey, two tallboys, elite guards who wear suits of plated armor with spindle legged armatures that help protect them from the plague rat swarms and would be assailants; just outside of the imposing Boyle mansion, of whichI must gain access in order to assassinate Lady Boyle, one of your targets on a long list. I could just merely bypass these two tallboys, and gain entry as I had procured an invitation from my previous mission, of courseI'll still need to sneak past him.. No, I instead decide that because this is the first time you encounter these guards (almost midway into Dishonored) and because I am doing a high chaos playthrough. I will kill both tallboys. I wait for the opportune moment to present itself, when both tallboys and a single City Watch guardsman are in close proximity, and so now I spring into action..I sprint towards my targets, and because of my upgraded boots my footsteps pound the pavement silently. I use Bend Time, then time completely stops, I then use Blink and am teleported up onto the shoulders of the first tallboy, I drive my blade through his neck, andbefore his blood begins to gush out, I blink onto the next tallboy, running him through the neck as well, I then jump off and air assassinate the lone city watch guardsman. And just as quickly as it began, it ends and time returns to its normal progression. I don't have to worry about the bodies either, thanks to Shadow Kill, which turns my enimies into ash upon death. All is quiet, no alarms sounding in the distance, no footsteps coming towards me, no shouts. Just the ambient sounds of the night, the party that is raging wihin the Boyle mansion. I proceed down the street that lines the garden of the Boyle mansion, I find a sewer duct and pass underneath it to access a side street that will take me to the doorman. I stroll up to the doorman and present my invitation. I then proceed inside of the mansion. This is the perfect party, as everyone is wearing a mask..I'll blend right in. Dishonored..is a story about revenge, how you choose in which manner to seek your revenge, is up to you. You play as Corvo Attano, known as The Royal Protector, whoturns into an assassin to seek revenge, you are given supernatural abilities in order to achieve your objectives.  As well as a mask to conceal your identity.   The world of Dishonored is both captivating and grim, yet this world that Arkane has created is beautiful. The atmosphere in Dunwall is well done. The art direction is also nicely done with an 18th century oil painting cast over everything. The buildings, streets and machinesare victorian-esque mixed with steampunk. You'll easily find yourself immersed in Dunwall. In terms of graphical fidelity, this game won't push your system and you'll often find many areas with low resolution textures, of which the oil painting overcast helps to conceal, it's done nicely, but you can still notice it at times. For the most part, however you'llbe too enthralled with the events taking place and enjoying the gameplay itself. There is nothing ugly about Dishonored's looks, it's style. In fact I find it refreshing.Dishonored allows a great deal of freedom for the player to go about completing their mission. The level design is nicely done, even if it is a bit linear. I found it frustrating at times when I wanted to reach a certain rooftop or ledge in order to go about completeing an objective, but could not do so, despite the Blink ability being able to easily reach the areas in question.  The possibilites of executing your missions are various, this does depend on what powers you choose to invest in, and your overall play style. Dishonored is able to suit it, for the most part. Corvo can use Posession to possess animals and people alike to bypass an area, or Corvo can use Devouring Swarm to distract guardsmen for example. There are many other possibilites. Dishonored is very much a story driven game, and while I will come up front and say that the writing isn't the best, it's a nice change from the typical type of writing we see in games today. There are a few moments where the writing is a bit clever, but for the most part it's straightfoward, this doesn't really cheapen the overall  experience of the story, even though what will occur next is predictable. I found the story intriuging enough, enough to invest myself into it and enjoy it for what it is. Decisions that you make also have an impact on certain events and the world of Dunwall. These impacts are limited, not as extensive as youcan find in a few other games. Corvo, himself is silent, he never speaks a single word throughout the entirety of the game. The game itself is quite short, however, this isn't a bad thing. The story is good, and besides you can play Dishonored in a number of ways. Non-lehtal, ghost, low chaos, a mix, or the opposite.Each run will will provide a different play experience and to a limited extent the story as well. I won't go into the aspects of the story any further, as to do so would reveal spoilers. The gamplay itself is fun and addicting. Each level is a playground for Corvo, and your powers will be your most used toys. Dishonored is an FPS, but it is unlike any that I've played before, and so it does not play like your average FPS title. The weapons at your disposal are limited, but these weapons can be upgradedand with upgrades comes visual changes to the weapon you've upgraded. At no point did I ever feel as though there wasn't enough at my disposal. Between your weapons and your powers, you have everything that you need, I like this design choice because it allows you, as the player to focus more on the story and the gameplay and less on which weapons or items should you take along with you. It's all with you already. By the time the first mission is over you have all of the weapons you'll have during the game, minus a couple of items like grenades and spring razor traps. The crossbow can fire multiple ammo types. Regular, sleepdarts and explosive arrows for instance. The gameplay never becomes dull, it remains refreshing, the gameworld introduces new enemies at the right intervals to keep the pace nice and fresh when sneaking about...or killing everyone. And while you are very vulnerable and can only take a couple of hits, you'll find that you feel like you are a master assassin! The audio in Dishonored is a rich experience, more so if you have 5.1 surround. The ambient sounds really adds to the game and helps you become more absorbed in the atmosphere. Footsteps can be heard clearly, rats scurrying about, guards talking, the wind blowing, music, fireworks, those who are infected withthe plague groaning and vomiting, the clash of steel on steel, gunshots ringing out. Sound is one of your key allies, it helps you determine when and where to move, when to take an unsuspecting guard out as well. It's also important for overhearing conversations as you'll often get clues by eavesdropping. However,if you rely on Dark Vision a lot, the ambient sounds of the game is significantly reduced. As for the voice overs, the male NPCs were done well enough, though not top notch, as were the key female NPCs, howeverthe rest of the female NPC voice work was done by one woman and when you hear the exact same voice from so many different women in the game, it breaks the immersion somewhat, it's a bit jarring.The controls of Dishonored are your standard layout where KB/M is concerned. I found the controls to be responsive with the exception that using Blink sometimes resulted in a delay. I also found that I tended to use the selection wheel by clicking and holding the middle mouse button, as opposed to using 1-10 keys for quick swaps. All the keys can be rebound, Dishonored is a game of options. You can customize your experience from FOV slider down to rat shadows, and you can choose which HUD elements will show, if any at all.

Posted: January 12, 2014
												So I just finished this game. I have to say - I absolutely loved the story, the setting, and the way your choices affected the way events played out. The game itself is played as a relatively short series of relatively long missions. Along the way, there's many things to collect that can easily be missed - bone charms that disappear if you don't nab them at a certain point, changing audio logs of NPCs and fleeting conversations. The former can be a bit frustrating, but the latter is always fun to collect, and illustrates the characters around you nicely. The powers were quite fun to use, and the game provided many, many ways to proceed on missions; things were never impossible, but having a certain ability would often open up a path. My largest complaint, however, would be that the game hands you a wide arsenal of killing tools and powers and then heavily discourages using them. The game has, basically, two paths; low chaos (nonlethal, stealth) and high chaos (lethal). There's a third tier, very high chaos, which is for the most part the same as high chaos, but nets even worse reactions from your allies (at this point, your Corvo Attano is pretty much murdering everyone he sees for ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles.) High chaos is easier to do at the beginning, because you don't have many powers yet, and the early missions take place in populated areas - but as the game progresses, high chaos creates more enemies, worse situations, crueller allies, and darker endings. It's understandable and rationalized from a story perspective - more bodies means more rats means more plague, and your allies follow the example you make - but given how much gamers are used to killing the bad guys being a core part of games - well, expect to spend some time adjusting with Dishonored, unless you want to see cute little Emily devolve into a tyrant. Also, if you're playing stealthy, which you should be - well, expect a lot of save scumming. When I played, I was saving on average of once every two minutes, sometimes even more often.

												Incredible game, smooth gameplay, brilliant story. It's a cross between two other incredible games: Rage and Half Life 2.  Set in the 1800s, before the wide use of crude oil, the game's characters fuel their world with refined whale oil. There is a Technocracy which suffers some political drama at the start of the game that the player has to advance from. The controls are simple and yet there are so many options for play and movement. I did get stuck in two places in the game where my avatar could not move and I had to load from autosave. I felt that something I shouldn't have happen in an AAA game. However, the game is so incredible in every other way that I just overload it!I highly recommend this game and it's one of the few games where I play it from start to finish. I may even play it again, which is something I don't think I've done for ANY GAME EVER!

Posted: October 2, 2015
												Great game with stealth mechanics and story. Unlike some games stealth does not feel forced, but it is very encouraged, especially to get items and achievements. This game has replayability to it due to the multiple ways to play as well. The game on normal was difficult, but not hard enough I had to goto sites to look up how to kill this or that boss... sometimes that stuff is annoying.Pros:-Great graphics for the most part.-Effects are stellar and they make great use of lighting effects with sunbeams etc.-Story is involving, though some parts are a tad predictable it was interesting.-Varied ways to play the game. Most of the game revolves around stealth, but you can decide hoe much you want to stealth play or how you want to stealth play etc.- Game has LOADS of achievements...- Your actions affect the game world in concurring levels, such as more kills = more rats etc.Cons:- While the FXAA was decent in this game, I was disappointed that Dishonored does not have AA. For the most part this did not affect the game, but if you were looking off into the distance, the city looked like jaggedy edges.- Not much is shown of Corvo in storyline videos or in third person. I was disappointed in this.- I think some things in the game could have been explained more, there is a character named "The Outsider" who it really tells little about him.All in all this was a good game... the graphical issues I believe derive from the fact the game is a port from consoles. I wish that game makers would make less ports and make more games so that computers can take advantage of their power.

Posted: December 23, 2012
												It's been criticized for its short storyline and its apparent copying of games such as Deus Ex, Assassin's Creed and Bioshock, but damn if Arkane didn't pull it off amazingly. Dishonored is highly immersive and an extremely fun game. The graphics are nice, gameplay is smooth and easy to understand, and the story is very intriguing. As I mentioned, the campaign is a bit on the short side, but the game does offer some degree of replayability due to the multiple methods you are offered in taking out your enemies. Similar to Deus Ex and Hitman style games, you have a ton of options on how you want to play the game. Whether you prefer to sneak by every guard undetected, or rush through with guns blazing and sword drawn, it's up to you. You don't even have to kill your assassination targets; instead you can find clever ways of making sure they're never seen again. The music is also absolutely amazing, and I'd hope to see an official soundtrack released at some point in the future. All of this combined with the Dunwall City Trials DLC (in which you compete with other players online in various mini-missions to gain the high score) makes this game a must-play, and one I wouldn't pass up lightly.

Posted: December 24, 2013
												Games as beautiful, fun, and engrossing as this don't come around everyday, which only serves to intensify the frustration that the story has no wind in its sails. It would have been easy enough to explain the protagonists' powers using the gorgeous whalepunk setting, the developers felt it necessary to force in witches, gods, and enough thematic references to Bioshock to make you sick. This game is certainly jaw droppingly gorgeous, plays arguably better, and the powers are very, very fun (you'll spend all day blinking to across rooftops), but ultimately you'll feel as if more focus on the rat plague and the central characters would have made you care more. It may never be Bioshock, as it desperately wants to be, but that won't stop you from enjoying every single minute inside this game. Forget the story they give you, and enjoy the amount of actual playing you can achieve, and you will be handsomely rewarded.

Posted: February 3, 2014
												This is game is one of those REAL STEALTH GAMES, meaning there's actually a need to sneak, not like that other assassin game :P This game requires a lot of patientce, although you could finish the game within a day, you'd be missing out on the back story of things. Pay attention to details, for they also add color to the picture. Lot's of books and notes around here, pretty weird stuff but quite interesting.This game is just one of those games where you can be really creative with your approach to situations, sometimes you could even get carried away with the many things you can do within the game. Players looking for a challenge can go try playing the game with just the blink ability and finish the game without acquiring other abilities and/or enhancement.The only downside to this game for me is that it doesn't include a variety of graphics settings, you'd have to tweak things in the ini file and add better AA via your video driver. Posted: December 16, 2013
												Set in a very interesting world where your actions affect the outcome of the story - one can choose to assassinate everyone and everything or simply subdue the enemy and complete each mission with non-lethal means of action. Dishonored was most enjoyable because of the freedom one had in the process of completing the game, if you aren't much of an explorer you can choose to complete the game in a matter of a few hours simply by doing just the necessary missions that follow the main storyline but you're also able to sweep every corner of every map, thoroughly, to find all the coins (used to buy upgrades and consumables), runes (used to learn different abilities, such as increased running speed, teleportation etc.) and bone charms (used as small perks), should you wish to.If you're an experienced firstperson PC-gamer you can have a lot of fun playing around in this game, even at the harder difficulties - the more skilled and faster you are, the more of an advantage you've got on the world around you.Interesting story, interesting gameplay and very interesting characters - recommended for any stealth/assassin enthusiast as well as the casual murderer.

Posted: December 16, 2013
												One of my absoulte favourite first-person titles of all time. A well-crafted combination of Half Life, Thief and Mirror's Edge combining into a unique blend of stealth, action and storytelling unlike any other game. Audiovisually impeccable, Dishonored let's you explore and be amazed by it's architechture, and it's characters, while not necessarily the smartest in gaming history, are some of the most colourful and well-acted I've ever seen.To top things off, I'll make an exception to my usual "no DLC ever" -policy and recommend the two story DLC packs for this game as well. Neither of the DLC's alone is much, but together they weave into the story of the main game and fill the player in on one of the least fleshed out, yet most important characters in the game.My only gripe is the passivity of the protagonist, Corvo, as his fall during a certain point in the game feel far too forced. Still, this game comes highly recommended, despite a minor gripe here or there.Playtime: 25+ hours (single playthrough, including DLC)Ratings (1-10)Visual: 10Audio: 10Story: 9Gameplay: 9Overall: 9

Posted: August 3, 2014
												Coming to the market from people blatantly trying to recreate a work like Thief the Dark Project, I bought this game with some skepticism.  I leave a skeptic as akways, but it is certainly worth the purchase for someone interested in the genre.  Gameplay:Dishonered lets you float like a butterfly, sting like a bee, almost to the point where you feel like you are playing Theif with cheat codes.  This feeling of absolute power seems to stem mostly from the absolute power of being able to blink (teleport short distances) which is probably the most valuable power you could ever dream of controlling in a stealth genre game.  The game manages to create a set of mechanics that allow you to approach a situation from many possible angles, allowing your individually crafted outcome to become something quite unique.  However, I felt the environments were still stagnant, and never really forced myself to approach problems from new and unique angles.  Dishonered throws you all the God like toys, but it never really forces you to get creative with them and really push the limits of the puzzle aspect it provides you.  Overall the game feels a bit too easy, finishing in just over 20 hours, with the only replay content being some DLC and going scavenging for missed runes and charms which is simply no fun for someone like me.  A note: games like this tend to boast their open ended approach, but in the end it still feels like you are being led along at the end of a leash.  Each objective is tagged with an omniscient arrow, which if you disable, you may easily be clueless about where to go next.Story:I found the story interesting enough, and it wasn't terribly difficult to sympathize with your character (Corvo's) plight.  There were many missed and unread notes and many nuances I probably didn't pick up from the extended material, but it is all saved in your journal so you can go back and read.  There seemed to be a definite morality system based on your action, big and small, and somehow I ended up being an agent of chaos, even though I felt like I tried my best to be a good guy.  Some larger decisions feel rather forced, and since my gamplay was very intermittent, I felt like I didn't have enough information about who should be saved and who should be eliminated.  I find games that constantly nag me to be the purveyor of some arbitary justice to be a bit forceful and annoying. In other words, I feel like they throw these situations at you because they know its this idea that theoretically all gamers crave weird difficult moral scenarios, so they throw a few random decisions your way because their producers breathe down their necks about it.overall i give it a 4/5, worth it, but could be better.

Posted: December 16, 2013
												Set in a very interesting world where your actions affect the outcome of the story - one can choose to assassinate everyone and everything or simply subdue the enemy and complete each mission with non-lethal means of action. Dishonored was most enjoyable because of the freedom one had in the process of completing the game, if you aren't much of an explorer you can choose to complete the game in a matter of a few hours simply by doing just the necessary missions that follow the main storyline but you're also able to sweep every corner of every map, thoroughly, to find all the coins (used to buy upgrades and consumables), runes (used to learn different abilities, such as increased running speed, teleportation etc.) and bone charms (used as small perks), should you wish to.If you're an experienced firstperson PC-gamer you can have a lot of fun playing around in this game, even at the harder difficulties - the more skilled and faster you are, the more of an advantage you've got on the world around you.Interesting story, interesting gameplay and very interesting characters - recommended for any stealth/assassin enthusiast as well as the casual murderer.

Disclaimer: This only a review of the Dunwall City Trials DLC and not the full game. I'll write the full review later (This is an awesome game!) but I need to get this off my chest.Dunwall City Trials DLC is a piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ It is everything Dishonored isn't. It's almost like it's from a different and a more crap game. What it is is a series of challenge maps, all testing a different ability. Except it's not at all about skill. It's mostly random chance plus memorization. I am not even joking when I say there is an actual map where you get bonus points for taking a lucky guess instead of actually doing what you are suppose to do. The ♥♥♥♥ing thing rewards luck! You have to be ♥♥♥♥ing kidding me...All the maps tell you how you can beat them in the beginning but that is a one big stinking lie. If you follow those instructions the game will only give you 1 star and tell you to ♥♥♥♥ off.  You'd think you would have a variety of different ways of solving a map but no. There is only ONE solution to each map and you must follow that solution to a t. If do anything even slightly different, if you are one pixel off, yet get the same result anyway it doesn't matter, you won't get 3 stars. It's discouraging creativity. And even when you know the solution you still have to do it 10-20 times before it feels like admitting your success.It's unimaginative, frustrating and not fun. I hate it. I hate it with passion.I hate this DLC because I like Dishonored. I hate it because this is a blemish on a good game. ♥♥♥♥ THIS♥♥♥♥♥♥TO HELL!

												Dishonored is a joy to play. The sheer amount of choice and freedom presented to the player lets you tackle missions the way you want to, and allows you to adjust your strategy on the fly. Posted: February 26, 2014
												Dishonored might be one of the absolute best games released this decade, it features a very interesting universe resembling a Steampunk Victorian London, designed by the AD from Half-Life 2, with gameplay highly reminiscient of Thief, in fact I would go so far as to call it a spiritual successor to Thief in many ways. It is also heavily inspired by Bioshock, Deus Ex and The Chronicles of Riddick: Escape from Butcher Bay. The story and gameplay consistently superb and the game is tailored after your playstyle. If you go for stealth and non-lethal options, for example, the outcome of the game will be much less dark than if you go for a direct and lethal way.I would highly recommend this game, to anyone who want that little extra in a game, and to fans of any of the franchises mentioned above.

Posted: February 15, 2014
												As part of a generation of self-proclaimed "Final Fantasy Allstars", it was always hard for me to really give other RPGs other than Chrono a real chance.  It was always me asking myself, "What could this other game that looks alright, really give me in a 50+ hour playthrough, that I couldn't get out of another run through any of my favorite Final Fantasies." I then sat through the opening sequence of Dishonored.  What Bethesda and Arkane do here is a slice of the steampunk cake, that makes me want to sit here and keep eating until there is nothing left.  Albeit a story which really gets hacked off at the knees with a rather weak ending, the environment and sound-tracking for Dishonored finds me hard pressed to suggest another RPG outside of my FF comfort zone. I had also never dabbled in the stealth games before, but even though that wasn't my thing when I started, and I hacked my way through the storyline, Arkane built the game so that based on type of play the storyline sees real changes.  If you are going to break out the digital wallet to pick up a new game, the game design alone had my steampunk and proto-industrial side poking like a nail, and everything else the game had to offer was just a huge plus.  Don't buy any other RPG, except maybe what I remember as being a reformatted FF8 (New to Steam, but not the same without a controller) - Dishonored is it.  Just exploring Dunwall was more than worth my money - so do it, and you won't regret it.

Posted: February 15, 2014
												A fantastic game that combines stealth mechanics with fast-paced action. As the former Lord Protector, being framed for the murder of your Empress is definitely something that grinds your gears, but the game allows the player, as Corvo Attano, to kill everything in sight in an act of vengeance, or to kill those that are deemed necessary to die. This game gives you several choices to make as an assassin. Granted, it's no Mass Effect game, but the decisions to either kill your targets or non-lethally dispose of them can make you feel like an accomplished assassin, or a forgiving hero of the city. The game's story is well thought out and the mechanics are well implemented in the game, my only concern is the growth of Corvo as a character. Understandably, there isn't much for him to learn as a person, seeing as you (the player) all the decisions for him, but it would be nice to see how he handles certain situations when talking to a person, where you make the initial yes/no decision for him and he carries out the actions.

Posted: August 31, 2014
												One of the most important aspects of videogames is a sense of movement, next is impact (how your weapons and movement "feels"), last is atmosphere.  These are probably the strongest aspects of Dishonored.  The atmosphere is palpably dark, gruesome and hopeless.  The impact of your attacks are satisfying and exciting. But the sense of movement is where this game shines. Second only to the glorious Mirror's Edge, Dishonored feels like a dance, a deadly, dark dance where you are the lead and your enemies follow you.  Usually to their ugly doom.  A must-have game.

Posted: June 29, 2014
												The game seems impossible (or damn close to it) without powers, due to the actually-fairly-good AI and their uncanny nack for looking in all the right places, so your prison escape is usually the most difficult part. Aside from that, the game seems to have a lot of emphasis on "let's count the ways you can commit mass murder" for a game that has a pseudo-morality system, the graphics and aesthetic are very nice (if just a combination of Bioshock's aesthetic and Half-Life 2's aesthetic), the gameplay holds up well until the absolute last bit of the absolute last level (where the guards are combination of immovable and clueless, for reasons I can't come up with), there are a fair number of powers but not enough runes to go around and not enough powers that can be used non-lethally (most of them focus on lethality or cause needless death when used), and the audio is very nice.Overall I give it a 4/5 (would recommend if it's $10-15, MAYBE $20), and it could be made absolutely perfect with modding. Personally I've had my fill of the game's mechanics (which for me, boil down to "blink behind guard, choke guard, hide guard, don't get caught, ad nauseum"), so I'd skip the DLCs.

Posted: September 24, 2014
												This is the only game that has managed to make me WANT to play with it's stealth mechanics. All of it feels fluid, useful and trustworthy. You can complete it without ever being seen and/or alerting any enemy, even if it's incredibly hard to do both at the same time.The aesthetics have a touch of steampunk, some Bioshock and a droplet of fantasy games, but soon you forget all of that and just enjoy how good does it all merge.The story isn't spectacular but it's pretty well engrained and hooks you up to the last moment, and it has different endings depending on how you play it.The DLCs are completely optional, and consist on extra missions.Overall, it's an awesome game and you'll hardly regret buying it.9/10

												There's so much about this game that makes it so interesting. Firstly, I think the entire game looks just beautiful, the artwork and the way the characters are made are just stunning and very interesting. You could say the story was somewhat expectable, but I think that's just a minor issue - although it wasn't the strongest story ever, it was really enjoyable and I would definitely recommend anyone to play through it. Posted: August 25, 2014
												From what i have played of the game so far (less than 10 hours 1-3 missions) the game is fantastic. the art style is amazing but slightly cartoony. This isnt a bad decision its just there. The combat is difficult and you cant just go swinging your sword around like a beserker and win. The game WILL punish you for trying to be a beserker and murder everyone you see. However if you play it quiet and never hurt anyone but your targets the game will reward you in ways i wont spoil for you. The story is very good but slightly predictable. Your the guardian to a queen her bodyguard infact. After she is murdered and she tells you her last words while dying in your arms the guards and conspirators against you find you you're hauled off to jail to await your fate. Unknown allies rescue you and from there the story really gets going. the game loves exploration and manipulation of the games powers. i never had any sort of gamebreaking glitch or texture glitch or horrible AI experience *Cough Rome 2 TW Cough Cough* the AI if it detects you will really try to hunt you down. My one concern is it seemed a little too easy to sneak past but maybe thats because i was playing on normal difficulty. Game mechanics are solid and no two playthroughs will be the same unless you specifically TRY to make it exactly the same. you have a variety of powers that are oh so fun you mess with and you cant have them all so you have to choose wisely. Overall the games a good buy especially at the current 5$ of the sale. Easily worth the 20 though. If you really love the game then the Game of the year edition takes you a step further with Daud the legendary Dunwall assassin who killed the Empress as your main protagonist and his story for redemption. The game is good and is worth a purchase.

Posted: September 14, 2013
												Well, I recently finished Dishonored and I can honestly say it was one of the best games I played this year! I did a low chaos run; minimal killing, no alarms from the half-way point onwards. Had lots of fun being the ultimate blinking, time-stopping ninja! :DThe story is a little straightforward, leading you on a path of revenge and redemption after being framed for the murder of the Empress. Missions generally revolve around an assassination target that needs to be removed in order to dismantle the new regime that has seized control of the Empire. There are also some missions that take a different approach (Lady Boyle's party was one of my favorite parts of the game).Your skills start small but can be developed to be quite devastating by the end of the game. It reminds me a lot of a Ninja-Bioshock; granting you an array of magic powers which are always at your disposal provided you have sufficient mana vials. Except in Dishonored you won’t be flinging lightning bolts or jets of fire, instead you are armed by much sneakier skills such as a mini-teleport, mind control, time control and the ability to see though walls.The level design is one of the best parts of Dishonored. While they may seem small or linear at first glance, a player who is willing to explore will find many different routes to their objectives. There are also many hidden items to loot, runes and charms to find which will improve your abilities and lore to be read in the form of notes, books and audio logs.I would strongly recommend Dishonored to the type of player who loves to explore a world, peeling back the layers and really getting absorbed into the experience. While you could play the game by running directly to the objective and killing everyone in your path, I feel you would be robbing yourself of so much more game that is being offered here.

Posted: April 19, 2014
												It's April 19 in 2014 and I have just finished my first playing of Dishonored.  I picked up the game of the year edition during it's last sale a few weeks ago.  I don't know why I ignored this game for so long.  I even played a demo when it was first released long ago.  It is a complex game with a little learning curve and I didn't realize at the time that Harvey Smith was a creative director of Dishonored.  Deus Ex was a taste changing landmark game for me.  I wasn't paying attention and the demo didn't capture my imagination at the time.  I must have been tired!This is a great first person perspective game with lots of alternative map paths to complete the missions and lots of interesting game play mechanics to change up your approaches to the many missions.  The plot was very involving for me with a great surprise twist in the middle of the game.  The voice acting is great and the dialogue has lots of variation depending upon how "chaotic" your play style.    You are going to want to play this at least twice.I am still waiting for that "good deal" to update my video card for the next generation so I have played this with a 9800 GT nvidia with just half a gig of video ram.  I can max out all of the settings and it still runs great.  The art work is beautiful.  It all works well and didn't seem at all compromised for performance at all.  You can sleep dart your opponents, sneak by them, kill them with an interesting array of weapons all having attractive displays.  I ended up using "blink" and my sword a lot so it ended up being a great sword fighting game for me against other "blinking" assassins.  I was pleasantly surprised by this.No one needs this review at this late date but I liked the game so much I just had to do it.

Posted: December 3, 2015
												I lost count of how many times I've played through this game. I love it, and for so many reasons: plot, gameplay, and replayability, to name a few.First off, the plot it actually very deep. If you're not looking for details you could easily miss it, but when you pay attention you find out all sorts of things. Arkane added a lot of depth to the story to make it more engaging, and even hid a few Easter eggs for players to find (for instance, you can find High Overseer Campbell as a weeper in the Flooded District if you elect to brand him instead of kill him earlier in the game). It's the small things that count: notes and journals that give you a glimpse into life in plague-ridden Dunwall; overhearing conversations between characters, even minor ones; hearing the experienced assassin Daud's lament over killing the Empress. Playing this game and taking the time to scour the maps for clues that reveal plot is one of the more fun and engaging things to do, even if you've finished your first playthrough.Second, gameplay. Ohhhh my, the gameplay. Even without magical powers, the gameplay is fun and there's always someone to stalk and assassinate (or choke out and hide, if that's your style). Drop assassinations never get old, and neither does taking out a Tallboy or taunting guards through an electric field that you rewired (the poor sods). But adding Blink to the party, not to mention the rest of the supernatural abilities, was the cherry on top. Allowing you the ability to do so many things, from moving silently across an open space without notice to appearing in front of an enemy and killing them before they could so much as blink (heh heh), the Blink ability increased the gameplay experience by an order of magnitude.Some gameplay factors also increased the replay value of the game, namely those factors allowing you to choose between options. You get to experiment with so many different ways to take out a target, and if you want to spare his life, there's a way to do that too. Maybe you liked sneaking around on the ground but would like to jump on rooftops more. Do more side quests that you overlooked on other playthroughs. I even knew a guy who did a playthrough that he called "Extreme Non-Lethal," where he went undetected and only choked out the targets he absolutely had to, focusing on finding ways to slip past without being noticed. Even though the game is linear, you are still allowed enough options to permit multiple creative plays of the game, as I have done.It is worth mentioning the game that Dishonored took its notes from, which is Thief: The Dark Project. I am happy to say that Arkane was kind enough to put in an Easter egg in the game in acknowledgement of their inspiration. This can be found in Daud's base, when you stumble across two assassins training for stealth; the dialogue from that scene is taken from Thief: The Dark Project almost verbatim.TL;DR - I found Dishonored to be a very enjoyable game, and I recommend it to anyone who has a love for games featuring stealth or stabbing (don't tell my psychiatrist). It has good graphics, great gameplay, commendable replayability (especially for a single-player game), and an in-depth plot to boot.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												I usually only write reviews for the best games in my library, and Dishonored is no exception. At the time of writing this review, I've completed the game and all of its DLCs twice; high chaos and low chaos. Pros The game is designed with every possible playstyle in mind, shown especially through the level design. There's pipes on the sides of buildings, ledges, hidden secrets and plenty to explore. Want to sneak past all of the guards? Easy, just blink between ledges on buildings, over walls, and onto streetlights. Want to kill absolutely everything? No problem, just whip out your trusty pistol/crossbow/otherworldly-tool-of-destruction and blast away at the guards on the street, or maybe grab some whale oil tanks and start exploding things. The gameplay is smooth and phenomenal all throughout.The game is pretty old, but the graphics (or art style, more like) still look pretty good. There's some nice bloom/light shaft effects, and the game doesn't try too hard to look realistic, just pleasant to look at. The closest thing I can compare it to is Borderlands, minus the harsh black lines on everything.There's a hell of a lot of creativity and freedom when it comes to playing the missions. For example, let's say there's five guards in a room. You could throw a grenade in, stop time, and shoot the grenade midair with a crossbow bolt. On the other hand, you could simply blast everyone with a gust of wind, and finish off anyone who didn't die when they hit the wall.This game can run on a potato. Cons The story isn't bad, but it's not great either. You're the royal guard of the Empress, she gets killed in front of you, other government-people rush in and frame you for it. There's that.For new players, there is a bit of trial and error for certain things. This can be a pro or a con, depending on who you ask, but here's some help with that; you can't blink through a Wall of Light. Arc Pylons aren't so dangerous if you're above them or below them. That should save you a couple of deaths if you're new.Not much else in the cons department. Conclusion 9/10, only wish the game could've been a bit longer (there's 9 missions in the main game, give or take 5-6 hours if you know what you're doing).

One of my all time favorite! - 10/conspiraciesHe has cut through armies of men, drown himself in rage and in the blood of street rats. of nobles. of assassins, trying to prove his innocent.But, he has also spared all of their souls as he walked from street to street, alley to alley in shadow and in the hope of saving his beloved ones.He has watched his empress died, and watched as his blade slithed open the throat of her murderer.But, he has also spared the assassin's life, giving him another chance after cutting through the assassin's army on a swamp.He has been dishonored, saved, then betrayed again.He has tracked down those who wronged him, and put an end to their miserable lives.But, he has also condemned them to a fate that is worse than death.He has seen the Outsider, been challenged, then praised by him.He has heard of conspiracies, he has been in conspiracies, and he has put and end to conspiracies.His name is Corvo Attano, and this, is his tale.

Posted: December 23, 2014
												A Worthy Purchase and a Quality Stealth game that truly works with the word Stealth. The main story of Corvo and his climb back up the ladder of betrayal, backstabbing and battling through a City tettering on the edge of total ruin and underhanded higherups fully willing to ride the fall is one that shouldn't be missed. As the story is laid out through missions into and around rat infested Dunwall, Corvo must make his way through the backallies, over the chimneys and into the places normal men refuse. Finding bits of history, listening in on coversations and uncovering just how the City currently suffers in the midst of the slaying of its Empress and the dealings of its scavenging aristocrats really pulls you into a well needed sense of immersion. Some tend to dismiss the game due to the powers gifted to Corvo as he does his dirty work but they make it far from a walk in the park. - Guards, passerbys and any eye you don't want on you will spot you with ease if you don't take them seriously.- Your magic abilites are far from all powerful as well. - While elixers are sadly overly plentiful, running and gunning while guzzling them is a next to impossible play style. - Bonecharms do their job well as a perk system that changes and requires rearranging depending on just how you want to accomplish a goal.- Sleep darts while powerful are not to be relied on or else you will find yourself in more than a few corners. And in true form to accomplishing goals, there are many many ways to approach your missions and the situations they entail. From total slaughter to not even breaking skin is possible. From Ghost to Demon, the game never blocks you off or makes you wish you had taken a different path. At the end of the game, depending on just how you went about it, I'm sure that you'll be far from disappointed it or at most, only disappointed in your own actions. So is Dishonored worth it? Never doubt it.

Posted: August 24, 2014
												Dishonored feels like a spiritual successor to the earlier Thief games, but really it's only a game inspired by those great stealth games. It's hard not to notice some of the Half-Life influences and maybe even a little BioShock. Right down to Dishonored's protaginist, Carvo who sort of has a Gordon Freeman vibe. And that's not a bad thing. Unlike Gordon who wears a special suit, Carvo wears a special mask to identify himself as some sort of iconic threat of "terror" to the citizens in Dishonored's world, which is quite beautiful thanks to the Unreal Engine. I played the game on normal because I picked this game up on the limited free weekend offer and wanted to play through until the end before this game expired. Unlike the normal mode in the Thief games, Dishonored felt more user friendly and easier. I would hope Hard mode would have offered more of a challenge. Don't get me wrong I died towards certain parts (especially the last mission) and only one area had me really stumped. However, nothing like what I encountered in Thief: The Dark Project. Even though I played mainly for gameplay I didn't really pay attention to the story, but did enjoy the interactive cutscenes, characters, and animation. It's all very well done. Dishonored takes the earlier Thief games and expands and improves on that formula. The gadgets, upgrades, powers, etc are all worthwhile and entertaining even though I didn't experience them all. Dishonored has a world full of immersive atmosphere, beautiful visuals, and addictive fun gameplay. Susan Sarandon even voices a random character, but oddly it feels more like a cameo, but still a cool touch. I am all for these types of stealth games. This is the type of game that totally stands on it's own whether or not a sequel is made.

Posted: January 27, 2014
												It is not easy to define Dishonored... Would I buy it again? YesWas an enjoyable experience? YesThe StoryA well written story with a plot that stands up on its own and multiple ending, probably would have been a great plus if the story itself was developed a bit more giving more charisma to the different characters in the game as in plenty of cases the game misses the opportunity to transform a good story in a great story, games like Bioshock are an example of the level of egnadgement can be achieved with few very charimastic characters. Too often speeches are too quick, a missed opportunity to create a great story.AudioThere is not such a thing, I probably notice that a bit late in the game but there is no soundtrack, then again Bioshock was the same. Voices in game well suite the characters. Sound effect are ok, not all level have much atmosphere sound-wise (I played the game with true 5.1 headset). GameplaySomething that reminds me of Bioshock, many things actually reminded me of it without never quiet reach the same quality level, good number and type of weapons and different upgrades, how you equip Corvo will affect the way you play the game it all depends if you are aiming to play stealth or "fps" style, this will affect the main story and ending. All kills are more or less similar a bit more of variety would have helped.GraphicProbably the biggest let down, don't take me wrong I am in the team of people saying that graphic isn't all however slightly polished textures and some more particles effects would have helped, the game is still using the Unreal Engine 3 that after so many years shouldn't be something new to programmer. However despite the two points there the game has its own style it is like to be in "steam-punk paint" and after the first hour or so you get use to the style adopted and you even start liking it. I probably wouldn't have been happy to pay the game full price, but for £15 is a must have and hopefully the developer will enhance the sequel with a better served story and a more polished graphic. Also the game can be finished pretty quickly however it has a good replay-ability as if you play stealth you may want to see how the story develop when playing with high chaos (killing lots of people in the cruel way possible).Try it, you won't regret it if you can cope with the above points!

Posted: January 7, 2015
												I like stealth games, so I decided to give Dishonored a go. It is fairly good, but who wouldn't expect that from the same guys who made Arx Fatalis?The story is compelling. I'll try and spell this out for you while forgoing the spoilers. You're Corvo, an agent and bodyguard of the Empress, but something terrible happens and you're to blame, stripped of all honorable titles. You must, with the help of some friends, stealthily take down or kill your way through the people who've set you up as the fall guy.The gameplay is simple and probably deceptively so. Basically, you're given the an objective, such as, "Get from point A to point B and eliminate this target." You'll encounter enemies along the way and you will have to decided to either kill them, eliminate them non-leathally or just sneak past.To aid you in your quests you're given tools of magically fast loading flintlock pistols and crossbows, a sword and some special abilities. These special abilities will help you either sneak or kill. The most important is probably "blink." It's sort of like a teleport, but it's not instantaneous and enemies can see you if you blink in front of them. You can also stop time, possess people and animals, the obligatory "reveal all enemies and obsticles for a short period of time" stealth game ability and some other cool stuff. The soundwork is pretty good. Nice, crunchy dissonant orchestral work juxtaposed with some beautiful stuff. My only complaint is that there was one point where there were some fireworks and the sound actually clipped. I hadn't experienced that in a AAA title for... in recent memory. It's not that big of a deal though.The level design is great, as it should be. Stealth games rely on good level design and this one doesn't pull any punches. Almost every enemy encounter is a puzzle in itself with more than a few solutions =)All in all, I'd say I'm pretty happy with Dishonored. I haven't played the DLC, but I'll get into that later.
