Posted: June 30, 2015
												This game is amazing. I have played it through multiple times on Xbox and have just now finished it on PC. This game is definitely worth the price, and then some. Had it not been for the graphics making people's foreheads look like the Gobi Desert, it would be pefect. If you overlook the graphics, which are pretty damn good for when it was released, this game could not be better. Corvo is a badass Royal Protector looking for vengeance, and you can kill your way to revenge, or you be all sneaky and assert revenge very very personally. Like knocking out a torturer and tossing him at a wall multiple times and still getting an acheivement for not killing anyone. Oh, and then the DLCs for this game!! Most DLCs for games are just ♥♥♥♥♥♥ little things meant to make the company money, but these are amazing and alot of fun. You can spend hours, or just rush through, but I recommend taking your time. A side note: Witches and Gravehounds are scary! Ahem-  Continuing on, we are trying to write a review here. Okay.... The story in Knife of Dunwall is okay, but a little short. I did just go on a massacre as being stealthy is a little difficult in this DLC. In the end there is an amazing plot twist. I will not reveal it. But you do play as Daud, the renowned assassin. Brigmore Witches is an amazing experience. I nearly♥♥♥♥♥♥ myself each time the Gravehounds howl. You will definitely need the powers you can buy for this one. Also, I recommend purchasing favors to get things done easier. I eventually got♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥with the witches and just blew them up cause they're scary, but if you are not scared by evil witches with supernatural powers and dogs that have a hellish howl, you'll be fine. I know this has been a long review, but now I'll tell you about the actual game with no DLCs. It is a great storyline and your choices affect the outcome of the game. You can get high or low chaos depending on you actions. High chaos comes from killing people, and low chaos comes from being stealthy and avoiding them. Try for the Ghost, Shadow, Mostly Flesh and Steel, and Clean Hands acheivements all in one go. I almost succeeded, but upgrading Blink goes against Flesh and Steel. I got the rest though. And not killing payed off with a very nice ending and a great feeling of success. Corvo is the Royal Protector of Lady Emily the Empress. You are framed for a murder and must escape prison. It all goes from that to having to seek revenge against an evil, corrupt tyrant, and choosing to seek revenge on other people that wronged you. It is just an amazing story, and if you made it this far through the review, congratulations!! I would give you a cake, but it's a lie... So have a virtual cookie!! :D And go buy this game now. It's definitely worth the money.On another sidenote: I have only had this game for a week or so on PC and already have more hours on it than I do on GTAV, which I've had since release. Just putting that out there. This game is amazing. And obviously better than GTA.

												SUMMARYAmazing blend of stealth and action, with an interesting steampunk universe to explore and loot and an amazing art style from the designers that brought you City 17. THE GOOD-Cool and useful powers for the player to use-Multiple playthrough options and strategies-RPG-lite leveling of skills and inventory to make Corvo a better assassin-Environments are amazing, and a joy to explore-Music is foreboding, and the atmosphere is dripping with styleTHE BAD-The guards repeat a lot of their dialogue throughout the game. It's kind of charming, in a way.-Not the most difficult stealth gameplay once you get used to the game's features, but it soon becomes a challenge of how to use your skills to maximum effect.I highly recommend this game! Especially worth checking out if it goes on sale. The Daud DLC is very interesting, and shows a lot more of the city of Dunwall and the plots surrounding Corvo.

Posted: November 25, 2016
												Dishonored is an amazing stealth based FPS where you have several different tools to get through each level in your own way. For example, group of 4 guards. You can blink past them and rewire their electric turret to kill each of them in less than a second. Or you can throw a grenade, freeze time and shoot the grenade out of the air with a crossbow. Or you can spawn a pile of flesh eating rats that will eat them alive. Or you can freeze time and shoot each of them with each invididual projectile, which is the normal gun, a normal dart, a sleep dart, and an exploding dart. Or you can lob a tank of exploding whale oil at them. Or you can summon an incredibly strong whirlwind and knock them off a cliff. Or you can simply run up and stab each of them old fasioned style.The possiblities with this game are nearly endless, and it has such a rich story with different endings, that one playthrough is simply not enough. To anyone who wants to be a ghost, a ninja, a warrior or anything in between, play this.10/10. Cheers.

Posted: July 7, 2015
												'Dishonored' is a first person stealth rpg game in a steampunk setting with an awesome storyline.First you have to know: The game is published by Bethesda! (Bethesda RPGs are always excellent IMO)You play as Corvo Attano, bodyguard to the Empress of the Isles, who gets in contact with the Outsider. You level Corvo by collecting runes. Corvo has six active and four passive powers:Active: Dark Vision, Blink, Possession, Devouring Swarm, Bend Time and Wind BlastPassive: Agility, Blood Thirsty, Shadow Kill, VitalityNone of these powers are pointless! You can play Corvo as YOU like to play the game:For example::: Killing slyly out of the shadows by using Blink/Bend Time and Shadow Kill/Blood Thirsty:: Playing non-lethal by using Blink/Possession and Agility:: Being Rambo by using Devouring Swarm/Wind Blast and Vitality/Blood Thirsty:: etc.Pros:+ Awesome sound on vision+ Imaginative abilities + None of the abilities are pointless.+ Excellent storyline+ High replayability+ Smooth course of the game(+ Brilliant DLCs; except "City Trials")(+ "Easy" collectable achievements)Cons:- not lip-sync- less hostile NPCs- unimaginative weapons (sword, pistol, grenades, mines)(- Graphics are not up to date)Recommended, even if it's not on sale, because of the great storyline and the excellent game mechanics.9/10

Posted: January 3, 2015
TechnicalsMenu is responsive and fairly optimized for PC, with plenty of displayed elements and no ridiculously large fonts. Graphical options aren't too varied, but acceptable. There's an FOV slider. There are plenty of gameplay options, such as the ability to hide UI elements or disable tutorial popups. There is no mouse acceleration. Separate audio channels for music/sfx/voice. All in all, it's a solid PC game, with no obvious console influences.GameplayI played on Hard. I hardly engaged in combat throughout the game, so I can't really comment on how the combat is. For what it's worth though, stealth is very very easy in this game. Blink is incredibly overpowered, especially when you consider that enemies take time to aggro. Once you get used to the timings, you can very easily manipulate the AI such that you're just blinking around on the edge of the AI's aggro meter.But stealth is fun. Lots of ways to get around objectives. Maps have lots of verticality, which is always nice for stealth.Combat is not neglected. About half the available powers are combat oriented.ControlsVery fluid! Mouse sensitivity has small enough steps to allow you to fine-tune your sensitivity. No mouse acceleration! Hitboxes are fairly accurate. Guns have no spread, I think. Bullets and projectiles have no drop or damage falloff. Headshots are very satisfying with the brief slow-mo. I think the solid controls are one of this game's main strengths.Collectibles & pick upsEvery map has a number of things to collect, from paintings to runes to bone charms. They're not particularly rewarding or even remotely required to progress though. I pretty much ignored all collectibles because I had no use for gold or power upgrades. I went through the game barely upgrading anything and with only upgraded Blink and Agility powers, and it was easy. Maybe if you were playing on Very Hard and are actively trying to cripple your playstyle to increase difficulty, then I could see these collectibles becoming essential. In its current state though, they're more for fun rather than necessity.StoryThis is not a god-tier or even top-tier story. It's average at best, but it certainly is engaging. Typical trope of using a likeable child character who looks up to you as the protagonist in order to instill a sense of protectiveness. It's cliche, but executed really well. The gameplay complements the story very well, so while the story by itself isn't that good, the overall package is quite stellar.GripesMan I hate silent protagonists.

Posted: August 25, 2014
												From what i have played of the game so far (less than 10 hours 1-3 missions) the game is fantastic. the art style is amazing but slightly cartoony. This isnt a bad decision its just there. The combat is difficult and you cant just go swinging your sword around like a beserker and win. The game WILL punish you for trying to be a beserker and murder everyone you see. However if you play it quiet and never hurt anyone but your targets the game will reward you in ways i wont spoil for you. The story is very good but slightly predictable. Your the guardian to a queen her bodyguard infact. After she is murdered and she tells you her last words while dying in your arms the guards and conspirators against you find you you're hauled off to jail to await your fate. Unknown allies rescue you and from there the story really gets going. the game loves exploration and manipulation of the games powers. i never had any sort of gamebreaking glitch or texture glitch or horrible AI experience *Cough Rome 2 TW Cough Cough* the AI if it detects you will really try to hunt you down. My one concern is it seemed a little too easy to sneak past but maybe thats because i was playing on normal difficulty. Game mechanics are solid and no two playthroughs will be the same unless you specifically TRY to make it exactly the same. you have a variety of powers that are oh so fun you mess with and you cant have them all so you have to choose wisely. Overall the games a good buy especially at the current 5$ of the sale. Easily worth the 20 though. If you really love the game then the Game of the year edition takes you a step further with Daud the legendary Dunwall assassin who killed the Empress as your main protagonist and his story for redemption. The game is good and is worth a purchase.

Posted: August 28, 2013
												This was a cool game. I love the character design, atleast for the main character. The gameplay, for the most part, is exciting. With all of the abilities and options you have at your disposal, you feel very powerful. Sometimes, though, you can be a little too powerful. I played through for the first time on the hardest difficulty without a hitch. It's possible to play through the whole game without being seen or killing anyone, but that can get kinda tedious. Why have all of these brutal abilities if you can't use them? As the game progressed I got more ruthless and stopped worrying about not being seen or not killing. One gripe I have with this game is the skill point collectibles. Since they are necessary to get more abilities, you constantly have to go out of your way to collect them. The story was good and kept me interested the whole time. The world feels alive.

Posted: September 14, 2013
												Well, I recently finished Dishonored and I can honestly say it was one of the best games I played this year! I did a low chaos run; minimal killing, no alarms from the half-way point onwards. Had lots of fun being the ultimate blinking, time-stopping ninja! :DThe story is a little straightforward, leading you on a path of revenge and redemption after being framed for the murder of the Empress. Missions generally revolve around an assassination target that needs to be removed in order to dismantle the new regime that has seized control of the Empire. There are also some missions that take a different approach (Lady Boyle's party was one of my favorite parts of the game).Your skills start small but can be developed to be quite devastating by the end of the game. It reminds me a lot of a Ninja-Bioshock; granting you an array of magic powers which are always at your disposal provided you have sufficient mana vials. Except in Dishonored you won’t be flinging lightning bolts or jets of fire, instead you are armed by much sneakier skills such as a mini-teleport, mind control, time control and the ability to see though walls.The level design is one of the best parts of Dishonored. While they may seem small or linear at first glance, a player who is willing to explore will find many different routes to their objectives. There are also many hidden items to loot, runes and charms to find which will improve your abilities and lore to be read in the form of notes, books and audio logs.I would strongly recommend Dishonored to the type of player who loves to explore a world, peeling back the layers and really getting absorbed into the experience. While you could play the game by running directly to the objective and killing everyone in your path, I feel you would be robbing yourself of so much more game that is being offered here.

Posted: January 9, 2016
												This game. Holy cow. What can I say about this game? It's hard to know where to start. I love stealth games but I think this is the first time I had one draw me in to this degree. It didn't take me long to get hooked. Of course I enjoyed the gameplay itself. Enough that I played it through in it's entirety twice. I really, really urge anyone playing for the first time to go for the High Chaos play first. It gives more impact to the Low Chaos play. And believe me, if you get as invested as I did, once you get the High Chaos end you're going to want that Low Chaos end. Can the Low Chaos play be frustrating? Absolutely. I put nearly 40 hours overall into this game, getting all three endings. (Yes. There's a third. It's considered worse than the High Chaos end. But you'll have to figure out how to get that yourself. No spoilers here. Though if you're paying attention it shouldn't be too hard to discern where the choice is that'll get you the third ending.) I feel like it has a strong story, good characters and manages to be fun despite being frustrating at times. I even managed to find Emily likable enough, when usually child characters are played up in a way that's somewhat annoying at the very least. I absolutely recommend this game. That said, if stealth games aren't your thing you probably won't enjoy everything this has to offer and might find certain aspects of the Low Chaos run very tedious or frustrating. I, personally, enjoyed this game immensely and look forward to it's sequel!

Posted: August 24, 2013
												Dishonored feels like Bioshock meets Hitman: Absolution with a mix of Assassin's Creed and a pinch of Darkness 2. The gameplay is very enjoyable and offers a multitude of play styles to suit your individual taste. The basic climbing aspects combined with the Blink power makes for some fluid and easy movements in the vertical space.The graphics really didn't inspire me to say wow, but they did fit the dark plague theme. It was also hard to understand the timeline between the plague (past) and available technology (futuristic). I also didn't really grasp the supernatural storyline at all so that aspect left me confused, but the revenge storyline was highly enjoyable. Although I always found it weird that a couple of drunk alcoholics kept barking orders at me to kill people while they got to sit in their cozy little bar and drink all day.Unfortunately there was too much reading--I ended up skipping most of the historical books which I probably would have followed if the passages offered voice overs.Despite the minor imperfections, Dishonored is genuinely a good game. For me, the gameplay is what shined and that is why I would play it again.

Posted: January 6, 2015
												Buy this game.  The game is a great stealth/assassination type game with some great weapons/powers to make the whole experience fun and enjoyable.  The story is a little predicatable and some of the characters a little bland and underdeveloped but the narative, enviroments and atmosphere of the game as a whole make for a great experience.SPOILER WARNING:  However with all that being said there were several design choices that to me made no sense and took away from the game experience as a whole.  First off, it isn't until after your first mission/area is completed that you are told that if you kill or just incapacitate the guards\civilians\etc... it makes a difference.  That kind of thing needs to be front and center BEFORE you get the chance to knife the first guy, because that makes a big difference in how I want to approach the game.Secondly, the subtitle for this game should probably read "I HOPE YOU LIKE A THOUSAND SHADES OF BROWN!!!".  One of the first powers I took and maxed was a power that let you see all items and enemies in a close proximity to you.  I thought that was awesome, I can discover a lot of hidden objects, see where are all the enemies are, what direction they are facing for stealth take outs and where they are going to set up my next stealth take out.  The problem with this power is that it turns the whole enviroment different shades of brown then highlights all people/enemies as yellow and items as green.  Because this power costs little mana/energy and you can regenerate that little bit it uses there is no penalty for having this on and helping set up awesome stealth kills/take downs.  The problem becomes that the game is brown ALL THE TIME.  You can't enjoy the fantastic enviroments that were made or the design of Dunwall because the game was brown for me half the time.  I think a better option could have been made that didn't result in having a brown screen for most of the game.Lastly, it was incredibly frustrating going through this game and trying to not kill people.  Not because it was hard or anything, but it seems that the game from a control standpoint vastly favoured you trying to kill your targets instead of incapacitating them.  For example, if you get behind someone to make a stealth take down you get several different options.  You can kill them, chocke them(incapacitate them) or just loot them if they have something to be looted.   With killing the target it doesn't seem to matter where you are in relation to your target as long as you are somewhere behind/beside/above them.  However with choking/incapacitating them you have be in a very particular spot and sometimes the action button doesn't show up for second or two, especially when you drop in behind your target or use your movement power to land behind him.  This made it incredibly frustrating at times to try to string together a set of stealth take downs or resulted in being detected by your target.Again those are mostly minor annoyances, the game is fantastic and I highly recommend it.

Posted: June 18, 2015
												NOTE: This review is based of the time I played it on XBOX 360, I realize I only have .6 hours of play on PC.Dishonored is one of those games that comes out and alot of people tend to overlook, and it's sad, since this is probably one of the best games to come out of 2012.The game starts out as you return home as Corvo, Guard to the Empress.  Arriving back, you are then later attacked by a group of unknowns and the Empress is killed in front of you and her daughter, Emily, is taken away.  You are then framed for the murder and dissapearance and are taken away to be executed.  From then on, it's your choice of how you play.  Do you choose to take revenge by killing everyone, or do you take the stealthy route and only bring those who wronged you to justice?Thoughts about PC Port:  The PC version of this game seems to run very well on Max settings, (Running on a Radeon HD 7800 and AMD 8 Core Proccessor @4ghz) with it staying at a consistent 60fps and never seeming to drop.  There is controller support if you do choose to play with one, but I prefer to play with KB+M since it allows for easier access to your weapons with the number keys.Overall, this is a great game, and if you are a fan of stealth games or just looking for a new IP that won't dissapoint, Dishonored is definetly worth the full price.

Posted: June 14, 2015
												Dishonored has to be one of the most under rated games I've ever played. I have to admit that when I first started I wasn't too sure about it, but as the game progressed, it grew on me. If you like fast paced games that blow by you, this game is not for you. The story is intricate and the game play is such that it feels familiar but has something not found in most games. Bethesda left their usual mechanics behind for this one. A rare gem on it's own, with it's borderline steam punk feel, strange soundtrack and slightly repetative but interesting dialogue I have to admit this game is not boring.Not truly an open world game it still has the feel of one, The graphics are different but well done and the characters, are interesting. There is one part of the game, with the risk of a spoiler, that feels a bit disjointed and removed from the rest of the game. That soon passes and the game returns to it's normal flow and feeling. All in all I enjoy playing Dishonored and find it an intelligent and well thought out game with enough action and puzzle solving to keep it interesting to the end.

Posted: June 29, 2014
												I can't believe it took me so long to play through this game.  The combat system is superb.  It's frustrating to fail, but you never want to stop chasing the next target.  Don't judge the game within the first 20 minutes of playing.  At least try out the first two missions.  By the time I finished playing my first play through on normal, I realized how many different ways I could've ended the game and that I couldn't just choose between a couple of options at the end of the game to see what could happen.  The replay value is significant and I do expect to be purchasing the DLC.  I recommend this game to anyone who doesn't mind violence, not that you have to kill anyone if you don't want to, or everyone if you so choose to do so.  There is so much freedom in this game.  Dishonored is possibly the best title I've seen released from Bethesda, though they never fail to dissapoint and this is a testament to that.  This was such an outlet for pent up aggression.  Good work Bethesda.  I'm glad I purchased the game when it was $60, even if I didn't play it until the summer sale when I saw it at $4.99.  The mechanics are fluid, the artwork is on par with that of far cry 3, perhaps even better in it's 18th century feel.  I love this game.  "Revenge solves everything"

Posted: November 25, 2013
												Amazing; The basic idea of Dishonored is freedom. Every level is lovingly crafted to present a variety of options, and the game's mechanics are perfectly tuned to present you with even more ways to accomplish goals, ones that the developers could never have foreseen. The characters are not particularly beatiful, but the art succeeds in creating the desired atmosphere.You can explore the world, or rush straight through to your goal. You can kill everyone in sight, only your targets, or literally no-one. You can teleport around a guard, stab him, shoot him, feed him to the rats ...It is like Thief where you can hold your ground in a fight, or like an action game where you do not have to fight at all. Moment-to-moment gameplay is smooth and well-executed, whether you are sneaking or fighting.This game's fame is well deserved.

Posted: November 19, 2012
												Dishonored feels like it was developed in an alternate universe in which Gears of War (and other games of that ilk) never existed. No brown/grey filter, no snapping to cover, and it's over ten hours long with no multiplayer whatsoever and no fully open world (though the levels are pretty nonlinear). It's a stealth game in which stealth is the only viable option--it's borderline impossible to rambo through it even on the easiest difficulty setting. This is a game that wasn't focus grouped to death; it feels like the developers had a clear vision of what they wished to accomplish and made few (if any) substantive compromises.One will not find bombastic setpieces here, just clever level design clad in a gorgeous, clean art style backed up by fantastic sound design. The structure is reminiscent of Assassin's Creed 1 (a game I loved) in that each mission goes through planning, infiltration, execution, and escape stages, which is something I'd love to see more of in games. The story itself isn't amazing, but the dialogue and characterization are wonderfully written. Everything comes together to create one of the most wonderful and well-rounded games I've played so far this year.

Posted: December 29, 2013
												Now THIS is a game.When I purchased Dishonored, I was pretty sceptical about everything - I believed it was just gonna be a mix of AC and Elder Scrolls involving mindless violence. However, when I started playing it properly, I really began to appreciate how brilliant the game really is. The art style is amazing, as is the voice acting and animation style. All three help you get immersed even more in the game, and effectively too.The gameplay is also stunning, with the choices you make (I refer to the fact that you can complete the game without killing ANYONE) effecting the outcome and storyline greatly. The combat system is much better, much more challenging and much more precise than I expected, and is one of my favourite features of the game. The game overall is quite challenging, making you think about your every step before you take it, and at the same time it's extremely enjoyable. Dishonored is now probably one of my favourite games, and I strongly recommend buying it. It's well worth the money.

Posted: January 12, 2014
												So I just finished this game. I have to say - I absolutely loved the story, the setting, and the way your choices affected the way events played out. The game itself is played as a relatively short series of relatively long missions. Along the way, there's many things to collect that can easily be missed - bone charms that disappear if you don't nab them at a certain point, changing audio logs of NPCs and fleeting conversations. The former can be a bit frustrating, but the latter is always fun to collect, and illustrates the characters around you nicely. The powers were quite fun to use, and the game provided many, many ways to proceed on missions; things were never impossible, but having a certain ability would often open up a path. My largest complaint, however, would be that the game hands you a wide arsenal of killing tools and powers and then heavily discourages using them. The game has, basically, two paths; low chaos (nonlethal, stealth) and high chaos (lethal). There's a third tier, very high chaos, which is for the most part the same as high chaos, but nets even worse reactions from your allies (at this point, your Corvo Attano is pretty much murdering everyone he sees for ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles.) High chaos is easier to do at the beginning, because you don't have many powers yet, and the early missions take place in populated areas - but as the game progresses, high chaos creates more enemies, worse situations, crueller allies, and darker endings. It's understandable and rationalized from a story perspective - more bodies means more rats means more plague, and your allies follow the example you make - but given how much gamers are used to killing the bad guys being a core part of games - well, expect to spend some time adjusting with Dishonored, unless you want to see cute little Emily devolve into a tyrant. Also, if you're playing stealthy, which you should be - well, expect a lot of save scumming. When I played, I was saving on average of once every two minutes, sometimes even more often.

												A very unique game with a steamPunk(Or WhalePunk more so)Vibe so it.Featuring varied ways of combat and traversing levels from running atop victorian-esque houses to skulking below guards in dingy sewers with them none the wiser.The gameplay benefits from a varied range of powers at your dispoal such as Blink,a power making you capable of swiftly teleporting forth to traverse the envrioment or swiftly dispatch a guard with a sneaky neck slice.The real star of the game is the Stealth aspect though lacking in some aspects(Non-lethal options such as weapons are generally lacking),there are so many ways to go about the levels as each area is multi-leveled with plenty of dilapidated houses which hint at a life gone past.The only real let-down is the story that is somewhat generic,you're the meperess's guard that gets framed for her murder(Hence the title dishonored)You then must go and clear your name which involves 'dealing' which various people of importance which opens up the question;Will you decapitate them in a bloody display of utter brutality or will you dispatch them with a well thought out non-lethal way?The length of the game is about 11-14 hours depending on if you choose to be a ghost unseen by the enemy or a menacing murderer(The latter usually cuts the game down to about 6-8 hours).I spent around 40+ hours on the game as i played it on Xbox 360 first and did a non-lethal,Lethal and ghost(No detection or kills) playthrough.I would highly recommend the game as it's a gem in an endless sea of generic FPS and MMOs,especially if your a fan of Deus Ex and Bioshock.

Posted: June 22, 2016
												Easily one of my favorite games ever. The world is indescribably unique and has a huge amount of character, far from a generic "dark steampunk" setting. Though the story is relatively short and the plot twist aren't hard to see coming, the characters themselves are a treat, with some very memorable faces. The Outsider in particular I think will survive in gaming memory for quite some time. And this isn't to say anything about the gameplay, which is incredibly smooth, intuitive, and engaging. It seems like there's dozens of ways to get through any given level, and though the game only has three endings, your choices affect the enemies, so it still feels like every kill-or-spare decision matters. There's never a down moment in this game. It never drags, and there are never places where you become complacent because you've learned all the enemies' tricks. It's the perfect pace and the perfect length for the gameplay it offers. 10/10, would definitely recommend, especially with the sequel coming out this year.

Posted: January 7, 2015
												I like stealth games, so I decided to give Dishonored a go. It is fairly good, but who wouldn't expect that from the same guys who made Arx Fatalis?The story is compelling. I'll try and spell this out for you while forgoing the spoilers. You're Corvo, an agent and bodyguard of the Empress, but something terrible happens and you're to blame, stripped of all honorable titles. You must, with the help of some friends, stealthily take down or kill your way through the people who've set you up as the fall guy.The gameplay is simple and probably deceptively so. Basically, you're given the an objective, such as, "Get from point A to point B and eliminate this target." You'll encounter enemies along the way and you will have to decided to either kill them, eliminate them non-leathally or just sneak past.To aid you in your quests you're given tools of magically fast loading flintlock pistols and crossbows, a sword and some special abilities. These special abilities will help you either sneak or kill. The most important is probably "blink." It's sort of like a teleport, but it's not instantaneous and enemies can see you if you blink in front of them. You can also stop time, possess people and animals, the obligatory "reveal all enemies and obsticles for a short period of time" stealth game ability and some other cool stuff. The soundwork is pretty good. Nice, crunchy dissonant orchestral work juxtaposed with some beautiful stuff. My only complaint is that there was one point where there were some fireworks and the sound actually clipped. I hadn't experienced that in a AAA title for... in recent memory. It's not that big of a deal though.The level design is great, as it should be. Stealth games rely on good level design and this one doesn't pull any punches. Almost every enemy encounter is a puzzle in itself with more than a few solutions =)All in all, I'd say I'm pretty happy with Dishonored. I haven't played the DLC, but I'll get into that later.

Posted: November 30, 2013
												Dishonored would have to be one of the very games in his genre, surpassing any others such as Assassin's Creed in my opinion. The setting of the game (a strange industrial era London type design) and sound/music builds an deep atmosphere in the game creating some truly beautiful moments. The story was impressive although not as grand as many other games out there but still worthy of praise. The gameplay itself was what made this game one of the more enjoyable ones I've played for a while. Once you figure out the initial controls it's relatively easy to learn more advanced tactics. Your "supernatural powers" can make each playthrough vastly different depending on what you decide to upgrade, whether you go for more stealth based abilities or offensive ones. The idea of having both lethal and non-lethal ways of killing both your targets and standard enemies adds a large variety to each mission, coupled with each mission have multiple ways to complete it allows you to replay it again and again without it losing it's touch. Having difference endings based upon how much "chaos" you caused was another nice feature in the game. It also has an effect on the next mission making how you plan out your course of action very important (more chaos equals a more dangerous city). Overall a brilliant game that beat my expectations at every turn. Buy it as soon as you can!

Posted: June 23, 2014
												This game is simply amazing! The stealth mechanics in it are so satisfyingly simple and easy to follow. It adds an extra layer of excitement and intensity when you play a no kill, never seen run, and the different weapons and magic abilities you can get in it  can tailor to any play style. Whether you are planning to run into a room to kill everyone with rats and grenades, or just planning to stop time and hit them all with sleep darts, this game falls nothing short of making you feel like a stealthy ninja assassin, or a completely indestructible god to be feared. Posted: July 7, 2014
												It's hard not to recommend this game. Let's start on the good stuff:> A fantastic new IP, with a great backstory and luciously dirty, grim, metallic, steam-punkesque artstyle and visuals that convey the plagued atmosphere of Dunwall excellently. Sort of a mix between Late Victorian London and the Half-life universe. >Despite having a linear story, the game offers many choices in how the missions are conducted - Stealth or Violence, you choose, with different consequences for your actions.>Stealth mechanics are well-implemented, and make you plan your method of negotiating a section, this is the game's strongest point. >Credits Song is great (neat little addition).It does have its flaws:>Depending on the way you play, the game can be very short (>8hrs).>The characters lack emotion and depth, and animations for NPCs are on the stiff and robotic side. >AI can be inconsistent (sometimes you can walk right past them,  sometimes they see you from 100s of feet away). Overall this is a 9/10, a great game that's bold and different, with a great universe that will leave you wanting more.

Posted: February 5, 2014
												Definitely a great game, but a few things are holding it back.  The gameplay itself is nearly completely solid, it gives you choices on how to go about things, and you have enough abilities and weapons so that it won't get too repetetive.  The only issues with the gameplay is it's too easy.  I was able to pretty much breeze through it, and even when you're out in the open, straight up fighting enemies, it still isn't that hard.  Also, the dark vision ability completely removes the need to be cautious, and the shadow kill ability completely removes the need to hide bodies, which makes the game even easier.  It's good gameplay, but it just isn't hard enough.The art and lore is really good, but a big problem with this game is the story.  The story itself is fine, but the morality system really ruins what could have been the perfect game about stabbing people.  You can either have fun in this game, or you can not kill anyone and get the "good ending", which I'll get to in  the end.  The morality system has no effect on the game aside from the ending, which is basically binary, although there can be slight differences in that binary ending, but nothing too significant.  If you have fun in the game and get the "bad ending", what you get is I fitting climatic end to a great game that fits the overarching themes perfectly, and is in general a brilliant ending, even if it isn't really creative.  But...on my second playthrough I got the good ending.  I feel like they had written the story without a moral system first, and then tacked on a good ending at the last minute without any regard to the themes of the story.  The story is fine, but getting the "good" ending, and even simply knowing that that ending is canon, ruins the story for me.  It's like if Great Expectations ends with Pip striking gold and making a fortune off working poor miners to death, and he's happy doing this.  It has no regard to any of the themes.  I'd recommend renaming them the "bad" ending to the "good" ending, and renaming the "good" ending to the "bad" ending (I realize that's not technically what the game calls them, but that's really what it means).Basically, even though I focused much more on what was bad, it's still really fun, and you should get it.  Just make sure you kill enough people so that the game is fun and the ending is good.

Posted: July 29, 2015
												Short Version: Dishonored is a Stealth-Game with variety and stunning gameplay that has a decent amount of replay potential7.5/10UPDATE: 9/10Reason for update: This game has insane lore and little hidden stories that make you want to read every thing you see in the City of Dunwall and piece everything together!Long Version: Take a seat, grab some snacks, and prepare yourself for an IGN-Youtube style review!Dishonored is primarily a stealth game with the usual concepts provided in stealth-genre games such as variety in how you can playthrough the game, a basketfull of tools to get you through the game with any amount of beautiful slaughter, as well as new mechanics unique to the game. OVERALL GAMEPLAY   Dishonored has generic stealth gameplay, along with the possibility to run through the entire game blasting, burning, serrating, and electrifying everyone you can think of. The missions do not force you to play in one certain style letting you do whatever you please, or just experiment with anyway you see fit.   Although the gameplay doesn't leave you feeling like you need to stay stealthy by putting you defenseless, nor does it make you feel like you are the center of the world (although in the end, you do put an influence on the weather!), but the game itself could use improvements. MECHANICS   Dishonored is unique in one aspect in comparison to the big-name stealth games out there like Metal Gear Solid, Thief, Splinter Cell, and the Batman Arkham Series. Dishonored gives you superpowers. The catch is, you don't even need to use all of them. You could play nearly the entire game without ever using the powers once, you could play the game using every power.  Blink: Allows you to silently move from one location to another location in the distance. Dark Vision: View life, gadgets, riches, and even noise through walls. You can also summon swarms of rats, slow or even stop time, possess people and animals, or blow people away with the wind! You can also modify the world around you, increasing your health, turning people to ashes, jumping higher, and make your enemies miss their shots (because they're scared and weak!) ET CETERA   There's replayability in the sense that you'd want to challenege yourself. The few amount of hours I've played is due to me constantly speedrunning the game in different playstyles.  Dishonored has a morale system that affects the world around you. Want to kill everyone? The consequence? Zombies and rats. Leave everyone alone? Brighter skies, more guilty friends.  Dishonored is a beautiful game and I definitely recommend playing the game before you play the second one coming out  IN 2016 AAUAUAUUUUUUGUGUHHHHHH  Closing Thoughts The game doesn't have enough beautifully built structure to buy while at full price, but it's definitely worth buying during any sale. Even if it's just 10% off.78/100 -TrixxieDesu! of TrixxiePlaysPiano

Posted: August 15, 2013
												Dishonored tells the story of Corvo Attano, bodyguard to the Empress of the Empire of Isles and ruler of the city of Dunwall. Wrongfully accused of her assassination, Corvo must clear his name and save Emily, daughter to the Empress and heir to the throne. The game tells a dark and gripping tale, and as Corvo you have absolute control over how it ends. Will you be merciful to the people who have wronged you, or will you act as an angel of vengeance and murder all those who dare stand in your way?Dishonored is quite unlike any stealth action game out there. With sprawling levels that reward exploration and thoroughness, great combat mechanics that feel tight as a drum, a beautiful watercolour art style and absolute freedom to go where you want and play how you want, this game is the true heir to such classics as Thief: The Dark Project and Deus Ex.

Posted: May 4, 2016
												The verticality of the gameplay is awesome - I was still finding rooms, corridors, and basements after having played through several times.  You can specialize your powers for stealth or aggression, and you can choose how deeply you immerse yourself in the world: focus just on the mission objectives, or take the time to find and read the books, letters, notes, and the Heart's commentary that flesh it out into something that obviously took a lot of thought.  It's tropey and reminds me a bit of a fairy tale in terms of narrative, but all in a way that's fun rather than boring and an homage to the genre.My main dissatisfaction is with the changes made between difficulty levels.  I had hoped that more enemies, or at least new patrol paths, would appear on the greatest difficulty, but the only thing that changes is the enemies' perceptiveness.  When you already know who is where and when, the difficulty doesn't actually change that much.

Posted: June 18, 2015
												NOTE: This review is based of the time I played it on XBOX 360, I realize I only have .6 hours of play on PC.Dishonored is one of those games that comes out and alot of people tend to overlook, and it's sad, since this is probably one of the best games to come out of 2012.The game starts out as you return home as Corvo, Guard to the Empress.  Arriving back, you are then later attacked by a group of unknowns and the Empress is killed in front of you and her daughter, Emily, is taken away.  You are then framed for the murder and dissapearance and are taken away to be executed.  From then on, it's your choice of how you play.  Do you choose to take revenge by killing everyone, or do you take the stealthy route and only bring those who wronged you to justice?Thoughts about PC Port:  The PC version of this game seems to run very well on Max settings, (Running on a Radeon HD 7800 and AMD 8 Core Proccessor @4ghz) with it staying at a consistent 60fps and never seeming to drop.  There is controller support if you do choose to play with one, but I prefer to play with KB+M since it allows for easier access to your weapons with the number keys.Overall, this is a great game, and if you are a fan of stealth games or just looking for a new IP that won't dissapoint, Dishonored is definetly worth the full price.

Posted: February 16, 2015
												My name is Corvo and I am an assassin.Have you ever wanted to play an assassin's creed game in first person or good theif game or hybrid of them. This is the game for you. Developed by Arcane studios (the guys who made the great game Dark Messiah) comes 'Dishonored' a stealth and action game hybrid.The story is alright. You play as Corvo, the empress's body gaurd who has just returned home after a long business trip. Things go awry quickly as group of assailants kill the empress and you get framed for the murder. On your quest for revenge against those who framed you will join a variety of characters to asist in hunting down those responsible for the crime.The gameplay is where this game trully shines. Basically you have missions to complete. Each mission sets you in small area to complete your objectives. You have both primary and secondary objectives. Primary objectives generally involves eliminating a target (lethal or non-lethally) or stealling/tamper with something. Secondary objectives are basically your side quests (which you may find in the map area) and are somewhat similar to primary objectives except it doesn't move the plot that much and you get a special reward for completing them (e.g. money, bone charm etc).You start off with the basic blade and pistol, holding range weapons /spells on the left and your melee weapon on the right. You can't buy any new weapons in the game (you may find some during the game though), but in between missions you can upgrade damage of your weapons, ammo capacity and armor which all costs money. You can also buy grenades to help take out blobs of foes. The final piece to your arsenal are magic powers. You start of with the blink ability (the most useful one), which allows you to quickly dash torwards the targeted location. Using magic powers drains your magic bar, which takes time to regnerate. Each spell cost a certain amount of magic to use, so it's important to learn them before using them in tough situations. As you play you may find objects which allow you to learn new spells (such as rat swarm) or upgrade existing ones. Furthermore, there are equipable items called 'bone charms' which gives you a certain perk (e.g.better powers, quicker movement etc).You can approach the missions in 3 ways: kill everyone, knock out people or don't kill anyone at all (you can mix them up if you wish). Furthermore, you can choose to use only range/melee/spells through out the whole game. As such you can play this as a thief, assassin, mage, shooter or mix of all of them. This open ended gameplay allows you to play the  game your way and add alot of freedom for the player. You face a variety of foes including gaurds, dogs, assassins, plants, each having a unique attack and reaction to the player. there are different endings depending on how you play the game.The map design is superb. Most of the time you have variety of ways to approach the target. Buildings have multiple windows to climb through as well as front and back doors to access. Sometimes there may also be tunnels available as well. Within the buldings there are plenty of furniture and items to hide behind and rooms to hide in as well.Audio adds to the atmosphere of the game. Quite and ambient music is played while your sneaking around, while in contrast to being spotted by foes a more fast pace track is played to add to the tensity of the situation. Also a feature I like is that when you are spotted by a gaurd, an alarm sound plays which allows you to quickly hide from sight or blink away. Weapon noises sound great easpecially gun shots.I highly reommend this game to people who want to experience a first person stealth action game that is all about choice.

												Finally got round to playing this game after picking it up for 4.99 a year ago! There's three things I really like about it:1. The playability. Movement is smooth and controls intuitive. And you can make lots of customisations to the user interface to make it play exactly as you like it.2. The steam achievements. There's loads of them and they make you do things in the game you wouldn't normally think about. Adds a layer of depth.3. Stealth versus lethal. And the combination of weapons and powers. Being able to play the game as you want to in your own style and not be penalised for it, instead it simply changes the story slightly. Genius.I can see why it scored over 90 in the metacritic score. Excellent game and well worth the fiver!

												This is a game with an excellent story and gameplay but where it truly shines is in weaving the two. It's one of the rare instances of a game where how you choose to play matters even if it doesn't have the marquee 'huge moral choices' of a Bioware game. Posted: August 7, 2016
												What can I possibly say about this game that I don't find in other reviews?One thing you ought to know, this game is very very very easy. Wether you choose to play it as a ghost or as the mystic god of murder, it's not that challanging. Why is that? Simple, your character is absurdly insanely OP. You are not a thief, you are not an assassin, you are basically the grim reaper, death incarnate. You are not immortal, bullets will hurt you, so will falling from high. Yet you are able to stop time, you can teleport to safety should you miss a jump, you can see through walls and even possess living beings to better infiltrate and exfiltrate enemy territory. Nothing can possibly stop you exept the witches in the second DLC, and even those can be handled without too much sweat if you get the jump on them.Yet despite this major flaw, the games has many virtues. The atmosphere is spot on. The visuals are charming and sometimes downright breathtaking. The world is grim, yet colorful and interesting, I just wish there was more of it to explore. The plot is very simple and straightforward, but still serviceable. It's one of the few games where I preferred the bad endings (among three possible outcomes).But the greatest virtue of the game is the level design. These truly feel like places rather then videogame stages and due to your supernatural abilities you can navigate in pretty much anyway you want. Not to mention how good they look.Dunwall is packed full with drunken whalers. And what do we do with the drunken whaler?

Posted: March 29, 2014
												The phrase “stealth mechanic” and/or “stealth mission” probably causes the everyday gamer to shudder. More often than not these are tedious, slow portions of a story which usually highlight the worst in level design, mechanics, and AI shenanigans. What starts off as the "good intentions" of a player in trying to properly sneak around ends up with the Rambo'ing of an entire level out of sheer frustration.Not with Dishonored.I've yet to play any stealth based game, including any Metal Gear Solid offering (arguably considered the king of stealth) that supplies the level of fluidity, options, and satisfaction in not being seen or shedding a single drop of blood that Dishonored provides. So much so that any time I had my cover broken, and invariably forced to switch to lethal methods, I felt a sense of responsibility to the spirit of the story to load a previous save and try utilizing different areas of the level or player abilities to successfully get through said portion completely unseen. In any other game I would consider this a complete waste of time, and slightly insane. But like I said, the “cool factor” of the stealth here is so freaking cool that you have to indulge it. The atmosphere, level design, and characters within the game are equally top notch. One thing I really appreciated was the fact that you don't have to suspend your disbelief too hard to get into the role of the main character, as the design decision not to make him talk (or see what he looks like) is absolutely the right one for a game of this nature. Brilliant all around. Can't wait for the sequel.

Posted: June 14, 2014
												If you have ever played Mirror's Edge and thought "Gee this game would be even better if I could sneak by these guys or drop down and assassinate them" then Dishonored may be the game for you. It nails first person platforming very well.There's a lot of choice in this game, there are many different play styles and an impressive amount of diffrent routes to tackle a mission. It definitely encourages multiple playthroughs.A few downsides are the fact story is pretty meh (you were betrayed, you must take revenge, you must save a little girl, blah blah) it's been done quite a bit.  Also upgraded Blink makes the game FAR too easy, you can honestly miss out on alot of Dishonored's content just by blinking across rooftops. Even if you don't do that, if you're a veteran of the stealth genre, you'll find this game not that challenging in general.But the way it fluidly mashes stealth and platforming more then makes up for it, it's quite the blast to play. Apparently the DLC is pretty good as well.

Posted: November 28, 2013
												Revenge solves everything in Dishonored.You play as the silent hero Corvo as being tasked with being the protector of the Empress. After an assassination you are framed with the murder of the one you where hired to protect along with the kidnapping of her daughter Emily. A day before you are to be executed you are broken out of prison by conspirators to begin your path to vengenance. Bestowed with powers by the so called Overseer it is up to you to carry out your judgement.The game encourages choice at all times. Carry out destruction and death to your target or be the ghost in the shadows as you hunt your prey, murder or destroy their life it is your choice. The game can be cleared with killing no one, not even you target. A good example is branding a high ranking religious figure as a heretic effectively casting him out ruining his life.The weapons are simple and not complicated Sword, Crossbow, bombs and mines fill your arsenal, however it is where your powers from the void inspire greatness. Being able to teleport, slow-time, see through walls and summon a plague of flesh eating rats encourages experimentation, being able to combine them sweetens the deal.The world of Dishonored is all settled in the city of Dunwall with codex entries fleshing out the world to a massive decree that matches Mass Effect lore. Run down districts with the clear seperation of the exploited poor with the corrupt rich in a steam punk world and breath taking visuals in a semi-open world is well done. Choose how you want to reach your target, sneak past guards on the ground or take to the rooftops and even crawl through the Dunwall sewers. Story changes based on your choices of gameplay, a high death streak cause the plague striking the city to fester causing more plague victims called Weepers to roam  the streets and increase in guard activity. Stealth maintains a calm atmosphere with basic guard duty unaware of your presence.  The game does have that sense of it should be played with stealth being the key as a gun-ho approach can rob you of what the game wants you to do but also the lenght of completetion striking missions from 2 hours to 1 hour doing a reckless approach, this of course robs you of the games merits of exploring its possibilities.The game unfortunately lacks a New Game Plus but hungry players can avail of the DLC expansions which offer more story with an alternate character crucial to the main plot.With nearly 65 hours in this game it is one i am not growing tired of, the story and most of all the world gribs me every time. The ability to Blink as what teleport is called is nothing short of a fantastic gameplay mechanic and its the first power you get after 30 minutes in the game.Choose your own path in Dishonored, cause destruction or stalk your foes from the dark, just remember your choices affect the world around you and how people perceive you.Gameplay lenght. ~20 hours

Posted: December 7, 2016
												Dishonored is a truly enjoyable game, in any of its possible gameplay styles.I played all the base game in a stealth style, not killing anybody, trying not to be spoted, using alternatives and sidequests to deal with objectives, etc... and it was really fun. You feel like a true assassin that could start killing everybody any minute, but you simply dont want. The maps are designed very good, so you have the chance to use diferent structures, ways and hideouts to move unnoticed.On the other hand, I played both story DLCs "The knife of Dunwall" and "The Brigmore witches" full bloody murderer, and it was a ton of fun too. Jumping from one enemy to another, changing weapon, slashing them, then disappearing again. And again maps bring you a lot of oportunities to planify your asault to enemies.The powers are fun for both styles and you have different ways to improve abilities depending on how you want to play.Seriously, the gameplay is really fun.The other aspects of the game are not that important, maybe because you dont need anymore, maybe because they dont shine specially. Sound is ok, graphics are ok (obviously great for its time, nowadays they are not impressive, but anyway it is a pretty game with good graphics), story is ok (nothing special, you just want to stealth/murder, but hearing a story meanwhile is nice), collectibles are ok. Nothing really shines aside from the gameplay, but that is not a problem at all.Talking about the DLCs, I think the three of them are great. The 2 that have story are very interesting, as they show another side of the story, what happens to other character at the same time Corvo's story developes. And if you find the game fun, these DLCs will be fun too, since it is more of the same, just with minimal changes. The other DLC, "Dunwall City Trials", is fun too. Some challenges to play with the powers and murder abilities, it is interesting to play, and may entertain you a lot if you are a completionist. I didnt spend much time with the challenges (completed all of them some times, spent 3-4 hours or so with it), but anyway I recommend it, since I had a fun time completing the challenges. They are well designed in my opinion.So, if you fancy the idea of being a ninja, a silent assassin whose victims dont notice until they are dead, or a bloodthirsty beast that enjoy fast assassination, this is your game.

												This is one of the few games that deserves a perfect 10/10 in my opinion.Pro's:-It's long enough, and doen't outstay it's welcome.-Gameplay is varied entertaining and can be implemented very creatively.-Mission play throughs can be done in many different ways.-Evil/good actions have conseqeunces in-game as wel as multiple ending scenes.-Runs as smooth as a buttered butt.-None lethal run possible.-Extremely lethal run possible.-Can play baseball with a decapitated head (try it it's awesome).-The knife of dunwall + brigmore witches dlc together are basically an entire campaign length.-Holds up extremely well with age so far and incredible replay value for a single player game.Cons:-I couldn't think of cons....Conclusion:I loved this game, it's (atm of writing this) my favorite stealth game i've ever played, I'ts above hitman absolution and thief in my list.It proves the point that games don't need multiplayer to be good.This game does (just like skyrim) DLC incredibly good, it first makes an incredible complete game which then makes you want to buy the DLC because you thirst for more awesomeness. Posted: August 15, 2013
												Dishonored tells the story of Corvo Attano, bodyguard to the Empress of the Empire of Isles and ruler of the city of Dunwall. Wrongfully accused of her assassination, Corvo must clear his name and save Emily, daughter to the Empress and heir to the throne. The game tells a dark and gripping tale, and as Corvo you have absolute control over how it ends. Will you be merciful to the people who have wronged you, or will you act as an angel of vengeance and murder all those who dare stand in your way?Dishonored is quite unlike any stealth action game out there. With sprawling levels that reward exploration and thoroughness, great combat mechanics that feel tight as a drum, a beautiful watercolour art style and absolute freedom to go where you want and play how you want, this game is the true heir to such classics as Thief: The Dark Project and Deus Ex.

Dishonored, worth buyingOverall impressionIt is not the most beautiful game when it comes to visuals. But the (various) storylines make it a very interesting and well-thought-out gaming experience. I have finished the main game and the DLC's now and I can honestly say that I am looking forward to my next play-through and find out more about the various options and search for all those things I have missed. The game is well-balanced. If you like to use your brain and stealth, this game offers you a nice challenge. If you prefer the more ruthless approach; go hogwild!  Player advice:Save early, save often.Bugs: No major problems encountered.Could be better: I would have liked to see that Corvo had a little more personality. His story is 'okay' but he lacks a voice (literally) unlike Daud who does have a voice and several 'inner dialogues' that make you feel closer to the protagonist.

Posted: June 16, 2015
												SUMMARYAmazing blend of stealth and action, with an interesting steampunk universe to explore and loot and an amazing art style from the designers that brought you City 17. THE GOOD-Cool and useful powers for the player to use-Multiple playthrough options and strategies-RPG-lite leveling of skills and inventory to make Corvo a better assassin-Environments are amazing, and a joy to explore-Music is foreboding, and the atmosphere is dripping with styleTHE BAD-The guards repeat a lot of their dialogue throughout the game. It's kind of charming, in a way.-Not the most difficult stealth gameplay once you get used to the game's features, but it soon becomes a challenge of how to use your skills to maximum effect.I highly recommend this game! Especially worth checking out if it goes on sale. The Daud DLC is very interesting, and shows a lot more of the city of Dunwall and the plots surrounding Corvo.

Posted: January 8, 2014
												A very in depth game with a plauge ridden Victorian Steampunk meets black magic theam.  Combat is smooth with a great Skill selection system and many great finishing moves that make the game a joy to play.  The use of the unreal engine means that the opponents are tough and tactically aware to a point.  Jump into a fight and you will quickly find yourself surrounded and dead.  The Steath system is well thought out with amazing abilities and many ways to ither sneak past opponents/obstructions, take them down from a distance or sneak up on them to deal with them personally.  Challenging yet fun, the use of achievements and your actions in the past dictating the game progression make the game worth playing over and over again.  The Download content and challenge runs are a fantastic way to hone your skills and play the game in ways one otherwise would not.

Posted: December 16, 2013
												Set in a very interesting world where your actions affect the outcome of the story - one can choose to assassinate everyone and everything or simply subdue the enemy and complete each mission with non-lethal means of action. Dishonored was most enjoyable because of the freedom one had in the process of completing the game, if you aren't much of an explorer you can choose to complete the game in a matter of a few hours simply by doing just the necessary missions that follow the main storyline but you're also able to sweep every corner of every map, thoroughly, to find all the coins (used to buy upgrades and consumables), runes (used to learn different abilities, such as increased running speed, teleportation etc.) and bone charms (used as small perks), should you wish to.If you're an experienced firstperson PC-gamer you can have a lot of fun playing around in this game, even at the harder difficulties - the more skilled and faster you are, the more of an advantage you've got on the world around you.Interesting story, interesting gameplay and very interesting characters - recommended for any stealth/assassin enthusiast as well as the casual murderer.

												Once upon a time I was a god of stealth video games. Spliter Cell 1 and 2? Total ghost, never seen. I've lost my patience for this sort of game, but I make an exception for Dishonored, truely the best game in the stealth genre I've ever played.

Posted: February 14, 2014
												There's something really special about Dishonored. I've played games that were more graphically impressive, I've played games that do combat and stealth better, and I've played games with more intriguing stories before. Dishonored, though, has a special SOMETHING, some mystery element, that makes it really shine. You find it easy to overlook graphical glitches in the face of beautifully designed mansions. You can forget how much better the stealth was in Thief when you're flooded with adrenaline from a perfect assasination takedown. There's just a special something that really sets this game apart.For me, the strongest thing Dishonored has going for it is that it's absolutely drenched in atmosphere. Even when the games' central story isn't much more than interesting, the world in which it takes place is absolutely awe-inspiring. It feels like a real world that's existed long before the exploits of Corvo, and will continue to exist long after he's dead.As far as the gameplay goes, the glue that really makes it stick is the wide array of powers that completely change the game. A player with the posession ability is going to approach a mission in a completely different way than someone who's focused on their ability to slow and stop time. As I blinked from rooftop to balcony to rooftop, my silenced boots letting me dash full speed, and dove from immense heights using unsuspecting guards to soften my landing, I realized that Dishonored was one of those rare games that really sells the fact that you ARE exactly as incredible as people will whisper that you are.On top of the extremely solid main game, there are four pieces of DLC available. One is your standard pre-order bonus package, which is fine, but the other three are absolutely worth the money. The Dunwall City Trials is a series of challenges that pit you against enemies, puzzles, and races, and they're worth the price alone. There's also a two-episode story expansion, though, that's especially fun. The Knife of Dunwall and the Brigmore Witches put you in the shoes of Daud, the assassin of the Empress, and allow you to see his side of the story. I won't spoil things here, but the DLC offers moments that rival and surpass the core game, and the blended Blink/Time Stop ability is absolutely amazing: it's a game-changer.I'm they type of person who has no problem going without a sequel. I adore Blade Runner, but I realize it isn't necessary to have a sequel. With the gorgeous, detailed world that Arkane has created here, though, it would be criminal not to explore it some more. The mystical, steampunky, run-down world of Dishonored is one I would revisit in an instant.

												I could write a book about all that there is to love about this game.  The combat system is fantastically simple, and simply fantastic.  The stealth gameplay is unparralleled.  The game is expansive, and rewards exploration heavily.  The characters are memorable, the voice acting is well done, and the interactions stick with you. Posted: June 28, 2016
												Dishonored is, without a doubt, my favorite stealth game ever. More than Metal Gear and more than Deus Ex. You are Corvo, the royal protector who was framed for the murder of the empress. You must then take your revenge on those who framed you with the help of magic from the Outsider and gadgets from Piero to aid you in your stealthing.One of the main reasons I love this game so much is player choice. My playtime reflects that you can play the game more than once. If you're playing it once you aren't doing it right. At the shortest, you can play the whole game excluding the even shorter DLCs in about ten hours. However, the game offers many ways to play it through multiple times. In this regard, Dishonored is like an RPG. To compare to Fallout, another Bethesda game, my first run in both games is what I would do. In Fallout, I would side with the good guys (mostly) and be mostly nice. In Dishonored, I would use as much magic as I could, get as many runes as possible, not kill many people (murder wasn't out of the question though) and do other things I won't get into for spoilers' sake. I played a female psychopath in Fallout next, and in Dishonored I got all three achiemements for not killing anyone. You can play the whole game without killing anyone and in the sequel, you can do the whole game without magic. Speaking of the magic, it's a great thing to put into a stealth game. In games like Metal Gear, it focuses on raw stealth in which you use distractions and funny looking diving to sneak about. With magic, you augment your sneaking so it becomes easier and more fun. It's optional however, except the first tier of blink. With blink, you can teleport a short distance to reach high places or traverse crowded streets faster. There is also dark vision that lets you see through walls. All of these powers make the game a very fun escape from traditional stealth games. Along with these powers, you get bone charms that add passives. To get this magic you have to collect runes and bone charms. These are often placed off the beaten path and finding them leads you into interesting sidequests and cool lore to find. The game is rich in lore. Books are everywhere and audiologs explain a lot of things. You will learn about the seven scriptures of the overseers and why they name the months like month of nets. These sidequests and alternate pathways are different each time you play. If you seek runes early in the game, someone will ask you to poison a bootleg elixr distillery, and in the very next level, you are recruited by the person you ruined to do something. With a story rich universe and fun mechanics and player choice, Dishonored is a must play for fans of stealth and story.

Posted: July 2, 2015
												This is literally the best game I've ever played. (played for many hours on the Xbox 360)The strongest aspects for me are the world and the characters. You can feel the history of the places you visit and the people you encounter. The books and journals you may or may not read all work perfectly together to weave a top notch fantasy setting. The well-voiced dialogue sells every emotion and burden a character has. You'll make friends with these people. There's something new to be discovered every time you play. The only weak point is the music. For the most part, it's bland, emotionless, and repetitive. It doesn't bring the game down but it certainly doesn't lift it up, either. Maybe it could have benifited from being less reliant on cues. For example, every time you discover a secret, the same 10 second clip plays. Over and over again throughout the game. Another incredibly awkward theme plays every time you return to your home base after a mission. Hopefully most people don't even notice it. Other than that one aspect, though, it's a perfect game.EDIT - Upon further review of the music, I've somewhat changed my mind. The two examples I listed above and one other (any time you choose to save a citizen on the streets from a potential threat) are indeed annoying to hear, but they are the minority. There is a LOT of music in the game and the vast majority of it is well done and immersive.EDIT 2 - No, the music sucks. Mostly. Sorry, composer. Still a great♥♥♥♥♥game, though.

												This game is simply amazing! The stealth mechanics in it are so satisfyingly simple and easy to follow. It adds an extra layer of excitement and intensity when you play a no kill, never seen run, and the different weapons and magic abilities you can get in it  can tailor to any play style. Whether you are planning to run into a room to kill everyone with rats and grenades, or just planning to stop time and hit them all with sleep darts, this game falls nothing short of making you feel like a stealthy ninja assassin, or a completely indestructible god to be feared. 												This game gets a lot of hate, which i feel is undeserved. The entertainment I've had from this game is based on the freedom to execute missions in different ways. The only other game that had this feeling for me was the original assassin's creed, but many were put off by the repetitivity of its objectives. I have heard scrutiny over difficulty of the game, but the freedom (in my mind) is in place of difficulty. It is closer to a simulation than most games. If you appreciate casual gaming experiences, violence, stealth, or the ability to tailor games to your liking, you have reason to enjoy this game.

Posted: November 28, 2012
												I consider myself to be an open-minded individual and as such, you will rarely (if ever) hear me say that you're playing a game "wrong." But as tasteless as it sounds, I'm willing to make an exception for Arkane Studio's Dishonored. There is indeed, in my humble opinion, a wrong way to play this game.Dishonored is a tale about revenge. The player assumes the role of Corvo Attano, the bodyguard of an empress presiding over the fictional city of Dunwall. Upon returning from a long trip, Corvo finds himself caught in a conspiracy in which he is framed for the empress’ murder. The plot, which is as generic as they come, follows Corvo as he exonerates himself by removing the corrupt government now in power.Not only is the plot an idea taken from many other works in the medium, but it is also extremely predictable. The mid-game twists can be guessed right from the get-go. Clearly, storytelling is not Arkane's strong suit. As a bit of a forewarning - don't pick up Dishonored if you're expecting anything revolutionary in the way of narrative.On a different note, the atmosphere surrounding the plot is rich and engrossing. If players really take their time to read every book and listen to every audiograph scattered throughout the game, they'll learn that Dunwall has a surprisingly deep and tragic history with even darker times ahead. The world of Dishonored truly feels fleshed out, and if there is one thing I can be sure of, it is that there are more tales to be told.But above all else, the gameplay needs to be thoroughly discussed. It is, after all, what you'll be doing for hours on end, and the core mechanics are what determine the overall quality of the game. Fortunately, Dishonored excels in this area with flying colors. This here is not a linear game devoid of options. Dishonored is an open-ended affair, filled to the brim with gameplay choices. For those who are looking for a title that tailors uniquely to how you want to play, there is no better match than Dishonored.There are only nine missions in the game (making it a very short one--but more on that later), and only eight of which take place in open maps. Each of those maps is extremely well designed, allowing for multiple paths to any one objective. You can take the direct route (bursting through the doors!) or a discrete one (gallivanting on the roofs or through the sewers!). You can even possess a rodent and travel through tiny vents. The possibilities, while not limitless, are certainly abundant.  Which brings me to my next point...Powers! There are a number of collectibles (runes) littered throughout each stage. Collecting grants player points to invest in new powers, of which there are about a dozen. Some of them are passive (such as increased vitality or speed) while others need to be triggered (possession, time bending, teleporting, and summoning swarms of rats to do your bidding). Whether or not you’ll be playing lethally or non-lethally, each ability will come in handy in their own unique ways.With so many ways to approach Dishonored, one might wonder, “How can you play the game ‘wrong’?” The simple answer would be: by playing it only once. With so many options available, you won’t be getting your money’s worth unless you are willing to investigate every avenue. Play through the game without killing or being detected and you’ll feel extremely skillful. Play through the game slaughtering every moving creature and you’ll feast on the stylishly animated kills. If you put Dishonored aside after witnessing only half of what it has to offer, it’ll not only be an affront to the developers, but a tragedy for you.Grade: 4/5

Posted: June 26, 2015
												Assassin's Creed could learn a thing or two from Dishonored!I don't know why it took me this long to play this game but I have to say I quite loved it. I'm not crazy about steampunk-ish art style games or whatever you want to call it, I enjoy them on rare occasions and I definitely enjoyed Dishonored's art style.My very first playthrough I accomplished on the hardest difficulty without killing anyone, never being detected, and not having spent any runes on the magic upgrades. Some say I may have missed out on the ultimate experience but I felt that it was quite unique and still very doable. A silent Batman who never kills, is unseen, and has no superpowers. Yeah, I liked this game.With an A List cast of voice actors including Lena Headey, Chloe Grace Moretz, Susan Sarandon, Michael Madsen, and even Carrie Fischer (Yes, Princess Leia from Star Wars) I have to say this game was a wonderful experience. The characters felt real and alive, your choices had consequences, and you had multiple ways to to go about your assassinations, unlike Assassin's Creed where it guides your hand on how THEY want you to kill someone, in Dishonored you don't feel like a slap on the hand when you decide to take out a target your own way.11/10 Highly recommend it.
