Whether you want to be super stealthy or go on an all out rampage during the levels, this game has so many ways of being completed that one playthrough won't ever be enough!I was impressed at the level of detail the game went in to, from the over-arching story to the little snippets of conversation you pick up as you're sneaking past a group of guards. I'd recommend playing hard/hardcore as it might be a little easy towards the end when you are an all-powerful assassin. Two things that stopped me giving it a top score; 1) A few minor glitches that I found a little annoying at some points2) I found myself playing a lot of the levels constantly with dark vision enabled which detracts from the amount of visual detail that this game has.Bought during the steam sale I can't believe the value for money I got here! Would recommend anyone to pay full price as it is AWESOME! Now to go back and find the coins I missed...

Posted: January 2, 2015
												DishonoredTL;DR - buy it Dishonored Is A (very Reccomendable) Great Steath/ Assassination game set in a perfectly styled run down 1900s style city, though its not an open world the individual mission levels are very large and branching often with multiple levels and ways to reach objectives and various shiny magical collectible things... which i rarely bothered to collect as i was busy focusing on the setting, which is wonderful ( Its a bad place to be , but an interesting place and one whose aesthetic really rung well with me ) =Story    NO SPOILERSYou ( as i am sure you have gathered from various other material you may have read about the game ) play as Corvo (Attano?) the former bodyguard of the empress framed for her murder and trying to help the "good guys" ( ie the ones who didnt frame you ) who are trying to find the emperess' daughter and put her on the throne.... i cant really say any more, other than its basically a long revenge plot with exciting twists and turns. The plot is not too long (only 9 missions as far as i can recall), it doesnt outstay its welcome like a ubisoft game... =AtmosphereThe atmosphere is what i really love about this game, its just so.. wordless. The city seems to be like victorian london , with tall, proud brick structures muddied by the smoggy choking industrial (more on whale oil later) city, Dunwall is also very ill, wreaked with a strange and incredibly contagious foreign plague which has turned the place into a very dangerous zone with the city gurads all around and strict quarantines. this contrasts very Starkly to the rich feasts and parties of the titled upper class aristocracy who are ALL bad. Whale oil, this newely discovered potent substance is used in all sorts of cool inventions which cheifly seem to be designed to kill You, runs the whole city, and massive iron gargantuans bring in whole live whales ready to be stripped down and have the oil extracted from their bodies in dirty factories and knackering yards. The religiuos dunwall citizens can pray to the creepy totalitarian "abbey of the everyman" whoose ramsey snow lookalike  god (or at least i think so) embues you with special magical killing powers ( such as blink) which really spices up gameplay=GameplayIsnt that well planned out how i got round to gameplay just like that... Well, The Gameplay from Playing this Game is very fun, and thats what mattersa in the end, you basically teleport around from roof to roof occasionally leaping onto an unsuspecting guard, If they realise youre there then they will all go looking for you, while one tells the others that the person who kills the "masked assassin" will be given whisky for a week, which, considering I killed so many big people i thought i was slightly higher priority and my killer would at least get maybe.. a ticker tape parade or something.apart from the exciting powers, you also have a cool looking fold up sword (for easy storage i presume), a loud but powerful pistol/shotgun and a more stealthy poison arrow killing wrist crossbow (they must have stollen it from assassins creed or something) which was always running out of ammo, there are a few types of bombs as well, which again, i rarely had any of.=GraphicsHeres a fun fact, dishonored is made in the same engine as The Vanishing of Ethan Carter (another very reccomendable game) but you wouldnt know it, the graphics, arent amazing, with low res textures etc but the overall art direction and aesthetic make up for that, so overall, though it is an old game , that just means it runs at a higher framerate.with my r9270x, i got above 60fps everwhere with all settings turned up to 11 and even some extra AA from catalyst control center=OverallIts well worth £19.99 for the GoT (thats game of the year not game of thrones) edition, tbh its worth £50...

Posted: October 19, 2015
												Halfway in and it has been lots of fun.Don't regret picking it up on sale, actually wish I'd gotten the DLC too.Almost didn't buy it, because people complain about the "forced" stealth and chaos system.Currently I play a full chaos playthrough and I don't see, what all the fuss is about.I like this stealth/combat balancing much more than for example in Deus Ex HR, where playing stealthy+nonlethal automatically leads to much more xp/skillpoints - now that's enforcing stealth with hard sanctions.Contrary to that Dishonored mainly changes the ambient mood depending on your style, NPC-bots complain about destructive player actions, the world becomes darker, the more people you kill...I see no problem with that.Basically, if you want to play offensive, you can... honestly, who cares about the story/ending in a game like this?For me this game is not exactly a RPG. It's about having fun with the gameplay action, the sneaking, swordfights, shooting, jumping, spellcasting, climbing, throat slitting, hiding in shadows, exploding things, peeping through keyholes, pickpocketing and so on.Those parts are the real fun, not what type of ending I get.Did anyone play Diablo for the story? I certainly didn't, I played it for the action. And yes, this is not a mere FPS.If you are vastly outnumbered and completely refuse to sneak and hide to get to better vantage points, you will have a hard time - the attack button will not save you in every situation.Still, it gives you lots of liberty how to achieve your objectives.Want to be a merciless assassin, killing pretty much everything that moves? Well go ahead, you can do that, actually the game even accepts(not "punishes") this playstyle choice by spawning more enemies, giving you more things to kill.Want to be a good samaritan, not even killing the really evil antagonists, avoiding all offensive confrontations?Well there you go, you can do that too (and it's actually harder than fighting your way through).And anything in between those extremes is possible too.Some aspects I consider negative:- there is no map. Many say none is needed, which is true. But when looking for hidden secrets,loot, passages I'd rather have one.- no new game plus, further playthroughs can't incorporate gained upgrades/skills. I'm ambiguous on this. Good for balancing and replay value with different skill setups, so I see the reason.- difficulty is a bit low for my taste (except in some spots with superior enemies/traps/alarms), definately going to switch to hardest, once I'm more used to the controls.- the mission/map progression is almost 100% linear (variations are minor, mainly whether and in which order you do current side objectives), though most maps offer a lot of freedom of movement and direction, different routes.   You can sidetrack, but only in a limited fashion/timeframe. (I find myself wishing it had an expansive open world like Skyrim - that would be a blast).- minor stuff that feels unintuitive with mouse+keyboard, like Esc not closing certain screens/the zoom view, such things.- though some say the story plot is good, I'd say if you're no kid and had your fair share of TV/books, there ain't much to surpise you.  I can pretty much predict the big twist already without spoilers.  This point doesn't bother me personally though, story is passable enough to not be painfull or silly.Big nostalgia bonus for (adult) Star Wars fans: Carrie Fischer is voice acting :)

Posted: January 12, 2014
												So I just finished this game. I have to say - I absolutely loved the story, the setting, and the way your choices affected the way events played out. The game itself is played as a relatively short series of relatively long missions. Along the way, there's many things to collect that can easily be missed - bone charms that disappear if you don't nab them at a certain point, changing audio logs of NPCs and fleeting conversations. The former can be a bit frustrating, but the latter is always fun to collect, and illustrates the characters around you nicely. The powers were quite fun to use, and the game provided many, many ways to proceed on missions; things were never impossible, but having a certain ability would often open up a path. My largest complaint, however, would be that the game hands you a wide arsenal of killing tools and powers and then heavily discourages using them. The game has, basically, two paths; low chaos (nonlethal, stealth) and high chaos (lethal). There's a third tier, very high chaos, which is for the most part the same as high chaos, but nets even worse reactions from your allies (at this point, your Corvo Attano is pretty much murdering everyone he sees for ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles.) High chaos is easier to do at the beginning, because you don't have many powers yet, and the early missions take place in populated areas - but as the game progresses, high chaos creates more enemies, worse situations, crueller allies, and darker endings. It's understandable and rationalized from a story perspective - more bodies means more rats means more plague, and your allies follow the example you make - but given how much gamers are used to killing the bad guys being a core part of games - well, expect to spend some time adjusting with Dishonored, unless you want to see cute little Emily devolve into a tyrant. Also, if you're playing stealthy, which you should be - well, expect a lot of save scumming. When I played, I was saving on average of once every two minutes, sometimes even more often.

Posted: June 29, 2015
												You get to play as Corvo, a bodyguard turned assassin who gets framed for murder and gets to seek revenge by eliminating targets in a series of missions.  The missions can be completed in a multiple of ways, think the prime focus is to play in stealth but you get to play how you want via stealth, combat or a mixture of both.  Go on a killing spree and kill everyone in sight with a wide variety of weapons and awesome supernatural powers, blow enemies up with whale oil, rewire traps to backfire on them, sneak behide and slit throats or even send a swarm of rats after them, slow time and watch.  You get to hide bodies you kill so not to alert others, dump them in piles and leave for the rats, spell out your name if you want, I made a long human centipede with unconscious bodies it was fun.Or take a totally different route and be stealthy, go undetected and choose to take the nonlethal option on targets and not kill anyone in game.  There really is that much freedom to choose.  All my playthroughs have been played in such a different way it's felt like a totally different game and given alternate endings.The DLC's are worth a look, they have a whole lot of good quality content and offer a heap load more gametime.  Still aint done with the DLC's myself.Could not wait to finish my working day to play this game, made me drive home faster so I could fit in more hours.Very highly recommended, I adore Dishonored

												This is one of the better stealth action/adventure games that I have played in a long time. The gameplay and story is linear, but the level design and multiple ways to get to your objective keeps the game from feeling stale. The weapons in the game are so-so. The majority of the time you will be teleporting around and stabbing people in the back with your blade. The only real time you use weapons is when you alert a guard and an entire militia comes after you. The graphics are decent. I am using SweetFX to make the colors more vibrant and add a little more anti-aliasing. The Unreal Engine is not pushed to the limit here. The art direction is similar to Bioshock:Infinite, but with a lot less attention to detail.

Posted: June 23, 2015
												Dishonored is a game you absolutely have to own, and play. This game allows you to play Stealth without killing a soul, and still complete any mission. Or you can go "guns blazing" and kill anything in sight. You can also mix up both play styles(s); go stealth and kill anyone you see or you can go "guns blazing" and when you feel you can't handle all the enemies you can escape and continue the mission undetected, and still complete any mission. The game rewards you for both play style(s). If you're a fan of stealth, then this game has stealth mechanics that are flawless and are really fun to play around with If you're a fan of killing and being the "apex predator" then the game has incredible combat mechanics to offerand if you like to mix the two game styles up, you can do so to. (IMPORTANT: The play style(s) you choose impact the ending)Therefor increasing replayability in a whole new level.I suggest playing this game both ways (Non-Lethal and Lethal) to get the full experience.I also recommend the DLC's. Just when you think this game has all, the DLC's come into play and offer a lot more.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												Amazing; The basic idea of Dishonored is freedom. Every level is lovingly crafted to present a variety of options, and the game's mechanics are perfectly tuned to present you with even more ways to accomplish goals, ones that the developers could never have foreseen. The characters are not particularly beatiful, but the art succeeds in creating the desired atmosphere.You can explore the world, or rush straight through to your goal. You can kill everyone in sight, only your targets, or literally no-one. You can teleport around a guard, stab him, shoot him, feed him to the rats ...It is like Thief where you can hold your ground in a fight, or like an action game where you do not have to fight at all. Moment-to-moment gameplay is smooth and well-executed, whether you are sneaking or fighting.This game's fame is well deserved.

Posted: July 30, 2014
												This game is for the most part action and stealth.  The main character is assigned targets that he may eliminate in a variety of different but fulfilling methods.  There is an interesting system of chaos.  The chaos will affect the next level.  High chaos makes the game more challenging and low chaos seems to make the game easier.  This system will punish players that chose a direct path rather than the stealthy path.  However, it is still possible to beat the game.  There is also an exploring aspect to each level to collect different items like collectibles.  The completion of each level is displayed when you finish the level.  The games has some rpgish element in the way you upgrade the character.  This game was an overall enjoyment.

Posted: June 21, 2015
												Brief review.Story: Epic tale in league with Bioshock Infinite. Simple story richly told. Likable characters. Interesting surprises.Mood: Half Life 2 and accompanying episodes. Moderate anxiety stealth with enhanced sensory awareness and many choices.Mechanic and special powers: reminiscent of Bioshock and inFAMOUS Second Son.Sets: Beautifully designed levels.Powerups: Rare but sufficient powerups dispersed throughout the levels. Health and special powers elixirs.Special powers system: “Powers” that you can select and use with one of your hands as in Bioshock and Skyrim. “Bone Charms” that give you special personal skills as in Fallout 3.Difficulty: Challenging missions, but very doable if you are patient and carefully plan your moves. Few boss fights and they are not crazy hard (on “Normal”).Replay value: High. Many different options, different gameplay styles to decide upon, different routes to take on any given mission. High chaos: many encounters with enemies. Low chaos: avoiding enemies with meticulous planning and stealth.Overall impression: One of the best games in my library. Compelling and immersive story that motivated me the way Bioshock Infinite, Wolfenstein: The New Order, and Half Life 2 did.Final thoughts: With a little modification, this game could have formed a solid foundation for Half Life 3.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												The game itself is your sneak through game, fairly similar to the Agent 47 / Hitman games. You play as Corvo, the right hand of the Empress. Corvo is framed and accused of the Empress' murder, and thrown into a cell and tortured by the real murderers. Corvo is given a chance to escape from prison and to help the Empress' daughter by putting some key people out of action. At the same time, the city Dunwall is under the influence of the pest. It is a tale of treason, murder and decay.After the first mission, you get the visit of a mystical pressence that grants you some magical powers, like teleporting, called blink, and see-through vision. However, you are penalized by using lethal weapons or powers. So you end up using the basic non lethal powers in order to get around the levels unnoticed. Do not get confused by the screenshots you might see everywhere: as with the Hitman games, it is best to avoid combat.The level I liked the most is the one that happens during a mask dance, because it is the only time where you can spend doing some detective work. The target for that mission is one of the three Boyle sisters, but you do not know which one is the target. You are only told that is the only way to leave the Lord Regent without any support. I do not know why taking one of the carefree partygoer sisters matters at all. As with the Hitman games, the overall story is lead by a tiny string.There is a goal marker in most of the missions, so it is fairly clear where you need to go and what to do. Some people like this kind of guiding, others not. Difficulty is on the easy side of things, so that most people should not get frustated by the game.Technically speaking, the game is dull. It is your typical console game of year 2011/12, so you have load screens between relatively short sections of the map and a low number of triangles on the character meshes. There aren't many persons wandering around (so it is easy to get around guards). The game does however have a fairly distinct artistic feel, with the character faces aiming for a more comic book feel. The only gripe here is that Corvo is not voiced, so I felt a little bit disconnected from the main character. The game does support the Xbox360 pad.Overall the game is OK, but not great.

Posted: September 24, 2014
												In more than a few ways Dishonored is the game that Bioshock Infinite wanted to be. The overall presentation of the two games are similar in more than a few ways. Both games use extensive world building to set the tone of the plot. Both are contined to a city that has as much personality as the characters that inhabit it. Dishonored takes place in Dunwall, a city that obviously has its inspiration taken from London. The world is on of industrial steampunk. Whale oil is a hot commodity that is used to power everything in the city. It's a shame the world is so much more interesting than the main plot, which is your standard revenge plot. This revenge story does leave room for a fun and dynamic morality system. Do you use the tools at your disposal to slaughter enemies by the dozens or do you sneak through the levels, only killing your main targets? It's definitely a fun juxtaposition between the two gameplay styles. Actual gameplay is again similar to Bioshock Infinite. Your left hand controls your powers, your right hand your sword. It's basic combat but it's fullfilling and gets the job done. How you play affects the world in small ways, such as how characters converse with you or how many enemies will be in an area. The game is fairly polished overall although there are a few things that are annoying. Enemies can sometimes be too perceptive. You'll get spotted a lot with no idea where or why. At your end of level tally, it's possible that you'll end up with kills even though you didn't kill anyone. I did glitch out once and fall through the floor. Once in the twenty or so hours I put into the game isn't bad though. Overall it's definitely a fun game that is worth a playthrough. I had much more fun than I expected. If you want to get the most out of the game make sure you explore the world and pay attention to your surroundings. It's definitely worth the $20 it goes for on the store and is aboslutely worth it if you pick it up on sale. There is a lot to love, even if the game does display the occasional hiccup here and there. I have to wonder why I'm writing this review after the game has been out for a year and most people have already picked it up. Anyways, hope this was useful for you.

Posted: October 1, 2014
												Dishonored is a game that pays fitting tribute to its predecessors in the stealth-action--RPG genre; games like Thief and Thief II, System Shock 2, Deus Ex, and Deus Ex: Human Revolution among others.The game explores player choice in a backdrop with a stunning amount of world-building detail, immersive and compelling mechanics, artsyle, and rich story.  It's at its best when you sneak your way through the corrupted City in a non-lethal run, but it is sufficiently balanced that all kinds of playstyles can - and should - be explored.Above all, the game is fun, immersive, and highly enjoyable.  I can't sing it's praises enough.  It has been criticized for flat characters in NPCs, which I can understand if not entirely agree with, and it has a few minor frustrations (spawning enemies in a stealth game), but this game shines.  It's a must play for anyone who enjoyed the titles I mentioned a the start of this review, including the DLC.

Posted: August 12, 2013
												Dishonored has certainly won a place in my heart as one of my favourite games ever made. First of all, it has a great setting; Dunwall is inspired by a steampunk London in an apocalyptic state once it has been consumed by a life-threatening plague. This sets the scene for a unique world that I have never seen before in a game, and the city of Dunwall is certainly fun to explore and investigate, seeing the results of this terrible disease ruining this city.   Don't let the game's linearity fool you, there is a world to explore. One may not notice at first, even after the game tells you, but there are lots of different pathways and routes to take to get from point A to B. The world does change and adapt to the decisions you make, but not quite as much as you would probably have first thought. I have to say I was a little dissapointed to not notice many differences between my two playthroughs of roleplaying as a psychotic serial killer and Jesus the second. Towards thelater levels there certainly are differences, but nothing game changing, a few more weepers and rats, whooptedoo.   While I am on the subject of everything that is wrong with the game, I have to say it looks like♥♥♥♥♥♥ Oh sure, the city of Dunwall is well designed, the character models are nice - even if most of the males have strangely large fingers - but texture quality is AWFUL. Don't inspect anything too closely or you may start to notice the terrible pixel smoothing, like when I found a sheet of paper that had no depth to it, it was clear it was painted onto the texture of the surface it was on. And the paper was at an angle, so the sides of it were pixelated.   The story in Dishonored is nothing overly special. It's nicely written, but nothing too complex. You get framed for the death of the Empress because you're her bodyguard and now you will seek revenge and find her daughter and keep her safe. There, I've summed it up rather quickly. It does get some uniqueness by being set in a steampunk plague infested London, and the love between the protagonist and the Empress' daughter is rather touching, but no one gets enough character development that I would feel like I would risk my life for them.   But the game certainly does deliver in the gameplay. If you like steath, you'll love this, and even if you don't like stealth, I still think there's fun to be had. The swordplay, while a bit tricky to get into at first, is great. A swordfight and magic fight with someone who is just as gifted of an assassin as you are is one of the greatest experiences in the game, and certainly satisfying once you beat them.   Speaking of assassination, this game does assassination better than any other I have found. Assassin's Creed may advertise as being an assassin game, but that franchise started off as being a good, if repetetive assassin game and slowly went downhill into a bussiness simulator in the 19th century, before it then dug a hole straight through to China when it became a pirate game instead.   If you rush through Dishonored, it won't last long. Sneak through it, and it'll last ages. If you like it, you'll want to beat it again, this time on the opposite chaos. If you're like me, who loves this game so dearly, you'll strive to collect all the achievements, which will make the game last tens of hours.

Posted: December 16, 2013
												One of my absoulte favourite first-person titles of all time. A well-crafted combination of Half Life, Thief and Mirror's Edge combining into a unique blend of stealth, action and storytelling unlike any other game. Audiovisually impeccable, Dishonored let's you explore and be amazed by it's architechture, and it's characters, while not necessarily the smartest in gaming history, are some of the most colourful and well-acted I've ever seen.To top things off, I'll make an exception to my usual "no DLC ever" -policy and recommend the two story DLC packs for this game as well. Neither of the DLC's alone is much, but together they weave into the story of the main game and fill the player in on one of the least fleshed out, yet most important characters in the game.My only gripe is the passivity of the protagonist, Corvo, as his fall during a certain point in the game feel far too forced. Still, this game comes highly recommended, despite a minor gripe here or there.Playtime: 25+ hours (single playthrough, including DLC)Ratings (1-10)Visual: 10Audio: 10Story: 9Gameplay: 9Overall: 9

Posted: February 5, 2016
												The trend of hyper-long games has left me with a lot of half-finished games in my library -  but Dishonored was never going to be one of those. I was hooked before I ever played it (what part of "magic steampunk parkour assassin" DOESN'T sound like a dream come true?) and once I started I knew I'd be in for the whole ride. The story is relatively generic but the setting and characters make it plenty interesting and compelling.The gameplay is great fun, and I appreciate that the "good" and "bad" endings (which are based on how much chaos your actions cause in the city as a whole) make sense for the play style that cause them. Climbing around on rooftops and plotting the demise of the guards was awesome, and when you get into the fray you get to make use of some of the other cool abilities. The setting itself is where the game really shines. The steampunk-esque (fantasy industrial? Whale-oil-punk?) world is full of detail from the grimy streets where commoners scuttle around like plague-rats to the sumptuous abodes of the nasty, plotting upper class. There's a clear aesthetic at work everywhere you look and the attention to detail is clear.

Posted: October 16, 2012
												When playing Dishonored, I am reminded of the tingling sensation I got when I first watched the Bioshock Infinite trailer a couple of years ago, and it achieves this through its own cool art style and steampunk-leanings.The way it's played is entirely down to you. It's not an open-world, but you can go non-lethal (even for the people you are supposed to assassinate, which is a nice touch), kill every ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in the map or go for anything in between.And it’s the sneaky non-lethal parts of this game that remind me of Thief. And I don't say that lightly. It would never be a contender for Garrett's throne, though: Corvo appears to be completely mute, more in line with heroes such as Gordon Freeman than the enigmatic Garrett, and perhaps this is to the game's detriment. However, Dishonored is a thoroughly enjoyable experience, and one that everyone who enjoys stealthy games, or even a rose-tinted gleam in their eye over the Thief series (or the original BioShock) should try.

Posted: May 26, 2014
												I absolutely love this game! If you haven't played it yet and you love games with alternate play styles, engaging storylines and RP choices that have actual impacts on your playthrough, then you're missing out. Keep in mind I may be biased as I normally love any kind of dark, gritty story that takes place in a dystopian society... However trust me when I say that this game is absolutely brilliant! I loved how it was acceptable for me to progress through quests with a clear objective, then to decide halfway through that I did not agree with it and do something completely different to make the ends meet. I was not led by hand through the game, I was allowed to play as I saw fit; It could be anything from scaling the chandeliers of a house to protecting a local thug from a crazy old bat. With every playthrough I discover something new, characters reacting to me in a different manner, new opportunities, stumbling upon side-characters I've never met before because I chose a different route and so on.However I do have a wee bit of nitpicking, very insignificant though I might add. I would've appreciated a short prologue in which I was allowed to get to know the Empress and Emily, I found myself not caring much for them, Emily did grow on me though as I got to interact with her. I also would've have liked more side quests that aren't DLCs, while it was refreshing that there were few, I also felt that they were so well made that I sort of wanted more... TL;DR - 10/10

Posted: August 28, 2016
Dishonored is a wonderful game.Do you enjoy running around in a mask stabbing people?Do you enjoy having superpowers, such as teleportation, manipulating time itself, or being able to summon a swarm of rabid rats?Do you enjoy using said superpowers to come up with inventively gruesome and/or needlessly convoluted ways to kill off your enemies?Do you believe that the best way to prove that you are innocent of murdering a high-ranking official is to go on a city-wide rampage and murder a bunch of other high-ranking officials?Alternatively, are you not that into violence, and would you prefer to shoot your enemies with tranquiliser darts and/or gently strangle them until they are sleepy?Do you prefer to use technicially non-lethal methods to punish wrongdoers (that are probably worse than death)?Do you believe that gathering for whiskey and cigars is a worthwhile recreational activity?Are you obsessed with whiskey and cigars in general?If you answered any or all of the above questions with "indeed, I believe so", then Dishonored is the perfect game for you.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												A very enjoyable game, but also somewhat of disappointment. I probably wanted it to be like Thief more than I should have, and although there are many similarities to Thief, the game-play just doesn't live up to it. The story, design and characters are all superb, and it's proof that a new idea, and a different approach to the typical shooter, can be successful.By the time I'd finished the game, trying to keep the death-count as low as possible, I felt like I'd missed out on taking a more savage approach to the missions. So I replayed the whole game, and tried to kill as many of the bad-guys as possible (and even a few innocents along the way), and it was like a different game. I'm all for choice within game, and a flexibility to how missions can be approached, but I think the game would have been slightly improved by, once in a while, forcing you to take either a stealthy approach or a guns-blazing approach (similar to the Thief games). This would have meant that someone like me, who's default approach would always be stealth, would have had the chance to let-loose once in a while. I know that choice was always there, and I could have done exactly that at any point, but I didn't really believe that the bad-guys really deserved to die. They were just following whomever was in command, after all. My immersion in the game's narrative was actually preventing me from having a bit of fun. Maybe if some of the levels contained baddies who really deserved getting blown-up or an arrow to the head I would have had more chance to use more of my weaponry on my first play-though. There were times when a stealthy approach was the best way to avoid being killed, so these situations forced you to use more softly-softly tactics, but there was no point when a more action-packed method was essential. Sometimes, too much choice is a bad thing.Once I did decided to replay the game and in a more gung-ho fashion, I noticed how much EASIER the game had become. I could breeze through some of the levels in a fraction of the time I did when I was trying not to kill anyone, and I started to understand the criticism of those who took this approach on their first play-though and felt short-changed.Also, I appreciate the fact that the developers spent a lot of time to make sure each platform was given individual focus, but it still felt as if the PC version retained too many aspects of the console version. The ability to turn off most of the HUD elements, for example, is proof of this, but it took so long for me to figure-out which I needed and which I didn't that it probably spoiled the opening chapter. There's no evidence (despite what some may believe) that PC gamers over the age of 18 are any more intelligent than console gamers over the age of 18, so introducing ways to make the game easier, beyond the usual difficulty levels; which generally affect combat rather than game-play; can only be catering specifically to younger players. And that is just WRONG. Anyway, I digress.Despite all this, Dishonored was like a breath of fresh-air, and I hope it gives more developers the courage to try something different with the common FPS. And I eagerly look forward to the inevitable sequel. Instead of filling the Thief-void, though, it just made me want Thief 4 to come sooner.

												It's a fun game with uniquely smooth firest-person freerunning mechanics that won't turn your stomach; it's definitely worth two playthroughs.  The story is good but the writting and delivery sometimes falter.  Open combat and gorey murder sprees are fun but almost too easy, especially as you get better toys and powers.  The game is only really challenging if you try to use stealth and complete missions with zero-kills.  It's also very rewarding to realize you found a path that maybe wasn't intentional.Edit:  The Knife of Dunwall and Brigmore Witches DLC are also well worth the time and money.  Together the two mission packs nearly double the game's campaign content.  They also flesh out one of the more interesting and conflicted characters who you get very little time with in the main campaign.

Posted: December 22, 2013
												Intense, enjoyable game. The many play-styles of this game are its strong point, stealth, tanking, a combination, assassination, going undetected and going non-lethal are all awesome ways to play, and are encouraged through the achievements, which require at least two or three playthroughs to get them all. The art is qwerky yet not too cartoonish, music is awesome and the setting of a steampunky decaying city on the coast feels so comfortable. With the introduction of supernatural powers to the physical elements the game just broadens as a whole, with the different powers and upgrades, as well as managing your money on upgrades for your sword, body and crossbow the game can be enjoyed by absolutely anyone. The general feel of the game from the art, setting, music and sound makes the game contantly intense, I love it.Overall review: 5/5

Posted: December 3, 2013
												*This long review will not spoil any story elements*This game plays right and feels right. If you shoot a guard in the leg, he grabs his leg and falls over. If you steal from someone who sees you, they warn you and eventually run to authorities. The game is very rewarding no matter if you play it loud or quietly. How you do the missions is up to you. I prefer to kill everything and loot everything. But, now I know I must replay the game and focus on stealth or magic playthroughs.A lot of the actions make sense and the ragdoll physics can be hilarious at times (which is necessary in this game - you'll see what I mean). I bust out laughing when I sleep dart any NPC and go up their unconscious body, loot them, and then carry them to a ledge of a high area and throw them off of it while they're still asleep. It's even more funny to throw them into pirahna-infested waters while they're asleep.Sound: 10/10Music: 10/10Gameplay: 9/10-Sometimes there is some BS, but very infrequent. Game is punishing if you think you're a god.-Any NPC is slayable.-A lot of gold is hard to come by.-Game progressively gets harder, more fun and more chaotic.-There are only 26 Runes in one playthrough, but you need 39 Runes to unlock EVERY trait. Pick your traits carefully.-Bone charms do not disappear when used/activated. Each bone charm is unique.Replayability: 7/10-You know the story the first playthrough, what changes next is HOW you want to beat the game again.-Any way you decide to play is enjoyable.Story: 10/10-Takes place in a rather chaotic time for the entire country. Now you add to the chaos based on how you play. I won't spoil anything for you... the story is ramped up, climactic, fun. It feels like you're actually running the whole story.DLC: 10/10-Great DLC. You can play as a different assassin with ALL NEW abilities.OVERALL SCORE: 9.0/10.0-The metacritics also gave a similar rating to mine, but this is how I feel the really deserves.-I hope they make a Dishonored 2. I would buy it for $50.

Posted: January 12, 2014
												So I just finished this game. I have to say - I absolutely loved the story, the setting, and the way your choices affected the way events played out. The game itself is played as a relatively short series of relatively long missions. Along the way, there's many things to collect that can easily be missed - bone charms that disappear if you don't nab them at a certain point, changing audio logs of NPCs and fleeting conversations. The former can be a bit frustrating, but the latter is always fun to collect, and illustrates the characters around you nicely. The powers were quite fun to use, and the game provided many, many ways to proceed on missions; things were never impossible, but having a certain ability would often open up a path. My largest complaint, however, would be that the game hands you a wide arsenal of killing tools and powers and then heavily discourages using them. The game has, basically, two paths; low chaos (nonlethal, stealth) and high chaos (lethal). There's a third tier, very high chaos, which is for the most part the same as high chaos, but nets even worse reactions from your allies (at this point, your Corvo Attano is pretty much murdering everyone he sees for ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles.) High chaos is easier to do at the beginning, because you don't have many powers yet, and the early missions take place in populated areas - but as the game progresses, high chaos creates more enemies, worse situations, crueller allies, and darker endings. It's understandable and rationalized from a story perspective - more bodies means more rats means more plague, and your allies follow the example you make - but given how much gamers are used to killing the bad guys being a core part of games - well, expect to spend some time adjusting with Dishonored, unless you want to see cute little Emily devolve into a tyrant. Also, if you're playing stealthy, which you should be - well, expect a lot of save scumming. When I played, I was saving on average of once every two minutes, sometimes even more often.

Posted: November 13, 2013
												Dishonored is somewhat short, but it is exceptionally well done through and through. The whole premise of the story is that you're framed for a murder you didn't commit and you are now going after your framers to fix things. The plot and environment are extremely well done, and there is plenty of optional lore via conversations and books.As you play, you'll unlock magical enhancements that can make you're character one with the shadows or an unstoppable force. The game lets you choose between being sneaky or straightforward, and between killing or not. There is a plague, so more death means a darker story and a more powerful plague (and plague enemies).Overall it's extremely well done. If you enjoy stealth games, or just melee games that have some magic and strategy in there, then I heavily recommend this game.

Posted: July 10, 2014
												For many years Thief series was one of my favourite games of all times. After the third game, which was slightly worse than second one, I was waiting for a new game done in the similar fashon. And for many years there was nothing out there. And then came Dishonored. The game so good that now I prefer it over Thief. The game I've finished five times already and will probably do few more runs. The game that lets you choose a style of play - you can be a shadow, you can be a tank, you can be an invisible predator. You can eachieve your goals in many ways, you can finish a game without hurting anyone or you can kill everyone you see moving. A steampunk world of Dunwall is also interesting and the only problem I see in this game is that it's short. Posted: July 30, 2014
												This game is for the most part action and stealth.  The main character is assigned targets that he may eliminate in a variety of different but fulfilling methods.  There is an interesting system of chaos.  The chaos will affect the next level.  High chaos makes the game more challenging and low chaos seems to make the game easier.  This system will punish players that chose a direct path rather than the stealthy path.  However, it is still possible to beat the game.  There is also an exploring aspect to each level to collect different items like collectibles.  The completion of each level is displayed when you finish the level.  The games has some rpgish element in the way you upgrade the character.  This game was an overall enjoyment.

Posted: August 25, 2014
												A game like Bioshock (the two good ones at least), this game has a rich story accompanied by incredable stealth and combat mechanics.  Never before have I experienced the feeling of being a legitament badass assassin.In the game, you play as a man, Corvo, framed for murdering the Empress and hiding away Emily, her beloved daughter, your are tried and sentenced to death.  However, you escape with the help of a small group dedicated to helping you.  They know the truth about you.Following after your escape, you act as an assassin, taking out targets and completing missions.  Each mission is very flexible, for you can play through and complete them in many ways.  There WILL be a way you can fit your playstyle in this game.  Additionally, those who would rather take the role of a stealthy(er) assassin, may find much enjoyment from sneaking around and taking out or incapacitating targets.The only issue I have with this game is Chaos, a mechanic that limits the player being at least this stealthy.  For example, killing too many will make your allies act differently toward you, and changing the overall game environment.  While it is arguable that this mechanic makes the game better by adding more challenges, I find it a bit of a pain because the thought of it pops in your head if you ever choose to kill a guard or something.Overall 9/10, worth getting (like Bioshock), especially when on sale.

Posted: August 25, 2014
												This game is HELLA short, I beat it in one day on the trial, so the trial worked out well! Even tho I beat it, there is more than one ending to the game and since the game was great the first time, going back and trying to be more stealthy would be fun to do, see what other endings may pop out.If you haven't decided whether or not to get the game, it is worth it, ON SALE. I think the game is too short to be $20, you may or may not get only around 10 hours out of the game as if you are a hardcore gamer you can blaze thru this in probably under 3 hours, then go back and get a different ending even faster. The game had a great story, minus the outsider who had no real business other then giving you powers, and also the lack of in real time change of how your actions affect people (would of been great to see them react differently when I came back after slaughtering everyone) after a mission, because then I would of been able to change mission to mission to maybe get a different ending but no one reacted majorly so I just kept doing the same and then by the end I had no chance of recovery.Everything in this game is fun and unique, some things seem really unrealistic to the era or even to anything but if you can get over it the game is really enjoyable.GET THIS GAME WHILST IT IS ON SALE! 8.5/10

Posted: October 14, 2016
												Great game with an interesting story and different endings depending on your actions throughout the missions. Dishonored is a game which allows you to complete the quests in whatever way you see fit, whether it's to sneak past everyone and not harm a single living being, or using your powers to summon rats to feast upon your enemies, the choice is up to you.

Posted: March 29, 2014
												The phrase “stealth mechanic” and/or “stealth mission” probably causes the everyday gamer to shudder. More often than not these are tedious, slow portions of a story which usually highlight the worst in level design, mechanics, and AI shenanigans. What starts off as the "good intentions" of a player in trying to properly sneak around ends up with the Rambo'ing of an entire level out of sheer frustration.Not with Dishonored.I've yet to play any stealth based game, including any Metal Gear Solid offering (arguably considered the king of stealth) that supplies the level of fluidity, options, and satisfaction in not being seen or shedding a single drop of blood that Dishonored provides. So much so that any time I had my cover broken, and invariably forced to switch to lethal methods, I felt a sense of responsibility to the spirit of the story to load a previous save and try utilizing different areas of the level or player abilities to successfully get through said portion completely unseen. In any other game I would consider this a complete waste of time, and slightly insane. But like I said, the “cool factor” of the stealth here is so freaking cool that you have to indulge it. The atmosphere, level design, and characters within the game are equally top notch. One thing I really appreciated was the fact that you don't have to suspend your disbelief too hard to get into the role of the main character, as the design decision not to make him talk (or see what he looks like) is absolutely the right one for a game of this nature. Brilliant all around. Can't wait for the sequel.

Posted: November 25, 2012
												Do you like games that give you agency and choice in a world?  Well Dishonored has delivered that more than any game I've played in the last few years!  Every level is a new mini-sandbox, where you can truly define your own path, and experiment with your abilities to some crazy combinations.  I've never encountered a game that has given me so many emergent moments, and is something that can provide a genuinely different experience multiple playthroughs.

Posted: March 9, 2013
												It's a fun game with uniquely smooth firest-person freerunning mechanics that won't turn your stomach; it's definitely worth two playthroughs.  The story is good but the writting and delivery sometimes falter.  Open combat and gorey murder sprees are fun but almost too easy, especially as you get better toys and powers.  The game is only really challenging if you try to use stealth and complete missions with zero-kills.  It's also very rewarding to realize you found a path that maybe wasn't intentional.Edit:  The Knife of Dunwall and Brigmore Witches DLC are also well worth the time and money.  Together the two mission packs nearly double the game's campaign content.  They also flesh out one of the more interesting and conflicted characters who you get very little time with in the main campaign.

												Dishonored is a one of a kind game. The designs remind you of a victorian Steampunk era, which is always nice to see. The gameplay is pretty solid with an excellent sneak and cover system, providing you use the environment and the powers you have around you.The story is not anything original but it does provide some nice twists at least. Posted: December 22, 2013
												Intense, enjoyable game. The many play-styles of this game are its strong point, stealth, tanking, a combination, assassination, going undetected and going non-lethal are all awesome ways to play, and are encouraged through the achievements, which require at least two or three playthroughs to get them all. The art is qwerky yet not too cartoonish, music is awesome and the setting of a steampunky decaying city on the coast feels so comfortable. With the introduction of supernatural powers to the physical elements the game just broadens as a whole, with the different powers and upgrades, as well as managing your money on upgrades for your sword, body and crossbow the game can be enjoyed by absolutely anyone. The general feel of the game from the art, setting, music and sound makes the game contantly intense, I love it.Overall review: 5/5

Posted: December 24, 2013
												Games as beautiful, fun, and engrossing as this don't come around everyday, which only serves to intensify the frustration that the story has no wind in its sails. It would have been easy enough to explain the protagonists' powers using the gorgeous whalepunk setting, the developers felt it necessary to force in witches, gods, and enough thematic references to Bioshock to make you sick. This game is certainly jaw droppingly gorgeous, plays arguably better, and the powers are very, very fun (you'll spend all day blinking to across rooftops), but ultimately you'll feel as if more focus on the rat plague and the central characters would have made you care more. It may never be Bioshock, as it desperately wants to be, but that won't stop you from enjoying every single minute inside this game. Forget the story they give you, and enjoy the amount of actual playing you can achieve, and you will be handsomely rewarded.

Posted: March 3, 2013
												You are Corvo, a royal bodyguard turned into a cold-hearted assassin, passing judgement on the authority figures of Dunwall, killing everyone in sight. You assassinate guards and corrupt leaders by the dozen, using a blade, a crossbow, and occasionally go all out, blasting people down with a powerful handgun. You are the most murderous being in history. Or not. You can make your way through every candle-lit hallway, smoke-filled room, and gloomy street with complete silence, never taking a life, and only taking someone down by suffocating people in to a still alive unconsiousness. You never have to take a life. You can slip past guards and expose the evil authority as corrupt. Not a single drop of blood has to touch your blade, not a single dead man has to hit the cobble-stone, growing colder by the second. You can change the world in whatever way you wish. As one of the best games I've ever played, I would highly recommend it to anyone.

Posted: December 23, 2013
												Really enjoyed this game.  Glad I got the GOTY edition while it was on sale.  The variations of how you could play the levels was great.  The level up system for your character was good, and needing to find the "rune" currency to upgrade your skills kept you engaged in more than just the main story.  Graphics were pretty good, the steam punk scenery may not be the most visually stunning, but it was fitting and not distracting.  I also really enjoyed that as you picked up items that had no value except trading for money, the items gave you that value and you didn't have to manage a complex inventory with encumbrance.  Some might say this isn't as real, but I felt like in games like Fallout you ended up spennding more time on that than the game at times.  It allowed me to just play the game rather than become a warehouse manager, which was cool.The DLC has also been great.  Good added value to the games.  I like how they show you a different side of the story than what you see in the main game.  More of the same with some additional skills and such.  Very much worth the on sale price.  Kept me wanting to come back, and I'll definitely replay all the missions over with a different take on the action (ie; more stealth).

Posted: February 22, 2015
DishonoredMy rating of the game will be split into 5 categories.-Atmosphere-Story-Gameplay-Characters-GraphicsDepending on however well it did, it will recieve a...1 - Perfect2 - Excellent3 - Good4 - Average5 - Below Average6 - BadAtmosphere1 - Perfect."I'd say I was being punished, but I know the world doesn't punish wicked people."Everything this game sets out to do in it's steampunky version of a Victorian England-esque London is done with the most attention to detail.Story3 - Good.This is the game's weakest point. While it is still good, it is rather predictable. It does have one or two surprising twists which you won't expect nearing the end of the game.Gameplay2 - Excellent.The gameplay is another strong point. There are so many different ways you can approach a level and deal with the scenario, from storming the front gate and killing everything inside, to sneaking in by teleporting up with your supernatural powes and knocking out the guards. However, the reason this is not  perfect is because there are only two ways of taking out enemies in a non-lethal way.Characters1 - Perfect"Think you'll get your own squad after what happened last night?"Characters in this game are brilliantly voice acted and have backstories you can find out about throughout the plot and by reading notes. For some reason, I feel the developers wanted to give everyone and English/British accent but later gave up and just got American voice actors to fill in guard dialogue and some major characters. But, that's no problem.Graphics2 - ExcellentDishonored's art style may seem similar to something along the lines of Half Life. That's because the man behind the art style was also the one behind Half Life's. The tone is a very darky brown setting, which perfectly fits the theme of a city ravaged by plague. Up close, the textures can look muddy and stretched, but that's just something you have to live with. If a dark tone isn't your style, there are multiple SweetFX mods that can change the overall colour of the game. Overall Rating - 9/10 [Near Perfect]"I wonder, are you chasing something... or running away?"

Posted: September 19, 2016
												This is a ♥♥♥♥ing brilliant game. Great story, good gameplay, and a unique feature, the Blink-182 (a shortdistance teleport) that actually adds to gameplay rather than being a useless gimmick crowbarred in for the sake of being original. The only slight dowsides are that the dialogue sounds like it was written for people suffering from severe amnesia. Like how the NPC's always very ham-handedly mention every story development in conversation to make sure you don't get lost, which makes it hard to connect with the characters. Also, the guard dialogue is a bit weird. They have a set number of standard responses, and when another guard asks them something, they will randomly choose one of those, without regard to whether it's appropriate for the situation. So you'll hear stuff like:Guard A: "Let's go for whisky and cigars tonight."Guard B: "Chances are very good."But besides that the game is amazing. The level design is great and really encourages the use of your Blink power. The combat is fluent and responsive and stealth is fun and challenging.Overall, this game isn't as good as Thief II, but it's damn close.9/10

Posted: December 27, 2012
												Easily one of the best stealth games I've ever played, and certainly the best first-person stealth game since Thief: The Dark Project first hit the scene in '98. In fact, Dishonored (sic) is almost excessively reminiscent of Thief, taking on a similar steampunk aesthetic although Thief's steampunk was of a more dark ages/medieval flavour than Dishonored's victorian stylings.The painted textures are very pleasing to the eye, the stealth mechanics are superb and the plot is interesting. The only issue is the morality system which causes characters unfavourably to you (down to calling you a -monster-) if you kill too many of the vicious, petty and murderous guards. This, of course, is irrespective of whether you killed them purposefully or due to knocking over a potted plant and having them run headfirst onto your sword. I've always been annoyed at how stealth games will give you one or two dull ways of non-lethally neutralizing enemies while giving you dozens upon dozens of amusing ways to kill them - and then give you the 'bad' ending if you use them. A game should not punish a player for enjoying themselves.But this is a minor quibble, the "bad" ending isn't that bad. It's still an excellent game and if the pooch finds itself thoroughly screwed with regards to Thief 4, at least we'll always have Dishonored (sic).

Posted: April 26, 2013
												If BioShock can be described as a spiritual successor to System Shock 2 then Dishonored can just as easily lay claim to being a spiritual successor to the Thief series. But that's not all that's contained within its DNA. You'll also find bits of Deus Ex (a mixture of lethal and non-lethal approaches, as well as weapons and skills upgrades) and Half-Life 2 (the two games share the same visual concept artist and a similarly oppressive regime who hide themselves away in a large tower while the world around them falls apart).By taking the lethal approach ("kill everyone!"), opting for the "easy" difficulty and turning all the HUD elements on (especially objective markers), Dishonored will be a short, brutal experience that may seem lacking. Opt for a non-lethal approach, on "hard" difficulty, with objective markers turned off (plus item glow, if you're brave), and you'll be in for a much longer and ultimately more rewarding experience as the world of Dunwall is afforded more opportunities to seep into your pores.An essential purchase if you're still pining for the days when Looking Glass Studios were still around. Or if you're simply sick and tired of most modern first-person shooters treating you like an idiot.

Posted: August 24, 2013
												Dishonored feels like Bioshock meets Hitman: Absolution with a mix of Assassin's Creed and a pinch of Darkness 2. The gameplay is very enjoyable and offers a multitude of play styles to suit your individual taste. The basic climbing aspects combined with the Blink power makes for some fluid and easy movements in the vertical space.The graphics really didn't inspire me to say wow, but they did fit the dark plague theme. It was also hard to understand the timeline between the plague (past) and available technology (futuristic). I also didn't really grasp the supernatural storyline at all so that aspect left me confused, but the revenge storyline was highly enjoyable. Although I always found it weird that a couple of drunk alcoholics kept barking orders at me to kill people while they got to sit in their cozy little bar and drink all day.Unfortunately there was too much reading--I ended up skipping most of the historical books which I probably would have followed if the passages offered voice overs.Despite the minor imperfections, Dishonored is genuinely a good game. For me, the gameplay is what shined and that is why I would play it again.

Posted: January 15
												Amazing gameplay and story.During the first missions of this game I got quite discouraged to play due to the lack of action and story to the contrary to the description and reviewers described. It had gotten to the point in which I was considering a refund for the game. BUT DON'T BE DISCOURAGEDUpon finishing the first few missions, you notice certain repetitivity in the game's mechanic (which, by the way, is the most invigorating thing you could ever feel AKA it's a good thing). As you grow fluent with the game's mechanics, you enjoy the game more, and everything just feels so... SATISFYING.Once you break all the barriers, the story is AMAZING. The story, itself, gives you a reason to fear what there is to fear, to hate what there is to hate, and to feel what there is to feel. It makes you think and contemplate your actions (something not a lot of games nowadays are able to do).You know that you don't want to kill this guard because you don't want more rats & weepers. You know that if you did 'this' then eventually 'this' will happen. All in all, AWESOME game. Nothing can ever grasp the extent in which this game has reached.

Posted: January 6, 2015
												Buy this game.  The game is a great stealth/assassination type game with some great weapons/powers to make the whole experience fun and enjoyable.  The story is a little predicatable and some of the characters a little bland and underdeveloped but the narative, enviroments and atmosphere of the game as a whole make for a great experience.SPOILER WARNING:  However with all that being said there were several design choices that to me made no sense and took away from the game experience as a whole.  First off, it isn't until after your first mission/area is completed that you are told that if you kill or just incapacitate the guards\civilians\etc... it makes a difference.  That kind of thing needs to be front and center BEFORE you get the chance to knife the first guy, because that makes a big difference in how I want to approach the game.Secondly, the subtitle for this game should probably read "I HOPE YOU LIKE A THOUSAND SHADES OF BROWN!!!".  One of the first powers I took and maxed was a power that let you see all items and enemies in a close proximity to you.  I thought that was awesome, I can discover a lot of hidden objects, see where are all the enemies are, what direction they are facing for stealth take outs and where they are going to set up my next stealth take out.  The problem with this power is that it turns the whole enviroment different shades of brown then highlights all people/enemies as yellow and items as green.  Because this power costs little mana/energy and you can regenerate that little bit it uses there is no penalty for having this on and helping set up awesome stealth kills/take downs.  The problem becomes that the game is brown ALL THE TIME.  You can't enjoy the fantastic enviroments that were made or the design of Dunwall because the game was brown for me half the time.  I think a better option could have been made that didn't result in having a brown screen for most of the game.Lastly, it was incredibly frustrating going through this game and trying to not kill people.  Not because it was hard or anything, but it seems that the game from a control standpoint vastly favoured you trying to kill your targets instead of incapacitating them.  For example, if you get behind someone to make a stealth take down you get several different options.  You can kill them, chocke them(incapacitate them) or just loot them if they have something to be looted.   With killing the target it doesn't seem to matter where you are in relation to your target as long as you are somewhere behind/beside/above them.  However with choking/incapacitating them you have be in a very particular spot and sometimes the action button doesn't show up for second or two, especially when you drop in behind your target or use your movement power to land behind him.  This made it incredibly frustrating at times to try to string together a set of stealth take downs or resulted in being detected by your target.Again those are mostly minor annoyances, the game is fantastic and I highly recommend it.

Posted: July 13, 2015
												[Full review of Dishonored]Graphics:So texture quality was one of the main complaints that I heard about Dishonored after its release and I'd have to agree as many textures do appear to be low in quality up close. However, this doesn't detract from overall look of the dirty, grimy city, which I found to be appropriately atmospheric. The entire game is also done in a watercolor painting style which I found to be interesting and ultimately preferable to the "ultra-realistic" look that they could've gone with. - 8/10Audio:There wasn't much background music but it wasn't really necessary so I'll give it a pass. The title screen music does add to the ambiance though. Voice acting is spot on in my opinion, especially that of the ominous, all-seeing heart that Corvo carries around as well as the Outsider's. Honorable mentions would have to be Granny Rag's voice acting and Emily's who is, of course, performed by the very talented, Chloë Grace Moretz. It is worth mentioning that Corvo is a silent protagonist which I prefer but am aware that many others do not. Sound effects are also spot on and background conversations add to the overall atmosphere. - 9/10Gameplay:Dishonored introduces many new stealth mechanics that I found to be very original and unique when compared to other titles in the genre. The supernatural element of the story allows for Corvo to possess various powers which are all upgradeable and allow for very different playstyles. Speaking of playstyles, you are given the choice between playing lethally (high chaos) or stealthily (low chaos). Both have their pros and cons but it is clear that the developers meant for players to play stealthily as that is where most of the content is. Combat is nothing special but this is a stealth game so ideally you'll never even engage in combat. There are also numerous side quests which I found to be mostly interesting and worth doing. The open sandbox level designs also allow for hours of exploration. - 10/10Story:Nothing too original but I personally loved it. The supernatural element that the Outsider adds is what really makes the story engaging and unique but the base story about revenge and political corruption is good enough on its own. Between Emily and the plague there was always plenty of motivation to complete the missions and continue through the story, though I would have to agree with other gamers when I say that the "twist" at the end was completely predictable. Shouldn't detract too much from the overall story though. - 8/10Replayability:As I said before, you can choose between a high chaos or low chaos playthrough which in itself warrants at least 2 playthroughs. There are also a couple of different sides to choose in the side quests and MANY different ways to go about incapacitating or killing your targets. I've personally completed 4 playthroughs and will probably complete another before the release of Dishonored 2. - 10/10Overall:Overall I have only small complaints - nitpicks, if you will; textures are low quality up close, ending is unoriginal, and the game is a bit on the short side. However, there is no doubt that I have gotten my money's worth as I have enjoyed over 100 hours of gameplay over multiple platforms. The DLC are well worth it as well. - 9/10

Posted: May 31, 2014
												Dishonored Many people, and I admit that I, myself am guilty of such, have begun to measure the value of games by the amount of time that can be taken from it. This, mathematical, rash and inadequate evaluation may be blamed on the explosive success of ceertain open-ended titles such as several MMOs, competitive multiplayer game and most certainly the explosive success of the "Elder scrolls" series. However, there are certain games that must be seen as what they are: a grand and majestic experience compiled into a small amount of time. Dishonored is that experience, it took me 30 hours to finish a completionist run on the hardest difficulty, since there are two possible ends, this can be increased to 40-50 hours (considering much of my time was spent either reloading retrying due to difficulty, cursing at the fact I forgot to press F5 and hunting achievements that carry throughout different playthroughs). Dishonored is not only a lovely game play experience, but an absolutely necessary narrative, no gamer who calls himself a story-line driven man can claim to be so without having played this game: it is narrative genius and yet another example why people who claim video games are not art are quite frankly morons. The story-line is deep and metaphorical, it is graphically stylized and the soundtrack is as depressive as the streets of Dunwall claim to be. An absolutely genius game that deserves to endure in the mind of it's players for eons to come, bravo, Arkane!

THE GOOD-Cool and useful powers for the player to use-Multiple playthrough options and strategies-RPG-lite leveling of skills and inventory to make Corvo a better assassin-Environments are amazing, and a joy to explore-Music is foreboding, and the atmosphere is dripping with styleTHE BAD-The guards repeat a lot of their dialogue throughout the game. Posted: January 13, 2014
												A glorious game that mixes steampunk, dystopian alternate reality, and witchcraft. There are two ways to play through the game. High Chaos, where you kill lots of people as you go, or Low Chaos, where you try to sneak past without anyone knowing you were there. To get 100% achievements, you'll need to play through the whole game both ways, but this is not a bad thing. It's almost like playing through two different games! The DLCs "The Knife of Dunwall" and "The Brigmore Witches" add interesting backstory.  I recommend them, if only to make the game not feel too short.I personally disliked the "Dunwall City Trials" DLC which is frustrating, button-mashing meant for hummingbirds on crack who enjoy playing the same challenge over and over (With NO saving) until they end up with not only a perfect run but also a natural 20 on the random game config. To me, the City Trials DLC is not only a waste of time and money, but also added steam achievements that I'll never get, and therefore, no "perfect game" for me!

Posted: August 11, 2014
												"Leave him to the hungry rats for dinner..."Dishonored brings to the table what i've been longing for all this time in terms of freedom in video games, after New Vegas that is. The rat plague is rampant and Corvo Attano has been sent by the empress Jessamine Kaldwin to search for aid, only that his return was everything but expected. Now the empress is dead and Corvo needs to clear his name and free Emily and put her on the throne. The setting, the spine-chilling music, and the sort of cartoony graphics all come together to bring alive the dead city of Dunwall(hehe), really some scenarios made me cry at what the rat plague has done, dead carcasses and weepers all roam the city while the Lord Regent lives on his suite up Dunwall Tower. The setting and story are good but the gameplay is where we're at. You have the freedom of any Bethesda game in your hands, for example is that person looking you the wrong way? Smash him with a brick or turn him to ashes via Wall of Light(essentialy a wall of elettricity), i kept a save just to screw around and try to kill people in numerous ways. There is also freedom on what is your approach to the key assassination target, do you want to go to the rooftops, sewers, windows, near building? you can and the game rewards you for it instead of punishing you by not going to the designed way. The keyword here is "freedom" and really i felt like Corvo while playing it. The things i disliked about this game were the powers, if i'm allowed to say, they were a bit OP. Really you can complete the game with only Blink and that power alone gives you an enormous advantage and the upgrades were minimum and i finished the game with a stack of unused runes. Overrall this game was a frickin' treat and i despise myself for not trying it earlier.Vote: 8/10

Posted: November 9, 2015
												After finishing the main campaign twice, as well as both story DLC, for a total of almost 36 hours of gameplay I can absolutely recommend this game. You can play through stealthily or full combat, and some missions have multiple possible solutions for eliminating or neutralizing your target. The story is interesting and has a couple of plot twists along the way. The combat as well as powers are fun and have a good feel to them. For anyone who wants a fun, stealthy, story driven FPS I highly recommend Dishonored as well as the two story based DLCs. The only real knock against the game is the graphics. You can tell that they were aiming to perform well on the 360 and PS3, and the PC version wasn't made to be much more pretty than the consoles. The good side of this is that the game will run well on high settings even for people with modestly powerful PCs.

Posted: June 29, 2014
												The game seems impossible (or damn close to it) without powers, due to the actually-fairly-good AI and their uncanny nack for looking in all the right places, so your prison escape is usually the most difficult part. Aside from that, the game seems to have a lot of emphasis on "let's count the ways you can commit mass murder" for a game that has a pseudo-morality system, the graphics and aesthetic are very nice (if just a combination of Bioshock's aesthetic and Half-Life 2's aesthetic), the gameplay holds up well until the absolute last bit of the absolute last level (where the guards are combination of immovable and clueless, for reasons I can't come up with), there are a fair number of powers but not enough runes to go around and not enough powers that can be used non-lethally (most of them focus on lethality or cause needless death when used), and the audio is very nice.Overall I give it a 4/5 (would recommend if it's $10-15, MAYBE $20), and it could be made absolutely perfect with modding. Personally I've had my fill of the game's mechanics (which for me, boil down to "blink behind guard, choke guard, hide guard, don't get caught, ad nauseum"), so I'd skip the DLCs.

Posted: July 5, 2014
												Dishonored's gameplay is very much its strongest suit. It offers challenging, intelligent level design which demands the player use all the tools acquired in shrewd ways in order to succeed. The game is aware that in stealth gameplay, satisfaction arises from a feeling of overcoming obstacles using thought, not brute force; playing Dishonored guns blazing (or sword drawn) is usually a recipe for death unless facing few opponents. And besides, most of the collectables and interesting locales are reached by stealth and ingenuity when it comes to moving around the level. Yet the combat in Dishonored does not suffer, as sword fighting is engaging and tactical, and the side weapons are always fun to play with. The variety of methods one can use to play through Dishonored give the game great replay value, made greater by the possibility of investing in different upgrades and the inclusion of different endings depending on the player's actions during the game.Story is weaker in Dishonored. While the setting is rich and compelling, and the overarching narrative is decent, the plot feels stilted because of the disconnected levels. After some time the plot feels like a way to justify the missions rather than the two working in tandem to add depth to the game's events; it feels artificial. Similarly the system of "chaos" in which many killings lead to darker story events and a more chaotic city feels arbitrary at times as the game does little to justify the changes to the city. However it is commendable that a game should make the player consider the ideas of killing, revenge, the value of life, and to what extent ends justify means. It's no philosophical powerhouse, but it touches on interesting topics.All in all, Dishonored is worth the money and the time. Despite some plot related weaknesses the game is great fun and requires thought and care to play through, whether sneaking about or crossing swords with the enemy.

Some gas grenades would've been nice at a minimum.Overall I'd say a 7/10. Not GOTY material because it really is babby's first stealth game and typical console port (viewmodel FOV is lol). Play Deus Ex or Thief if you want a more challenging/enjoyable experience.

After the third game, which was slightly worse than second one, I was waiting for a new game done in the similar fashon. And for many years there was nothing out there. And then came Dishonored. The game so good that now I prefer it over Thief. The game I've finished five times already and will probably do few more runs. The game that lets you choose a style of play - you can be a shadow, you can be a tank, you can be an invisible predator. You can eachieve your goals in many ways, you can finish a game without hurting anyone or you can kill everyone you see moving. A steampunk world of Dunwall is also interesting and the only problem I see in this game is that it's short. It comes with two brilliant DLCs thought (Knife of Dunwall and The Brightmore Witches) and a mediocre one (Dunwall City Trials). Overall, this game is high on my Top 10 list of games of all times.

Posted: July 7, 2015
												'Dishonored' is a first person stealth rpg game in a steampunk setting with an awesome storyline.First you have to know: The game is published by Bethesda! (Bethesda RPGs are always excellent IMO)You play as Corvo Attano, bodyguard to the Empress of the Isles, who gets in contact with the Outsider. You level Corvo by collecting runes. Corvo has six active and four passive powers:Active: Dark Vision, Blink, Possession, Devouring Swarm, Bend Time and Wind BlastPassive: Agility, Blood Thirsty, Shadow Kill, VitalityNone of these powers are pointless! You can play Corvo as YOU like to play the game:For example::: Killing slyly out of the shadows by using Blink/Bend Time and Shadow Kill/Blood Thirsty:: Playing non-lethal by using Blink/Possession and Agility:: Being Rambo by using Devouring Swarm/Wind Blast and Vitality/Blood Thirsty:: etc.Pros:+ Awesome sound on vision+ Imaginative abilities + None of the abilities are pointless.+ Excellent storyline+ High replayability+ Smooth course of the game(+ Brilliant DLCs; except "City Trials")(+ "Easy" collectable achievements)Cons:- not lip-sync- less hostile NPCs- unimaginative weapons (sword, pistol, grenades, mines)(- Graphics are not up to date)Recommended, even if it's not on sale, because of the great storyline and the excellent game mechanics.9/10
