content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												I usually only write reviews for the best games in my library, and Dishonored is no exception. At the time of writing this review, I've completed the game and all of its DLCs twice; high chaos and low chaos. Pros The game is designed with every possible playstyle in mind, shown especially through the level design. There's pipes on the sides of buildings, ledges, hidden secrets and plenty to explore. Want to sneak past all of the guards? Easy, just blink between ledges on buildings, over walls, and onto streetlights. Want to kill absolutely everything? No problem, just whip out your trusty pistol/crossbow/otherworldly-tool-of-destruction and blast away at the guards on the street, or maybe grab some whale oil tanks and start exploding things. The gameplay is smooth and phenomenal all throughout.The game is pretty old, but the graphics (or art style, more like) still look pretty good. There's some nice bloom/light shaft effects, and the game doesn't try too hard to look realistic, just pleasant to look at. The closest thing I can compare it to is Borderlands, minus the harsh black lines on everything.There's a hell of a lot of creativity and freedom when it comes to playing the missions. For example, let's say there's five guards in a room. You could throw a grenade in, stop time, and shoot the grenade midair with a crossbow bolt. On the other hand, you could simply blast everyone with a gust of wind, and finish off anyone who didn't die when they hit the wall.This game can run on a potato. Cons The story isn't bad, but it's not great either. You're the royal guard of the Empress, she gets killed in front of you, other government-people rush in and frame you for it. There's that.For new players, there is a bit of trial and error for certain things. This can be a pro or a con, depending on who you ask, but here's some help with that; you can't blink through a Wall of Light. Arc Pylons aren't so dangerous if you're above them or below them. That should save you a couple of deaths if you're new.Not much else in the cons department. Conclusion 9/10, only wish the game could've been a bit longer (there's 9 missions in the main game, give or take 5-6 hours if you know what you're doing).

Posted: March 2, 2014
												Dishonored is like if you took Deus Ex's attention to detail, wide-open gameplay choices, and wealth of world-building, and mixed it with Thief's stealth and setting. It's a game where you can play through it entirely without ever being spotted or killing anyone, or you can run through and murder everybody and both choices are equally valid and fun. You can play through it and get the basic story, or you can dig into every book, note, and mind-read and get as much detail on the city of Dunwall and the people who inhabit it as you want. It's fantastic. The stealth is not too skittish or completely dim. the action and movement feel great, which is an area Arkane always does well in. Everything is stylized more than super-technically impressive, but it all looks good. You should get Dishonored if you're into Deus Ex, or Thief, if you like action or stealth games, or if you're into games lots of lore. And while you're at it, get The Knife of Dunwall and The Brigmore Witches DLC, because they add a sidestory involving characters from the main game. It tweaks some abilities, adds new equipment, it's about 2/3rds as long as the base game, and it's also great!

Posted: June 28, 2016
												Dishonored is, without a doubt, my favorite stealth game ever. More than Metal Gear and more than Deus Ex. You are Corvo, the royal protector who was framed for the murder of the empress. You must then take your revenge on those who framed you with the help of magic from the Outsider and gadgets from Piero to aid you in your stealthing.One of the main reasons I love this game so much is player choice. My playtime reflects that you can play the game more than once. If you're playing it once you aren't doing it right. At the shortest, you can play the whole game excluding the even shorter DLCs in about ten hours. However, the game offers many ways to play it through multiple times. In this regard, Dishonored is like an RPG. To compare to Fallout, another Bethesda game, my first run in both games is what I would do. In Fallout, I would side with the good guys (mostly) and be mostly nice. In Dishonored, I would use as much magic as I could, get as many runes as possible, not kill many people (murder wasn't out of the question though) and do other things I won't get into for spoilers' sake. I played a female psychopath in Fallout next, and in Dishonored I got all three achiemements for not killing anyone. You can play the whole game without killing anyone and in the sequel, you can do the whole game without magic. Speaking of the magic, it's a great thing to put into a stealth game. In games like Metal Gear, it focuses on raw stealth in which you use distractions and funny looking diving to sneak about. With magic, you augment your sneaking so it becomes easier and more fun. It's optional however, except the first tier of blink. With blink, you can teleport a short distance to reach high places or traverse crowded streets faster. There is also dark vision that lets you see through walls. All of these powers make the game a very fun escape from traditional stealth games. Along with these powers, you get bone charms that add passives. To get this magic you have to collect runes and bone charms. These are often placed off the beaten path and finding them leads you into interesting sidequests and cool lore to find. The game is rich in lore. Books are everywhere and audiologs explain a lot of things. You will learn about the seven scriptures of the overseers and why they name the months like month of nets. These sidequests and alternate pathways are different each time you play. If you seek runes early in the game, someone will ask you to poison a bootleg elixr distillery, and in the very next level, you are recruited by the person you ruined to do something. With a story rich universe and fun mechanics and player choice, Dishonored is a must play for fans of stealth and story.

Posted: August 8, 2014
												A game that has a lot of positives - replayable value(you get to choose your style of play violent or non-violent), bioshock-like feel (which is always a plus), atmosphere and architecture because of the same engine that both games share and some collaborations involved between studios, a fitting soundtrack that perfectly sets the mood, gory yet awesomely crafted fighting scenes to make this game even more enticing. The biggest issue that everyone had was the generic storyline, which doesnt have a lot of twists and turns and just blatantly forces you to not care about anything that is happening while simply enjoying the entertainment that this game provides in its action packed gameplay; you are just a man on a mission that seeks revenge, nothing extraordinary. But I must say, the DLC's were a refreshing gulp, since you get a chance to play from a different perspective through another person and his journey, that certainly gets you more involved in his struggles and road to redemption. Unlike in the original, the protagonist in the DLC actually has his own voice this time and a new array of tricks and gadgets. You can talk about this game forever, but all I can it has been a very enjoyable game that has a lot to offer, and since i've completed the high chaos, which is the violent way, I will indulge myself into the stealth side of this game. Dark, gory, visually beautiful and breathtaking game that holds its position strong as one of my favorites games to date.

												It's not a bad game, it certainly shows a lot of potential, but falls short in some aspects. The story is a little clichè and a little short, I finished it in 17 hours on hard without killing anyone or being spotted, getting the low chaos ending, I couldn't pull myself trough another gameplay to see the high chaos ending, maybe someday. Usually you get multiple ways of infiltrating and disposing of your target, but when you aim for perfection the game becomes quite linear, especially in the non lethal part, but there is still some fair choice involved, especially in the infiltration, with you being able to blink almost where you want, possess an animal, a person, stop time, etc. The powers are nice and original, as I said the posess ability can open new paths, you can pass check points as guards or get inside some small holes as a rat. I like the setting, which is trying to give you the steam punk vibe but not always succeeds, and sometimes it's more post apocalyptic, yes the general "lore" is definitely nice and interesting, like the weepers. I say this is a nice game, but nowhere near the best of the year or the best assassination one. In short, good fun for the first playthrough, but definitely overrated.

Posted: August 25, 2014
												A game like Bioshock (the two good ones at least), this game has a rich story accompanied by incredable stealth and combat mechanics.  Never before have I experienced the feeling of being a legitament badass assassin.In the game, you play as a man, Corvo, framed for murdering the Empress and hiding away Emily, her beloved daughter, your are tried and sentenced to death.  However, you escape with the help of a small group dedicated to helping you.  They know the truth about you.Following after your escape, you act as an assassin, taking out targets and completing missions.  Each mission is very flexible, for you can play through and complete them in many ways.  There WILL be a way you can fit your playstyle in this game.  Additionally, those who would rather take the role of a stealthy(er) assassin, may find much enjoyment from sneaking around and taking out or incapacitating targets.The only issue I have with this game is Chaos, a mechanic that limits the player being at least this stealthy.  For example, killing too many will make your allies act differently toward you, and changing the overall game environment.  While it is arguable that this mechanic makes the game better by adding more challenges, I find it a bit of a pain because the thought of it pops in your head if you ever choose to kill a guard or something.Overall 9/10, worth getting (like Bioshock), especially when on sale.

Posted: December 28, 2014
												115 hours. That's for a single player game. This does not include the 50+ hours spent on Xbox.If you've heard anything about dishonored, it's probably that the game not only excells in Replayability, but the technicality of system itself. To start off:1) The gameplay is as versatile as it gets, AND retains it's balance. Dishonored can essentially be played in 4 different ways: Letal ghost, Letal loud, Non-lethal ghost, non-lethal loud. BUT WAIT THERE'S MORE! While those are the base ways you can play the game, and despite it being a linear map, the path from start to end for each level is anything but restriced. For instance, there's a path ahead of you into the stronghold. Sure, you can charge in through the front door guns and abilities blazing, or you could climb the buildings besides it to get to the roof and through a window. Oh, but you can of course posess a guard to get past a checkpoint, or posess a rat to go in through a ventilation pipe. What's that? want more? There's a locked door just on the side. Either sneak to the guard checkpoint to get a key, or blast the door down with a grenade. And YES, there's more ways than just that to get inside!2) The level design is phenominal in terms of being versatile, as it isn't messy in the slightest. Say you max out your agility and teleport, well, you might find that you can climb certain ledges that you couldn't normally. The great thing about this is that it doesn't feel like you improvise much to get to these places. It's not hard to guess how to get up to certain places if you take a couple seconds to look around. But it isn't in-your-face obvious either. It's almost like Mirrors edge in terms of platforming and traveling like that.3) The maps are huge, considering that it's a single load at a time, no need to reload partways through the level. Now, this in itself isnt that big of a deal, what the great thing is, is that the game doesn't need a high end PC to run it well. Bethedsa has made a game that works brilliantly, and is nearly as efficent as the source engine.4) The art detail. This is probably the best steampunk based game I've played, and I'm not really that big on steampunk. But these guys got the art director from Half Life 2 on this, and he implemented both a unique, abstract, and despite it's water color, a believeable fictional universe. Oh, and while you can't see it from the screenshots, you get to go to a certain abstract world that I dare not spoil here. Needless to say, it's incredibly refreshing and new in a way.5) The replayability. Play through this game on stealth? That's cool, so did I. Now, how about you give it another go with guns and arrows out and see how you fare. Seriously, it feels like a new game when you switch it up like that. I've easily played throught the campaign 5-6 times for both fun and for achievements, and I will keep going for a while I imagine. I hadn't even found this much fun in replayability in Deus Ex Human Revolution, and that game in itself is fantastic too.So, If this poorly written review hasn't compelled you, then please look at the 100+ game of the year awards. Unless youe looking for a non-FPS game or one that is specifically focused on guns, Dishonored is a must own and a must play.10/10

I can say that this is the best game i've played so far.

Posted: December 27, 2012
												Easily one of the best stealth games I've ever played, and certainly the best first-person stealth game since Thief: The Dark Project first hit the scene in '98. In fact, Dishonored (sic) is almost excessively reminiscent of Thief, taking on a similar steampunk aesthetic although Thief's steampunk was of a more dark ages/medieval flavour than Dishonored's victorian stylings.The painted textures are very pleasing to the eye, the stealth mechanics are superb and the plot is interesting. The only issue is the morality system which causes characters unfavourably to you (down to calling you a -monster-) if you kill too many of the vicious, petty and murderous guards. This, of course, is irrespective of whether you killed them purposefully or due to knocking over a potted plant and having them run headfirst onto your sword. I've always been annoyed at how stealth games will give you one or two dull ways of non-lethally neutralizing enemies while giving you dozens upon dozens of amusing ways to kill them - and then give you the 'bad' ending if you use them. A game should not punish a player for enjoying themselves.But this is a minor quibble, the "bad" ending isn't that bad. It's still an excellent game and if the pooch finds itself thoroughly screwed with regards to Thief 4, at least we'll always have Dishonored (sic).

Posted: December 3, 2015
												I lost count of how many times I've played through this game. I love it, and for so many reasons: plot, gameplay, and replayability, to name a few.First off, the plot it actually very deep. If you're not looking for details you could easily miss it, but when you pay attention you find out all sorts of things. Arkane added a lot of depth to the story to make it more engaging, and even hid a few Easter eggs for players to find (for instance, you can find High Overseer Campbell as a weeper in the Flooded District if you elect to brand him instead of kill him earlier in the game). It's the small things that count: notes and journals that give you a glimpse into life in plague-ridden Dunwall; overhearing conversations between characters, even minor ones; hearing the experienced assassin Daud's lament over killing the Empress. Playing this game and taking the time to scour the maps for clues that reveal plot is one of the more fun and engaging things to do, even if you've finished your first playthrough.Second, gameplay. Ohhhh my, the gameplay. Even without magical powers, the gameplay is fun and there's always someone to stalk and assassinate (or choke out and hide, if that's your style). Drop assassinations never get old, and neither does taking out a Tallboy or taunting guards through an electric field that you rewired (the poor sods). But adding Blink to the party, not to mention the rest of the supernatural abilities, was the cherry on top. Allowing you the ability to do so many things, from moving silently across an open space without notice to appearing in front of an enemy and killing them before they could so much as blink (heh heh), the Blink ability increased the gameplay experience by an order of magnitude.Some gameplay factors also increased the replay value of the game, namely those factors allowing you to choose between options. You get to experiment with so many different ways to take out a target, and if you want to spare his life, there's a way to do that too. Maybe you liked sneaking around on the ground but would like to jump on rooftops more. Do more side quests that you overlooked on other playthroughs. I even knew a guy who did a playthrough that he called "Extreme Non-Lethal," where he went undetected and only choked out the targets he absolutely had to, focusing on finding ways to slip past without being noticed. Even though the game is linear, you are still allowed enough options to permit multiple creative plays of the game, as I have done.It is worth mentioning the game that Dishonored took its notes from, which is Thief: The Dark Project. I am happy to say that Arkane was kind enough to put in an Easter egg in the game in acknowledgement of their inspiration. This can be found in Daud's base, when you stumble across two assassins training for stealth; the dialogue from that scene is taken from Thief: The Dark Project almost verbatim.TL;DR - I found Dishonored to be a very enjoyable game, and I recommend it to anyone who has a love for games featuring stealth or stabbing (don't tell my psychiatrist). It has good graphics, great gameplay, commendable replayability (especially for a single-player game), and an in-depth plot to boot.
